title: Grumpy Bubbles
description: Big thanks to @jsh for his Day 1 project, River Waltz, which served as inspiration and as material for my project. I was inspired early on by the use of clones in River Waltz, and wanted to pay tribute to that inspiration with a slightly cheeky remix.
instructions:
First, check out @jsh's River Waltz: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235484400/
This remix project is the behind-the-scenes peek at the bubbles in the background of that project—bubbles who are not nearly as courteous as the fish!
Click the Green Flag, then mouse over the bubbles to see what they're grumbling about!

title: Raindrops
description:
I've found that I don't always initially consider sound with my projects. For this project I wanted to work on getting timing and pace to seem natural. I wanted to go beyond "I can make the rain fall" to "can I make the rain fall well?" Having sound as an element of that process has helped. I'm not sure I'm quite at natural pacing, but I think it's getting there (:

(update: edited the speed of the day rain to simulate gravity! how does this compare to the non-gravitational falling of night rain? I also set the clones to a range of sizes. I'd like to go back later to connect size with gravity)

rain sound:
https://freesound.org/people/macdaddyno1/sounds/396484/
instructions: Press the green flag.

title: Night Rain
description:
After simulating rain drops for today's challenge, I was reminded of my use of clones for loudness sensing day. As I was exploring sound as a significant dimension of my project today, I wondered how the rainfall and the noise-reacting stars might interact -- both with sound in the project and from whoever is watching.

rain sound:
https://freesound.org/people/macdaddyno1/sounds/396484/
instructions:
Press the green flag, allow for the microphone to detect sound, and turn speaker volume up (I recommend all the way!) (Also feel free to sing, scream, hum, talk, etc)


I also recommend full screen

title: Lights
description:
This project was created for Day 19 of Getting Unstuck. Our mission was to explore clones, which I was excited about because I've really been enjoying clones throughout Getting Unstuck (previously, clones were an unexplored feature for me). 

For an initial version of this project, I relied more heavily on Scratch's built-in blocks (e.g., X Position, Y Position, Point Towards, Move X) to calculate movement. But there was a slight problem with this; I wanted the clones to appear to continue their circular motion even when offstage. The solution was to do more of the calculations manually, storing things like current position in variables (so, not limited to the size of the stage). 

Music: Gustav Holst, "Neptune, the Mystic" (The Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra)
instructions: Enjoy the procession of the clones!
writing:

For an initial version of this project, I relied more heavily on Scratch's built-in blocks (e.g., X Position, Y Position, Point Towards, Move X) to calculate movement. But there was a slight problem with this; I wanted the clones to appear to continue their circular motion even when offstage. The solution was to do more of the calculations manually, storing things like current position in variables (so, not limited to the size of the stage). 

Music: Gustav Holst, "Neptune, the Mystic" (The Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra)Enjoy the procession of the clones!

title: Slim Cantore - Penquin Weather Channel Event
instructions:
This project is based on a Weather Story by Weather Channel Reporter Jim Cantore. On February 15, 2015 he experienced six episodes of thundersnow in Plymouth, MA while reporting.  Real footage from this event can be seen at: http://www.weather.com/news/news/jim-cantore-thundersnow-plymouth-massachusetts.
This is my first experience with cloning.
The original project was remixed from CSFirst module on Storytelling.

Here's another fun cloning project: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237137845/

title: Unstuck Day 19: Using Clones
description:
I did this project for Getting Unstuck challenge Day 19, using clones to mimic a natural or human made phenomenon. I had never made variables into sliders before! I thought I had seen it but didn't know how people got that, and it turns out you have to right click in the variable to get the option to turn it into a slider.
It would be nice if you could put limits on a slider as above 20 on each of these is not particularly useful. I could put the limit in how the variables are used but then the number show does not represent what is happening.
instructions:
Play with ripples! 
Just added sound, too.
See how adding more clones slows down the project.
Thanks @mstone326 for the tip on setting the slider min and max!

title: EC Maker Game
description:
This is a sketch for a "maker game" I drew two years ago as part of a "maker games" project made possible by Tufts CEEO Innovation Fund. Two of us later produced a very different game but I've always wanted to develop this sketch for early childhood students. 

For day 19 of GettingUnstuck, in which the theme is cloning, I'm sharing the sketch and inviting others to remix (i.e., "clone") it and develop their own games. Feel free to use, remix, and riff on this backdrop in any context within Scratch (if you use this backdrop please credit me for the drawing). I'm going to be using this as the basis for some game design prototyping in a summer camp class this upcoming week.

The features of the board are listed below with corresponding iterative maker concepts:

school (where players start)
park (for play, rest, passion projects)
design & co (test and (re)design, outsource design)
patent office (protect IP)
general store (obtain new materials)
junkyard (obtain free materials, leftovers etc)
skate park (hack, tinker)
maker bank (obtain funds for new materials*)
movie theater (develop and share documentation/narrative)
public library (research)
museum of makings (exhibit works)
train station [lower left corner] (pitch/present)

This drawing was loosely based on my hometown. At my game design summer camp week we'll be drawing maps as a starting point for some game backdrops as well.

*in some versions of our games players received tokens periodically which could be used to purchase materials. I like to use narrative as currency: players have to tell a story about their progress in order to obtain new building materials.
instructions: Please Remix! . . . and develop virtual board games to support iterative maker-centered activities.

title: Getting Unstuck #19
description:
I played with fireworks on day 6 https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236008448/ and thought about using clones then. I looked at the Scratch wiki for inspiration this evening and it mentioned fireworks, so I had another go at it, this time with clones.
I'm happy with this, but if I were to do this again, or if I had more time I'd really want to master gravity, which is a big ask for someone who struggles with long division. 
I got the sound effects from https://freesound.org/s/142019/

V2 I added very simple gravity and some ghost effect to the clones so that they fade out as they fall. I'm pleased with it, and thanks to @alirb for pointing me in the direction of @HSSLab and @Mittensbrother
instructions: Just press the green flag. Use the slider to change the number of sparks.

title: Critical Hit Revisited (Unstuck 19)
description:
I couldn't let my #18 project go without another iteration! So...

After some research on the "stop:all" block - it looks like it works only for scripts that are started by the green flag - I decided to add a sword sprite and rethink some of the interactions. 

For today's prompt, it seemed appropriate to add some (cloned) loot drops. There are still a few "features" that I need to fix, but I'm happy with this so far!
instructions: Attack the Beholder with your sword for 1d4 damage or 2d8 on a critical hit (20).

title: Asteroidal 6 (GetUnstuck#19)
description:
I did borrow ideas and bits of code from others but I actually made this ages ago and I've forgotten who they were. I'll make an effort to find out someday soon and will credit accordingly. Apart from the asteroids, all other so-called 'artwork' is my own.

The ship does have a certain degree of inertia (ie it should 'coast' after you take your finger off the 'thrust') but it needs tweaking. 

To add (someday!):
Asteroids should break apart into smaller frocks when hit, creating harder-to-hit targets.
Increasing levels of difficulty
Better ship design!
instructions:
Work-in-progress inspired by ASTEROIDS. Created this to experiment with clones, firing lasers/bullets, and the play/pause function. I was also curious about making things re-appear on the opposite side of the screen (as in 'proper' ASTEROIDS).

Cursor/arrow left/right to rotate, up arrow to move/fire thruster. x fires 'retro' rockets (handy because there's no maximum speed!), space fires laser.

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge 19 - Trivia
description:
This project is all cloning. I thought of using the import/export csv or txt from the other day. Each category has 6 questions, so the list works as such. 1-6 is category 1, etc. 

Create your csv or txt, import your file into the questions,answers list and project this on the wall as a review in class or just for fun. 

Just added a great idea from @rbotero, to add an option for images to be shown with the question. Will comment more inside the project.

Can add final jeopardy if interested. Thinking of ideas to be used in a classroom setting as reviews etc. Even thinking of adding a Raspberry Pi and some buttons to "buzz in" .
instructions:
Click on the question block to reveal the question. 
Press space to show the answer
Press space again to return to the game board
(will add text engine for spelling categories, for now you'll have to go to the paint editor, however, I made them vector so you can click on the text tool and just edit the existing text)

(few tiny issues with my text engine near the right margin, will fix by adding hyphens when I get a chance)

Each clone has an id, and a state if is clickable or not. When you create a "for this sprite only" variable each clone will keep their own copy of that variable. Each question block has "can select local" variable which is set to 1. As you click each block it sets their own copy to 0, at which point they can no longer be chosen.

Just added a great idea from @rbotero, to add an option for images to be shown with the question. Will comment more inside the project.

Can add final jeopardy if interested. Thinking of ideas to be used in a classroom setting as reviews etc. Even thinking of adding a Raspberry Pi and some buttons to "buzz in" .

Each question block has "can select local" variable which is set to 1. As you click each block it sets their own copy to 0, at which point they can no longer be chosen.

title: Elastic wave
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 19
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I use clone function to produce a series of particle that vibrates with a slight time shift, forming a mechanical wave.
Each clone have private variables that regulates its oscillation.
instructions:
*** How a mechanical wave is formed? ***

Imagine a single particle which start moving up and down with harmonic motion at constant frequency and amplitude. 

The energy of the particle is transferred to the particle next to it with a slight delay, depending on the characteristics of the medium (the distance between the particles divided by the time delay equals the velocity of waves in that medium).

Therefore the second particle starts its harmonic motion at a different time but with the same frequency and amplitude of the first particle.
The motion is then transferred to the third particle and so one.
That's how an elastic wave is created!

Do you see some particle moving horizontally?
Actually they are just keep oscillating up and down...
writing:
Getting Unstuck - day 19
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I use clone function to produce a series of particle that vibrates with a slight time shift, forming a mechanical wave.
Each clone have private variables that regulates its oscillation.

*** How a mechanical wave is formed? ***

Imagine a single particle which start moving up and down with harmonic motion at constant frequency and amplitude. 

The energy of the particle is transferred to the particle next to it with a slight delay, depending on the characteristics of the medium (the distance between the particles divided by the time delay equals the velocity of waves in that medium).

Therefore the second particle starts its harmonic motion at a different time but with the same frequency and amplitude of the first particle.
The motion is then transferred to the third particle and so one.
That's how an elastic wave is created!

Do you see some particle moving horizontally?
Actually they are just keep oscillating up and down...

title: Day 19: You Are My Sunshine
description:
My first attempt at using the cloning function . . .
My grand plan was to have sunflowers with a greater y-value to appear smaller to give the illusion of distance.  Also wanted randomized left/right facings.  Earlier drafts had various sized sunflowers appearing all over the bottom half of the background in different directions.  Current version has large flowers.  
Sunflowers were popping up very quickly, so I added more wait time.  Now it sometimes takes a while for flowers to start "stamping". 
Will definitely go back to de-bug and refine this project, and to experiment with other methods of cloning.
Sunflower was created for a sketchnoting challenge earlier this year.
Background is from Day 6 challenge (Old MacDonald).
Will probably add some feature to the blue sky for interest. 
Imagine a ukulele version of "You Are My Sunshine" playing in the background :)
That's enough for today :)
instructions:
Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. 
Press the green flag to begin.

title: Unstuck 19 Clone Rabbits
description:
At first I wanted to simulate a bunch of rabbits hopping around randomly in different directions, starting from the mouse click position. 
It took me some time to figure out how to get nothing to display if the sky is clicked.
Due to time constraints I simplified it to the rabbits running in the same direction. If I had more time I would like to:
-have the rabbits run either left or right
-have the rabbits run in "bounding leaps" using gravity and varying heights
instructions:
Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch to represent a natural or human-made phenomenon. For example, you could represent a flock of birds or a fireworks celebration.

The rabbit will give you instructions ;-)

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 19
description:
This is my project for Day 19 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. I had fun trying to create the wake effect. If I had more time I would try to recreate the snake game. I think I created the base for the famous snake game. By changing the number of clones over time according to a certain condition, it is possible to recreate the same effect that you have in the original game. The idea seems interesting to me and I think I'll work on it!

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions:
Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. For example, you could make a project that represents a natural or human-made phenomenon.

Use the arrow keys to move the heart.

title: Water balloon game (Getting Unstuck Day 19)
description:
Okay, today I didn't really have a good idea. I got stuck on the water drops. Only one clone kept appearing instead of five. After having dinner I found a solution. Not my best game.

If I had more time, I think I would try to make another game...

This is an old game also using invisable clones and is more fun to play in my opinion: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/48052388/
instructions:
Pop the water balloons with the arrow that follows the mouse. But there is a trick: the arrow can only move on the right side of the screen (behind the orange lines). And the balloons are invisible overthere, but they are still there. And when you click on them, water drops will fall down. You can pop twenty balloons. What's your best score?

This made for Getting Unstuck Day 19. The challenge of today:
Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch to represent a natural or human-made phenomenon.

title: Getting Unstuck #19: Fishing and cloning
description:
Scratch project was originally created as part of the WWF educational program "Healthy children, healthy planet" with the aim to raise awareness on responsible fishing. Due to "Getting Unstuck" activity #19 the project was modified and clones replaced 23 sprites! I believe this was an improvement to the project, and I am very glad I had the chance to practice with clones! 

Day #18 Challenge: Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. For example, you could make a project that represents a natural or human-made phenomenon.
instructions: Press the green flag!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 19 — Wall Writer
description:
Reflect

I've been wanting to design a system for generating dynamic text from a string in Scratch for awhile. This seemed like the perfect opportunity to try this out.

What I like about this project is that the dynamic text blocks can be imported into other projects and can be easily modified. This example uses clones, but it could be modified to use stamps. Since each letter is a sprite, they can be animated in real-time after being being created. Lots of possibilities.
instructions:
Welcome to Wall Writer!

- Tell Scratch Cat what you want written on the walls.
- Use the sliders to control the size and spacing of the letters.

Welcome to Wall Writer!

- Tell Scratch Cat what you want written on the walls.
- Use the sliders to control the size and spacing of the letters.

Let's see it as a "fireworks celebration" :P

title: Getting Unstuck 19
description:
For this project I recreated a scene from one of my favorite movies (and books). 

I used clones for the elves, cutting the costumes out of the original image with the background removal tool. The image wasn't great, so the elves still had a bit of background around them and I couldn't get it as neat as I wanted. I decided to use the select and duplicate tool on the background to get rid of the remaining elves so it wouldn't look weird when the moving elves passed in front of them. It still looks weird, but hopefully less weird.

Image from http://www.syfy.com/syfywire/5-directions-amazon%E2%80%99s-lord-of-the-rings-tv-series-could-head
Sound from Ambient Mixer
instructions: Click the green flag.

title: Boston Weather_GU_Day19
description:
I wanted to use humor in my project. I combined a well-known idiom and some old-time pics with current information.
I spent some time figuring out how to clip the audio file. (It started out as 6+ minutes long.) Every time that I cut again, I used a copy of my previous cut. That way, if I goofed, I could easily go back to my last try. I left my intermediate cuts for you to see.
Credits:
The weather is from National Weather Service  3:22 pm report on 7/23/18  https://forecast.weather.gov/showsigwx.php?warnzone=MAZ015&warncounty=MAC025&firewxzone=MAZ015&local_place1=Boston%20MA&product1=Hazardous+Weather+Outlook&lat=42.3587&lon=-71.0567
http://freemusicarchive.org/music/Livio_Amato/Collected_Thoughts/Livio_Amato_-__Collected_thoughts_-_04_Rain_Suite
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_vehicle#/media/File:EdisonElectricCar1913.jpg
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:1978_AMC_Matador_sedan_red_NC_detail_of_factory_AM-FM-stereo-8-track_unit.jpg
https://www.nps.gov/getaways/boston/

title: Matter/Antimatter: Getting Unstuck Day 19 Clones
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 19 Clones

I thought about making a whole lot of clones, but then I thought about what happens when there are too many clones, so I decided that they should spontaneously annihilate each other... like matter and antimatter! So that's where the two types of clones come from.

However, I am having some issues with making the two clones properly sense each other. Sometimes, one particle will disappear but the other won't! So, still working on how to make sure the particles sense each other.
instructions: Click the green flag and watch what happens

title: musical toy - tiled vibes
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 20
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
First, create a studio and add all of your Getting Unstuck projects to it.
-> https://scratch.mit.edu/studios/5251088/

Second, choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it. What's something about the project that would benefit from more time or fresh eyes? 
-> This version with the colourful polygons is more what I had in mind initially. I'm glad I could spend a little more time on it.
Yet another improvement will have to wait for another day ^^

title: generative art - storm clouds flying by
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 5
Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying. 

Getting Unstuck: Day 19
Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. For example, you could make a project that represents a natural or human-made phenomenon.

I got really stuck on a few unexplained glitches but got unstuck after simplifying of the maths magic. 

As a bonus, I discovered an interesting graphical technique while debugging, when I turned on the pen to study the clones' path. See inside the code to try it for yourself!
instructions: Press the green flag and enjoy the fog :)

title: Getting Unstuck Day 19: Popping Bubbles
description:
My idea was to created something similar to the Pickle Picnic game at http://minimouse.us/ which is one of the games my students play in our computer lab to get used to a mouse. I plan to do more with clones and science simulations in the future but thought I'd do this first. 

At times I end up with a clone that does not fall properly and I'm not sure why?
instructions:
Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. 

Dan needs to pop as many bubbles as possible. Dan moves with the mouse pointer and will jump if you click the mouse. The game ends when 50ish bubbles have been created and popped either by Dan or by hitting the ground.
writing:
My idea was to created something similar to the Pickle Picnic game at http://minimouse.us/ which is one of the games my students play in our computer lab to get used to a mouse. I plan to do more with clones and science simulations in the future but thought I'd do this first. 

At times I end up with a clone that does not fall properly and I'm not sure why?Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. 

Dan needs to pop as many bubbles as possible. Dan moves with the mouse pointer and will jump if you click the mouse. The game ends when 50ish bubbles have been created and popped either by Dan or by hitting the ground.

title: Day 19: Bioluminescent Plankton
description:
I was inspired to create this project to recreate one of my favorite memories as a teenager who lived at the beach, swimming at night on the rare occasions that the ocean glowed!
I used clones for both plankton and then just one clone to give the movement of the ocean.
instructions:
Click the green flag to see a beautiful phenomenon of bioluminescent plankton. 

Day 19 Challenge: Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch to represent a natural or human-made phenomenon.
writing:
I was inspired to create this project to recreate one of my favorite memories as a teenager who lived at the beach, swimming at night on the rare occasions that the ocean glowed!
I used clones for both plankton and then just one clone to give the movement of the ocean.  

Click the green flag to see a beautiful phenomenon of bioluminescent plankton. 

Day 19 Challenge: Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch to represent a natural or human-made phenomenon.

title: Unstuck Day 19 - Erupting Volcano
description: This was really fun to make. I cloned dots to make the lava spurt out of the volcano and travel down the sides. I also used the pen to make the lava. I used a .wav file from Freesound.com as well as a free to reuse image from Wikimedia for the background.
instructions: Click the flag to see the volcano erupt. Make sure you have your speakers turned on.
writing:
This was really fun to make. I cloned dots to make the lava spurt out of the volcano and travel down the sides. I also used the pen to make the lava. I used a .wav file from Freesound.com as well as a free to reuse image from Wikimedia for the background.

Click the flag to see the volcano erupt. Make sure you have your speakers turned on.

title: Matter/Antimatter: Getting Unstuck Day 19 Clones copy
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 19 Clones

I thought about making a whole lot of clones, but then I thought about what happens when there are too many clones, so I decided that they should spontaneously annihilate each other... like matter and antimatter! So that's where the two types of clones come from.

However, I am having some issues with making the two clones properly sense each other. Sometimes, one particle will disappear but the other won't! So, still working on how to make sure the particles sense each other.
instructions: Click the green flag and watch what happens

title: #19 Getting Unstuck challenge #19 Spiraling star
description:
Instructions came from Computer Coding Projects for Kids Carol Vorderman.
My kids love the clone block and use often when creating games. 
I like the option of using the pen with this project, and then being able to change the angle and speed.
While relatively simple in its coding, my kids enjoy changing the sprite - creating their own shapes, or using different costumes, changing backdrop colours, and then pen size.
The book is an excellent resource for project ideas.
instructions:
Click the green flag and watch the pattern.
Change the angle and speed whilst in motion.
Press the space bar to clear the stage.

title: Stop the infection!
description:
I wanted to explore more the cloning features by creating a simple game. 
I realized that when there are many clones, they slow down the game. So, I've tried to solve it by adding, hidding and deleting a clone at a specific time. I know that isn't perfect, but is the way I found.

I'd like to add more levels and to change the behaviour of the AI.
instructions:
Press the green flag and then the play button to start.
Go to a safe zone to get a grey antibody that makes you immune only for a few seconds.
Try to block all viruses to win.
*Warning*: don't touch a virus without getting a grey antibody. You'll lose health and move slowly.

                             ----Getting Unstuck Day 19---
"Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch."

title: PALLINE o TAPPI?
description: Libera interpretazione di un Tutorial di Pixel Art di Mondo Computazionale :  Tutorial Scratch [ITA]: Creiamo Pixel Art con Scratch (2 di 2)
instructions:
Clicca sulle palline, cambiano colore.
Si può usare per disegni in Pixel Art monocromatici (a più colori modificando i blocchi ).
Creato non per la Pixel Art, ma per trasporre in Scratch un'attività presentata in un Mooc di Matematica dell'Università di Torino , fatta con i tappi delle bottiglie. Dal tappo, alla rappresentazione sulla carta, a Scratch (relazioni e funzioni).
writing:
Libera interpretazione di un Tutorial di Pixel Art di Mondo Computazionale :  Tutorial Scratch [ITA]: Creiamo Pixel Art con Scratch (2 di 2)Clicca sulle palline, cambiano colore.
Si può usare per disegni in Pixel Art monocromatici (a più colori modificando i blocchi ).
Creato non per la Pixel Art, ma per trasporre in Scratch un'attività presentata in un Mooc di Matematica dell'Università di Torino , fatta con i tappi delle bottiglie. Dal tappo, alla rappresentazione sulla carta, a Scratch (relazioni e funzioni).

title: Growing Flower Clones - Getting Unstuck Day 19
description:
One of those projects that with a little more time I could have spiffed this up a bit. Still, using clones is fun. I am definetly doing something slightly wrong with this the basics of this project too. I caught one mistake, I was just hiding the seed clones instead of deleting them, and it was causing trouble. 
Still, sometimes I end up with 2 sunflowers instead of one, and I am not sure why. 
Something else I would change would be making sure that the sunflowers would show up directly where the seed was. 95% sure I could have done that with a variable or list, I just didn't get a chance to do it!
instructions: Click the space bar to plant a seed. When your watering can touches a seed, get ready for a sunny surprise!
writing:
One of those projects that with a little more time I could have spiffed this up a bit. Still, using clones is fun. I am definetly doing something slightly wrong with this the basics of this project too. I caught one mistake, I was just hiding the seed clones instead of deleting them, and it was causing trouble. 
Still, sometimes I end up with 2 sunflowers instead of one, and I am not sure why. 
Something else I would change would be making sure that the sunflowers would show up directly where the seed was. 95% sure I could have done that with a variable or list, I just didn't get a chance to do it!Click the space bar to plant a seed. When your watering can touches a seed, get ready for a sunny surprise!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 19
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 19 Reflection:
I apologize if you don't like bugs - I can't let this play for very long before I have to stop it myself!  I wanted to see if I could make a swarm of something appear by creating clones of clones, and what would happen if they continued unchecked.  I'd like to create a way for to bring the population back under control again, by making another sprite that would eat the bugs.
instructions: Click on the green flag and move your mouse around.  Watch the infestation of bugs follow you around the screen.
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 19 Reflection:
I apologize if you don't like bugs - I can't let this play for very long before I have to stop it myself!  I wanted to see if I could make a swarm of something appear by creating clones of clones, and what would happen if they continued unchecked.  I'd like to create a way for to bring the population back under control again, by making another sprite that would eat the bugs.Click on the green flag and move your mouse around.  Watch the infestation of bugs follow you around the screen.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 19 - clones
description:
The inspiration for the game came from the awesome project @antonellamazzobel created at https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237141092/

This was a lot of fun to make. For some reason I like to turn all my projects into games.

I could probably make this game even harder by subtracting points every time a bubble disappeared on its own.
instructions:

title: #GettingUnstuck19 - Massive ant clones
description:
The ant gif is taken from https://ianparberry.wordpress.com/2013/02/01/ant-walk-cycles/

This is a wonderful first project to learn how to use clones in Scratch :) There is another version that aggregates some figures in order to teach some thoughts about basic statistics. You can find it at https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/136934582/
instructions:
Press Green flag and follow the instructions.

This project is part of #GettingUnstuck initiative #CreativeComputing, Day 19

"Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. For example, you could make a project that represents a natural or human-made phenomenon"

This project will create an infinite number of ants, which will start at the center of the screen and then will move randomly to the borders. They will use the pen to draw their trajectory.

- You can press 'q' to speed up the number of ants per second (less wait time), and 'a' to speed down (more wait time).
- If you want to finish, press <space bar>
writing:
The ant gif is taken from https://ianparberry.wordpress.com/2013/02/01/ant-walk-cycles/

This is a wonderful first project to learn how to use clones in Scratch :) There is another version that aggregates some figures in order to teach some thoughts about basic statistics. You can find it at https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/136934582/Press Green flag and follow the instructions.

This project is part of #GettingUnstuck initiative #CreativeComputing, Day 19

"Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. For example, you could make a project that represents a natural or human-made phenomenon"

This project will create an infinite number of ants, which will start at the center of the screen and then will move randomly to the borders. They will use the pen to draw their trajectory.

- You can press 'q' to speed up the number of ants per second (less wait time), and 'a' to speed down (more wait time).
- If you want to finish, press <space bar>

title: Conway (Cellular Automaton)
instructions:
Just press the green flag and watch.

This is a variant of Conway's Game of Life - a cellular automaton. The original uses a grid, while this allows the cells to be placed randomly. It detects neighbours by jiggling left, right, up and down and counting how many neighbours it is touching. If it has fewer than 2 neighbours (lonely) or more than 3 neighbours (overcrowded), it dies. If it has exactly three neighbours, it clones itself (and the child moves a short distance away from its parent).

The min/max population sliders control the range of values for the initial, random population. Play with these to find values for stable populations and where overcrowding or loneliness kills the colony off very quickly.
writing:
nanJust press the green flag and watch.

This is a variant of Conway's Game of Life - a cellular automaton. The original uses a grid, while this allows the cells to be placed randomly. It detects neighbours by jiggling left, right, up and down and counting how many neighbours it is touching. If it has fewer than 2 neighbours (lonely) or more than 3 neighbours (overcrowded), it dies. If it has exactly three neighbours, it clones itself (and the child moves a short distance away from its parent).

The min/max population sliders control the range of values for the initial, random population. Play with these to find values for stable populations and where overcrowding or loneliness kills the colony off very quickly.

title: Bubbles
description:
Yaay! I couldn't wait to make bubbles with Scratch! :) 

Last week I've been facilitating a workshop on tinkering with Scratch in the physical world (theme was "summer sounds"). 
Two of the participants were working on making bubbles and popping them using video sensing. They didn't know how to use clones and their exploration went in a different direction, but I was super excited about their idea and I could't wait to make my own version of it!

If it wasn't 1am, I would keep working on this! There is a lot to play with the wind and physics, but also imagining different scenarios (I wasn't sure if it was underwater, or in a park, or somewhere else?) or any type of stories, I could play with colors and making bubble arts, design many games that involve movement.. and much more!

Anyway, I'm really enjoying making with Scratch! Only 2 projects to unstuck.. and only 2 days to unstick! :) (I feel extremely extrinsically motivated by Steven's sticker!)

Happy bubbles!
instructions:
Space bar to make bubbles!
Try changing the wind with left and right arrows..
Enjoy and remix!

title: Cell Replication (Getting Unstuck #19)
description:
Getting Unstuck activity 19 - "Create a project that uses the cloning features of Scratch. For example, you could make a project that represents a natural or human-made phenomenon. "

Fairly basic script - the sprite moves in a loop then pauses and clones itself. Each clone picks a new random direction and copies the logic of the original sprite until the screen is full of cells.
instructions: Click the flag to start the cell replication process!

title: Three of a Kind
description:
I was recently in Las Vegas for my grandmother's 90th birthday party. (She's very adventurous!) While there, I was stunned by the number of slot machines—I think it left a deep aesthetic impression on me. And so when I saw today's prompt (Day 18 of Getting Unstuck), it made me think of these games of chance! The structure of the prompt and the structure of my lived experiences collided to produce this creation!
My sound effects selections don't sound right to me, but I wasn't entirely what would be better (and where to find it). If you have any audio recommendations, please let me know—I would be very grateful! (Update: I switched from gong on spin-click to computer beeps, which seems less blarghy.)
instructions:
Press the green flag, then spin to play.
Can you get three of a kind?

title: Puzzle
description:
This project was created for Day 18 of Getting Unstuck. I've always loved puzzle games, so I thought I would try my hand at making one today. Conclusion: it's harder than it seems!  

I thought I would "keep it simple" and avoid clones with the project, but I had some major regrets due to the amount of work to keep the nearly-identical sprites in sync with each other. Lesson learned: use clones when you can!

Music: 4bstr4ck3r, "Random Effect"

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 18 — Guessing Game
description:
Reflection

For today's Getting Unstuck, I use the AND block to sanitize the input. Players should only be able to select a number between 1 and 100. Should the player enter in a number outside of this range, or anything else that isn't a pure number, Scratch Cat informs them that the input is invalid, and players are not penalized.
instructions:
Welcome to the Guessing Game!!

Choose a number between 1 and 100 until you guess the correct number. The less number of guesses it takes you, the better the prize.

writing:
Scratch project was created as activity #18 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #18 Challenge: Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed. Press the green flag and follow the instructions!

title: Unstuck 18 Multiple conditions
description: I saw this challenge as an opportunity to build upon and improve one of my previous projects, involving game levels. Specifically, in addition to incorporating "multiple condition checking," I wanted to get more practice using clones as "game treasures" and "game features" (in this case platforms. I learned that "delete this clone" is necessary in order for global counters to be used in the "when I start as a clone" block. I am motivated to do some more reading about exactly what happens to scratch variables when clones are created. I didn't have time to fancy up the game ending, including stopping the display of clones at the end of the game.
instructions:
Create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

Collect all the treasures and keys to reveal the secret.
writing:
I saw this challenge as an opportunity to build upon and improve one of my previous projects, involving game levels. Specifically, in addition to incorporating "multiple condition checking," I wanted to get more practice using clones as "game treasures" and "game features" (in this case platforms. I learned that "delete this clone" is necessary in order for global counters to be used in the "when I start as a clone" block. I am motivated to do some more reading about exactly what happens to scratch variables when clones are created. I didn't have time to fancy up the game ending, including stopping the display of clones at the end of the game.

title: Unstuck: Day 18, Secret Revealed V2
description:
This project is for Getting Unstuck challenge day 18, reveal something by user interaction.
This one is an update to my first submitted project today, adding the feature of changing the colors.
instructions:
What color are the 3 columns of circles? Click the button to reveal the secret! Try different color combinations and see which create a more effective illusion.
This project is an example of a Munker illusion, in which bands of different colors are shown to affect each other in surprising ways. I came across a version of it online here https://twitter.com/NovickProf/status/1019592963259691008. 
It's hard to believe your eyes!

title: If you dare ... (Getting Unstuck Day 18)
description:
This is my sixth Getting Unstuck project (two of them can be found on my other account @PinkyPepper).

I remixed an old project and turned it into a puzzle game. I would have liked to make a real escape room, but I gave myself a time constraint today. I used a list again, because I learned more about using lists yesterday. My daughter tested my project and found a bug, which was easy to solve. If you find another one, please let me know.
instructions:
This is a puzzle game. Can you reveal the surpise? Take a chance and look around in the dark  if you dare ...

I made this for Day 18 of Getting Unstuck. Todays challenge:
Create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

title: Intro to Circuits
description: For getting unstuck day 18, multiple conditions. This was inspired by @paulinah's really cool and complex circuit project. I basically started over and kept things simple so I could use this as an accompanying Scratch piece to paper circuit projects for early childhood students. Thanks paulinah for the inspiration!
instructions: Click the green flag, then use the pointer to drag each of two wires to a position on the stage where they will make a complete circuit. The LED will light up. If you accidentally drag one of the other sprites (the battery or the LED), click the green flag again to put them back in position.

title: Challenge 18 - to the moon
description:
We had a pipe burst in the street right outside my driveway the other day. The city workers worked hard all day and at one point one of the guys yelled, "HEY, STAND ON THAT PIPE". 

That is all it took for inspiration for this project apparently. No city workers were harmed in the making of this project nor did any end up in space. :)
instructions:
Ok, challenge 18......... Had so many ideas and I was messing around while finalizing an idea and as I was messing around this came full circle. There isn't so much of a secret but there is a surprise when conditions are met. best with sound on

Another wild ride. Click the flag and enjoy I very rarely do animations. However, Getting Unstuck has had me creating them and I have had fun doing them.

title: Day 18: I like to eat . . .
description:
I created this project during the "mouse over" challenge, but couldn't get it to work that day.  Fixed that (yay!!)
When the surprise was revealed, I wanted to make the appearance of sprites more "showy" and to play a certain song :)  Had trouble changing the size of sprites when grow and shrink were clicked.  Also wanted to introduce a chomping sound, but it glitched.  When instructions were coded to do something fancy, such as turn right and then left, the sprite followed the first instruction but not the next ones in the series. 
I wanted the intro script to run completely before the scroll over options began, so I introduced the space bar (in addition to green flag and broadcast). I suspect there is conflict with the "Event" blocks as with an earlier challenge, but not sure. 
Suggestions for debugging and alternate/more efficient use of code are welcome.
instructions:
Press the green flag and you may find out what Nano likes to eat!

Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.
writing:
I created this project during the "mouse over" challenge, but couldn't get it to work that day.  Fixed that (yay!!)
When the surprise was revealed, I wanted to make the appearance of sprites more "showy" and to play a certain song :)  Had trouble changing the size of sprites when grow and shrink were clicked.  Also wanted to introduce a chomping sound, but it glitched.  When instructions were coded to do something fancy, such as turn right and then left, the sprite followed the first instruction but not the next ones in the series. 
I wanted the intro script to run completely before the scroll over options began, so I introduced the space bar (in addition to green flag and broadcast). I suspect there is conflict with the "Event" blocks as with an earlier challenge, but not sure. 
Suggestions for debugging and alternate/more efficient use of code are welcome.
Press the green flag and you may find out what Nano likes to eat!

title: Memory
description:
I started the project three times because I kept missing the objective of today's challenge. And even this one is barely hits. I removed the ands and ors and used a not condition to make the program understand that the two cards are the same. I got stuck several times, mainly because I needed to figure how to randomize the lists. I did a list with numbers from 1 to 20 and then randomly it puts them in other two lists, deleting the number so it can't be used again. So card n.1 (the cat) are in position list1 n.1 and list2 n.1. Card n.2 (the crab) are in position list1 n.2 and list2 n.2. Headache? :P
Every clone has a private variable (remember, the sprite variables are also clone variables) with a progressive number, so every time the user clicks on a card, it's possible to know what it is looking for its number in the lists.

Fun facts: the whole game is inspired by an old (early eighties) quiz show, named BIS, where the cells were small slide projectors' screens controlled by wire from a console.

Credits: map by Tubs and hands+vinyl by Mbdortmund, from Wikipedia
instructions: It's the classic memory game! Click on the cards and search for matches. A riddle will be shown after you remove the cards.

title: Unstuck 18 Multiple conditions (v2)
description:
Update v2:
-I think I fixed the problems with not displaying the "game complete" message correctly. I spent some time reading the scratch wiki to better understand how clones work, which has been a challenge for me. I made some changes based on what I learned.
-cleaned up leftover platform clones at end of game.
-added a "this way" sprite to show how to get to the next level.

I saw this challenge as an opportunity to build upon and improve one of my previous projects, involving game levels. Specifically, in addition to incorporating "multiple condition checking," I wanted to get more practice using clones as "game treasures" and "game features" (in this case platforms. I learned that "delete this clone" is necessary in order for global counters to be used in the "when I start as a clone" block. I am motivated to do some more reading about exactly what happens to scratch variables when clones are created. I didn't have time to fancy up the game ending, including stopping the display of clones at the end of the game.
instructions:
Create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

Collect all the treasures and keys to reveal the secret.

-added a "this way" sprite to show how to get to the next level.

title: Unstuck 18 Pickup Sticks *Draft*
description:
I got stuck so many times creating this project. It was a lot of fun to figure out how to get each piece to work!

I worked through a number of issues with layers, but can't figure out how to place a stick that is moved from the middle of the remaining pile back to it's same location after it is moved to the front. I have to rethink the system of using variables to track the layers.

This might work best abandoning the layers altogether and using some sort of physical controller (makey makey, scratchbit, micro:bit?) and collabroation between one person moving the mouse and another operating the mouse click, press, and release.
instructions:
Did you ever play the game pick up sticks? You had to move a stick off a pile without any other stick moving.

I've been working all day on having the user move the top stick off the pile, but I'm running into trouble managing layers. I put it back together but now it delays when you move the seventh stick. Keep trying and I'll come back to it later to try to fix it.

If you separate all the sticks, you will see a surprise!

I still need to add audio effects, but wanted to get it posted.

title: Getting Unstuck #18
description:
Getting Unstuck day 18.
When this email arrived I was thinking about one of my favourite childrens' books, Harquin, the Fox who went down to went down to the valley. In this program, if it's night, and the squire's not about, Harquin will come out and look around. If either of these conditions is not met he'll (eventually) go back to his burrow. 
There is no surprise in this project. I was so intent on doing something using Harquin that I didn't really read the prompt. There's a lesson there.
I enjoyed using the vector editor, and suspect I'll be using it again.
I think I have the timings about right; Harquin seems to appear and disappear often enough.
instructions: Press the green flag.

title: Critical Hit? (Unstuck 18)
description:
For such a simple prompt, this one really challenged me. Since I didn't know where to start, I approached this the same way when working with other material, and just started "doing stuff." Once I put a few blocks together, this idea came together.

Right now, there's no real end to the game and I'm open to suggestions. I'm struggling with having the scripts stop when Hit Points equal zero or less. I've tried a lot of variations with the "stop all" block, and haven't had any success - will try again soon.
instructions:
Click on the Beholder to "roll" your d20 and see if you can get a critical hit for 2x damage -- before its hit points reach 0.

This is a work in progress (see below).

title: Get Smart_GU_Day18
description:
This project took on a life of its own. I didn't get stuck today. Oh, wait, I spoke too soon. When running my project to check it, sometimes the sprite with the intro words becomes very large & off the screen. (Is this b/c I have both bitmap & vector graphics running at the same time?) 
However, since the project is multi-faceted, it took a very long time to accomplish.There is so much more that can be done to enhance it. 
Inspiration for the Q & A came from @karenb 's project with the escape room.

(If you want to peek, the answers are in a list.) The questions are chosen at random from a list of 10. You will answer 2 questions at a time. If you get one wrong, you will be given another question (or perhaps the same one, again, It's random!)

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 18
description:
This is my project for Day 18 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. As the challenge goes on, it becomes increasingly difficult to find a solution to the proposed problem. I think I've made a nice game even if I have to say it's a hard to win. However, the difficulty can be adjusted by changing the speed of the figures or the speed of the ball.

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions:
Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

English: 3 geometric figures travels in space. If you hit the square you will gain 1 point, otherwise you'll lose a point. Try to get a score above 3 (it seems easy but it's not, trust me :P) and you will have access to the surprise. 
How to throw the ball? Press the SPACE key and point the mouse in the direction you want the ball to be launched.


Italian translation: 3 figure geometriche viaggiano nello spazio. Se colpisci il quadrato otterrai 1 punto, altrimenti perderai un punto. Cerca di ottenere un punteggio superiore a 3 (sembra facile ma non lo è, fidati di me: P) e avrai accesso alla sorpresa.
Come lanciare la palla? Premi il tasto SPAZIO e punta il mouse nella direzione in cui vuoi che venga lanciata la palla.
writing:
This is my project for Day 18 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. As the challenge goes on, it becomes increasingly difficult to find a solution to the proposed problem. I think I've made a nice game even if I have to say it's a hard to win. However, the difficulty can be adjusted by changing the speed of the figures or the speed of the ball.

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

English: 3 geometric figures travels in space. If you hit the square you will gain 1 point, otherwise you'll lose a point. Try to get a score above 3 (it seems easy but it's not, trust me :P) and you will have access to the surprise. 
How to throw the ball? Press the SPACE key and point the mouse in the direction you want the ball to be launched.


Italian translation: 3 figure geometriche viaggiano nello spazio. Se colpisci il quadrato otterrai 1 punto, altrimenti perderai un punto. Cerca di ottenere un punteggio superiore a 3 (sembra facile ma non lo è, fidati di me: P) e avrai accesso alla sorpresa.
Come lanciare la palla? Premi il tasto SPAZIO e punta il mouse nella direzione in cui vuoi che venga lanciata la palla.

title: Unstuck Day 18 - Mood Survey
description:
I had a tough time today. I had most of this project done in the morning then went to see Hamilton. When I logged into Scratch this evening, my project was gone.I did the best I could making it a second time. The tallies don't seem to be working, so I need to fix that. But that's for another day. BTW - If you have a chance to see Hamilton, it's fantastic! 

It sounds like I need cloud variables in order for the tallies to remain. I don't believe I have the ability to make them. So feel free to do this several times and change your anwers each time.
instructions: Press the flag to begin. You will be asked two questions - your gender and your mood.
writing:

When I logged into Scratch this evening, my project was gone.I did the best I could making it a second time. The tallies don't seem to be working, so I need to fix that. But that's for another day. BTW - If you have a chance to see Hamilton, it's fantastic! 

It sounds like I need cloud variables in order for the tallies to remain. I don't believe I have the ability to make them. So feel free to do this several times and change your anwers each time. Press the flag to begin. You will be asked two questions - your gender and your mood.

Once again, I resorted to using information from one of my trusty DK books.  This project came from "Coding Projects in Scratch." 

I know that I am learning a LOT and I like the fact that the projects force me to learn about blocks that I would otherwise ignore. I am hopeful that I will soon be able to create a project without relying heavily on someone else's project.

title: challenge18EscapeRoom
description: This project turned out way more complicated than I first intended it to be. I used the "and" operator block twice: once to check that all the coefficients of the balanced chemical equation were correct, and once to set a range for the answer to a gram calculation.I used the "or" key to take into account the different ways the user could enter the limiting reagent - by name or formula. I made the key sprites myself, from pictures. The sounds are all in public domain, except for the door unlocked sound, which was recorded by Mike Koenig and found at SoundBible.com.
instructions: This is an escape room. The clues to escape are chemistry questions. Click the green flag to begin.
writing: This project turned out way more complicated than I first intended it to be. I used the "and" operator block twice: once to check that all the coefficients of the balanced chemical equation were correct, and once to set a range for the answer to a gram calculation.I used the "or" key to take into account the different ways the user could enter the limiting reagent - by name or formula. I made the key sprites myself, from pictures. The sounds are all in public domain, except for the door unlocked sound, which was recorded by Mike Koenig and found at SoundBible.com. This is an escape room. The clues to escape are chemistry questions. Click the green flag to begin.

title: Two Dice Game
description:
Unstuck Challenge 18: Using one or more of the and, or, and not Operators blocks, create a project that when multiple conditions have been satisfied, a secret is revealed.

This project is designed for 7th Grade Math Probability Unit: compound event. Possible remix idea is to simulate "Two Dice Sum" or "Two Dice Product".
instructions: Click on the green flag to start. You can choose to roll the pair of dice once, or you can ask the computer to roll the dice 10 time. The results will be recorded each time.

This project is designed for 7th Grade Math Probability Unit: compound event. Possible remix idea is to simulate "Two Dice Sum" or "Two Dice Product". Click on the green flag to start. You can choose to roll the pair of dice once, or you can ask the computer to roll the dice 10 time. The results will be recorded each time.

title: Little gold miner
description:
At first, I didn't know what to do today.Then I realized, that I could do something interesting by using the pen blocks.
So, I decided to create a game where you can find different hidden things. I used clones for the treasures and when they are close, they are making a sound that help us to find them.

I'd like to add more things to find, music  and another way to improve the use of pen blocks.
instructions:
Help the gold miner to find precious metals or other things before time  runs out.
Press the play button to start and follow the directions.
Mouse to move.
Space and mouse button to dig.
You've got 120 secs.

title: Getting Unlocked
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 18
by Massimo Marletta

The user must guess a number satisfying all the 3 secret criteria.
Each of the orange block will move as one criterion is satisfied.
instructions:
* You have to guess a number which satisfies some secret criteria.

* Set your guess with the green buttons (the left one decrease and the right one increase the values showed in the display).

* Click on the key to check if your number is the secret one.

Each of the tree locks (the orange blocks on the right) will move and became blue (indicating you have unlocked a part of the mechanism) if your guess satisfies a criterion. Only if your guess satisfies ALL the criteria the mechanism will be completely unlocked!
(for example if the secret number is 10, the first lock could be unlocked if your guess is multiple of 2, the second if your guess if multiple of 5, ...).

title: Virtual Flower
description:
I was able to get this project to work, but I don't think I've got the conditions quite right - I think it's just picking up on the touching the pot bottom and that's all it needs to do.  I think I need to work on it more to figure out how to introduce another condition.

Given more time, I'd also move the water and food to sprinkle onto the flowers and then move back. I would also add variables to monitor hunger, thirst, and light.

I got the original idea from Scratch's Virtual Pet project - from a set of Scratch Coding Cards that I just received. https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237145343/#editor
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to begin.

Provide just the right condition for the flowers to grow to their fullest...

title: Logic - Getting Unstuck Day 18
description: I started down this path and I think I got too far into it to stop.
instructions:
An interesting logic puzzle. 
Click the green flag to start the project.  and click on the top row of balls to change the colour. 
Depending on the logic the balls in the second row will change colours.  
When the balls in the last row match you have unlocked the background!!  
It can be easy depending on the ball to match. or very challenging!!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18
description:
Not my most creative project.  Actually pretty literal. I have an engineering background and this took me back to beginning college classes. 

The hardest part of the project was working with the costumes.  I prefer using the costume names, but that was not working here.  So I had to use the costume numbers.
instructions:

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18 - conditionals
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 18: conditionals.

For this project I revisited an earlier game I made for Day 9. I figured out a way to use conditionals to randomly place the food, plus used conditionals to determine whether the player was successful or not.
instructions:
Press the green flag to get started. Your objective is to gather as many food pellets as possible to take to the feeding center.

Use the arrow keys to move the ant through the maze.

Red pellets = kills the ant and stops all action
Yellow/green = +1 point
Purple/pink = -1 point

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 18 Reflection:
This is really simple, but I got to try a few different operators that I hadn't used before.  MsNykorchuk5's project has more riddles, which is what I'd like to figure out how to do.
I think the and/or/not operators are helpful, but I have to think more about when to use them.  A lot of times the if/then blocks seem to work just as well, if not better.  But I am not a very advanced Scratch user - I'm sure they have their uses that I don't quite understand yet!
instructions: Click on the green flag and see if you can solve the riddle.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 18
description:
Inspiration came from Day 18 of Getting Unstuck asking me to use the and block in a conditional statement. I decided to follow the example of some early 8-bit games where the player had to collect objects to get to the next level.
I used the pacman from an earlier project and used the backpack to move it across.
To improve this project I would add more objects to collect, perhaps using cloning to do it efficiently. I'd also like to add more levels.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to start.
Use the arrow keys to control the pacman.
Avoid the red lines.
Collect the three items and make your way to the rainbow to finish the game.

title: Dance with letters
description:
Today's prompt was to make a project using some logical operators "and, or, not" to reveal a secret. The prompt was too wide and all it came in my mind were logic puzzles, but I wanted to do something more artistic.

The inspiration came from a video that I watched today about an installation at Artechouse, where people were immersed in a sea of letters and could interact with them by moving their bodies.

I made a first version pretty quickly but then I realized that I wasn't using the logical operators and I needed a secret to reveal. I got stuck, so I went for a walk. When I came back I had the idea of using the letters to reveal a word. The project got much more complicated but I learned more about clones and I'm pretty satisfied with the final result.

Enjoy!

PS: I've just realized that the prompt for day 19 is about clones! Now I have to make a different one! :)
instructions:
Click the green flag, make sure your webcam is on and... dance until you find the "secret" message!

To fully enjoy this project, get far from the screen and use all of your body to move the letters around.
writing:
Today's prompt was to make a project using some logical operators "and, or, not" to reveal a secret. The prompt was too wide and all it came in my mind were logic puzzles, but I wanted to do something more artistic.

The inspiration came from a video that I watched today about an installation at Artechouse, where people were immersed in a sea of letters and could interact with them by moving their bodies.

I made a first version pretty quickly but then I realized that I wasn't using the logical operators and I needed a secret to reveal. I got stuck, so I went for a walk. When I came back I had the idea of using the letters to reveal a word. The project got much more complicated but I learned more about clones and I'm pretty satisfied with the final result.

Enjoy!

PS: I've just realized that the prompt for day 19 is about clones! Now I have to make a different one! :)Click the green flag, make sure your webcam is on and... dance until you find the "secret" message!

To fully enjoy this project, get far from the screen and use all of your body to move the letters around.

title: Catch 'em all (v2 - remixed!)-3
description: Have spent too many hours on this today and it definitely leaves me frustrated and thinking about the experiences of students and teachers in classrooms. Currently I'm teaching in a classroom with both desktops and laptops (different models, every kid has a slightly different one), and I've run into all kinds of bugs like these, which definitely make the process of learning to code harder!
instructions: UGH. Press the green flag to get a sense of things. I remixed a previous project so that everything falling was part of the scrolling, but ran into a TON of bugs. It works great offline; breaks differently in Chrome (can't move left/right) than it does in Firefox (where the background turns pink and giant for some reason). Debugging encouraged! (It seems like all the sprites work fine, but there's something about the way the background is blown up that Scratch hates? But also, it worked fine in the previous iteration?

title: The "See You At MIT!" Pass-It-On Project
description: For Day 20 of Getting Unstuck, I decide to revisit the "3 Favorite Things" pass-it-on project from Day 11! I loved learning about the Getting Unstuck community. I also loved that day because people remixed the project to make it better, making each element standalone (using "when sprite clicked") instead of sequential (using "broadcast and wait"). I'm starting this new pass-it-on project in this way that scales better. I hope you'll join in! And I hope to see you in person this week! ❤️✨
instructions: Click on me to find out why I'm excited about the MIT Scratch Conference, which is taking place this week! Then add yourself to this pass-it-on project!
writing: For Day 20 of Getting Unstuck, I decide to revisit the "3 Favorite Things" pass-it-on project from Day 11! I loved learning about the Getting Unstuck community. I also loved that day because people remixed the project to make it better, making each element standalone (using "when sprite clicked") instead of sequential (using "broadcast and wait"). I'm starting this new pass-it-on project in this way that scales better. I hope you'll join in! And I hope to see you in person this week! ❤️✨Click on me to find out why I'm excited about the MIT Scratch Conference, which is taking place this week! Then add yourself to this pass-it-on project!

title: Truffle's Idea Tumbler
description:
updates on this iteration for Day 20:
I made a few detail edits, such as adding in spaces between the responses that Truffle joins as an idea. Sometimes when trying something new, the details are missed, and I'm glad to come back to this! I also added a feature where you can add a question to Truffle's memory. What question might bring some playful ideas?

original notes:
AHHHHH - This was my first time exploring strings and lists!
^---- that's a very excited ahhhh!

At first I wasn't even sure what the string blocks might be used for. I started off by looking at the Scratch wiki (https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/String) to see what they even did. (thanks @paulinah)! Then I thought that I would create something that generated randomized text. 

The most exciting part of creating this came as I was thinking of questions to ask. As I plugged in Ask " " and wait, and "add answer to list" at least 15 times, and saw my code grow longer and longer, I wondered how I could randomize the questions so that they might appear in another order (or be repeated, for re-considering other potential responses.) I thought, if I could put them somewhere and ask for a random one, that would be great. I had just created my first list of the answers to questions. It was a sparkly realization moment when I thought "what if I stored the *questions* in a list, too??? This way, they could both be randomized when called upon and ALSO be more organized, not making my script forever long. I was honestly feeling kind of unsure about taking on lists -- and there I was, creating lists on lists to be joined in (lovingly) weird strings! I'm excited to see where this new discovery goes!

During the recent Getting Unstuck project on changing scenes, I decided to try a "pause and come back" strategy in stuck moments. When I paused, I'd go in the vector editor and work on this cat face, thinking I'd surely use it for something in the future. I felt comfortable enough to play around with creating the cat while also thinking through the challenges in the project I was programming. For this challenge, I didn't spend ANY time on drawing, as I'd already created the cat. I wonder how far I would've gotten in the lists + strings exploration if I were also focusing on creating my own graphics?
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, press the space bar to start.

Once Truffle has started sharing potential ideas, click on her and she'll share more (:

(update: press up arrow to add a question to Truffle's memory!)
writing:
updates on this iteration for Day 20:
I made a few detail edits, such as adding in spaces between the responses that Truffle joins as an idea. Sometimes when trying something new, the details are missed, and I'm glad to come back to this! I also added a feature where you can add a question to Truffle's memory. What question might bring some playful ideas?

original notes:
AHHHHH - This was my first time exploring strings and lists!
^---- that's a very excited ahhhh!

At first I wasn't even sure what the string blocks might be used for. I started off by looking at the Scratch wiki (https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/String) to see what they even did. (thanks @paulinah)! Then I thought that I would create something that generated randomized text. 

The most exciting part of creating this came as I was thinking of questions to ask. As I plugged in Ask " " and wait, and "add answer to list" at least 15 times, and saw my code grow longer and longer, I wondered how I could randomize the questions so that they might appear in another order (or be repeated, for re-considering other potential responses.) I thought, if I could put them somewhere and ask for a random one, that would be great. I had just created my first list of the answers to questions. It was a sparkly realization moment when I thought "what if I stored the *questions* in a list, too??? This way, they could both be randomized when called upon and ALSO be more organized, not making my script forever long. I was honestly feeling kind of unsure about taking on lists -- and there I was, creating lists on lists to be joined in (lovingly) weird strings! I'm excited to see where this new discovery goes!

During the recent Getting Unstuck project on changing scenes, I decided to try a "pause and come back" strategy in stuck moments. When I paused, I'd go in the vector editor and work on this cat face, thinking I'd surely use it for something in the future. I felt comfortable enough to play around with creating the cat while also thinking through the challenges in the project I was programming. For this challenge, I didn't spend ANY time on drawing, as I'd already created the cat. I wonder how far I would've gotten in the lists + strings exploration if I were also focusing on creating my own graphics?After pressing the green flag, press the space bar to start.

Once Truffle has started sharing potential ideas, click on her and she'll share more (:

(update: press up arrow to add a question to Truffle's memory!)

title: Visual Editor, Improved
description:
This project was originally created for Day 14 for Getting Unstuck, and then revised for Day 20 of Getting Unstuck. I had originally set out to make a multiline text editing box, maybe even with a scroll bar. Wow, that was harder than I thought it would be. So on Day 14, I settled for the ability to enter characters.  

For Day 20, I added support for the Delete and Enter keys. Again, this was much harder than I thought it would be; it actually makes use of an undocumented Scratch feature, described here: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19199766/.  After concluding that there would probably not be an IPO for "Visual Editor, Improved", I decided that the only thing left to do before abandoning ship was to add a cool Easter egg. Enjoy!
instructions:
Press the green flag and enter a brief message in the text box. Only lowercase, unaccented characters and space key accepted for now.  The delete key can be used to fix mistakes; press enter when done. 

Easter egg: What happens when you type a few words but forget to press enter for a few seconds?

description:
Unstuck day 20
This is derivative of a project I began on day 13 and revised on days 14-15.  I've experimented with: connecting it to makeymakey instruments, bending notes based on the cursor's y position, separating graphix from sound, creating feedback loops through the user's microphone, and with eliminating a need for a user.

In this edition I changed the primary graphic to a spinning ball of thread. Given further time, I'd like to gamify this by creating an additional sprite that one tries to "catch" or grab with the fingertip. I think it will be necessary to use the timer and reset blocks to establish whether one has caught the other sprite (to distinguish it from a coincidental on stage passing-by).

An exciting discovery from this project has been the ability to use phantom sprites (e.g., no costume) to shadow other sprites, often by looping a glide instruction e.g. to the x/y of the first sprite. At this phase of iteration I may not be using any phantom sprites in a significant way, but - as we near the conclusion of GU - that's the grist on my mill. Another breakthrough from days 13-15 for me was that I could make these graphix without requiring the user to click or press down on the mouse/trackpad. The gentle fingertip and trackpad activity feels like a new Scratch experience. I'm very grateful for these discoveries! Thanks for the provocations!

Followup: made a remix for PicoBoard so the instrument can be set by a force resistant sensor connected to port D https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237255829/
instructions: Green flag. Move fingertip on touchscreen to change note.

title: Unstuck Day 20: Remix of Making Music
description:
For my Getting Unstuck challenge Day 20 I decided to add more features to my earlier music playing project. I got stuck big time on what seems to be a bug in Scratch. If a variable is displaying below a Y position of 0 you can't get the options you should get when you right click on it. I finally figured out you only get those options if you move it above 0. Big headache!
The trickiest part of adding all these features was design. It was hard to think of ways to give the user enough information. I still think some lines on the bars would make it better to show the increments you can differentiate by.
instructions:
Pick notes to play in a rhythm on the BLUE bar, then click PLAY.
Play along with your rhythm loop on the LIVE bar.
You can change both instruments on the RHYTHM and SOLO bars.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20 - Getting Random Improved
description:
I realized today I missed day 6 which was all about random, so I started to create, and iterated on the fly - I'm calling this day 6 and day 20 as I've spent far longer than usual on the challenge and have made big improvements on my original idea! 

I spent lots of time tweaking how you know as the user if for example two random costumes are the same (so used a changing backdrop to let you know the costume had changed) and also how you can be sure you've clicked one of the sprites below.

Enjoy!
instructions:
Here's a project to test your memory.  When you click the green flag, you'll see the sprite with the box around it change costumes.

Once it's finished, click the sprites at the bottom of the screen in the same order that the main sprite changed. Press space bar to see if you got it right, and to advance.

I spent lots of time tweaking how you know as the user if for example two random costumes are the same (so used a changing backdrop to let you know the costume had changed) and also how you can be sure you've clicked one of the sprites below.

Enjoy! Here's a project to test your memory.  When you click the green flag, you'll see the sprite with the box around it change costumes.

Once it's finished, click the sprites at the bottom of the screen in the same order that the main sprite changed. Press space bar to see if you got it right, and to advance.

When I first made this program, my flowers only cloned 10 times and it was difficult to see all ten flowers because they cloned on top of one another.  I have fixed that and also added some extra "fun" things to jazz this project up a bit.

title: Getting Unstuck day 20
description: For today I added to yesterday's project. I wanted to add a power up that would make it possible to eliminate some of the dealy tacos. I thought about have the cat shoot lightning bolts at the tacos, but that brought up all the complications of aiming and so on. Then I hit on just having a shield that destroyed the tacos if they touch it. At first I made the force field a costume the cat has. That did not work, i guess because the tacos had contradictory instructions. So I made the force field a sprite that always goes to the cat, but is hidden unless the shield is recharged and the user presses <space> before getting hit with a taco.
instructions:
green flag to start
arrow keys to move
space key for a 2 second force field that destroys tacos 

careful- the force field has to recharge before you can use it again

title: Day 20 - Day18 - Treasure Island redo
description:
http://soundbible.com/1830-Sad-Trombone.html
http://freemusicarchive.org/music/Wellington_Sea_Shanty_Society/

I added sound effects, background music, an additional backdrop, a timer, and some more hazards! I also shrunk all the game elements to make it more challenging.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag and follow the directions
Space bar to start game
S to move straight
R to move right
L to move left
Don't go in the water!
