Space bar to start game
S to move straight
R to move right
L to move left
Don't go in the water!

title: Unstuck 20 Clone Rabbits Jumping
description:
I wanted to complete the following behaviours I didn't have time to include before. Happy with the result. 
- clones run both left and right
- clones disappear as they near the left and right edge of screen (first time using the ghost effect).
I experimented with multiple "When I start as a clone" blocks. Love this.
If I had more time, I would like to make the hopping effect more realistic by making sure when rabbit lands, he changes costume immediately before traveling along the x-axis. I probably should have NOT using multiple "When I start as a clone" blocks in order to make it look better. Oh well, the short and simple was good enough for today.
instructions:
Choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck and revise it.

The Rabbit will give you instructions.

title: day 20 revision and revisiting
description: I started learning about Kolam designs. I had never really thought about how graph paper traditionally has the dots in a 90 degree relationship and how if the dots were in a 60 degree relationship - everything would be so different!! This made me wonder about making 90 degree and 60 degree patterns in the same file online. I think I used the clones to track where I was, but I'm still really unsure about what clones are and how they work... and how I might have coded exactly this same result without using clones and most importantly the pros and cons to using clones here!!!! Please help me understand this!!??
instructions: Click the green flag to start and see if you can imagine how to make another shape flower

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 20 — Reactive Rainbow
description:
Reflection

I decided to make a couple of changes to my Day 13 project. I really liked the effect of the colors chasing the mouse, but overall the project needed a few extra tweaks to give it a more finished feel.

The changes I made are: The dots are now smaller. I added the use of the mosaic effect. And the dots are now created in a grid formation rather than randomly.

Even though the changes are minimal, the overall look and feel of the project has improved significantly.
instructions: Move the mouse pointer of the red dots.
writing:
Reflection

I decided to make a couple of changes to my Day 13 project. I really liked the effect of the colors chasing the mouse, but overall the project needed a few extra tweaks to give it a more finished feel.

The changes I made are: The dots are now smaller. I added the use of the mosaic effect. And the dots are now created in a grid formation rather than randomly.

Even though the changes are minimal, the overall look and feel of the project has improved significantly.Move the mouse pointer of the red dots.

title: Cat on a desert island copy
description:
This is an improved version of the stranded cat. Now with CLOUD VARIABLES.

Cloud variables are very interesting. The most easy thing to do with CV are records tables and halls of fame, but they can be used to do a lot of things, like multiplayer (if you have a good connection).
I have the feeling that is one of the interesting features that I used the less (besides creating plug-ins for the offline version).

Sounds on freesound.org:
rainfall by sonitusetaudio
thunders by juskiddink, Yoyodaman234 and olliehahn12
instructions:
Show and modify variable "hour" to see the different states of this scene.

The starting position should reflect the time of the day. The cat goes to bed at 22 o'clock and gets up at 7 in the morning. Some days are rainy!

Every time someone visits the island (in a single day), a fruit will appear!

title: Challenge20 - Platformer copy
description:
Had a few minutes and had always wanted to create a game where the user gets to play it how they want. I didn't have time for the whole game so I thought I'd create an engine with all condtions ready to go.

This game allows people to play the way they want. Be creative, get your cat to the yellow.
instructions:
Forgot to create a copy. So copied and re added to the studio, removed the first one.

Redoing this from a few projects ago. Thought I'd see it through, add a few levels and few extra effects. Will add more levels when I have time. 

Draw bridges, platforms, whatever to get Scratch to the yellow. 

Arrow Keys left/right/up

You get 50 line points to draw platforms to get your cat to yellow

Space resets the level
Z to undo your last line

title: Projectile Motion Example - Bowtie Launcher
description:
This is a demonstration of my approach to scripting realistic projectile motion in scratch. Check out the comments on the script blocks to learn more about how it works.

For Day 20 of Getting Unstuck, I chose to revisit my Bowtie Launcher project to make the scripts clearer and add comments for anyone curious about how they work.
instructions:
Hold down the mouse to 'charge up' the starting velocity of your shot, then let go to launch.

Adjust Gravity with the slider.

This was my project from Unstuck Day 18. I cleaned it up a bit. Plus I added cloud variables. This allows the values to remain. As more users answer the questions, the values will continue to grow.

Thank you to mstone326 for telling me about cloud variables and being a Scratcher. 

The doctor image is from Google and has "free to use" usage rights.

title: Two Dice Game V2
description:
Unstuck Challenge 20: choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it. 

This is a remix from my day 18's challenge. I customized the game to used with my 7th grade probability unit: compound events & law of large numbers.
instructions: Click on the green flag to start. You can choose to roll the pair of dice once, or you can ask the computer to roll the dice 10 times or 100 times. The results will be recorded each time.
writing:

title: Unstuck Day 20: Over the Moon (Day 12 Revised)
description:
It works!
Fix-ups: Repeated motion across screen prevented the broadcast from switching to the next command because the previous instruction was not complete. (Thank you @paulinah for your feedback and advice!) There were too many types of event block command (green flag, space bar, when __ broadcast, when backdrop changes) – messy.  Stages weren't changing on cue.  .  Changed “broadcast and wait” (in Stage coding) to “broadcast” (and not wait) on sprite pages.  Hide/show sprites changed to "broadcast . . . " instead of "when backdrop changes to . . . "
instructions:

title: Slinky Remix Unstuck #20
description: I thought this would be quick and easy - ha! I spent hours remixing this, but I'm really happy with how it turned out. In the original project I defined a block called "circle", the sprite drew the circle, moved a little, and made another circle. It was a cool design, but I wanted it to look more like a real slinky.  I ended up almost completely remaking the entire project. In the end I made the sprite the actual circle and stamped it. The code is pretty simple, so it doesn't look like I spent hours on it, but I kept trying different things and then tweaking it until I came up with this.
instructions: Click the green flag to begin
writing: I thought this would be quick and easy - ha! I spent hours remixing this, but I'm really happy with how it turned out. In the original project I defined a block called "circle", the sprite drew the circle, moved a little, and made another circle. It was a cool design, but I wanted it to look more like a real slinky.  I ended up almost completely remaking the entire project. In the end I made the sprite the actual circle and stamped it. The code is pretty simple, so it doesn't look like I spent hours on it, but I kept trying different things and then tweaking it until I came up with this.Click the green flag to begin

title: Get Smart enhanced_GU_Day20
description:
Day20 changes include: addition of background music, additional backdrops (including psychedelic flowers as a clue for the final puzzle), only one question per mission, & tightened up some code.
Original comments: This project took on a life of its own. I didn't get stuck today. Oh, wait, I spoke too soon. When running my project to check it, sometimes the sprite with the intro words becomes very large & off the screen. (Is this b/c I have both bitmap & vector graphics running at the same time?) 
Since the project is multi-faceted, it took a very long time to accomplish.There is so much more that can be done to enhance it. 
Inspiration for the Q & A came from @karenb 's project with the escape room.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 20
description:
This is my project for Day 20 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. I chose to review my "Getting Unstuck: Day 4" project because I would have liked to add the possibility of inserting new fishes but I didn't do it because of time. In this new version the user can insert new fish at any time by pressing the SPACE button.

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions:
First, create a studio and add all of your Getting Unstuck projects to it. Done, here is the link: https://scratch.mit.edu/studios/5253085/

Second, choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it. 

Press B = the fish gets a little bigger
Press S = the fish gets a little smaller
Press M = the fish changes its appearance
Press SPACE = add a new colored fish (this is a new feature!)

This is my project from day 3. I added the ability to play all the wind instruments after clicking 6 in a row. You can reset the visual effects with space bar, but it also creates some clones. Lots of stuff going on here. I think I like it.

title: Tag Day20: Getting Unstuck Day 13 copy
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 13

The idea of interacting with the mouse led me to the idea of tag. I don't know if my project really fulfills the brief, but I enjoyed making it.
If I were to continue working on it, I would introduce a few other elements, such as making the reaction of "running away" sprites dependent on their distance to "it." 
In addition, I would have the characters call out "You're it!" or "I'm it!" when they were tagged.
So, I've worked a bit more on making my sprites a bit more individual in their strategies. In addition, I made Scratch Cat's speed more like that of the other sprites.
instructions: Press the green flag. Play tag as Scratch Cat.

title: Getting Unstuck #20
description:
For day 20 I decided to rethink day 7. I wan't overjoyed with my day 7 project. And I thought rather than trying to make something that ended with a static result, something that constantly moved may be more interesting.
I included some of the cloning ideas that I worked with yesterday. I'm happier with this than day 7's project. I could still tinker with this for ages if I had the time.
instructions: Just press the green flag.
writing:
For day 20 I decided to rethink day 7. I wan't overjoyed with my day 7 project. And I thought rather than trying to make something that ended with a static result, something that constantly moved may be more interesting.
I included some of the cloning ideas that I worked with yesterday. I'm happier with this than day 7's project. I could still tinker with this for ages if I had the time.Just press the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20 - Day 9 revisited
description:
I didn't know what to revisit. I spent ages going between projects. I went through the getting unstuck cards and played with some featured projects. When I returned to my getting unstuck studio I saw my "robot line follower" from day 9 and knew it was the one from the notes I'd written about what I'd like to try with more time. I'd never normally write notes like that, so I think I will try to in future to capture my thoughts at the time rather than allowing them to drift away. 

I have been thinking about line following robots. Seemed like the perfect opportunity to try out very simple rules, eg move forwards; if touching red turn right; if touching blue turn left. Seems to work surprisingly well. I like the idea that Scratch could be used to prototype real world robot algorithms.

I started with Scratch Cat rather than a ball, but extremities would "catch" on the colours and lead to twirling and getting stuck.

I said: "I'd like to experiment further with different angles and number of steps. Maybe with a timer to see how fast the ball completes the track. This could be automated to determine the best parameters."

I've started this. Runs are now automated with randomly selected parameters. I need to sort the list on time to create a proper sense of which parameters work best or even better, plot a surface with the 2 parameters to see the "shape" of the parameter space. I also need to add jitter to the start point to see how robust each result is.

Sometimes the robot cheats and returns to the gate by going the wrong way down the track. Maybe need multiple gates to track this?

Oh dear - I said I was going to get an early night tonight...
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 20 - Revisiting Day 9

Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?).

Just run the project and the ball will use simple rules to travel around the uncoloured track. It will run over and over with different speed and angle parameters and store them in 3 lists: time for run, speed and angle. Press s/h to show/hide the lists.

title: Wandering Race for Watermelon
description:
This is a remix of Getting Unstuck #7 Pen patterns Wandering for Watermelon https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236164578/
At a suggestion from a fellow Scratcher's comment, I added a watermelon explosion.

Reflection:  I have enjoyed creating new challenges each day.  I would recommend the 21 days Getting Unstuck challenge to everyone.  The community was great and I would wait for the 7 am email to come to find out what was the challenge.  Early on I would jump right in to create.  Later I would think about the challenge during my day and then code with a plan.

See you at the Scratch Conference!
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #20 Revise a previous challenge project.

Click the green flag.  Notice whether Gobo gets out before Scratch Cat finishes drawing the circle and rays.

title: Day 20-Revised copy of Day5-platform:MajorTomCat
description:
I decided to go back to my Day5 platform game.  I was very stuck on day 5 but had a lot help from @mstone326 and @HESteachers. Both who were kind enough to remix my original project https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235953588/
Using my backpack, I brought in some of their scripts in this version and made some adjustments.  To be honest, I am still not happy with this project, but my time tonight is limited, as I got to pack up and get ready to travel tomorrow for the Scratch@MIT Conference!!!! 

Music: David Bowie Space Oddity
instructions:
Click green flag to start.  Level 1 get Major TomCAT to his rocket. Level 2 give Major TomCAT a happy ending and get him home.
Arrow keys to move left and right and Space key to jump.  When you touch the jetpack, you can fly too. 

Day 20 challenge: choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it. 
I chose https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235953588/

title: Unstuck Day 20 Remix of Day15
description:
Day 20 is Day 15 project remixed  - oops NOT remixed.  I jforgot - 
If I just make changes to the project instead of remixing it the first project is GONE!!!!! 
It is gone from My Stuff and it is gone from the original Day 15 Unstuck Studio.
I wanted to make a project that had a series of unrelated actions so that a player needed to figure out what was happening in this project.
Sorry it is so late today.  I arrived in Boston this morning and had to decide whether to do the Unstuck homework or ... play hookey and see the sites.  The tourist in me won out!!! Visited JFK Museum.

title: Day 20 HELP What animal are you? REMIX2
description: I need more questions too. That would probably help make it more useful.
instructions: This is the project I cannot figure out. It is supposed to be one of those quizzes that tells you what kind of animal you are based on some questions. Well, I got everything to work, except the only problem is, if there is a tie (I used variables to assign a score to answers). Can anybody help me figure out how I'd go about giving a score if none of the animals have the majority of answers?

title: Unstuck Day 20: Cat Chase revised
description:
This is a basic remix of the game Cheese Chase by John Woodcock from the book Coding Games in Scratch. The first time I made Cheese Chase, it was so difficult! 


When I posted this game for day 9, I only had the dog, the cat and the ghost.  Now, I added the crabs to increase the difficulty.  I also put in the message 'Game Over' to signal the end of the game.  The one thing that I can't seem to get is how to stop the music when the game is completed.
instructions:
Click on the green flag to begin. You will be using the arrow keys to try and navigate the dog to catch the cat.  If the dog touches the blue wall, it will stop.  Every time you touch the cat, you will score 10 points. 
There are a few things that can stop you, though.  If a crab touches the dog, the dog won't be able to move and the game is over.  Also, there is a ghost that will randomly pop up.  If it touches the dog, the game is over.  Have fun!
writing:
This is a basic remix of the game Cheese Chase by John Woodcock from the book Coding Games in Scratch. The first time I made Cheese Chase, it was so difficult! 


When I posted this game for day 9, I only had the dog, the cat and the ghost.  Now, I added the crabs to increase the difficulty.  I also put in the message 'Game Over' to signal the end of the game.  The one thing that I can't seem to get is how to stop the music when the game is completed.Click on the green flag to begin. You will be using the arrow keys to try and navigate the dog to catch the cat.  If the dog touches the blue wall, it will stop.  Every time you touch the cat, you will score 10 points. 
There are a few things that can stop you, though.  If a crab touches the dog, the dog won't be able to move and the game is over.  Also, there is a ghost that will randomly pop up.  If it touches the dog, the game is over.  Have fun!

title: Ninja Duck v1.5
description:
This is an updated version of Ninja Duck v1.0, now with another challenge.
I used variables to control each level.
I added music and cloning features on enemies to make it more challenging too.
                                          ---Credits---
+ Song: "A-END" by Labbed is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.
instructions:
Press the green flag and then the play button.
Choose "Challenge I" or "Challenge II" to start.
 ++Challenge I++
Try to avoid the enemies in 20 seconds to win the challenge.
Press Left and Right arrow keys to move the Duck.
Use Up key to jump.

 ++Challenge II++
Try to avoid the baloons in 30 seconds to win the challenge.
Press Left and Right arrow keys to move the Duck.
Use Up key to jump.
Don't touch water or you'll slip.

Enjoy it!

                            --Getting Unstuck Day 20--
First, create a studio and add all of your Getting Unstuck projects to it. Second, choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it.

title: Haiku vs Cut-Up: Revisited (Unstuck 20)
description: I'm so glad that revisiting an earlier project was the prompt for Getting Unstuck 20. I was in a bit of a rush and had problems tracking down the right music to set the mood for the first version. (Although it was tempting to re-revisit #19.)
instructions:
Press the flag to let Beat poet and author William Borroughs tranform your words into a poem using the "cut-up" technque.

Additions in this revisit: now with motion and music plus a more Blue Note records vibe.

(Although it was tempting to re-revisit #19.)Press the flag to let Beat poet and author William Borroughs tranform your words into a poem using the "cut-up" technque.

Additions in this revisit: now with motion and music plus a more Blue Note records vibe.

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge #18 copy
description:
A remix of Challenge #18.
I was pushed for time when creating this one and wasn't totally happy with the result, so have now added sounds and fixed the issue of too many comments appearing at once - just by changing the broadcast with a broadcast and wait block!

Have so enjoyed this challenge experience.
Being in a different timezone meant it felt like I was always coming late to the party!
I realize I often interpreted the instructions differently to others, sometimes being THAT kid that didn't read instructions carefully!
I loved seeing others creative coding talents and know the future of coding is very excited if our students are being exposed to such brilliant minds.
I look forward to the next set of challenges and to presenting them to students.  Thankyou!
instructions: Click green flag and watch.

title: Flower remix! - Getting Unstuck! - Day 20
instructions:
I took my project from Day 2 to remix it.  I liked it as a basic project and thought there might be some interesting ways to add to it. 

I added a random factor for the starting colours and also the differences between colours of the parts of the flowers. 

I also added the random size factor. 

The last thing I changed was I was bored of clicking.  So now it is based on the mouse pointer location.
writing:
nanI took my project from Day 2 to remix it.  I liked it as a basic project and thought there might be some interesting ways to add to it. 

I added a random factor for the starting colours and also the differences between colours of the parts of the flowers. 

I also added the random size factor. 

The last thing I changed was I was bored of clicking.  So now it is based on the mouse pointer location.

title: Getting Unstuck #20: Sirtaki dance (redo)
description:
Scratch project was created originally, as "Getting Unstuck" activity #15 and then, revised as part of the activity #20. More backdrops were created to better reflect the loudness of the room/music and the backdrop switch conditions improved.

From original project: Thanks to this challenge and "Chromophobia" https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236675985/ by @karenb, I familiarized myself with the loudness sensor and its use!

Day #20 Challenge: First, create a studio and add all of your Getting Unstuck projects to it. Second, choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it.
instructions: Adjust the speaker level to high volume, press the green flag and enjoy the music and the effect of the loudness sensor!

title: water clock
description:
Getting Unstuck day 20
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
I started from a previous project of mine, where I used a pendulum performing a regular motion as the oscillator which gives "tic" to the clock. 
In this revised project I use drops of water dripping from a tap at regular time intervals to generate a "tic" broadcast message than make the needles move.
Each needle when receive the "tic" message rotates of a fixed amount, depending on the period of the drops falling and on the "role" of the needle (hours, minutes, seconds). In reality it depends on the gears that connect needles to the mechanism.
The drop block uses "slide in N seconds" to generate "tic" messages  at regular time intervals.

Credits for images:
www.flaticon.com
Tap by Pixel perfect
Drop & Recipient by Freepik
Clock by Dimitry Miroliubo
instructions:
In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
A regular phenomenon, as the dripping of water from a tap, can be used as source of a regular pulse that make the clock move.
The clock synchronizes with the real time clock when the green flag is pressed (seconds are excluded, so that thin needle always starts at 00).
writing:
Getting Unstuck day 20
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
I started from a previous project of mine, where I used a pendulum performing a regular motion as the oscillator which gives "tic" to the clock. 
In this revised project I use drops of water dripping from a tap at regular time intervals to generate a "tic" broadcast message than make the needles move.
Each needle when receive the "tic" message rotates of a fixed amount, depending on the period of the drops falling and on the "role" of the needle (hours, minutes, seconds). In reality it depends on the gears that connect needles to the mechanism.
The drop block uses "slide in N seconds" to generate "tic" messages  at regular time intervals.

Credits for images:
www.flaticon.com
Tap by Pixel perfect
Drop & Recipient by Freepik
Clock by Dimitry MiroliuboIn this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
A regular phenomenon, as the dripping of water from a tap, can be used as source of a regular pulse that make the clock move.
The clock synchronizes with the real time clock when the green flag is pressed (seconds are excluded, so that thin needle always starts at 00).

description: ."Walk on the wild side" cover by Chillz https://soundcloud.com/user-307337610/walk-on-the-wild-side
instructions:
The Scratch's cat does a random walk and will eventually touch Gobo or Pico.

If you open the project in edit mode then you can modify the "coin" behavior by adding more heads and/or tails to the list.

Try to bias the coin so that the Scratch cat meets only Gobo or Pico.

Would it be possible to bias the coin in such a way that the cat oscillates around the staring position without touching Gobo or Pico?

title: Getting Unstuck 20 - Day 7 update
description:
For this remade project, I decided to incorporate a fair isle pattern into the knitting animation. For now it can only draw a flower, but I would like to have it do a different design each time, either randomly or letting the user choose from a list of designs.

I was a few rows into putting all the stitches into one long script when I realized the top of the design is the bottom in reverse. That made it a lot quicker - I made each row a separate block then did them in reverse after I got to the middle. 

Music is Good Thoughts by Lobo Loco from the Free Music Archive.
instructions:
Click the green flag to fill the screen with knitting. You can press shift while clicking the green flag to run it in turbo mode, which will create the whole pattern very quickly, as the regular mode is pretty slow. This does make the animation of the needles kind of go away though - I wish there was an in-between!

Also sometimes you need to click the green flag twice to get the needles to start moving? Not sure why.
writing:
For this remade project, I decided to incorporate a fair isle pattern into the knitting animation. For now it can only draw a flower, but I would like to have it do a different design each time, either randomly or letting the user choose from a list of designs.

I was a few rows into putting all the stitches into one long script when I realized the top of the design is the bottom in reverse. That made it a lot quicker - I made each row a separate block then did them in reverse after I got to the middle. 

Music is Good Thoughts by Lobo Loco from the Free Music Archive.Click the green flag to fill the screen with knitting. You can press shift while clicking the green flag to run it in turbo mode, which will create the whole pattern very quickly, as the regular mode is pretty slow. This does make the animation of the needles kind of go away though - I wish there was an in-between!

Also sometimes you need to click the green flag twice to get the needles to start moving? Not sure why.

title: Day 20 Getting Unstuck - revision of Day 13
description:
Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

"ceiling fan blue" image from wpclipart.com

Reflect: Why did you choose this project to revisit?
I knew the path the balloon takes when blown could be better modeled by improving the mathematics used to determine the new location. I don't teach geometry or trigonometry so I had to do a little research and some trial and error modeling to figure out if my mathematics was correct so I also used this as a reason to use the Desmos online graphing calculator a little more fully. 
The mathematics required to determine the path the balloon should take when blown by the fan is demonstrated at https://www.desmos.com/calculator/pftuv8rh3f
instructions: Move the fan close to the balloon to blow it around. If you leave the balloon alone for a few seconds, it will change color.  The balloon will return to the center if you blow it off the screen.

title: Virtual Flowers v.2
description:
In this version, I moved the water and food over the flowers and then moved them back. I also got the flowers to react the way I wanted them to. Correlates to my ability to take care of flowers, or lack thereof. :) 

I still would like to add variables to monitor hunger, thirst, and light at some point.

I got the original idea from Scratch's Virtual Pet project - from a set of Scratch Coding Cards that I just received. https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237145343/#editor
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to begin.

Provide just the right condition for the flowers to grow to their fullest. Be careful not to overdo it!

title: Unstuck - Day 20
description:
This project is a remix of a previous unstuck challenge.  It is just a variation of a traditional pong game.  We decided to count how many times the ball hits the Scratch Cat. When the score is greater than 10, then the ball moves faster. After 20 and 30 it also gets faster.  

I made these changes: 
Each time the ball goes behind the cat, the score decreases by 5.  When the score is less than 0, the game is over and a Game Over background  appears.
When the speed changes, the ball switched colors (changes costume)
instructions:
Click Green Flag to Start.
Move your mouse up and down and try to hit the ball.
Try to keep up!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 20 Reflection:
I used the original version of this for Day 7.  I didn't like how my hexagon turned out, but that turned out to be a much easier fix than I expected it to be.  I decided to try creating other shapes and see if I could figure out how to make the shapes appear in different places (and disappear so the screen didn't get too cluttered).  The more time I spend on it, the more things I want to refine.  I think that's the point of today's challenge, though.  :)
instructions: Press the green flag to start drawing a hexagonal spirograph.  Press the spare bar to clear the stage.
writing:

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20 - revisit
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 20: choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it.

For this project I revisited an earlier game I made for Day 9 and 18. There was some code that I couldn't get working properly (the food sensing the ant and assigning points based on the costume). I had put a request in the forum and had some good advice. I still couldn't get the code working and gave up. Because the Scratchers giving me advice were ALOT more experienced than I, I figured they must know what they are talking about and the code should work. So I decided to revisit this same project, determined to figure out the code. After looking at it I found the problem (conflicting actions) and was able to make it work, just like they said it should!

I think several things worked:
1) I needed the break from the pervious day to see it all with fresh eyes
2) determination, knowing that the code SHOULD work. Therefore there was a problem somewhere that I needed to find
3) help from others
instructions:
Press the green flag to get started. Your objective is to gather as many food pellets as possible to take to the feeding center.

Use the arrow keys to move the ant through the maze.

Red pellets = kills the ant and stops all action
Yellow/green = +1 point
Purple/pink = -1 point
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 20: choose one of your projects from a previous day of Getting Unstuck, make a copy of it, and revise it.

For this project I revisited an earlier game I made for Day 9 and 18. There was some code that I couldn't get working properly (the food sensing the ant and assigning points based on the costume). I had put a request in the forum and had some good advice. I still couldn't get the code working and gave up. Because the Scratchers giving me advice were ALOT more experienced than I, I figured they must know what they are talking about and the code should work. So I decided to revisit this same project, determined to figure out the code. After looking at it I found the problem (conflicting actions) and was able to make it work, just like they said it should!

I think several things worked:
1) I needed the break from the pervious day to see it all with fresh eyes
2) determination, knowing that the code SHOULD work. Therefore there was a problem somewhere that I needed to find
3) help from othersPress the green flag to get started. Your objective is to gather as many food pellets as possible to take to the feeding center.

Use the arrow keys to move the ant through the maze.

Red pellets = kills the ant and stops all action
Yellow/green = +1 point
Purple/pink = -1 point

title: Unstuck Day 20 project copy
description:
I finally figured out one way to get the sprite to follow the mouse x coordinate only when I want to: I used boolean operators to permit the sprite to move only if the cursor is within a certain y coordinate value. I'm sure there are other ways to do this, but this one works and I was happy to add it to the project.

The new problem I had was assigning notes to the values of the x axis. I tried unsuccessfully to come up with a formula to solve it for me, so I ended up using lots of "if x is greater than m and less than n, then play note p" which was tedious, but hey, it works!

Unstuck Challenge Day 3 remixed for Day 20 #CreativeComputing
instructions:
Drag the Scratch cats along the black lines to change the note!

The bottom line plays low notes, the middle line plays notes in the middle, and the top line plays high notes.

Press "play chord" to hear all 3 notes (low, middle, and high) together!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 20
description:
Made for the Getting Unstuck Day 20 activity which was to revisit an earlier project. In this case it was the one I did for day 2.
For this revision I added a slider so that the user can choose the line width of the flower. I also added a random element for the size of the flower.

Notes for the original, Day 2 project.
Inspired by Seymour Papert and Turtle Logo I thought I would use the pen tools and draw things that are a bit like crystal flowers. When doing any Logo I'm always reminded of a photo in the MIT museum of Seymour with one of the big early turtles.

I started with drawing the flowers in a random place but this felt a little strange so I changed it to draw at the mouse pointer to give the user more control. The random block is still there though, if you want to give it a try.
The next thing I'd like to do is let the user choose a colour from a palette. Maybe choose the line thickness as well.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag.
Click anywhere on the background to draw a flower.

Click anywhere on the background to draw a flower.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 20
description:
The Getting Unstuck Challenge for day 20 was to copy and revise a previous day's project.  I chose my project from day 9, which was to create a project that uses the "touching color" block.  It was originally just the first backdrop, so I extended it to two maze screens and added the variable to keep track of how many times Scratch hits the wall (touches black).

My new version now  also includes challenges from several of the previous days!

Day 19 - Use the "create a clone" block
Day 14 - Use the "join" block
Day 12 - Have 3 separate scenes
Day 8 - Create a variable to keep track of the number of times something happens
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Getting Unstuck Challenge for day 9 was: "Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game."
instructions:
Click the green arrow to start the maze.

Use the arrow keys to guide Scratch the Cat through the maze.  If you touch any of the walls Scratch will turn around and move back.

Click the green arrow to start over.

title: Sum of multiples of 3 and 5
description:
When @karenb and I first got started with these challenge designs, one of our sources of inspiration was Project Euler, which has been one of my favorite ways to learn coding (at first in Python) for a long time. What I love about Project Euler is that it encourages a variety of solutions to a single problem, and once you "solve" a problem, you're still encouraged to look at how others did it, as well as consider how you might refactor your code to be more elegant, or faster, or more beautiful, and I love the idea that you're never really done with any of the challenges. It's very mathematically focused, though, so perhaps not appropriate for all audiences, but there are certainly some students who might appreciate them! 

This project is downloaded from @karenb - I changed the background + fixed a bug that was overcounting multiples + added sound.
instructions:
Press the green flag to get started!

Getting Unstuck Prompt: Find a Project Euler problem you're excited about at projecteuler.net. Solve it using a Scratch project!

(Other prompts I was excited about - fixing others' bugs, focusing on modulo/other math blocks...)

It's very mathematically focused, though, so perhaps not appropriate for all audiences, but there are certainly some students who might appreciate them! 

This project is downloaded from @karenb - I changed the background + fixed a bug that was overcounting multiples + added sound.Press the green flag to get started!

title: CatCat
description:
For Day 21 of Getting Unstuck, we were challenged to create our own prompt. My prompt for today is "Make a project that provides helpful advice, making use of a block that you haven't used (much) before."

The block that I selected for today's project is the 'username' block from the Sensing category, which provides the username of the person running the project. It's a simple block, but can provide a very personal touch. 

This project is dedicated to the Getting Unstuck community. It has been a joy to participate in Getting Unstuck with you for all 21 days. So many great prompts, projects, and people! 

Illustrations: 
- Getting Unstuck Strategies by Paulina, https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/strategies.html
- pixabay.com

Music: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, "Nutcracker Suite: Arabian Dance" (London Festival Orchestra)
instructions: Press the green flag to receive your complimentary reading.

title: Ideas, Meet Layers
description:
"Scratch, Meet Ideas. Ideas, Meet Scratch"
Create: 
Either: Start with an idea you're not quite sure how to bring to life in Scratch. Try it, see where it goes! 
OR 
Start with a feature/block/functionality that you haven't used in Scratch. Try it, see where it goes!
(OR, try both!)

Reflect:
Why did you choose the starting point that you did? Where did you imagine you might end up? Where did your process go?

I decided to go with the latter, seeking to play with layers. What can manipulating layers bring to a project? Here I start to think about that with a selection of simple sprites. How will the image shift as layering shifts?

What was I thinking about in designing this challenge?
I've been thinking about the differences between starting the creative process when driven by an idea or concept and when driven by an exploration of a new feature/block/function. What does process look like in each of those? What's exciting about each? What does exploring new feature/block/functionality do for our ideas? And what do our ideas do for discovering features/blocks/functionality? 

A way to start exploring those differences seemed to be noticing which is driving a project, and then noticing process along the way.

(For example, my exploration on Day 10 foregrounded functionality:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236354120 and on Day 18 foregrounded an idea I envisioned: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237060823)
instructions:
Press the green flag, then use these keys to create with layers!

                   Make Clones:          Bring to Front:      Send Back:
purple               right                          d                           s
violet               space                          v                           b
yellow              down                          y                           u
pink                    left                           p                           o
(can you find a surprise in the keys?)

https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236354120 and on Day 18 foregrounded an idea I envisioned: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237060823)Press the green flag, then use these keys to create with layers!

                   Make Clones:          Bring to Front:      Send Back:
purple               right                          d                           s
violet               space                          v                           b
yellow              down                          y                           u
pink                    left                           p                           o
(can you find a surprise in the keys?)

title: 1s1s splat (1s1s tetris V0.7 remix)
description:
My Day 21 Getting Unstuck prompt...
1s1s: Create a 1s1s project (i.e., a project with only 1 sprite and 1 script).

I was randomly scouring the Scratch Forums and came across a discussion about the "1s1s" phenomenon. Here's the discussion thread in question: https://scratch.mit.edu/discuss/topic/12378/ and here are examples of 1s1s projects: https://scratch.mit.edu/search/projects?q=1s1s

As one poster noted, "Yeah, 1s1s or any of its variations are usually challenges that Scratchers set themselves when making a project to make it more impressive." I don't know about the "more impressive" claim, but there's something interesting about playing with constraints, which is certainly a theme of Getting Unstuck. I've never made (at least not intentionally!) a 1s1s project, so the novelty factor was definitely high!

To be honest, I wasn't at all sure where to begin. I knew I wanted to do a 1s1s, but wasn't sure what types of programs might be best suited to the genre. I love Tetris (so much) so, on a whim, I search for 1s1s Tetris, which led to two results. One of the two results had a version number of 0.7, so I saw an opportunity to extend someone else's neat work, while learning a lot in the process.

In practice, this was kind of a total disaster. (It feels pretty good to end my Getting Unstuck experience with a spectacular failure.) I ended up so confused and frustrated that I turned it into a "splat" situation—when blocks land they lose their shape. (But, appropriately, that doesn't even work totally correctly.)
instructions:
My Day 21 Getting Unstuck prompt...
1s1s: Create a 1s1s project (i.e., project w/only 1 sprite and 1 script).

Green flag: Start.
Space key: Rotate block.
Left/Right arrow keys: Move block horizontally.
Down arrow key: Move block vertically (slowly).

title: 1s1s Maze
description:
OK, as I shared in 1s1s splat (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237310116/), I had a big vision for my CYOGUP (Choose Your Own Getting Unstuck Prompt), but it was a flaming disaster. I didn't really understand the 1s1s mechanism and I remixed a project that I found confusing.

BUT I woke up this morning with some idea of how 1s1s works! (It's basically one big control loop that does everything. Revelation!) So, I decided to take one of my very classic projects (which is in the Creative Computing Curriculum Guide, it was one of the first game projects I tried to help people learn) and make it 1s1s! This project is that attempt!!!

Compare the code from the original (from 2009!): https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/612964/#editor
with this project's code!

Now I don't think I'm ready for a 1s1s situation that is as complicated or as gorgeous as this Super Mario Brothers 1s1s (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/2176968/#editor), but I feel like I've made a bit of conceptual progress!!! EVERYTHING IS ITERATIVE!!! YAYYYYY!
instructions:
Press green flag to initialize, then use the arrow key to navigate through the maze.

A second attempt at my Day 21 Getting Unstuck prompt...
1s1s: Create a 1s1s project (i.e., project w/only 1 sprite and 1 script).

title: Unstuck Day 21: Use Broadcast and Wait
description:
For the Getting Unstuck challenge Day 21 I set a challenge to use the Broadcast and Wait block because my students often accidentally use it instead of plain Broadcast and I never understood what it does. What is it waiting for? So I set out to understand it so I can recommend to students when it's a useful block.
Turns out to be simple, and very useful! It just waits for the action that is triggered by its broadcast message to finish before it goes on to the next block. If several sprites are responding to its broadcast with different durations it will wait until the last one is done. Here the different partyers are saying thank you for different amounts of time.
Audio source: http://www.daveross.com/audio/wah_wah_SFX.mp3
instructions: Click green flag for a special message!

title: Getting Unstuck # 21 - Firefox
description:
My prompt - create a project from things in your backpack. They can be from your own previous projects, or from other people's.  Combine elements from other projects into something new and interesting.

Today I've combined my two favourite projects from the last week; fireworks, and Harquin the fox, to create Firefox, satisfying my own prompt and my love of a good pun.

Originally, the little foxes disappeared, but I was told it looked like I was blowing up foxes, which wasn't my intention, so I've changed it so that they run off to play with each other.
instructions: Just click the green flag.

title: Splat!
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 21 Prompt: Create a project using the camera control feature (video blocks) - Turn Video On, Turn Video Off, Wait Until Video Motion.

I used the Window Cleaner project in the book Coding Projects in Scratch: A step-by-step visual guide to coding your own animations, games, simulations, and more! by Jon Woodcock @RoboSquid to get me started on my project.

I'd never used the Turn Video on/off blocks before, so I wanted to give it a try.
instructions:
Clean up the splats with motion detection (wave your hand over the splats).

Get 60 splats within 60 seconds to win. You can change the difficulty with the slider.

Click Allow to enable use of your webcam.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 21
description: Borrowed most of it from here: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19267371/#editor I think I'd prefer to use maths rather than this simple move, rotate trick next time though. Perhaps something like this: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237051194/
instructions:
Drawing a circle is something everyone can do, we do it as children to show the Sun for instance. Even though sometimes those child drawn circles aren't perfectly round we all sort of know what the big ball is in the sky.

Use the Pen tool to create a sun; you can even colour it in if you want. (Remember, if you get stuck, find inspiration and support in the Teaching with Scratch Facebook group, our list of Getting Unstuck strategies, or on Twitter at #CreativeComputing.)

title: Unstuck Day 21 - Multiplication Machine
description:
My prompt is "Create a project that you can share with elementary students."

 My experience is that kids always want to make games in Scratch. I thought if I could make something fun with math, perhaps the students would be tempted to make something other than a game.
instructions: Press the flag to start. Give the young man some numbers to multiply for you. The numbers can be whole or decimals.

title: Planets
description:
OK my challenge is to use the sensor of distance, x, y or direction of another sprite or mouse pointer. Today I did another project with the same theme (check "compasses") which is beautiful but not very interesting. So I used a routine for elaborating gravity I wrote in my projects "orbiter" and "planet seeder", and I simplified putting the mouse pointer as an attractor.

The distance between the clones and the pointer is important because gravity force is proportional with it.

Fun fact: if the pointer touch a planet, this will be thrown away. This seems to be a bug, but it's a rough emulation of the gravitational slingshot, exploiting the gravitational pull of a planet but eventually missing it (in my demo, there is no collision) so is possible to increase speed without using rockets.
instructions: Planets wanders into space. Your mouse pointer has some gravity. Try to get them into an orbit!

title: PicoBoard Lab
description:
My self-authored Getting Unstuck Unstuck Day 21 Provocation:

What academic subject(s) or domain(s) are/were confusing or difficult for you in school? Make a Scratch project to explore that/those topic(s). Afterwards, reflect on what you knew, and what you now know and do not know. Did your exploration through Scratch change your understanding of what you think you know?

//

I chose to make this particular project for two reasons: as a teacher I find the PicoBoard to be a powerful tool used in conjunction with MakeyMakey. MakeyMakey is more reliably supported across different platforms, but relies on binary variables and boolean expressions. PicoBoard introduces, in a physical computing context, non-binary variables as well. I like to focus on that distinction.

I also chose to build this reusable "laboratory" for PicoBoards, which can be easily used (via ports C and D) for comparing the conductivity of different household substances, and which therefore bridges a gap from electronics to chemistry.  As a high school student I was very disenfranchised by math and science classes, and dropped out of STEM entirely in 10th grade. So, this project is my working through areas of ignorance and confusion.

I used a PicoBoard with students last week to measure the conductivity of liquids found in our school fridge. Mustard was the most conductive substance - more conductive than water! That sent us toward a chemist for some explanations. The school's scientist was out, so I texted my wife (an erstwhile scientist), who explained that mustard has a lot of vinegar in it, and vinegar has lots of free hydrogen ions.  I (believe that I) know that vinegar is frequently used, because of its chemical stability, in homemade batteries.  As part of our semi-systematic investigation, this was exciting because it led our computing class to chemistry and then to physics. We started with a device I think I know well, the PicoBoard, but ended in wonderful domains that are beyond my understanding.

"Cherish your doubt for doubt is the handmaiden of truth" -Talmud
instructions: Connect a PicoBoard to Scratch and install any needed browser extension. Connect port A to a rotary potentiometer (which will be calibrated 0-50, unlike other sensors which are 0-100), port B to a force resistant sensor. Leads from ports C and D can be connected to fruits/vegetables or set into liquids (make sure the leads are not touching) to measure the conductivity/resistance of the substances and liquids.

We started with a device I think I know well, the PicoBoard, but ended in wonderful domains that are beyond my understanding.

"Cherish your doubt for doubt is the handmaiden of truth" -TalmudConnect a PicoBoard to Scratch and install any needed browser extension. Connect port A to a rotary potentiometer (which will be calibrated 0-50, unlike other sensors which are 0-100), port B to a force resistant sensor. Leads from ports C and D can be connected to fruits/vegetables or set into liquids (make sure the leads are not touching) to measure the conductivity/resistance of the substances and liquids.

title: Getting Unstuck 21
description:
When I started teaching computer science a couple of years ago I drew off this Beauty and Joy of Computing lesson (which uses Snap, and offshoot of Scratch): https://bjc.edc.org/Jan2017/bjc-r/cur/teaching-guide/U2/lab-pages/4-abstraction.html?topic=nyc_bjc%2F2-teaching-guide.topic&course=bjc4nyc_teacher.html&novideo&noassignment. 

The assignment asks students to write a program that draws a brick wall, making blocks to draw bricks and rows of bricks.
I modified it to use Scratch instead and used it as a way to introduce the concept of abstraction through the Make a Block tools. 

My prompt for today keeps the original intent of focusing on abstraction but makes it more open by having you create whatever you want by making blocks. 

For my project itself, I wanted to do something that wasn't drawing, so I made a catch-the-thing-while-avoiding-the-other-thing-type game. Creating it with modular blocks was harder than I thought - it was hard to decide which functions of the game needed their own block, and which blocks should control what. I'm also not sure it streamlined my code as much as I thought it would.



I've had so much fun these three weeks - thank you @paulinah, @alirb, and @karenb!

Turtle image from pngimg
instructions: My prompt: Design a project that is modular, using the Make a Block tools. Maybe it could draw a picture, or compute something. How does making your own blocks streamline your program?

title: Challenge 21 - Trip to Conference
description:
What a great 21 days this was. I thought I'd throw together a quick tour of Boston as people are getting ready for the Scratch Conference. 

You'll cross see the Freedom Trail, Bunker Hill, Fenway Park, Faneuil Hall and the MIT Media Lab. Planes from Logan and the tall ships also make appearances as does a pesky run away crab. Don't fall into the Boston Harbor

Thank you again to the Getting Unstuck Team. This has been a blast. Enjoy your virtual trip through Boston and enjoy the conference. 

It has been a pleasure meeting, collaborating and sharing ideas with you all. I look forward "what's next". 

Music from bensound.com
crab warning from me :)

arrow keys left / right/ up
Get to the MIT Media Lab to enjoy the Scratch Conference

My prompt was to create a scrolling game that had items placed in the world. This project features 3 layers of parallax scrolling, the foreground, locations and the background. The plane and ship have their own movement based on the location of the world.

title: Day 21: Roller Coaster Ride
description:
Being part of this Getting Unstuck challenge has been a very fun adventure!  Thank you, Scratch team and community of "Scratchers" for your generous sharing and support!  Look forward to learning more about Scratch in the future.  
When I was considering ideas for completing the Day 15 project relating to the use of sound (change background depending on volume), I came up with the idea of a roller coaster.  I wanted quieter sounds for images in distance and louder sounds for close-ups.  Started drawing background and roller coaster animation and realized that my priority was making the animation, and that adding in a sound element would have to wait for another time if I was going to finish my challenge that day.
What I like most about my prompt is that it combines two types of online challenges I have enjoyed this year . . . learning how to draw on my tablet through sketch-noting,  and learning how to code with Scratch during Getting Unstuck.

Drew carts and backdrop on tablet, and uploaded.
Made "costumes" to put different sprites in carts. 
Coded path of sprites.
Checked layers - made sure distant path was back one layer, and close up moved to front.
Made clouds look wispy and float across the sky.
"Carefree" mp3 file from https://incompetech.com/music/royalty-free/music.html
instructions:
Day 21: Create an animation which includes modified sprites made by combining digital drawings and costumes from the library.  
Press the green flag to begin. Enjoy your summer!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 21 — Blocks
description:
Reflection

I decided to base my project around the custom define blocks for a few reason:

1) The green flag script is easier to read as it's kept short.
2) Define blocks help organize the code in logical units. Descriptive names for define blocks help. 
3) There's an optional feature called "Run without screen refresh" in define blocks that allows blocks, exto run faster.
instructions:
Game instructions:
Welcome to the lottery game! Choose 3 numbers between 1 and 10.

My Getting Unstuck Prompt:
Did you know we you can create your own blocks for your Scratch projects? Go to "More Blocks" in the scripts tab and make one or more block to use in your project. Experiment with creating number, string, or boolean inputs. What do you think the "Run with screen refresh" does?

title: Who was POTUS when you were born?_GU_Day21
description:
What makes you curious? Is it a concept or theme that you have been thinking about? Is it how to use a component of Scratch? Is it where your fellow 21-Days "GettingUnstuckers" live? (I'm curious about all of the above.) 
PROMPT: Create a project in which you explore something about which you are curious.
Sporadically, I kept track of interactions with Scratchers from other countries. My list includes: Singapore, Taiwan, Sudan, Israel, Brazil, Australia, New Zealand, Slovenia, Ukraine, Greece, Italy, Spain, Portugal, France, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Sweden, Finland, UK, Ireland & Canada. That's 6 continents!
I am curious about the ages of my fellow 21-Days participants. I want to see if I can gather information from users. I am reading about the cloud variable.   https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Cloud_Data  
Hmm... I did not have a list at first. But in thinking about how to avoid a gigantic if-or-or-or...block, I realized that I could put all of the conditions into a list and then use the "list contains ___" with my if-else statement. 
Hmm...I am struggling with figuring out how to convert a string answer to a number b/c cloud variables can only use numbers. Changed my approach.
Hmm...I just discovered that there is a limit of ten cloud variables in a project. I will have to make some changes b/c currently I need 15. I will use only 10 presidents.
instructions:
Fingers crossed that this will keep track of everyone's responses!
Click on the green flag and respond.

POTUS is an acronym which means: President Of The United States

title: day 21 - prompt Use clones to make weather effects
description: I used this project to go back and explore more about clones. I still wonder about how to articulate your learning and make sure you are learning enough each time. One problem I have with my students is that if an administrator asks them if what they did was hard. They often say not really. What I just made was not hard. BUT I worked on it for over an hour, read the help blocks about clones, used the wiki, used the paint editor in ways that I had never done before, used clones and adjusted my scripts to get the affects I wanted with the clones... but I would still answer it wasn't really hard. Hummm but then the person says that I am obviously not challenging my students enough... Now what???

title: Unstuck - Day 21
description:
I liked being able to create my own Unstuck Challenge.  I thought I would approach this project as a culminating activity.  I can already think of the rubric that I would create to have my students give one another feedback.  What I liked most about my prompt is that it is very open ended - all the students have to do is make an interactive greeting card.  It is a great way for them to demonstrate the skills that they have learned.  I should be able to look at the projects they create and quickly see what skills they have mastered and what skills they can still improve upon  This will give me an idea of how to approach upcoming projects and assignments.

Make it interactive - not just a card to view.  The recipient of your card can make decisions, click around, or interact in some way with the project.  Use as many of the skills you have practiced in previous Unstuck exercises or projects.

title: Day 21 - 1s1s Maze remix
description:
Today I was a bit stuck!  I had a look through other's projects and loved the simplicity of 1s1s.  I decided to remix. 
I didnt think it was possible to create a game with one sprite and one script with a background change!  Its actually amazing how much you can get out of scratch!

Thank you Karen for your inspiration!

Use the arrow keys to navigate to the end.

description: After teaching my students the blocks of Scratch, I challenge them to do a transportation scene.  The sprite must travel at least 2 backdrops, must use say or think blocks, and must have a sound.  This is done with 7th graders after only a few day intro to Scratch.  This helps me assess their knowledge.  This student really enjoyed coding!  If you'd like the instructions and rubric - eave a comment below with contact info.

title: Unstuck 21 Looks effects
description:
My solution to my prompt - explored the "change ___ effect" and "set ___ effect" blocks in my "Jump" game. This was a very frustrating exercise today, as I found that sometimes the offline version of scratch does not behave the same as the online version. In the offline version, I successfully had the background changing with a transition effect, after each game level. When I uploaded to the online version, nothing worked, and in fact it caused erratic unexplainable behaviours to appear. After hours of troubleshooting I found the cause was any use of the "change ___ effect" block on my stage, when it received a broadcast. So sadly that is left out of this posted project, but it works beautifully on my offline version. I put a comment to show where that code should be, in the stage scripts.
Would love someone to explain this to me, if they can!
instructions:
Design your own Getting Unstuck prompt. Create a project in response to your prompt! Post your prompt in the comments section for others to see!
Prompt I created: Use some of the graphics effects in "Looks" to improve one of your previous projects.

So sadly that is left out of this posted project, but it works beautifully on my offline version. I put a comment to show where that code should be, in the stage scripts.
Would love someone to explain this to me, if they can!
Design your own Getting Unstuck prompt. Create a project in response to your prompt! Post your prompt in the comments section for others to see!
Prompt I created: Use some of the graphics effects in "Looks" to improve one of your previous projects.

title: Idea Explosion (Unstuck 21) remix

However, each day I was surprised, challenged, excited...well, so many thoughts and emotions that I wanted to capture all of this is a "Scratchy" way, starting with remixing the amazing "Pen Explosion" that captivated me.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 21
description:
This is my project for Day 21 (this is sad because it's the last day) of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. This challenge initiative has covered almost all the Scratch features. The only one I had never tryed was the custom block feature so I decided to motivate myself to try it :P
Basically this type of blocks represents functions and are a quick way to name a series of instructions and recall them whenever needed within the project. If I had more time I would have added some music and thought of some new effects to add. 

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions:

Press A to draw lines
Press S to draw squares
Press D to draw petals

title: Unstuck Day 21: Fantastic Flowers
description:
For my final project, I wanted to learn how use a customized Scratch block. I also wanted to play around a bit more with the stamp block.  My inspiration was found in the Coding projects in Scratch.

One would think it would be easy to just follow directions to create the project, but I managed to make some errors with my values which led to some great debugging work.
instructions: Click the green flag to begin, then click somewhere on the stage to create a flower. Wherever you click, you will generate a new flower.  Press the space bar to clear your field.

title: Unstuck My Own Prompt
description:
Prompt: Create a program using the pen tool. (Very open-ended, not typical of a prompt I would use in my classroom.)

Intro to CS Prompt: Give the students the start of this drawing tool, but without the code to make the shapes. Students should analyze how the program uses broadcast messages to set the color and choose a shape to draw (I would relate this to calling a function.) Students are to write the code to draw the square and rectangle. Students can add another shape sprite and code of their own.
instructions:
A very simple drawing tool!
Click flag for directions.

title: Dynamic Triangle - Getting Unstuck - Day 21
description:
I actually had some trouble with this one.  I didn't really have an idea for a prompt but I knew that I wanted to do this project.  So I did this project and about halfway through I thought about a prompt. 

Create a project using the slider variable. 

When I was close to done I thought about another prompt

Create a project using the __ of__ block - the complex math block (bottom of the Operations tab)
instructions:
Click on the green flag to see this dynamic triangle in action. 

I had seen something similar to this - but it was just changing the numbers for the angles - I wanted to actually change the angles in the triangle.  

I needed to play with the numbers for the line between the ends of the two side but in the end I picked those numbers based on an Angle of 0 and 90 as the two extremes. 

What kind of triangle is this?  Should I remix this for other triangles?

Enjoy!!

Enjoy!!

title: Day 21: An Interactive Tale
description:
So I am cheating a bit here because of time. I traveled all day, but I did not want to miss the last challenge.  This project is one that I made under another one of my accounts( @cspd4me) that I used for CS PD and more recently for a summer camp; I facilitate this summer. 
I made this project last year; it was a fun one to make.  I liked the idea of using Scratch to tell a story in which the viewer gets to participate.  Depending on how the viewer answers the question there are different possible endings.  

Castle backgrounds from Wikipedia
instructions:
Click the green flag to get started.   You are in control of the story. Different answers-different outcomes.

title: Choose Your Own Adventure-Day 21
description:
Invent a new Getting Unstuck prompt. Create a project in response to your prompt. 
**I've done this project with my students and it is so fun to see what they come up with!
instructions:
Press the green flag and answer the duck's questions with Yes or No.

CHOOSE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE STORY

Choose Your Own Adventure is a series of children's gamebooks where each story is written from a second-person point of view, with the reader assuming the role of the protagonist and making choices that determine the main character's actions and the plot's outcome.

The stories are formatted so that, after a couple of pages of reading, the protagonist faces two or three options, each of which leads to more options, and then to one of many endings.

Use the Events blocks (broadcast, when backdrop switches, etc.) to code a project that lets the viewer choose the outcomes of the story.

title: Ducky run
description:
I've created a simple platformer game where the stage moves across the screen little by little. 
I used a "scroll" variable to do that and I found a way to stop it at a specific moment. 
I change the color of some platforms to make it more difficult. When you hit a wall you go backwards.
I experimented with username block too.
I'd like to modify some elements and add more levels.

Getting Unstuck has been a wonderful experience.
I've challenged myself many times and I've learned from other projects.
It has been a pleasure. Thanks a lot @alirb, @karenb, @paulinah and the Getting Unstuck community.

                                        --- Credits ---
+ Song: "Echo Turbo" by Labbed is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.

Space bar to jump.
*Warning: Be careful with lava or you'll start again.

title: Look for the glow
description: I wasn't getting anywhere. I had an idea about trying clones if you were stuck: "send in the clones," but it wasn't right. I went for the oldest trick in the book, and slept on it. This is the result. I hope you find it useful.
instructions:
Gutting Unstuck Day 21 - Invent a new Getting Unstuck prompt

LOOK FOR THE GLOW
When a stack is running it has a glowing edge. If your code is misbehaving then watch for this and you'll see which stacks are running at each moment in time.
writing:
I wasn't getting anywhere. I had an idea about trying clones if you were stuck: "send in the clones," but it wasn't right. I went for the oldest trick in the book, and slept on it. This is the result. I hope you find it useful.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 21
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 21 Reflection:
Coming up with my own prompt idea was harder than I thought - doing these 21 challenges the past 3 weeks (and especially seeing how creative the other participants are) has shown me how shallow my knowledge of Scratch really is.  This just "scratched" the surface, pun intended!
What I wanted to do with my prompt was focus on the duplicate or stamp tool, since it can be used for a lot more than I initially thought.  Not only can you duplicate sprites and scripts, you can duplicate backdrops to modify them.  However,  I didn't use duplicate as much as I wanted to.  Since I had an open-ended question, using a clone script better suited my needs.  I duplicated and combined aspects of 2 backdrops to form one, so I was pleased that that worked.  Anyway, Getting Unstuck was a lot of fun to do.  I really appreciate this opportunity!
instructions: Click on the green flag and type in your age for a birthday message.

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia:
Turtle graphics is a popular way for introducing programming to kids. It was part of the original Logo programming language developed by Wally Feurzig and Seymour Papert in 1966. Imagine a robotic turtle starting at (0, 0) in the x-y plane.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turtle_graphics

Add a draw pressing the space bar and clean the screen touching Angel with the mouse.

title: Small Planet
description:
Getting Unstuck day-21
by Massimo Marletta

My self-assignment is: 
"Create a game where you use some advanced mathematical functions (such as Sin, Cos, Log, Exp, etc)".

The items on the planet (trees, mountains, aliens) are sprites that, by using trigonometric functions, rotate about an arbitrary point which is 
external to the sprite itself (in this case the centre of the planet).

Credits for Images: 
* Mountains and Tree by Freepik @ www.flaticon.com
* Asteroid by Nikita Golubev @ www.flaticon.com
* Alien by Smashicons @ www.flaticon.com
instructions:
You have the power to rotate a small planet!

Unfortunately you have two problems: 
1) Some ugly aliens have invaded your planet
2) Your little planet is bombed by some asteroids

Rotate the planet (use Left and Right arrows to decide verse and velocity of the rotation) to make the asteroid hit the aliens and not the trees and the mountains of your beautiful little world.

* Note that the asteroid can hit an item only when it is close to the planet (i.e. on the opposite side of the planet respect the point it came from).

* Note that the asteroid can hit an item only when it is close to the planet (i.e. on the opposite side of the planet respect the point it came from).
* You earn 2 points if the asteroid hits an alien
* You lose 1 point if it hits a tree
* You lose 2 points if it hits a mountain

title: Getting Unstuck Day 21 - prompt
description:
I know a lot of my students want to create a shooting style game, so I wanted to explore how to shoot/launch objects from another object. The most obvious way to me is a typical Space Invaders style game.

I thought it would be a lot harder, but I actually found it quite easy to code the bullets to appear at the cannon and move from there, as if fired from it.

Of course there is much more that can be done to this project, but I wanted to focus on that particular skill.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 21: Invent a new Getting Unstuck prompt. Create a project in response to your prompt. 

Create a project involving shooting, launching, or throwing an object.

Press the green flag to start. Use left/right arrows to aim. Press the space bar to shoot.
writing:
I know a lot of my students want to create a shooting style game, so I wanted to explore how to shoot/launch objects from another object. The most obvious way to me is a typical Space Invaders style game.

I thought it would be a lot harder, but I actually found it quite easy to code the bullets to appear at the cannon and move from there, as if fired from it.

Of course there is much more that can be done to this project, but I wanted to focus on that particular skill.Getting Unstuck Day 21: Invent a new Getting Unstuck prompt. Create a project in response to your prompt. 

Create a project involving shooting, launching, or throwing an object.

Press the green flag to start. Use left/right arrows to aim. Press the space bar to shoot.

title: Rube Goldberg Fan
description:
Prompt:  Play with ways to show how a force may create motion.
For years I have been fascinated by Rube Goldberg creations. While considering how to get inspiration for this project I asked myself a series of questions like, "In what ways are levels in video games similar to parts of a RG machine b/c the path to a goal may be convoluted with many obstacles to conquer.?" I know that Rube never meant for there to be physical interpretations of his ideas b/c his cartoons were a social commentary about the industrial revolution. This makes me wonder about how a Scratch project may be used to provoke conversation. For now, I'm just playing with my "how can I make weird things happen" fascination!
When I was working with the clone part I got stuck. Everything was working, and then it was not. I was mystified. I finally learned that I had reached the limit of cloning (301 clones) b/c I had not been deleting them as I tested my code. When I clicked on "stop all", everything was better!
Credits:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/internetarchivebookimages/19905670383/
instructions:
Click the green flag to turn on the fan.
(Yes, this title is a pun!)

(This took more than a day to create, hence the late entry into Day 21.)

title: Who was POTUS when you were born?_GU_Day21 Improved
description:
What makes you curious? Is it a concept or theme that you have been thinking about? Is it how to use a component of Scratch? Is it where your fellow 21-Days "GettingUnstuckers" live? (I'm curious about all of the above.) 
PROMPT: Create a project in which you explore something about which you are curious.
Sporadically, I kept track of interactions with Scratchers from other countries. My list includes: Singapore, Taiwan, Sudan, Israel, Brazil, Australia, New Zealand, Slovenia, Ukraine, Greece, Italy, Spain, Portugal, France, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Sweden, Finland, UK, Ireland & Canada. That's 6 continents!
I am curious about the ages of my fellow 21-Days participants. I want to see if I can gather information from users. I am reading about the cloud variable.   https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Cloud_Data  
Hmm... I did not have a list at first. But in thinking about how to avoid a gigantic if-or-or-or...block, I realized that I could put all of the conditions into a list and then use the "list contains ___" with my if-else statement. 
Hmm...I am struggling with figuring out how to convert a string answer to a number b/c cloud variables can only use numbers. Changed my approach.
Hmm...I just discovered that there is a limit of ten cloud variables in a project. I will have to make some changes b/c currently I need 15. I will use only 10 presidents.
instructions:
Fingers crossed that this will keep track of everyone's responses!
Click on the green flag and respond.

POTUS is an acronym which means: President Of The United States

title: Getting Unstuck Day 8: Fish Chomp remix
description:
Seagull and clams from Creative Commons image search.

The Day 8 challenge reminded me of a student activity page in the Creative Computing Curriculum Guide (http://scratched.gse.harvard.edu/guide/) and I wanted to see how it might feel for a student to go through the activity on their own.

I changed the way the user manipulates the big fish (I thought it was awkward to use the mouse from a laptop), and added two new levels. I was trying to recreate a game that I loved when I was little (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dZUXImHsEIQ) for level 3.

There are still some buggy things (such as the creepy kind-of-dead-looking seagull), and I hope to come back to this project later to smooth them out!
instructions:
Guide the big fish with the arrow keys to eat the little fish. See how many little fish you can catch!

Level up at a score of 10, 20, and 30.

title: Know Your Mollusks! (Getting Unstuck, Day 8)
description:
For Day 8 of gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

I had SO MUCH FUN making this. I was walking down the street with @jsh, when we saw a huge pile of abandoned mussels on the side of the road. I asked @jsh what they were and he said, "I don't really know my mollusks!" And thus a project was born!

I used counting in two ways in this project: to determine when the player has reached the target of 10 mollusks, and then to report out the count for each of the 3 types of mollusks at the end (if you win).

I searched for "harp music" on Scratch and found @lkaufm's "Irish Harp Interactive": https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/53006916/
I found the images from wikimedia, searching for "illustrations [harpist/cat/clam/etc.]".
instructions: Press the green flag to start. Then, correctly identify 10 mollusks!
