title: Playing with Plants!
description:
Thanks to:
eebeec for the plant sprite!
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/85226318/#player

I gave myself a challenge to not draw my own sprites. I couldn't find a fitting plant in the sprite library, and @paulinah suggested I take a look at other plant projects for sprites! I was delighted to find the base sprite for this plant by @eebeec! (I did let myself make some (relatively) small costume edits in the paint editor. (and I made the lil drop in the paint editor)

This is my first game (and my first time using clones!) and it was so much fun to make! This definitely feels like the kind of meeting of idea + challenge that I was aspiring for with yesterday's project. Maybe I need a Getting Unstuck strategy that's something like "Remember Not Every Project Will Feel Good (and they shouldn't!)" I probably am not taking risks if I love *everything* I make. I LOVE THIS GAME, THO!

That being said, I would like to play around with how much water the plant would like to have for healthy hydration (and the corresponding too dry/too wet feedback). I'd also like to add a "water level" meter.
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, press the space bar and use the left and right arrow to move the plant to catch water drops to keep the plant well-watered. Be careful not to over or under water!

What ideas do you have for continued work on the game? When playing, what are you wishing were part?

title: Day 8 Unstuck
description: This one was difficult for me.  I started with @alirb raindrop code in my backpack but I really didn't understand how the cloning worked.  Next I figured out that the glide in her original code had to finish running before that sprite could be hidden.  For the longest time I could only get one Icecream scoop to fall, eventually through a lot of guess I added a forever block ontop of it all and it worked.  Don't completely understand it and there must be a cleaner way to do this but I definitely feel I got unstuck today!

title: Magellan School Fitness Challenge (Unstuck 8)
description:
This is a remix of the Exploratorium's "Makey Makey Physical Fitness Challenge" from 2012 that incorported physical movement and computational tinkering. This one is specific to push-ups, but can be easily repurposed for just about any physical activity and part of a collaboration with our awesome PE coach for an upcoming unit in the fall.

Link to original blog:
https://tinkering.exploratorium.edu/tinkering/2012/06/15/makey-makey-physical-fitness-challenge

The most difficult part for me with this remix was figuring out how to prevent players from scoring points after the timer went off. After getting seriously stuck and getting help from a friend, we came up with a variable based on the game's state as either "on" or "off." Such a simple, powerful idea.
instructions:
For use with Makey Makey. To play: 
First, put on the conductive wristband, then touch the Start pad (Spacebar). After the dialogue is finished and the timer starts, do as many pushups as you can, making sure to touch the pads after each one (Right->Down->Up). Stop when you hear the buzzer. See if you can get the top score!

This one is specific to push-ups, but can be easily repurposed for just about any physical activity and part of a collaboration with our awesome PE coach for an upcoming unit in the fall.

Link to original blog:
https://tinkering.exploratorium.edu/tinkering/2012/06/15/makey-makey-physical-fitness-challenge

The most difficult part for me with this remix was figuring out how to prevent players from scoring points after the timer went off. After getting seriously stuck and getting help from a friend, we came up with a variable based on the game's state as either "on" or "off." Such a simple, powerful idea.For use with Makey Makey. To play: 
First, put on the conductive wristband, then touch the Start pad (Spacebar). After the dialogue is finished and the timer starts, do as many pushups as you can, making sure to touch the pads after each one (Right->Down->Up). Stop when you hear the buzzer. See if you can get the top score!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 8 — Concentric Circles
description:
Reflection

After starting on a few different ideas, I landed on creating a concentric circle generator that accepts input from the user via the slider. 

The process is simple. It stamps a circle, changes costume, reduces size, and repeats a number of times specified by the slider.

The number of circles that are drawn is stored in the nCircles variable. The slider feature of this variable enabled. Instead of drawing the concentric circles every frame, the script instead responds to when the value of nCircle changes. There's a note in the script that points to where this happens.

One feature that could be added is moving the center point of a stamped circle each iteration to generate images similar to Marcel Duchamp's Anémic Cinéma rotoreliefs.
instructions: Use the slider to change the number of concentric circles.
writing:

title: Just a little bit
description:
Getting Unstuck day-8
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I explain how counting is done in binary numbers.

For the "bit" I used a Sprite with 2 costumes (0 and 1). This Sprite has several local variables (its properties), such as its value (0 or 1), its position (0=least significative bit, 1=second signitificative bit, etc).

The Green Button increase the first bit, when a bit pass from 1 to 0 (overflow) it set the variable Destination to its Position+1 and send a broadcast message to all the sprites yelling "overflow!".
The bit that have the Position corresponding to the Destination (i.e. the bit at the left of the bit that raised the overflow) is then incremented and (if necessary) it can raise the overflow again...
So the global variable Destination is used to select which bit must respond to the broadcast message.

The number of bits is not fixed from the beginning (you start with just  1 bit). If a further bit is needed it is created by cloning the one who is about to raise the overflow.
A Lightening represent the overflow which propagates through the bits.
The global variable Count (showed at screen) counts in decimal number.
instructions:
*** Do you know how to count in binary?
*** Press the Green Button to increase the binary number shown!

At the beginning you have just a single bit 0, when you press the button it becomes 1, when you press the button again it cannon grow again (in binary the only symbols allowed are 0 and 1) and therefore it get back to 0 raising an Overflow (represented by the Lightening) to the bit at its left. If such a bit does not exist, it is created... so you can count from 0 to +Infinite in binary numbers!
writing:
Getting Unstuck day-8
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I explain how counting is done in binary numbers.

For the "bit" I used a Sprite with 2 costumes (0 and 1). This Sprite has several local variables (its properties), such as its value (0 or 1), its position (0=least significative bit, 1=second signitificative bit, etc).

The Green Button increase the first bit, when a bit pass from 1 to 0 (overflow) it set the variable Destination to its Position+1 and send a broadcast message to all the sprites yelling "overflow!".
The bit that have the Position corresponding to the Destination (i.e. the bit at the left of the bit that raised the overflow) is then incremented and (if necessary) it can raise the overflow again...
So the global variable Destination is used to select which bit must respond to the broadcast message.

The number of bits is not fixed from the beginning (you start with just  1 bit). If a further bit is needed it is created by cloning the one who is about to raise the overflow.
A Lightening represent the overflow which propagates through the bits.
The global variable Count (showed at screen) counts in decimal number.
*** Do you know how to count in binary?
*** Press the Green Button to increase the binary number shown!

At the beginning you have just a single bit 0, when you press the button it becomes 1, when you press the button again it cannon grow again (in binary the only symbols allowed are 0 and 1) and therefore it get back to 0 raising an Overflow (represented by the Lightening) to the bit at its left. If such a bit does not exist, it is created... so you can count from 0 to +Infinite in binary numbers!

title: savetheclocktower
description:
for Day 8 of GettingUnstuck, I'm tinkering a bit more with this project in preparation for a physical computing camp next week.

The speed of the vehicle in MPH is calculated at the second circuit point and published on screen. As a math dropout I'm always unsure of my calculations so I would appreciate feedback on these.

If the calculated speed is between 8 and 9 mph (a nod to the 88 mph benchmark established in Back to the Future), the background changes briefly.

PROBLEMS: 1) this calculates the average speed over a stretch of track, but is it possible to calculate speed at a specific location? One can shorten the gap between circuits but the conceptual problem remains. 2) Is there a threshold amount of time needed for makeymakey to recognize that a circuit has been completed? 3) Passing through the circuits slows the vehicle down, based on how I've engineered the wires. Is there a better way to engineer this so the vehicle isn't slowed down? 4) Can the program be improved, possibly by adding another circuit to the course, so that the slowdown at each circuit point is calculated, and the speed at the final circuit is suitably discounted? 5) Scratch's moonwalking isn't very good.
instructions:
v. 1 the beginning of a physical computing project to measure the speed of a matchbox car at a given point in space

Connect makeymakey up arrow and down arrow to two incomplete circuits on a hotwheels track, twelve inches apart. The car should pass through the up arrow circuit first. Configure a car with copper tape so the car can complete the circuits when passing through.

(Without makeymakey, simulate w/ flag, up arrow, down arrow.)

title: Unstuck 08 Frog Game
description:
This is a remix of a project I build with students over six to eight classes. I modified it for the Unstuck Challenge so the game changes when five flies are caught, so the project responds when the variable reaches a certain number. I didn't meet that condition in my first project post (coin flip simulator)

I had to significantly modify the script so the game would pause after five flies are caught. The modification changed the game play so now the frog moves much more quickly and smoothly since the move scripts are all inside a forever loop instead of separate <when ___ key is pressed> event blocks. This will be a great way to show students how different script solutions, both valid, create different experiences for the program users.

I suppose I could make this change after a certain amount of time passes using the timer variable instead...
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin. 

Catch all ten flies as quickly as possible. 

Use the arrow keys to move the frog around the screen and press the space key to flick the frog's tongue and catch the flies.

title: Day 8
description:
music from https://emp3.direct.com

Wow! So many amazing projects in the studio! I was inspired by mizzpeters remix and also alirb plant project. I need some sort of intensive internal reprogramming myself so that I make one thing work and then do the next. For reasons?! I am always making everything at once and then it is a nightmare detangling clumps of code when I need to adjust one aspect. Spent eons trying to get the timer to cooperate - I still can't figure out why it won't shut down at 0!

Thanks to MrQuentin for explaining why my score counter was rocketing into the thousands! Also for acting as my game tester (I can't actually successfully play any video game - my students find this hilarious, but it makes it really hard to test the code and see if the game really works!), and showing me a better way to program the arrow keys!
instructions: Click the Green Flag and follow the Scratch Cat's prompts to nurture this plant!
writing:
music from https://emp3.direct.com

Wow! So many amazing projects in the studio! I was inspired by mizzpeters remix and also alirb plant project. I need some sort of intensive internal reprogramming myself so that I make one thing work and then do the next. For reasons?! I am always making everything at once and then it is a nightmare detangling clumps of code when I need to adjust one aspect. Spent eons trying to get the timer to cooperate - I still can't figure out why it won't shut down at 0!

Thanks to MrQuentin for explaining why my score counter was rocketing into the thousands! Also for acting as my game tester (I can't actually successfully play any video game - my students find this hilarious, but it makes it really hard to test the code and see if the game really works!), and showing me a better way to program the arrow keys!Click the Green Flag and follow the Scratch Cat's prompts to nurture this plant!

title: Penguin Jumper Unstuck #8 & #12
description:
This project came from a book I bought at our Spring Book Fair. It's called "20 Games to Create With Scratch" by Max Waine Wright. 

I wanted to stretch my comfort level, especially since this project deals with variables. I've used variables for scoring, but not much else. I liked this idea because in addition to score it uses variables to set the speed and angle of the penguin. At first the game was too easy. All you had to do was point at the iceberg. I had to play around and tweak the speed and gap to get the penguin to launch at the angle I wanted.

I figured out how to add lives when a certain score is reached, but I'd like to be able to add a life at certain increments, for example at every multiple of 50. I'm sure it must be an easy math calculation, but I couldn't figure out how to do that. Any suggestions would be most appreciated.
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin. Aim the arrow and then click on it to send the penguin to the blue iceberg.

I added levels & scenes to this for Unstuck #12

title: Winter Catch-game GettingUnstuck-08
description:
This time I decided to remix an old project of mine.
This winter-themed game was intended as an example provided to kids for a workshop in Italy: we had many examples of different difficulty to show that the ceiling was indeed really high.
While translating the dialogues I noticed a bug, so anyway this challenge was a good opportunity to improve it
instructions:
Catch the holly but avoid snowflakes.
Green flag to start and use mouse to control the bowl.

To understand why I'm posting a winter game in mid-July you have to read the Notes...

title: Getting Unstuck 8
description:
This was a fun one. I like playing around with making things look animated. I still need to work on the details a bit so the cars don't drive into each other. I also learned that you can use the costume # as a variable, which made this a lot easier!

Some things I could add if I had time: fixing the animation as I mentioned, adding some sprites as scenery that will pass by as you drive, and playing with the rules so you lose points if you click on a car that's not blue. Also a soundtrack - I always overlook this (mostly because my computer is almost always on mute).

UPDATE: I added sound and it's so much better! Now I need to go back and incorporate sound into my earlier projects.
instructions: Click on the green flag to start. Click on the cars to count them - only count the blue ones!

title: Bubble duck!!
description:
This game is based on the "Bomb Jack" game.
When I was a child I used to play it on my game boy a lot, so I have good memories about it.
I decided to use simple gravity when the character reaches the ground and a variable to control when it jumps.
The enemies moves differently in each level and I also have clones for the bubbles.

                                    ---Questions---
+What did you like most about your project? 
I think it is fun.

+What would you do with it next, if you had more time?
I'd like to add more levels, power-ups and enemies with different abilities.

---Credits---
+Music: sound effects and song are from scratch gallery.
+Game design: I've created characters, and other sprites with  the scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Press the green flag and then press the play button.
Use the Left and Right arrow keys to move your player.
Use the Up arrow key to jump.
Get the bubbles and try to avoid the enemies.
You have 3 lives.
Good luck!!

title: Pop the balloons!
description:
Did you know that sprite variables are different for every clone of the sprite? I discovered by chance and now I always use them. That's useful for keeping track the energy of an enemy and other parameters of a single clone.
For example, if you are trying to simulate a snowy day, every snowflake can have a different falling speed. The starting value is inherited by the parent sprite, so you can randomize it and then create a clone.
In this project I used the parameter "inflate!" to keep track of a balloon's status. When the count is 3, the balloon is popped and a point is scored.

Credits to NFour for the inflating sound ( http://soundbible.com/1410-Inflating-Balloon.html ) and to Andeh Pinkard for Badonk-a-donk font ( https://www.dafont.com/badonk-a-donk.font )
instructions:
Click three times on the balloons, the third time the balloon will pop and you will score a point.
How many points are you able to get in a minute?
writing:
Did you know that sprite variables are different for every clone of the sprite? I discovered by chance and now I always use them. That's useful for keeping track the energy of an enemy and other parameters of a single clone.
For example, if you are trying to simulate a snowy day, every snowflake can have a different falling speed. The starting value is inherited by the parent sprite, so you can randomize it and then create a clone.
In this project I used the parameter "inflate!" to keep track of a balloon's status. When the count is 3, the balloon is popped and a point is scored.

Credits to NFour for the inflating sound ( http://soundbible.com/1410-Inflating-Balloon.html ) and to Andeh Pinkard for Badonk-a-donk font ( https://www.dafont.com/badonk-a-donk.font ) Click three times on the balloons, the third time the balloon will pop and you will score a point.
How many points are you able to get in a minute?

title: Bubbles Video Sensing remix: Getting Unstuck Day 8 Variables
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 8 Variables

I wasn't feeling this project today (because reasons) but I wanted to stick with it, so I decided to take the "easy way out" and remix another project. The reason I say that is that I always want to make my own thing and remixing someone else's work feels a bit like cheating, or at least a short cut. 
But I am convinced of the remix spirit. I was able to do more remixing this video in half an hour than I would have been able to do on my own. Using the video function of Scratch is a blast, and the simple bubble popping action was perfect to add a variable to and turn into a "game" that ends when you hit an arbitrary number. 
I was already fairly comfortable with variables, so it was great to use today's prompt to discover a different unknown aspect of Scratch.
instructions:
Pop the bubbles or just watch them float up the screen. 
(This requires a webcam. )
REMIX TIPS:
- Animate the bubble when it pops.
- Change where the bubbles come from.
- Keep track of how many bubbles have been popped.

The reason I say that is that I always want to make my own thing and remixing someone else's work feels a bit like cheating, or at least a short cut. 
But I am convinced of the remix spirit. I was able to do more remixing this video in half an hour than I would have been able to do on my own. Using the video function of Scratch is a blast, and the simple bubble popping action was perfect to add a variable to and turn into a "game" that ends when you hit an arbitrary number. 
I was already fairly comfortable with variables, so it was great to use today's prompt to discover a different unknown aspect of Scratch.Pop the bubbles or just watch them float up the screen. 
(This requires a webcam. )
REMIX TIPS:
- Animate the bubble when it pops.
- Change where the bubbles come from.
- Keep track of how many bubbles have been popped.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 8 - Pong
description: This is my first time designing a "Pong" game. I recently taught 4th + 5th grade students to design, build, and program their own "operation" games using cereal boxes, tweezers, MakeyMakey, and scratch. This year we upped the difficulty by incorporating score/ lives.
instructions: Select the Green Flag to start/ reset the game. Then use the Left and Right Arrows to move the paddle left and right. Try not to let the purple ball hit the bottom. If it does, then you lose a life and you only have 7 lives before the game is over.

title: The Royal Dice Theatre
description:
This project responds to the prompt for Getting Unstuck Day 8:  "Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number." 

Today's strategy was "Find a Tutorial" + Remix a Project."  I referred to Ch. 5 (Variables) in the book "Learn to Program with Scratch" by Majed Marji.  The book features starter projects that one can access online.  I followed instructions to build the project, then added more dice sprites, a Score variable, a new backdrop, costume, text, and sounds.  For info on the book, go to https://nostarch.com/learnscratch/ . (Not sure if there will be a revised edition for Scratch 3.0, but it's still a great resource!)
instructions: Click on the green flag to start, then click on the Queen's crown to start each round.  See if you can score 10 to receive a special message!
writing:

Today's strategy was "Find a Tutorial" + Remix a Project."  I referred to Ch. 5 (Variables) in the book "Learn to Program with Scratch" by Majed Marji.  The book features starter projects that one can access online.  I followed instructions to build the project, then added more dice sprites, a Score variable, a new backdrop, costume, text, and sounds.  For info on the book, go to https://nostarch.com/learnscratch/ . (Not sure if there will be a revised edition for Scratch 3.0, but it's still a great resource!)Click on the green flag to start, then click on the Queen's crown to start each round. title: Untitled-56
description:
I've been tinkering with sound for the entire week, and I recently got very interested in understanding how synthesizers work, so I continued experimenting also with this (super experimental) project.

I wondered about ways to have a seamless transitions between notes. After more than 2 hours and thousands of experiments, I tried with two scripts calling each other using messages.

I was very surprised by the effect and I haven't quite understood how it works, but the code looks elegant and it sounds.. interesting! :) 
As you can hear, the sound still goes through some sort of stages. In my next experiments I will try to get to something more continuous.

I wanted to keep the stage minimal, so that people can concentrate on the sound. I kept the title as Untitled-56, as a reminder of the many attempts I made and the unfinished nature of this work.

Enjoy!
instructions: Make sure your volume is not too high and press the green flag!
writing:
I've been tinkering with sound for the entire week, and I recently got very interested in understanding how synthesizers work, so I continued experimenting also with this (super experimental) project.

I was very surprised by the effect and I haven't quite understood how it works, but the code looks elegant and it sounds.. interesting! :) 
As you can hear, the sound still goes through some sort of stages. In my next experiments I will try to get to something more continuous.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 8: PIcture!
description:
As continuing my Mexican context for the challenges (and preparing projects that I can use later in my classes), I wanted to represent some of the most iconic Mexican characters in a single picture some of my students will mostly remember.

Thank you to @Mittensbrother for inspiring my project. Your ideas are out of normal. I used the coding strategy for the variable waiting until 0 for something to happen and for my camera to take a picture until characters were ready. You cleared my mind!

Characters from different sources: Frida (Nicholas Muray) Cantinflas (sexenio.com.mx), El Santo (Devian art), El Chapulin (Wikia) Pedro Infante (La Bombilla), Camera (Canon)
instructions: Click green flag. Wait for all famous Mexican characters  to be ready and still for the picture.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 8
description:
This is my project for Day 8 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. This example is very useful in my opionion because it allows you to understand how to introduce levels in games and how to change the difficulty based on any event.

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions:
Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number.
In this example of animation, the ball changes its speed every 5 bounce. The animation stops when the number of bounces reach the value 200.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 8
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 8 Reflection:
This was fun to make.  I was excited when I finally figured out how to make something else happen when the variable reached 10.  That took longer than I thought.  If I had more time I'd want to figure out why my original ladybug stopped cooperating.  At first it moved and counted towards the total like the clones did, but I messed something up somewhere.  I just hid it in the end and added another clone to make the game work the way I wanted it to.  I'd also like to figure out a better way for the bugs to move.  My way is kind of a pain to catch and doesn't accurately portray how bugs move.
instructions: Click start and use the arrow keys so the bat can eat all of the bugs.
writing:

If I had more time I'd want to figure out why my original ladybug stopped cooperating.  At first it moved and counted towards the total like the clones did, but I messed something up somewhere.  I just hid it in the end and added another clone to make the game work the way I wanted it to.  I'd also like to figure out a better way for the bugs to move.  My way is kind of a pain to catch and doesn't accurately portray how bugs move.Click start and use the arrow keys so the bat can eat all of the bugs.

title: Unstuck - Day 8
description:
This project is just a variation of a traditional pong game.  We decided to count how many times the ball hits the Scratch Cat. When the score is greater than 10, then the ball moves faster. After 20 and 30 it also gets faster.  Each time the ball goes behind the cat, the score decreases by 1.  When the score is less than 1, the game is over.
Some modifications we plan to make include: 
-When the speed changes, the ball switched colors (changes costume)
-When the ball goes behind the cat, the score changes by -5, making the game a bit more challenging.
-Once the ball gets faster, it doesn't slow down (still haven't figured out how to do this - any suggestions?  I'm thinking maybe using If, then, else or set a range such as score > 10 and score <20)
-Have a timer that counts how long the player keeps playing.  When the game is over, the time is displayed.
-Anyone else have suggestions?
instructions:
Click Green Flag to Start.
Move your mouse up and down and try to hit the ball.
Try to keep up!

title: #GettingUnstuck8 - Random numbers and means
description:
All sprites and costumes taken from the Scratch repository.

This project can be easily optimized, but it is just a fast draft for the GettingUnstuck 8th challenge.
instructions:
Press green flag and follow the instructions. Keep space bar to finish the program.

This project generates 50 random numbers [1..100] each time and saves the results. It also calculates the mean of all numbers and saves it in a list (so you can check how it varies).

This project is part of #GettingUnstuck initiative #CreativeComputing, Day 8.

title: Fruit and Veggie Challenge
description:
Very loosely based on the classic video arcade game Pacman.

I reworked a previous project that I first created back in 2013.  I made some adjustments in this version - making the sprites smaller and hiding the sprites after they are chomped (I've always wanted to do that but never found the time to get around to it). I discovered that once I hid the sprites though, I had to go back and adjust my scoring variables because they were no longer on the screen to allow for a higher score. The game is a little bit trickier now, I think.  You have to chomp all five healthy foods (50 points) while avoiding unhealthy foods (so that you don't lose points). You have to get 50 points within 20 seconds to win.
instructions:
Click Green Flag to start.

Chomp  healthy fruits and veggies - You earn points
Stay away from unhealthy snacks (You lose points if you chomp them)

Chomp all healthy foods to earn 50 points to Win!  Good luck, you only have 20 seconds!

title: Unstuck 8: Melon Bounce
description: Credit: modified code from Coding in Scratch Games Workbook.
instructions:
Click the flag to start the game.
Cat has to stop the falling watermelons from hitting the ground, but he doesn't know where they'll appear or which melon will drop first. Help him to keep the melons in the air.
Each melon starts in a random position. The melons bounce off the cat and back up into the air.
Left key - moves the cat forward.
Right key - moves the cat in reverse direction. When a melon hits the bottom of the stage, you hear a cymbal, and it's the end of the game.

Credit: modified code from Coding in Scratch Games Workbook.Click the flag to start the game.
Cat has to stop the falling watermelons from hitting the ground, but he doesn't know where they'll appear or which melon will drop first. Help him to keep the melons in the air.
Each melon starts in a random position. The melons bounce off the cat and back up into the air.
Left key - moves the cat forward.
Right key - moves the cat in reverse direction. When a melon hits the bottom of the stage, you hear a cymbal, and it's the end of the game.

I enjoyed how I was able to make the shrink and as it moves towards the city, it gives a sense of motion. If I had more time, I would have made the other Sprites disappear and reappear after the cat touches them.

Click on green flag to start the program. Use the arrow keys to control the Scratch Cat. Note - as you move around, the cat will shrink - Try to get to 11 or more points before the Sprite disappears. After getting the required points, then swim to shore using the arrow keys.

I hope you enjoy the game.

title: Cat Lollipops (Unstuck #8)
description:
Day 8 of Getting Unstuck! Join us at gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu.

Our activity of the day: Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens—and responds when the count reaches a certain number.

This works with a List! (not variables, strictly speaking — but it does count and report variations, and respond to the count!)
instructions:
How many lollipops can one cat handle?

Press the green flag and then follow the story to find out!

Day 8 of Getting Unstuck! Join us at gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu.

Our activity of the day: Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens—and responds when the count reaches a certain number.

description: This little game could easily be customized and expanded. You can add more hippos or change it to an addition game, etc. One problem I have that I would fix if I had more time, is that the hippos sometimes end up on top of each other.  I think this would be a great kindergarten game!
instructions: Click on the green arrow and then count the hippos. You can drag the hippos on the screen to make sure you see them all or to help you count them. When you get 3 answers correct, you win.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 8
description:
The challenge for Day 9 was: Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number.

My backdrop poses the question of "Can Scratch do 5 jumping jacks?".  Of course he can! When he does completes the 5 there is a clapping sound. I added a random block (given to us in the day 6 challenge) to have him complete a few extra jumps.  Of course I also have the counter on the bottom to keep track of how many jumping jacks he completes!
instructions:
Do you think that Scratch the Cat can do more than 5 jumping jacks?

Click the green arrow to see how many he can do!
Don't forget to give him props for completing his five!

title: Total Turtle Turn random angles--evolve into sprays
description:
Getting Unstuck - Day 8
"create a project that counts the number of times something happens—and responds when the count reaches a certain number"
This project has definitely evolved -- it began with walking around a circle, but with random turns -- checking the total until it reached or exceeded 360, then adjusting so that the final turn made the total 360. Thinking about turtle art and mathematical stitching, after a number of variations (from dots to colored lines), the randomly generated points of the turns are stored in lists, then the lists are stepped through to create the lines from the first point of each original path. The color changes for each design; shading changes step by step until the "floor" of the distance to the point is reached. (Hopefully this will make more sense if you happen to look at the code.)
instructions:
0. Green Flag = clear
1. Use slider to change the 'step-length' (optional)
2. Spacebar - generate one spray of design
3. Drag the cat to a new location

Repeat steps 1-3 to create your design

title: Colorful sine waves
description: Even though I have limited time to work on these, I've been trying to challenge myself to explore aspects of Scratch I haven't used before. Although I've known that you can use RGB colors in Scratch, I've never actually tried, and a long long time ago, I used to be really into geometry. So, this is a simple project, but it forced me to learn a little more about how to implement sine functions in Scratch, explore RGB color range, and also use the sensing color block! Looks simple, but I learned a lot. :)
instructions: Press the green flag to start, the stop button to clear, and move the sliders around to experiment with RGB colors.
writing: Even though I have limited time to work on these, I've been trying to challenge myself to explore aspects of Scratch I haven't used before. Although I've known that you can use RGB colors in Scratch, I've never actually tried, and a long long time ago, I used to be really into geometry. So, this is a simple project, but it forced me to learn a little more about how to implement sine functions in Scratch, explore RGB color range, and also use the sensing color block! Looks simple, but I learned a lot. :)Press the green flag to start, the stop button to clear, and move the sliders around to experiment with RGB colors.

title: Xylophone Music
description: I *really* wanted to make a Pac Man style game for today's challenge. After working on it for too long, getting super frustrated, and making dinner, I came back with a totally different idea. I wanted to see if I could do a xylophone game where the music was controlled by colors, as opposed to each xylophone key being a separate sprite. I'll keep working on my Pac Man project and share it another day :)
instructions:
Click the mallet to play music. Press "h" to add harmony to your song!

Press space to put the mallet(s) away.

title: Color Reader! (Getting Unstuck, Day 9)
description: When I first started the project, it was a bit of a disaster. I was using the original, full-color Starry Night and it was wayyyy too many colors to try to detect. I was feeling a bit demoralized and thought about abandoning the project entirely. And then I thought, "If I can't make the code easier (detecting these millions and millions of colors), could I make something _else_ easier?" And that's when I had the insight to make the image "easier" by reducing the number of unique colors in the image. (I found Van Gogh's Starry Night on Google's Art and Culture, took a screen capture of it, then reduced the number of colors in Photoshop.) Of course, it doesn't look as beautiful or as vivid as the original—but I think you can still tell that it's Starry Night. I'm excited about this prototype. :)
instructions:
My friend Dock is color blind. He occasionally appears in my office and asks what colors he's wearing (and if they make sense together). For today's Getting Unstuck challenge of color sensing, I was wondering how he experiences art.

Press the green flag, then move your mouse over the stage.

title: Drops
description:
This project was created for Day 9 of Getting Unstuck. Today's goal was to create a project that makes use of color sensing blocks. I wanted to create the feeling of objects falling alternately through air and fluid. Of course, there had to be some accompanying sound. 

If I were going to spend more time on this project, I would explore different instrument samples and more interesting chord progressions.

Vibraphone samples courtesy of University of Iowa Electronic Music Studios (http://theremin.music.uiowa.edu/index.html)

title: Helicopter Doodler
description:
This project is inspired by a recent read -- 'The Boy Who Would be a Helicopter: The Uses of Storytelling in the Classroom' by Vivian Paley  

Doodle a scene from a story you've been dreaming, a frustration you've been feeling, something inspired by a project in a Getting Unstuck Studio -- whatever you'd like! 

Then, clear it away! 
(or take a screen shot and share it with a friend!)


I'm excited to create a program for creating! I'd like to play around with the keys/inputs. Perhaps on-screen buttons to press would be simpler. I'm also torn about including an "erasing' function. Thoughts?
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, bring the helicopter to a color on top and click the mouse to pick it up! 

Press p when you're ready to doodle
Press SPACE if you'd like to pause
Go to bottom left to change the size and shade of pen
                           (there are so many color possibilities!)
Press c to clear the canvas

title: Unstuck Day 9: Touching Color
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #9-using the touching color block- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
This was fun as it came together! The part I got stuck on was the prize sprite wasn't changing to the right color costume each time. It turned out both the arrow sprite and the prize sprite were doing something in triggered by receiving the prize broadcast and since the prize sprite conditions depended on a variable set by the arrow I had to add a slight delay to the prize sprite so the variable would have time to be set by the arrow. I find a lot of times things don't happen as you expect because of timing in Scratch.
instructions:
What will Dee get? Spin the wheel to choose a gift for Dee!
Argh I'm finding sometimes it doesn't work but I have to go to jury duty...will try to fix later. Hmm added a longer delay in the prize, seems to be working consistently.
Added some sound and an intro.
Still can't figure out why it sometimes picks the color it has gone past...
Ohh! I stupidly put the color detection in the arrow instead of the little dot that is more precise.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 9!
description:
My biggest take-away from this project was to have the sprite rotate but for the costume to not rotate visually. 

I found Scratch has three rotation styles:
-Full rotation (default)
-Left/Right
-No rotation (this is what I selected)

This was helpful to get keep the sprites from ending up upside down or sideways.
instructions:
Click the green flag. 
Sprite will change costume depending on what color it touches.
Click the STOP sign to stop.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9
description:
I have been thinking about line following robots. Seemed like the perfect opportunity to try out very simple rules, eg move forwards; if touching red turn right; if touching blue turn left. Seems to work surprisingly well. I like the idea that Scratch could be used to prototype real world robot algorithms.

I started with Scratch Cat rather than a ball, but extremities would "catch" on the colours and lead to twirling and getting stuck.

I'd like to experiment further with different angles and number of steps. Maybe with a timer to see how fast the ball completes the track. This could be automated to determine the best parameters.

More complex tracks would be fun. And maybe a player controller car to race the computer controlled (AI?) ball.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 9

Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?).

Just run the project and the ball will use simple rules to travel around the uncoloured track.

I improved this a bit by making several 'touching color' blocks sampled from different points on the green leaves, and connecting them with 'and' blocks, but it still doesn't work all the time :)

Also, I don't know why the drum loop stops before the very end of the script... (solved by @MrQuentin)

title: Getting Unstuck #9
description:
I was really stuck with this, so checked out the studio and was inspired by @karenb, @mizzpeters and @jsh's projects. I thought it would be great to get an aural interpretation of an artwork. Like @karenb I struck the problem of too much depth of colour, but I think I picked up enough of them to get the idea.

There's still so much to do to improve this. With more time I'd add the ability to change the instruments of each sprite, and a slider to change the number of beats played. The Speed slider really doesn't change things as much as I'd like.

This is one of my favourite paintings:
https://cv.vic.gov.au/stories/creative-life/from-watercolours-to-decorative-arts/australian-home-painting-by-howard-arkley/
instructions: Just press the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck day 9
description: I started with one sprite bouncing around the stage and changing costumes. I duplicated this sprite twice. I did not realize that the conditionals that change their colors would be "True" when the sprites are touching each other (duh). Then I decided to add random "music" to the touching. I discovered that the notes and the color change/movement had to be in different scripts or else the sprites stopped moving after each step while the note played. The scale is G major in case you were wondering. I need to tinker some more with the speed the sprites are moving to see if the "music" could be a little more pleasing to the ear.
instructions: Click the green flag

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 9 — Generative Art
description:
Reflection

I wanted to improve on my Day 7 project in which multiple cloned pens draw sine waves to the screen. Instead of using dumb agents (that's the technical term) I integrated the color touch block so that the pens can respond to their environment.

The idea is simple, randomly pick a place to start a pair of smart agents, randomly choose a direction for the first agent and a user-defined offset (controlled by the slider) for the second, and let them move until they detect black, at which point they stop.

Overall, it works pretty well. However, one issue is the color touching block looks specifically for black. Because of anti-aliasing drawn lines, some of the pixels are dark grey and don't register with the color sensing block. I could complain, but I think the generated compositions look better because of this glitchiness.
instructions: Move the slider and watch as the art emerges.
writing:
Reflection

I wanted to improve on my Day 7 project in which multiple cloned pens draw sine waves to the screen. Instead of using dumb agents (that's the technical term) I integrated the color touch block so that the pens can respond to their environment.

The idea is simple, randomly pick a place to start a pair of smart agents, randomly choose a direction for the first agent and a user-defined offset (controlled by the slider) for the second, and let them move until they detect black, at which point they stop.

Overall, it works pretty well. However, one issue is the color touching block looks specifically for black. Because of anti-aliasing drawn lines, some of the pixels are dark grey and don't register with the color sensing block. I could complain, but I think the generated compositions look better because of this glitchiness. Move the slider and watch as the art emerges.

This project is inspired by todays project of  @mizzpeters, which I like a lot : https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236177857/

I tried to use costum blocks for the musical notes, but that didn't work out. I don't know why. Then I used messages instead and it worked like I wished it would work.

title: Unstuck 09 Sensing colour
description: I always wanted to learn how to create a PacMan game, and a simple maze navigation seemed like a good start. Super happy with what I learned on this challenge. Next time I'd like to learn how to turn the maze walls into a sprite, and also how to have the ghost creatures auto traveling around.
instructions: Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game.
writing:
I always wanted to learn how to create a PacMan game, and a simple maze navigation seemed like a good start. Super happy with what I learned on this challenge. Next time I'd like to learn how to turn the maze walls into a sprite, and also how to have the ghost creatures auto traveling around. 
Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game.

title: Day 9 - Pre Symphony
description:
Sounds like symphony warming up. There must exist some algorithm to make it sound less discordant but my scope... Would also be fun to make the color light up when it is strikes but then each color would need to be a sprite. Additionally, there seems to be a timing factor in that the sprite has to sense the color at a certain pace for it to register. In any event, again, had a blast doing it and the sidetrack investigations were as compelling as the challenge. This is great! Though time is a factor, I definitely plan to stick it out.

title: Music Bending Machine
description:
I've had to recreate this in Scratch 1.4 in order for my PicoBoard to work - but I know some people have success using later editions of Scratch, including web based Scratch, with Pico.   When Pico is connected, I like to replace the slider with a pressure sensor.

Problems I'm stuck on: I can't actually bend a note until the beat is complete, and then I can change the note before it repeats. I've settled on a beat of .15.  Does anyone know how to play a sustained note but bend the note while it is being played using a slider?
instructions:
Use with both MakeyMakey and a PicoBoard. Connect 5 spoons to Makey Makey's four arrows plus space bar. The program should allow one to bend notes using the sliding potentiometer. A note will be true if the potentiometer is set at 50.

Currently this is configured to play without the slider, and you can use your keyboard arrows and space bar. (There's a duplicate sprite that has the Pico blocks removed). Be sure to hit the green flag first.

The suggested starting sequence is up arrow, right arrow, left arrow, down arrow, space bar.

title: Day 9 Getting Unstuck Color Interactions
description:
My idea was to make an homage to Josef Albers and allow the user to change the colors noting that different colors would make the sizes of the boxes appear different but it's not working. :(

Everything appears to be on different layers so the shapes are going in front or behind each other so the sensing blocks are not working. You can see I got frustrated and tried a broadcast solution. I wanted to get unstuck myself before sharing.. but....
instructions:
drag the black ball around to change the colors but it's not working :(

I'm stuck!
I'm stuck about why the shapes are not on the same layer and thus unable to affect each other.
AND
I'm stuck about why I am unable to make a square without a border or with a transparent border.

title: Q-game
description:
Thank you, Alexey Garbuzenko for the idea of this project
Scratch On!
instructions:
Q-Game puzzle was first released on mobile phones and then ported to lot of platforms. Game is simple but challenging set of puzzles. Move your billiard balls to pockets with corresponding color.
Use mouse for select/unselect ball, arrow keys for move ball.
Up-left corner - restart button
Down-left corner - custom level
Use fullscreen mode!
Enjoy!

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge 9 - Paint
description:
Thinking about using touching color I thought of a drawing game. I structured a few things unlike how I usually would because I don't use the touching color much but it was fun experience.

Pretty fun making a single mouse press design and then hitting z to watch it go away on its own

The undo block works pretty well too. I was going to make it without screen refresh but I enjoy watching it backtrack over the last mouse down moves.
instructions:
In game. 
Quick reference under the info button.
mouse down to draw
up/down arrows to change colors
left/right to change size
press z and watch, it will undo your moves(sometimes takes 2 taps). 

(I have to add the pen size, so this undo is assuming that the pen sized isn't changed prior to pressing z. )

title: Bouncing Watermelon -- Unstuck Challenge 9
description: Though this isn't a very elaborate project, it was good practice in seeing how to make sprites respond to elements on the page.  If I were going to work on this more, I'd want to add more interactivity with the user.  My original idea was to have a "Plinko" style game in which dropping the watermelon produced random results.  I decided that project would take too much time at this point, so I scaled down my original plan just to test out the features.  Perhaps with more time, I'll be able to return to my original idea.
instructions: Drag the watermelon anywhere on the page and watch what happens.
writing: Though this isn't a very elaborate project, it was good practice in seeing how to make sprites respond to elements on the page.  If I were going to work on this more, I'd want to add more interactivity with the user.  My original idea was to have a "Plinko" style game in which dropping the watermelon produced random results.  I decided that project would take too much time at this point, so I scaled down my original plan just to test out the features.  Perhaps with more time, I'll be able to return to my original idea.Drag the watermelon anywhere on the page and watch what happens.

title: Day 9
description:
music - Edvard Grieg's Morning Mood from Peer Gynt via www.yourclassical.org

I really struggled with this and never got it to do what I wanted. The second I read the challenge I knew I wanted to make a chameleon. I can't draw well enough for that, so switched to a butterfly.
I fought with the color changing for almost an hour and a half! I WANT to be able to create a variable that senses color and then changes the sprite to match that color. I could not figure out how to do that. I tried to create a block that would recognize color, but no. I then fell back on "if touching color x" "set color to x". Looking up all the color values. That doesn't work - FYI - I still don't really know why.
I then simplified my background to only 4 (sorry about how lurid) colors and learned that the value you set in color is altered by the color at which your sprite starts! When it was white, the color change was so infinitesimal I couldn't really see it! Okay, turned it to a nice vibrant purple and then one color at a time experimented with numbers until they shifted to a reasonable approximation of the desired color.
Thanks to MrQuentin for bearing with the increasingly unhinged ranting that accompanied today's project and figuring out that part about the original color of the sprite affecting the color changes! 
I wonder if the previous iterations would work now that the sprite is purple, but will have to test that later.
instructions: Click the green flag!

title: Mouse Maze
description: I have also taught the basics of the ball interaction with the maze background to second grade students. They have created additional background mazes, but all their mazes start in the same x and y position. I removed the list of x and y coords to move the ball to different starting points for them.
instructions:
This game is designed for Kindergarten students to practice controlling the mouse. Click the green flag to begin, grab the purple circle with the mouse, and move it to the yellow finish line to get to the next maze. If you touch the red, you go back to start.

For the Getting Unstuck challenge, I have started adding additional obstacles and challenges to some of the mazes. Maze two has a narrow passageway, maze three has a disappearing/reappearing path, and maze six has a red wall sliding back and forth across the path. Any other ideas for obstacles? Please let me know.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 9
description: The hardest part of this project was choosing the sprites.  Realistic flowers made id difficult to use the "touching color" because of the shaded portions.  It was easier to use clipart with solid colors. The timing for the introduction was also tricky so that the reader can get through the introduction before the game begins.  I could have used broadcast events to time it easier, but choose wait blocks instead.
instructions:

title: Infection v2
description: I chose to revist my project from the randomness day, which already used `touching color`. Adding both a third state (immune) and a "healing" zone increased the complexity of tracking states slightly and also forced me to think more critically about when I should be "infecting" - previously infected dots were trying to infect each other which caused unecessary slowdowns. I'm also playing around with the graphic effects a bit, which I've never toyed with much.

title: Donut Collector Take 2 - GettingUnstuck#9
description:
GettingUnstuck#9 - "Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?)"

This is a bit of a cheat as it is a copy of yesterday's mini game with "if touching sprite" replaced with "if touching color". 

I tried a different idea with a character moving and saying something when standing in a blue "puddle" or brown "mud". But I hit issue with "touching color" being true over and over and over and I couldn't think of a good way to move the sprite away from the colour fully.  I successfully got the sprite to bounce back the latest movement if it had just touched the colour. But then I realised that if I turned the sprite and more than a tiny part of it's body was in the colour then it got stuck!

Hopefully other people's project will give me hints to get around this.
instructions: Move the cat using the arrow keys. Collect all 10 donuts to complete the game.
writing:
GettingUnstuck#9 - "Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?)"

This is a bit of a cheat as it is a copy of yesterday's mini game with "if touching sprite" replaced with "if touching color". 

I tried a different idea with a character moving and saying something when standing in a blue "puddle" or brown "mud". But I hit issue with "touching color" being true over and over and over and I couldn't think of a good way to move the sprite away from the colour fully.  I successfully got the sprite to bounce back the latest movement if it had just touched the colour. But then I realised that if I turned the sprite and more than a tiny part of it's body was in the colour then it got stuck!

Hopefully other people's project will give me hints to get around this.Move the cat using the arrow keys. Collect all 10 donuts to complete the game.

title: GU_Day9_sidetracked
description: I was curious about the relationship between complementary colors. After reading an article, I learned they are opposite each other on the color wheel. I started playing with the idea of find complementary colors in clothes. This was fun to make. However, it does not follow the intent of Day 9. After I share this, it's back to work!
instructions: Click on the green flag, then choose what color blouse you would like. The project will choose a complementary colored skirt to wear with it.

title: Help TacoCat (Unstuck 9)
description:
This is a remixed tribute my maker educator friend, Mark Barnett.  He shared the orignal version few years ago at conference. Project 9 was a great opportunity to revisit it an make some tweaks to the original.

The dog animation took me more time than expected to figure out, specifically, how to go back and forth how I envisioned. The Scratch Ed blog had some great user created examples which really helped.
instructions:
Press the flag to being. Help Cat find Taco by navigating through the maze with the arrow keys. Watch out for the walls and especially for the dog.

(This is meant to be combined with a Makey Makey and custom controller.)

title: Getting Unstuck 9
description:
My goal is to try something new on each of these challenges, and this time it was downloading and animating sprites. 

I didn't really get stuck on anything that's here, although I did also try to add an axe sprite that the woodsman could throw. I couldn't figure out how to make it go toward the clones of the monster instead of the original (hidden) monster, so I ended up scrapping that idea.

Woodsman & Monsters sprites by Warlock's Gauntlet team on OpenGameArt.org
Music is Spooky Theme by Mystified from the Free Music Archive
instructions: Click the green flag to start then use your mouse to navigate the woodsman through the cave. Don't touch the cave walls, and avoid the monsters!

description:
I remixed my day 5 project (the jumping sprite) to work on figuring out how to get the penguin to jump on and walk off the rainbow with "gravity". 

I got a little overly ambitious and tried to throw in a scrolling background as well... it worked for a bit, but now is stuck! I'd love any suggestions or pointers to tutorials :)

title: Molecular Generator
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 9

sometimes atom failed to make a bond and turned endlessy. To solve this issue I have added the possibility to move again that atom somewhere, just pressing space while it's turning
instructions:
35 atoms for creating a molecular structure in chaotic way. Every time a bond is created, you will listen a "pop"
If an atom cannot make a bond and continues to turn endlessly, you can press the SPACE Key to make it move towards other atoms.

title: Challenge20 - Platformer
description:
Disclaimer: this is an engine for a touching color game. I only have 2 levels drawn as examples. Wanted to create something extra using touching color and this came to mind. (Have to add x collision, whenI get back I will)

Had a few minutes and had always wanted to create a game where the user gets to play it how they want. I didn't have time for the whole game so I thought I'd create an engine with all condtions ready to go.

Red resets, yellow next level, too low on stage resets

Redoing this from a few projects ago. Thought I'd see it through, add a few levels and few extra effects. Will add more levels when I have time. 

Draw bridges, platforms, whatever to get Scratch to the yellow. 

Arrow Keys left/right/up

You get 50 line points to draw platforms to get your cat to yellow

Space resets the level
Z to undo your last line

title: Magic colour ball
description: The main idea came from an interesting game developer studio called BinaryZoo. They made one of the best Asteroids clones ever, Echoes, which I tried to remake in Scratch (check my project Asteroidx) but the inspiration for this mini-game is Mono. In Mono you have to shoot at coloured blobs that leave a trail after they explode. The trail influences other blobs hovering upon them, like speeding up, making them spin towards you or shooting.
instructions:
Our hero has a magic ball that is influenced by colours! Red makes it spin anticlockwise while blue turns it clockwise.

First you have to paint the background. Aim the brush with the mouse and click to leave a spot. 1 & 2 change from red to blue. After you made the course, press space and the Cat will throw the ball in front of it!
writing:

Red makes it spin anticlockwise while blue turns it clockwise.

First you have to paint the background. Aim the brush with the mouse and click to leave a spot. 1 & 2 change from red to blue. After you made the course, press space and the Cat will throw the ball in front of it!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9
description: I'm not certain if it was because my browser kept freezing today but I tried a few different combinations of changes and the sprite would get stuck on the first one.  The forever block also caused issues in that respect and I had to tweak that.
instructions:
Press Green Flag to Begin
Press Space Bar to Clear

If Scratch touches the black background the sprite color will change by 10.
If Scratch touches the red circle pixilation will change by 1.
If Scratch touches the orange circle sprite will switch costumes.
If Scratch touches blue circle sprite will make meow sound.

title: Getting Unstuck #9: touching color blocks in the Sensing category
description:
Scratch project was created as activity #9 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #9 Challenge: Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game.
instructions: Press the green flag!
writing:
Scratch project was created as activity #9 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #9 Challenge: Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game. Press the green flag!

title: Unstuck Day 9 - Colorful Fish
description: The challenge was figuring out what move blocks worked best to insure the fish traveled through the 5 different colors. When I tried using the random block with the glide block, he didn't always change color. I'm assuming it's because the proper part of his body didn't touch the color.
instructions: Press the flag to see the little fish swim through the colorful ocean waters. He will change based on the colorful of the water. There's a little surprise when he bumps into a starfish.

Press the flag to see the little fish swim through the colorful ocean waters. He will change based on the colorful of the water. There's a little surprise when he bumps into a starfish.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9: Germ Free?
description:
I know it's too much :)  
I wanted to try to make a Pac-man style game that modelled the immune system.  LOL.  
When part of a loop is moved and there is too many code, instructions got mixed up. (Next time, I will make numbered copies of draft versions.)
I do like the paths I created for sprites to follow. Put "guide" sprites along white path and told sprites to move from one to another, then hid them. Used "random" to vary routes. They worked nicely until I moved parts of the code.  
Wanted "Smiling Sprites" to turn to a frown when touching "Grumpy Spites".  Wanted "Grumpy Sprites" to change colour when they touched the "Grinning Blue Sprites".  Wanted to clone the moving sprites, but just had them create stamps along the path, which is somewhat entertaining. (Might have wanted too much.)
Technically, one or two "Grumpy Sprites" changed colour, so the objective of the challenge was reached (?)
Stay tuned for a simple project tomorrow :)
instructions:
Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category.
Watch sprites sort-of chase each other along the path. Press green flag to start.

description:
I've created a very a simple pinball game.
Today I've found really difficult how to bounce the ball in a more realistic way by using variables. 
Unfortunately, I've couldn't implemented it yet, so I've decided to improve it later on.
Any suggestions or comments are welcomed.
instructions:
Press the green flag.
Press Space button to start the game.
Press the left arrow key to use one flipper and the right key to use another.
Try to get as many points as possible.
Enjoy it!!

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge 9
description:
I wanted to create something to use in the class, that was not a game type activity.
What started off as a simple naming of  the States and Territories then led me to adding additional information/images about the States and Territories.
Apologies to ACT which was too small to link - will have to work on this!
Can see this progressing to emblems, flags, etc.
I think I could have probably used different code to link the broadcasting without duplicating seven individual codes perhaps with a if then block.
Had to be careful when sprite is touching two colours again more time to be spent on recoding.
instructions:
Click the green flag.
Use the arrow keys to place the koala on a colour.
Once on a colour ( not overlapping two colours!) press the space bar.
Enjoy learning about Australia.

title: Synesthesia: Getting Unstuck Day 9 Touching Colour
description:
So, still not sure why I can't get my notes to synchronise. Even a single clone that plays a note sounds like 5 or 10 notes played not-quite-simultaneously.
Still not clear on how Scratch treats notes. Does the script stop while the note plays and then continue after or does the command to play the note go out and the script continue in parallel to the note playing?
>:-\
instructions: Press the Green Flag. There are two different patterns (that alternate each time you restart the project) of music to be played
writing:
So, still not sure why I can't get my notes to synchronise. Even a single clone that plays a note sounds like 5 or 10 notes played not-quite-simultaneously.
Still not clear on how Scratch treats notes. Does the script stop while the note plays and then continue after or does the command to play the note go out and the script continue in parallel to the note playing?
>:-\Press the Green Flag. There are two different patterns (that alternate each time you restart the project) of music to be played

title: Day9  Color Switch
description:
Day 9: Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category 

When I started this project, I thought this would be a quick and easy project, but that was not the case.  It is working but only a very basic version.  I plan to come back to this project again to add better graphics, sounds and more levels.
instructions:
This is based on the Color Switch Game.  Attempting to build a very basic version of it.
Click green flag to start
Press the space bar to make the dot move.  The dot much touches the star but can only go through the matching color.  

Still working on this project.  But I wanted to share anyway.  Some parts are working but not all yet.
writing:
Day 9: Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category

title: Unstuck Day 9: Cat Chase
description: This is a basic remix of the game Cheese Chase by John Woodcock from the book Coding Games in Scratch. The first time I made Cheese Chase, it was so difficult!  This time, things went much more smoothly, although there are still things to work on!
instructions: Click on the green flag to begin. You will be using the arrow keys to try and navigate the dog to catch the cat.  If the dog touches the blue wall, it will stop.  Every time you touch the cat, you will score 10 points. Be careful of the ghost, though!  It will randomly pop up.  If it touches the dog, the game is over.  Have fun!

title: Ceci c'est ne pas un projet
description:
Today I visited the SF Museum of Modern Art and completely felt in love with Magritte. So I decided to make something about it.

I've been spending more than 2 hours on a different project (inspired by the painting "Clear Ideas") but couldn't get anything good from it. I thought it was a great opportunity to check out again the "getting unstuck tip" on the website. 

I tried "Just Keep Going" for a while, but I was feeling more and more frustrated. I was inspired by the "Problem? Opportunity!" but still didn't know how to apply that to my super stuck situation.. Finally reading the "Try Something Different" gave me the courage and confidence to put all my previous work aside and start with a completely new project, and this time I tried to keep it as simple as I could.

I started with a simple painting of the sky, decided to add only one object, and focus on finding a way to use color sensing. I experienced the same problem of @karenb with the painting having many different colors. Then I realized that the different shades of gray of the clouds could become an opportunity to add a bit of randomness.. so the umbrella get stuck only when their handle touches a specific color.

Now it's 2:25am, and I'm exhausted, and joyful, and proud. 
This is not (just) a Scratch project!

Enjoy! :)
instructions: Click the green flag and be open to be surprised.
writing:
Today I visited the SF Museum of Modern Art and completely felt in love with Magritte. So I decided to make something about it.

I've been spending more than 2 hours on a different project (inspired by the painting "Clear Ideas") but couldn't get anything good from it. I thought it was a great opportunity to check out again the "getting unstuck tip" on the website. 

I tried "Just Keep Going" for a while, but I was feeling more and more frustrated. I was inspired by the "Problem? Opportunity!" but still didn't know how to apply that to my super stuck situation.. Finally reading the "Try Something Different" gave me the courage and confidence to put all my previous work aside and start with a completely new project, and this time I tried to keep it as simple as I could.

I started with a simple painting of the sky, decided to add only one object, and focus on finding a way to use color sensing. I experienced the same problem of @karenb with the painting having many different colors. Then I realized that the different shades of gray of the clouds could become an opportunity to add a bit of randomness.. so the umbrella get stuck only when their handle touches a specific color.

Now it's 2:25am, and I'm exhausted, and joyful, and proud. 
This is not (just) a Scratch project!

Enjoy! :)Click the green flag and be open to be surprised.

title: Unstuck Day 9 - Touch Color
description: I think there are a number of variations possible here, including letting the user navigate the car, and making the maze a little tighter. What would you do differently?
instructions:
Challenge:
Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?).

So this is not really a game, just a way to test out the Touching Color blocks. Here is the goal: The car must reach the green square. It bounces off of black, but the black is occasionally modified by white squares that appear randomly throughout, thus allowing the car to temporarily go through the wall. The car is self-driving. The timer is there to see how long it takes to reach the goal, and after five minutes, the "journey" ends regardless. My lowest time is 27 seconds.

So this is not really a game, just a way to test out the Touching Color blocks. Here is the goal: The car must reach the green square. It bounces off of black, but the black is occasionally modified by white squares that appear randomly throughout, thus allowing the car to temporarily go through the wall. The car is self-driving. The timer is there to see how long it takes to reach the goal, and after five minutes, the "journey" ends regardless. My lowest time is 27 seconds.

title: Touching Colours Effects
description: I hadn't tried getting a flying sprite to fly randomly but to stay upright before this challenge. I had to explore some different sprite abilities for this. I also discovered that the most recently moved sprite was the one that would show on top, until that my bird was going behind the flowers. Now I've got the bird moving in front of the flowers but the bird faces in a different direction with each flap of his wings. If I had more time I would fix that.

title: Unstuck Day 9 - Sensing Color
description: This started as an idea to get a bug to dance, but somehow turned into a game. I want to come back to it and clean it up sometime - I think it has the potential to be a fun little game.
instructions:
The object of the game is to get the bug to the orange from as far away as possible. Once activated the bug will move based on the color of the square it is above. You will have no control once it starts, so you must work backward from the orange and figure out where you can start from! Your score is the distance away from the orange when you start (if you successfully get to the orange!)

Click the Green Flag to create a random background. Move the bug to the square you want to start on (the little grey dot on the bug's back is the sensor) and click the bug to begin. Clicking Space will reset the bug to the center without changing the background.
writing:
This started as an idea to get a bug to dance, but somehow turned into a game. I want to come back to it and clean it up sometime - I think it has the potential to be a fun little game.The object of the game is to get the bug to the orange from as far away as possible. Once activated the bug will move based on the color of the square it is above. You will have no control once it starts, so you must work backward from the orange and figure out where you can start from! Your score is the distance away from the orange when you start (if you successfully get to the orange!)

Click the Green Flag to create a random background. Move the bug to the square you want to start on (the little grey dot on the bug's back is the sensor) and click the bug to begin. Clicking Space will reset the bug to the center without changing the background.

title: Day 9 Getting Unstuck - paint bucket blueout
description:
This is incomplete, but it does use color detection per the Getting Unstuck challenge.

One difficulty I encountered was figuring out how to draw on a sprite with the pen. You can't do that, but you can use a stamp to get the image of a sprite on the backdrop then hide the sprite as suggested at https://scratch.mit.edu/discuss/topic/114508/?page=1#post-1008090.

I might be able to solve the bug by starting the drawing on the mid point of the area to be filled at the same y value where I clicked instead of starting at the click location. I ran out of time to pursue this since there are so many other challenges to try.  There is also another bug that shows up when trying to fill the start that's a little different.
instructions:
Click anywhere to fill all non-black areas of that object with blue. 
This runs painfully slow unless you use enable Turbo Mode (under the Edit menu) before running.

Bug: It does not fill above or below where you click if that area is narrower than where you clicked.

title: Unstuck - Day 9
description:
This was s cool project.  We started with the idea of a magic mitten.  When it would touch different colors something would happen.  We drew the mitten on the Scratch Cat.  The cat is controlled with the arrow keys and when the mitten touches a color on a ball, the background switches.  
Can someone help me with this?
I want to be able to play a zoop sound when the ball is touched, but I can't get it to stop repeating the sound.  The answer is probably obvious.

Use up, down, left, right to move the Scratch Cat to the magic transport balls.  Touch the balls with the red mitten to travel to distant lands.

The red dots are turbo dots - the car will go a bit faster there - be sure to steer!
Make one lap and reach the yellow finish line without crashing good luck.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 9
description: I started this as a basic maze and then I decided to add the inventory items to make it a little more challenging.  Since this was a color activity, they were just color circles otherwise, I would have tried to come up with a theme and used actual items that fit the story of why the main character has to make it through the maze.  If I had more time, I would add problems (math or word problems) when the ball touched each of the color circles.  You would have to get the answer correct to get the credit.  I enjoyed making this project.  Music
instructions: Click on the flag to begin.  Use the arrow keys to move the ball around the maze.  Don't touch the walls or you will have to go back to the beginning!  Make sure you gather all the items in your inventory before you get to the end of the maze.  Have fun!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 9 Reflection:
This was my hardest challenge yet - I restarted this project a few times because I couldn't get it to work.  I think my problem was in choosing backgrounds from the library.  They have more color variation, so trying to make my sprite react to different colors didn't work properly.  This project is a lot simpler than I intended it to be (from a coding standpoint anyway!), but it's also the project I've learned the most from so far.
instructions: Click on play and use the arrow keys to help the mouse get to the cheesy puffs.  But don't touch the walls or you have to start over!
