title: Getting Unstuck - Day 9 : My 2nd attempt!
description:
Okay, the journey to this project was two-fold.  I started by making a basic animation of the cat jumping on the beach background.  When he was touching the color of the sand he would jump and say that it was too hot, then return back to the sand and continue in a loop.  It was very basic, but it completed the challenge of the day.  I knew that I would have preferred to make my own background, like it was suggested in the email, but had never tried it before. 

Then I went to the library with my daughter and discovered the book, "Code Your Own Games" by Max Wainewright and one of the games was the 'Amazing Maze'.  So I had a lot of "help" with this one!  I would suggest drawing out your maze first.  I would also like to figure out how to make the cat bounce off the walls or edges if possible, or add an animation for completing the maze successfully.
instructions:
Click the green arrow to start the maze.

Use the arrow keys to guide Scratch the Cat through the maze.  If you touch any of the walls Scratch will turn around and move back.

Click the green arrow to start over.

It was very basic, but it completed the challenge of the day.  I knew that I would have preferred to make my own background, like it was suggested in the email, but had never tried it before.

title: HexaPaths remix
description:
Remixed from @technoboy10 - this was a bit challenging because I definitely tried to overcomplicate the math involved! Also I often struggle with remixes because sometimes I find it really difficult to really understand someone else's code, and then to make a meaningful change to it...that can definitely be hard. Originally I had thought I might try my hand at some fractals and recursive trees, but that will have to wait for a day that is less busy. 

I learned that if a sprite is covering the slider variables, you can't touch the slider variable (I thought the sliders were always on the top layer, but I guess I'm wrong), and I also found that the way transparency/ghosting was handled in this project to be fairly clever (It's a second sprite layer with a white background). 

Music: http://freemusicarchive.org/music/Chan_Wai_Fat/ - Dream Instrumental
instructions:
Watch the project create random paths and move the slider up and down to change the shape of the polygon.

Changes:
+ added a slider to change the polygon shape
+ added music
+ changed size of polygons (which is somewhat dependent on polygon type)
writing:
Remixed from @technoboy10 - this was a bit challenging because I definitely tried to overcomplicate the math involved! Also I often struggle with remixes because sometimes I find it really difficult to really understand someone else's code, and then to make a meaningful change to it...that can definitely be hard. Originally I had thought I might try my hand at some fractals and recursive trees, but that will have to wait for a day that is less busy. 

I learned that if a sprite is covering the slider variables, you can't touch the slider variable (I thought the sliders were always on the top layer, but I guess I'm wrong), and I also found that the way transparency/ghosting was handled in this project to be fairly clever (It's a second sprite layer with a white background). 

Music: http://freemusicarchive.org/music/Chan_Wai_Fat/ - Dream Instrumental
Watch the project create random paths and move the slider up and down to change the shape of the polygon.

Changes:
+ added a slider to change the polygon shape
+ added music
+ changed size of polygons (which is somewhat dependent on polygon type)

title: Getting Unstuck Day 7: Pattern Maker Remix Remix
description:
For Day 7, I remixed a project that I did with a student last year. @aurorabell taught me a lot about clones and stamping with her original project, and I wanted to see what would happen if I incorporated the pen tool as well. I also learned about defining my own Scratch blocks!

It was fun to revisit this project, because when I made the original remix I don't think I understood all of the code. When I came back to this project, I knew exactly what was going on and was able to modify it to fit what I was envisioning! Thanks, @aurorabell and #GettingUnstuck! :)
instructions:
Press the green flag to start.
Use the arrow keys to make a line pattern! 
Press space to stamp more dots on the page.
Press b to change the background color.
If you want your project to be even weirder, press the "r" key to turn on random mode!

title: The Rainbow Sensorium (Getting Unstuck, Day 7)
description:
I was feeling REALLY creatively stuck today. As I chatted with @mizzpeters and @asparklekat about feeling stuck, @mizzpeters asked me what I was excited about and @asparklekat suggested tinkering. I ended up mashing both of these pieces of advice together to produce this project for Day 7 of Getting Unstuck.

I started out wanting to make a program that printed graph paper. (I'm OBSESSED with graph paper.) After I had programmed the basic grid making, I went back to the Pen category to see what I might tinker around with. That led me to play with the Pen color and the Pen size blocks. The Pen size block really blew the program open for me in terms of creative inspiration and engagement! I abandoned the horizontal line drawing (although the code is still in there), and just kept the vertical line drawing. Tinkering with these streaks of rainbows by varying the grid size feels very engaging and satisfying to me. My equation for today: passion + some tinkering = some new, previously unimagined exploration and fun!
instructions:
Welcome to the Rainbow Sensorium, a place to play with rainbows!
Press the space key to draw streaks of rainbows of different widths.

To speed up the drawing, try it in turbo mode (by pressing the shift key before clicking the green flag). Thank you for the inspiration, @coderangers!

title: 1 Week of Getting Unstuck!
description:
I enjoy how different pieces of the pattern emerge as it's drawn (over)!

Admittedly, my main excitement here was the time-based celebration and not necessarily a celebration of pen-patterns. I LOVE PATTERNS, THO -- I think my excitement about being 1-week in made me stubbornly forget - I'll come back to pattern drawing, for sure. I'd like for questions like "Why a pattern with this concept?" and then "How will I create a pattern?" to be more considered in my process of this project. I'd like to imagine the patterns I'd like to draw and then think of what would be necessary to draw them (or find something more surprising that I also enjoy!)

How are you thinking about the relationship between concept and the day's challenge in your Getting Unstuck projects? 
What are your strategies when you're having a hard time meeting your passions with the day's challenge?

I created my own blocks for the first time! Ultimately I really didn't need to, as I realized I wanted each sprite to draw a different specific color, so really each one is only called on once instead of the initially intended use across sprites. I could've just used the definition script and not created a block. I'd like to think about where it does make sense to create a block to make use of throughout! (:
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, press the space bar for a pen-drawing celebration of 7 days of Getting Unstuck! 

(pattern comes in after each sprite shares)

title: Kaleido!
description:
I almost cheated, as I made another project similar in the past (this one https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/151194070/ ). I'm fascinated by the beautifulness of random patterns just giving a hint of regularity (for example symmetry, or recursivity... like the mandelbrot fractal or bismuth crystals, but also trees or snails).

I stuck in trying to get a 90° direction only, and trying to get unstuck I discovered that the glitched version was giving better looking results than the regular one. So I kept 'em both.
instructions:
The direction of the trails is changed by pointer x and the dimension by the y.

Left/Right = change background
Up/Down = change bg brightness

SPACE = makes movement more or less angular 
Mouse button = changes color

title: Unstuck Day 07 Pen Intro
description:
This is the lesson I use to introduce the pen blocks to students. They have previously created a forever->>move-->bounce on edge script to get the sprite moving around the stage, so now they add pen down and change pen color to make a cool rainbow pattern. 

There are a few different patterns that generate discussion, and when students start plugging other numbers in the change pen color by block that makes for a new burst of excitement. They love being able to control what happens, even if they aren't sure exactly why their changes have a specific effect. The big idea is that they are controlling the action through code.

Additional extensions include creating key events to change pen size and clear the stage while the main script is running. Instead of randomizing the beginning direction, younger students go under the hood of the sprite and manually drag the blue direction line to a starting angle.
instructions:
The green flag erases the design and centers the cat.

Space key begins the cat on a drawing journey around the stage.

What cool design will your cat make?

instructions:

Use the a to stop all and then keep going, or take a photo to use as a bkg!

Press and hold two keys at once and see what happens :)

I'm not sure if the left arrow key brightens the lines but it is supposed to.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 7 — Sine Crawlers
description:
Reflection

The task was to use the "pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage." For this example, I decided to use sine waves. To accomplish this, I utilized the sin operator block. Local variables and clones were needed to create autonomous agents that walk across the screen while generating the sine wave patterns.

If I spent more time on this, I would play with more modulations to get a more interesting pattern.
instructions: Click the green flag and watch as the image emerges.
writing:
Reflection

The task was to use the "pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage." For this example, I decided to use sine waves. To accomplish this, I utilized the sin operator block. Local variables and clones were needed to create autonomous agents that walk across the screen while generating the sine wave patterns.

If I spent more time on this, I would play with more modulations to get a more interesting pattern.Click the green flag and watch as the image emerges.

title: Magic Pencil! - GettingUnstuck#7
description:
Getting Unstuck challenge/activity #7 - "Create a project that uses the Pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage."

First pattern was accidentally created when trying to make a basic circle. But I just went with it and made adjustments to see what other patterns could be made.

Improvements would be to make some of the variables set via user input so that the user could experiment.  Also needs a "Try another pattern?" button rather than relying on using flag to restart.
instructions: Click the flag to start or reset (to pick another pattern)

title: Getting Unstuck Day 7
description:
I love generative art. I just threw a few blocks together, starting with a simple random walk with the pen down and it evolved into this over about 15 minutes!

Try changing the initial colour and the values set for "dist" and "angle" at the start of the script. You could display the values or change the variables to sliders on the stage to try to understand and adjust the action.

Run without turbo mode set to follow the action in slow motion.

If I had more time I'd have experimented even further and maybe ended up with a totally different effect.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 7

Create a project that uses the Pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage. 

USE TURBO MODE - HOLD SHIFT AND CLICK GREEN FLAG THEN RELEASE SHIFT AND CLICK GREEN FLAG AGAIN TO RUN

title: Curved Lines (day-7)
description:
Getting Unstuck Day-7
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I use Pen blocks to draw straight lines according to a mathematical rule. Despite the fact that the lines are all straight, the overall figure seems curved as an equilateral hyperbola is formed.

To make more readable the code I used a custom block that perform the drawing of a single line given the coordinates of the two ends.

The drawing is made by a Sprite (which is hidden). The click on the Stage is notified to the Sprite by means of a broadcast message.

Revision - I added some improvements to the drawing: the pen color is changed at each line and lines are wider.
instructions:
Click on the screen or press the green flag to see the drawing take shape.

You will see a series of straight lines giving the illusion of a curve (equilateral hyperbola).

title: Sunflower spiral
description:
The sunflower spiral is a pattern seen in several the arrangement of leaves in plants (known as phyllotaxis), and is in connections to the Fibonacci sequence and Fibonacci angle that is 137.5°

Its funny to see different patterns created by different angles.
You can set different colors while drawing

ver2: manual color selection and clear screen on/off
instructions:
click on the numbers (angles) on the left to see different spirals pattern, or use MANUAL INPUT to insert different angle's value 
**COLORS**
AUTO: change color automatically
To choose the pen color click on single bock-color on the right
**CLEAR SCREEN**
CLEAR OFF:  leaves all the previous drawings on the screen
CLEAR ON: cleans the screen before new drawing starts

title: Speed Lines Experiment
description:
I'm new to using the 'stamp' pen block, so I started out trying to make a stamping project. Remembering how wooden block stamps never make a perfect impression, I made a costume-less sprite (Eraser) to bounce around and use the 'pen' block to remove pixels from the stamp. While playing around with this, I noticed the stamps started disappearing in a cool way, so I abandoned my original idea and imported the Eraser sprite to a project I had already made with my son.

(credit to the boy for insisting that Scratch Cat be blue and make a horse sound when the '2' key is pressed)
instructions: Use the arrow keys to fly Scratch Cat around the screen.
writing:
I'm new to using the 'stamp' pen block, so I started out trying to make a stamping project. title: GU_Day7
description:
Today I looked at many projects before beginning. There is so much to learn by just being curious! 
Since the theme of the day is patterns, I decided to visualize a pattern that is found in nature - the Fibonacci Spiral. I sketched out squares: 1-1-2-3-5-8-13. I saw the relationship of a quarter circle being inscribed within each square. Then I needed to figure out how to code for each desired radius. 
I notice that when the scale = 1, then I can make the number of repeats as high as 9. When the scale = 20, only 5 repeats will fit on the screen.
instructions:
I learned about Turbo Mode today. Hold the shift key before you press the green flag. 
Use the scale slider to choose how small or large to draw a Fibonacci Spiral.

title: Shapes -- Unstuck Challenge 7
description:
Figuring out the angles and number of steps for the shapes was a good math exercise!

I would like to work more on getting the sprite animations a little smoother while still drawing (especially on the first figure), and I think I might like to randomize the pen color for each figure (maybe even randomize the shape each time they draw -- but I think that would require a little more time investment than I have right now!)

title: Rhodonea Curve
description: The first mention of this curve is the Florentine monk Guido Grandi in two letters to Leibniz in December 1713 and calls it "rhodonea", from the Greek. ῥόδον - "rose"). Ten years later he published an article about her in The Philosophical Works of the Royal Society, where he examined varieties of this curve with a different number of petals and also called them " rose-shaped". Five years later, Guido Grandi developed the theory of rose-shaped curves in a separate work.
instructions:
Moving the cursor, select the desired shape. 
By clicking the mouse button you confirm that you want to draw this shape
(Note: indicate the color square in which the figure is located, and not the figure itself - the color matters)
Key "space" - stop the drawing and hide the pencil
Key "m" - show the menu

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 7 (pen)
description:
I'm really excited about this project! I've seen pen patterns forever, but I've never created one myself. I wanted to challenge myself to make something on my own before I looked at others' projects or copied over code, and figured out how to do what I wanted to do after a few tries, moving carefully through the code to understand what was going on and write what I wanted it to do.

I decided to define my own blocks to make the code easier for later remixing :)
instructions: Click the green flag to draw a rainbow circle pattern!

title: Getting Unstuck 7
description:
I wanted to incorporate my love of knitting into at least one of these challenges! I programmed the pen to draw the knit stitches stitch by stitch and row by row, then I added the knitting needles. I tried to use Make a Block, repeats, and variables to keep the program as efficient as possible.

The only trouble I had was in getting the needles to be empty of stitches on the first row, then to have stitches on each subsequent row. I ended up creating a variable to keep track of whether it was the first row or not and use that to determine which costumes the needles were showing.

The program is also kind of slow (or maybe meditative? Perhaps I should add some soothing music...(UPDATE: Music added!)). I could adjust the speed on the stitches' turns by doing fewer repeats with a sharper turning angle, but this would also change the shape of the stitches and I kind of like them the way they are.

Music is Good Thoughts by Lobo Loco from the Free Music Archive.
instructions:
Click the green flag to fill the screen with knitting. You can press shift while clicking the green flag to run it in turbo mode, which will create the whole pattern very quickly, as the regular mode is pretty slow. This does make the animation of the needles kind of go away though - I wish there was an in-between!

Also sometimes you need to click the green flag twice to get the needles to start moving? Not sure why.

The only trouble I had was in getting the needles to be empty of stitches on the first row, then to have stitches on each subsequent row. I ended up creating a variable to keep track of whether it was the first row or not and use that to determine which costumes the needles were showing.

The program is also kind of slow (or maybe meditative? Perhaps I should add some soothing music...(UPDATE: Music added!)). I could adjust the speed on the stitches' turns by doing fewer repeats with a sharper turning angle, but this would also change the shape of the stitches and I kind of like them the way they are.

description: Today I "wanted" to draw a star and then continue the drawing to create a spirograph type figure.  I found several tutorials, but got bogged down watching YouTube. I'm so glad to be working on these challenges this week because my coding club next week will be doing similar challenges.  It's always good to experience activities as a student!

title: Unstuck Day 7 - Calming Star
description:
Challenge: use the pen block to draw a pattern on the stage
I wanted to make a project that relaxed someone when he viewed it.
I used the pen to draw the lines which always start at 0,0. I used the random block to choose the 2nd coordinate of the line. I would have liked to use more relaxing music. The music I used is from the sound library, but I made it longer by copying and pasting the original clip into the audio file editor.

Update: I tried to add some calming music from Freesound.org, but the file wouldn't upload. So I made a simple musical pattern using a flutes.

title: Drunk Bear
description:
This was my attempt at addressing the Scratch Day 7 challenge, using the pen blocks. I had a couple things I couldn't figure out how to do... if anyone out there feels like lending a helping hand and giving me feedback, I'd appreciate it!
(1) Any idea how to remove the white background of the beer can (which seemed to be transparent when I found the image)?
(2) Instead of having the bear wildly meander when the user hits the space bar, I'd love to have this action initiated when the user walks the bear into the beer can (ie, the sprites touch).
(3) There seems to be a problem with having everything reset when hitting the "c" key -- it requires that it be clicked on two times. What's that all about? Also, is there a way to get the bear to revert to its original angle (straight, not tilted)?
THANKS IN ADVANCE!
instructions: Make the bear walk in different directions with the up, down, left and right arrows. Hit "space" to let him ramble around. Hit "c" to restart.
writing:
This was my attempt at addressing the Scratch Day 7 challenge, using the pen blocks. I had a couple things I couldn't figure out how to do... if anyone out there feels like lending a helping hand and giving me feedback, I'd appreciate it!
(1) Any idea how to remove the white background of the beer can (which seemed to be transparent when I found the image)?
(2) Instead of having the bear wildly meander when the user hits the space bar, I'd love to have this action initiated when the user walks the bear into the beer can (ie, the sprites touch).
(3) There seems to be a problem with having everything reset when hitting the "c" key -- it requires that it be clicked on two times. What's that all about? Also, is there a way to get the bear to revert to its original angle (straight, not tilted)?
THANKS IN ADVANCE!Make the bear walk in different directions with the up, down, left and right arrows. Hit "space" to let him ramble around. Hit "c" to restart.

title: Unstuck Day 7 Rushing
description:
Using the More Blocks feature in Scratch, you can create a new block (Function) and define the rule that applies to that block.  If you look inside, you will see functions for various shapes and the rules that define them. 
Can you remix this and make your own design? 
What additional shapes can you make by creating more FUNCTIONS?
instructions:

Click the  Space Key to Clear the screen.

title: Unstuck Day 7 - Pen Blocks
description:
Try as I might, I could not get the cat to leave the black square. It seemed odd because although I had the cat return to x=0 and y=0 at the beginning of the program, it did not return there between scribbles. I had it start a subsequent scribble from wherever it left off on the previous one. 

Answer: Because the glide command currently keeps the cat to -100 and 100 in both X and Y directions, the travel range is limited. Thank you Scratch Community!
instructions:
Challenge:
Create a project that uses the Pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage. 

Hit the space bar to see a random scribble created by Scratch cat. Hit the space bar again to create a new one.
writing:
Try as I might, I could not get the cat to leave the black square. It seemed odd because although I had the cat return to x=0 and y=0 at the beginning of the program, it did not return there between scribbles. I had it start a subsequent scribble from wherever it left off on the previous one. 

Answer: Because the glide command currently keeps the cat to -100 and 100 in both X and Y directions, the travel range is limited. Thank you Scratch Community!
Challenge:
Create a project that uses the Pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage. 

Hit the space bar to see a random scribble created by Scratch cat. Hit the space bar again to create a new one.

title: Getting Unstuck #7
description: I originally had a very different idea for this, but just couldn't figure out how to do it. If I had more time I'd like to make sure that users couldn't put in fewer than 3 or more than 10 sides, or more than 100 instances. I'm going to have to look into how to do this. I tried a few different ways and couldn't figure it out.
instructions:
Just pop in the values for sides and instances. Sides are best if they're 9 or fewer, and instances will be best under 100.

V2.0 I've added sliders thanks to @visionsbyvicky. Much nicer.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 7 Activity
description:
This is my project for Day 7 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge.

By using a black background this is a little like a scratch off art activity where you cover a sheet of paper with colours and then add black ink all over it and then scratch off a design.

After @alirb left a comment I tried again with this and now you are able to move the ball to a different spot with the pen up. There is still a bug when you put the pen down again but I am getting there.
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin the program.
Press the space bar to start drawing with the ball.
Press and hold the D key to have the pen down.
Move the mouse to draw.
Press and hold the L key to move the ball without drawing.
Press the s key to stop drawing.
writing:

By using a black background this is a little like a scratch off art activity where you cover a sheet of paper with colours and then add black ink all over it and then scratch off a design.

After @alirb left a comment I tried again with this and now you are able to move the ball to a different spot with the pen up. There is still a bug when you put the pen down again but I am getting there. Click the green flag to begin the program.

Press and hold the D key to have the pen down.
Move the mouse to draw.
Press and hold the L key to move the ball without drawing.
Press the s key to stop drawing.

title: Rainbow Lines
description:
I've made different versions of this project in the past. I was tempted to post one of my old ones, but I wanted to make something new. With this one I tried to keep the code as simple as possible, while making interesting drawings.

I love when the line make a curve, if I had more time I would try to understand how to make the points bounce in a way that generates more of those nice curves. I would also add some music, I guess something like a theremin would sound good.

Feel free to remix and enjoy!
instructions: Click the green flag and enjoy watching your computer drawing!
writing:
I've made different versions of this project in the past. I was tempted to post one of my old ones, but I wanted to make something new. With this one I tried to keep the code as simple as possible, while making interesting drawings.

I love when the line make a curve, if I had more time I would try to understand how to make the points bounce in a way that generates more of those nice curves. I would also add some music, I guess something like a theremin would sound good.

title: Getting Unstuck #7.3
description:
I've redone this so that it now has sliders, but the length of the sides also changes in a Fibonacci sequence. It doesn't look as good, but figuring out the arithmetic was a bit of fun.
Now the length of the sides is 1,1,2,3,5, etc. It's a great illustration of how quickly they add up to big numbers.
instructions:
Just pop in the values for sides and instances. Sides are best if they're 9 or fewer, and instances will be best under 100.

V2.0 I've added sliders thanks to @visionsbyvicky. Much nicer.
writing:
I've redone this so that it now has sliders, but the length of the sides also changes in a Fibonacci sequence. It doesn't look as good, but figuring out the arithmetic was a bit of fun.
Now the length of the sides is 1,1,2,3,5, etc. It's a great illustration of how quickly they add up to big numbers. Just pop in the values for sides and instances. Sides are best if they're 9 or fewer, and instances will be best under 100.

V2.0 I've added sliders thanks to @visionsbyvicky. Much nicer.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 7
description:
I started this project originally as an assignment for my students.  We started with just drawing a triangle.  Then we added the "sides" slider.  I added the other user options to make it more interesting.  The most difficult part of the project for my students was the math.

What I'd like to add is a way to disable the arrow buttons while the witch is drawing.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 7: Create a project that uses the Pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage. 

Use the Green Flag to clear the page.
Use the space bar to have the witch draw shapes specified by the slider settings. 
Use the arrow keys to move the witch around the screen between drawings.

title: Day 7:  Oh Happy Day!
description:
I saw a drawing pencil sprite like this many years ago and always wanted to try it.  To make it look like the pencil was drawing, I put the crosshairs of the sprite on the tip of the pencil.  I also used a chain reaction type broadcast scheme.

It's a little obsessive, but I enjoyed figuring out a good strategy for doing this (I drew a background with the words, traced them with glides, then erased the background).

I also learned that there is a limit to the number of blocks under a hat!  I had to break up "Happy" under three broadcast blocks.

Music is Etta James singing "Oh Happy Day!"
instructions: just press the green arrow
writing:

title: Getting Unstuck Day 7
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 7 Reflection:
I think my project looks cool while it's running - I like that the colors gradually change as it's overwriting itself.  I don't like that there's a flaw somewhere in the hexagon code, so it messes up a side, but using a forever loop covers that up.  If I had more time I would troubleshoot that more - it's been driving me crazy!  :)
instructions: Press the green flag to start drawing a hexagonal spirograph.  Press the spare bar to clear the stage.
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 7 Reflection:
I think my project looks cool while it's running - I like that the colors gradually change as it's overwriting itself.  I don't like that there's a flaw somewhere in the hexagon code, so it messes up a side, but using a forever loop covers that up.  If I had more time I would troubleshoot that more - it's been driving me crazy!  :)Press the green flag to start drawing a hexagonal spirograph.  Press the spare bar to clear the stage.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 7
description:
Again, like my work for an earlier project, I am inspired by Seymour Papert's work with Logo.
I love making patterns like this. It's something to do with the regularity of it I think! I used to love the Spirograph toy when I was younger.
I'm planning on adding some sort of input, maybe using loudness to change the thickness of the line or perhaps adding a random element. I did something like this at the conference at MIT in 2016.
instructions: Click the Green Flag to go!

Again, like my work for an earlier project, I am inspired by Seymour Papert's work with Logo.
I love making patterns like this. It's something to do with the regularity of it I think! I used to love the Spirograph toy when I was younger.
I'm planning on adding some sort of input, maybe using loudness to change the thickness of the line or perhaps adding a random element. I did something like this at the conference at MIT in 2016.Click the Green Flag to go!

title: coral reef - Getting Unstuck day 7
description:
This time I was inspired by https://speechfoodie.com/fractal-trees/

I wanted a little less regular and deterministic appearance and then coral reef was born.

I'm not fully happy at the result but I think it is a nice starting point for future remixes. The execution is too heavy for not so high values of height but the result looks enough natural to me.

Credits go to 

https://speechfoodie.com/fractal-trees/

Even if it is not a proper remix, I would like to thanks  OriginallySystemized [1] for the RGB Color Detector project[2]

It was fundamental to comprehend how to generate a random color

[1]: https://scratch.mit.edu/users/OriginallySystemized/  
[2]: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/157358820/
instructions:
Press green flag to start a new reef 
Press space to grow a new coral 
Press B to see an appropriate background (though I prefer the white one)
Press W slightly change the corals appearance.

title: Pinwheel (Getting Unstuck #7)
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 7
Create a project that uses the Pen blocks to automatically draw a pattern on the stage. 

Up until now I had some idea of how to do the daily projects. Then came day 7. I've never used the Pen blocks before, today's task was completely new to me!

Didn't take to long to figure out a square. So my next challenge was to see what other shapes I could create...making a triangle wasn't as easy as I thought. This is a great way to explore and discuss angles and cartesian plane in elementary math.

Finally, produced a rainbow pinwheel!
instructions: Click the down arrow to get Scratch cat to create a rainbow pinwheel. Use the space key to clear the screen.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 7
description:
Today's challenge was to use the pen block to create a pattern.

I knew that I wanted something to be drawing a geometric pattern, so I had to find two sprites that would go together.  Then it took me a few tries to get the sprite to move slow enough to be viewable while drawing.  Then I had to experiment with the turning angles and repeat blocks to get it to return to the middle.
instructions:
Click the green arrow and the wizard will create a pattern with his magic wand!

Click the space bar to clear the pattern and start over.

title: Spiraling flowers
description:
Getting Unstuck - Day 7
My hope was to figure out how to generate an "even" looking spiral to use in a pattern, but I got stuck on this 12-petalled flower. :)  I thought a spiral's angle might change with each step, but it seems to not be done with a constant amount of decrease.

For now, I am posting this as a draft -- I have an idea still to try, so perhaps I am somewhere between stuck and unstuck at the moment...!?
instructions:
Create designs using a spiral-like flower, varying sizes as you go.
Click green flag to clear and reset.
Click red flag to stop.
Use up and down arrows change the flower size from .5 to 5 (step size is 0.1).
Click the background to place a flower.
For a quicker run, turn on turbo mode.

title: Spiraling Spiraling
description:
I used 'Spiralizer' in the book Coding Projects in Scratch: A Step-by-Step Visual Guide to Coding Your Own Animations, Games, Simulations, and More! by Jon Woodcock @RoboSquid to help me with my project.

I used clones, variables, and drawing with the pen.  It was a fun project and I learned some things that I hadn't known before - slider control on the stage variables and destroying clones.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to begin.

Change to the Angle and Speed sliders to experiment.

Click Space Bar to clear all.

title: DIY Poketown
description:
I had originally though to recreate a more complex town and built out the background using Adobe Illustrator, but once I realized how complicated the code would be (so that buildings didn't land on streets), I pared it down. Reused what I learned about sprites walking in yesterday's project for today's. Only some of the buildings move around, and they mostly don't land on each other or on the street, but it's still a little buggy. 

Got lots of help from the Scratch Forum for figuring out how to stop one sound and turn another one on!

Credits:
Music: KHInsider.com (Pokemon Ruby/Sapphire soundtracks)
Sprites: Spriters-Resource.com (Pokemon background)
instructions: Press space to randomize town buildings, s/w to turn on a season (summer or winter, with snowflakes/music), and arrow keys to navigate May around town.
writing:
I had originally though to recreate a more complex town and built out the background using Adobe Illustrator, but once I realized how complicated the code would be (so that buildings didn't land on streets), I pared it down. Only some of the buildings move around, and they mostly don't land on each other or on the street, but it's still a little buggy.

Press space to randomize town buildings, s/w to turn on a season (summer or winter, with snowflakes/music), and arrow keys to navigate May around town.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 6 - Fortunes!
description: I had a really fun time learning about the list function with this project! I wasn't quite sure how to do it, but after some tinkering it all worked out! I'm still a bit confused about how to let the cookie flow more fluidly to the other edge while also being able to let the scuba diver intercept it. I also learned one way to do a scroll effect :D
instructions:
Press space to start the game
Use up arrow or down to move the scuba diver
Catch a fortune!!

title: Random
description:
This project was created for day 6 of Getting Stuck. I started by importing the cloning logic from my day 4 project using the Scratch backpack feature. Then, I tried to imagine the most random thing that I could make with 300 clones. Et voila!

I was surprised to lose an argument with a friend recently about whether or not clones can have their own private data. They can! This technique is very helpful with clones. I hope that my friend is surprised and delighted by the (random) fruit of our discussion.

Music: Metre, "Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability"
instructions: Turn up the sound, go full screen, and enjoy the randomness! The running time of the show is about 60 seconds.
writing:
This project was created for day 6 of Getting Stuck. I started by importing the cloning logic from my day 4 project using the Scratch backpack feature. Then, I tried to imagine the most random thing that I could make with 300 clones. Et voila!

I was surprised to lose an argument with a friend recently about whether or not clones can have their own private data. They can! This technique is very helpful with clones. I hope that my friend is surprised and delighted by the (random) fruit of our discussion.

Music: Metre, "Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability"Turn up the sound, go full screen, and enjoy the randomness! The running time of the show is about 60 seconds.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 6: Dress-Up Game
description:
I've wondered how dress-up games work for a while. Today's challenge was to use the random block, so I made the colors change randomly... although I'm not really sure that's very fun for the user.

If I had more time, I'd add more costumes and I'd add options for changing hair style, hair color, and skin tone separately, and maybe even a bar where you can control the color of each clothing item. I also thought about learning how to make words scroll out onto the page (like @jsh's flower project) but decided I'll have to wait for another day.

I started with the fashion tutorial (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/editor/?tip_bar=fashion) but quickly ventured into making my own items. I struggled a lot with the paint editor doing what I wanted, but I'm happy with my final product!
instructions:
Welcome to my first dress-up game!
Click on the clothing items on the left side of the screen to change the item.
Click on Dani to change their hairstyle and skin tone.
Click on Dani's clothes to change colors.
Click on the accessories on the right side of the screen to add them. Click on the accessory again to delete.

title: Find the Random Cat! (Getting Unstuck, Day 6)
description:
I've wanted to learn more about cloning, so I used today's Getting Unstuck prompt to combine randomness with an investigation of cloning.

The big surprise? Clones can maintain their own variables! (I was also surprised by how little code this actually took!)

If I had more time, I think I would want to explore other ways of using this particular design. Quiz show? Escape room? I'd love to hear what you might do!
instructions:
The Scratch Cat has gathered four friends to test your visual acuity. Can you spot which cat is the random cat?

Press the Green Flag to start playing!
writing:
I've wanted to learn more about cloning, so I used today's Getting Unstuck prompt to combine randomness with an investigation of cloning.

The big surprise? Clones can maintain their own variables! (I was also surprised by how little code this actually took!)

If I had more time, I think I would want to explore other ways of using this particular design. Quiz show? Escape room? I'd love to hear what you might do!The Scratch Cat has gathered four friends to test your visual acuity. Can you spot which cat is the random cat?

Press the Green Flag to start playing!

title: oddportunity
description:
Problem --> Opportunity --> Oddportunity

Inspired by a conversation with a friend during which the word oddportunity came into our lives, I decided to turn all the scripts which weren't working in the process of creating my Day 5 project, along with some of my verbal responses throughout, into randomly-generated representations.

I'd like to play with more ways of randomizing how the scripts and sounds are represented. (:
I'd also clean it up much more -- the stray pixels are mildly maddening.
instructions: After pressing the green flag, use the space bar to switch things up!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 6 — Snow
description:
Reflection

I learned something new about the random block: It can output integers or floating point numbers. For example, this will select a whole number from 1 through 10:

(pick random (1) to (10))

If a decimal values are used as parameters then a decimal value is returned. For example, the following will produce a number between 0.0 and 1.0:

(pick random (0.0) to (1.0))

However, I also just learned that decimal numbers with a .0 are truncated to whole numbers when the projected is loaded back up. So there's a bug in Scratch. To get around this, instead of using -1.0 and 1.0 for the jitter, I set the value range to -1.1 and 1.1, which keeps the values from truncating. I also used 4.9 and 16.1 for generating the size of the snowflakes.

More on the random block at the wiki:
https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Pick_Random_()_to_()_(block)

As for this project, the random block is used twice. First, it is used to randomly generate the size of a snowflake. Second, it is used to add jitter as it falls to the ground.
instructions: Use the slider to control the wind.

title: Moon Dance
description:
Inspired by the Getting Unstuck Challenges.  I'm a little bit behind so I combined Day 1 and Day 6. 

My big surprise today? Having everything freeze up when I tried to add sound.  I fell victim to the ever-present danger of not saving early and saving often. Lost a bunch of scripts and had to re-do them.  

Two programming challenges that my brain is not ready for this morning: 1- getting the music to stop if a key is pressed 2- Getting the sprites to move away from each other when they touch.  Right now, there are a lot of random scripts and eventually, they stop touching.
instructions: Just press the green flag to start.

title: Random Draw Unstuck #6
description:
To create the design I used a code from when I first learned Logo a very long time ago. The sprite draws a line, retraces that line and then turns. The turn multiplied by the number of repeats will equal 360. You can get different effects by changing the the repeats and turns as long as it is equal to 360. 

The color effect took me longer than I expected. At first I kept getting dull browns and blacks. I played around and finally added set pen shade to 50 and that gave me the brighter colors I was looking for.
instructions: Click on the wizard to begin. A design is drawn in random colors and sizes and also in random locations around the screen. The background color changes randomly as well.
writing:
To create the design I used a code from when I first learned Logo a very long time ago. The sprite draws a line, retraces that line and then turns. The turn multiplied by the number of repeats will equal 360. You can get different effects by changing the the repeats and turns as long as it is equal to 360. 

The color effect took me longer than I expected. At first I kept getting dull browns and blacks. I played around and finally added set pen shade to 50 and that gave me the brighter colors I was looking for.Click on the wizard to begin. title: Monty Hall Problem (GettingUnstuck#6)
description:
Getting Unstuck challenge/activity#6 - "create a project that uses the random block"

When I read "random" I immediately thought of the Monty Hall problem for some reason (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monty_Hall_problem) . 

The use of random is limited to randomly selecting an initial door and then randomly selecting one of the two remaining non-winning doors if the initial selection is the winner.

So while random isn't use much I really liked the idea and it took me into some new territory e.g.:
- using "define" to build a block to reset on first clicking the flag and clicking a "try again" option.
- using messages to make actions on one sprite affect others.

Improved version which calculates win percentages can be found at https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236138150/
instructions:
Click the flag to start and the click on the doors to select a choice. Can you find the door the "prize" is behind?

There may be some bugs if you click too fast or click doors once complete (but I think I sorted most of them).
writing:
Getting Unstuck challenge/activity#6 - "create a project that uses the random block"

When I read "random" I immediately thought of the Monty Hall problem for some reason (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monty_Hall_problem) . 

The use of random is limited to randomly selecting an initial door and then randomly selecting one of the two remaining non-winning doors if the initial selection is the winner.

So while random isn't use much I really liked the idea and it took me into some new territory e.g.:
- using "define" to build a block to reset on first clicking the flag and clicking a "try again" option.
- using messages to make actions on one sprite affect others.

Improved version which calculates win percentages can be found at https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236138150/Click the flag to start and the click on the doors to select a choice. Can you find the door the "prize" is behind?

There may be some bugs if you click too fast or click doors once complete (but I think I sorted most of them).

title: day 6 - Guess My Colors
description:
In this game the program randomly generates an urn containing balls of different colors, the urn might contain more than one ball of the same color. We have balls of eleven different colors: white, yellow, orange, red, pink, purple, green, blue, brown, black, grey.

The game has two level, on the first level the urn is composed of 5 to 9 balls, in the second level there are 10-15 balls.

Your task is to guess what’s inside the urn by counting the occurrence of colors in the extractions. Note that extractions are nondestructive, i.e. once extracted a ball is reintroduced in the urn.

For example, 300 extractions from an urn (containing: 3 red balls, 1 black, 1 yellow, and 1 purple) might result in: 150 red, 56 black, 47 yellow, 47 purple. To guess the colors in the urn the player ought to construct the following list [red, red, red, black, yellow, purple].

Experimenting with random generators might be fun if you can automatize the extractions and the process of counting what has been extracted.
instructions:
Start by extracting (click the "Extract" button), than click "Count".

Click on the dice to construct the list of colors in the urn (see below for a description of the game). 

Note that to edit this list you should be in edit mode. Click"See inside"and the green flag.

Start by extracting (click the "Extract" button), than click "Count".

Click on the dice to construct the list of colors in the urn (see below for a description of the game). 

Note that to edit this list you should be in edit mode. Click"See inside"and the green flag.

title: Infection
description: When I saw that the challenge was randomness I immediately thought that I wanted to do something with perlin noise. After looking through a bunch of examples in the gallery of folks implementing perlin noise in Scratch I decided that in the interest of time I would need to remix an existing implementation, which didn't feel super satisfying. Instead I fell back on another one of my favorite applications for randomness, modeling and simulation. This quick and dirty sim models the spread of infection.

title: GettingUnstuck-06 - PI Calculator
description:
Today my plans were really confused: I wanted to generate procedurally random trees, then snowflakes, then I was prone to generate random sequences and test their randomness. Then time went by and I did just this...
A lot of reflection indeed.
It took me really long to realize that cloning dots was a REALLY bad idea...
instructions:
Green flag to start.
Random dots are thrown on the ground to compute Pi with the MonteCarlo method.
This is a classical recipe to approximate PI (or alternatively to state how random are the random dots) on which I cannot take any credit.

title: Getting Unstuck 6
description:
source for faces: https://dribbble.com/shots/2064451-Dudes-part-2/attachments/369543

This one was a little ambitious. I chose to make a Guess Who game where both the player and the Scratch cat choose a face, then ask & answer questions to narrow down the choices until they can guess which face the other chose. The randomness is incorporated in two places: which face the Scratch Cat chooses and the order in which the questions are asked.

It's a work-in-progress. Right now the cat asks the questions, but the way he does it doesn't quite work. There should be 5 questions total, enough to narrow down the choices to 1, and he should ask different questions until that happens. Unfortunately he asks the same questions multiple times, and he doesn't ask all the questions. I could have him ask them in the same order every time, but that would make the playing field uneven - depending on which face was chosen, either the cat or the player would have an advantage, and if you knew which face to pick you could win every time (unless the cat picked the same face). 

I'm sharing as a draft because, well, I have to go make dinner now. But I'll try to fix it later.

UPDATE: I fixed the question issue, so it asks each question once. The code I had to do that was mostly fine, but the block that reset the counting variable used to iterate over the list was in the wrong place.

New issue: it's not eliminating the correct faces in response to the player's answers to the questions. I think this is, again, a list-related problem. I'm currently running the program with the faces list displayed to see what's going on.

Again, the code to reset the counting variable was in the wrong place. I fixed that, but it's still not eliminating the right faces.

UPDATE 2: IT WORKS!! I used this project from ListWizard: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/11260012/#editor to see an example of how to delete items from a list. I needed to change the variable that iterates through the list by -1 after deleting the item. I think I get why, since the length of the list has now changed, but I'm not 100% percent sure why it works.
instructions: Click the green flag to start the game.

title: Catch the creatures!
description:
---Reflect---

At first I had though to recreate a more complex velcro dart board game, but after a while I realized that it could be difficult how to throw the balls in a realistic way.
So, I decided to create a mini game where you use the mouse to catch creatures that appears randomly. 
You can also get different points depending on the section.
I also decided to use the list block to add what kind of creature we finally catch.

                                          ---Credits---
- Music: Sound effects 1 and 12 are from "Dunk Hunt" video game ost.
- Art design: I've created characters and backgrounds with the Scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Press the green flag.
Use the mouse to catch all the creatures without pressing it.
Try to get as many creatures and points as you can.
You have 20 seconds!!
Enjoy it!

                            --Getting Unstuck Day 6--
Today, on Day 6 of Getting Unstuck, we'll be exploring the element of surprise and the unexpected through randomness.
Create a project that uses the random block.

title: Griddle me this: Getting Unstuck Day 6 Random
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 6 Random

Creativity:
I had already used random variables (by chance) in yesterday's project, so I wanted to go a bit further in my exploration of HOW random variables can influence a project. To fully grasp the effect of randomness, you need a large sample size... so I made sure to have lots of clones of a sprite, each random in some way.

Production:
I decided to test changing three different variables for a single sprite. There is also the question of HOW the randomness affects those variables. So, I ended up having 9 different conditions, so that's 9 nested "if-then" loops. I was helped by a fellow Scratcher's observations that variables can be different for each clone of a sprite, so I didn't have to figure out how to duplicate a whole bunch of variables 165 times (or more!).

Getting Unstuck:
I actually got "pre-unstuck" by thinking about what I wanted to achieve and then looking through some similar projects before getting started. Because I knew what I wanted to do, I was able to hone in on strategies that I felt would be useful for my project.
I did want to go further, by examining how to apply the random effects to each element in the grid, or the same random effect to all of the elements at once, or to some subset of the grid, for example, row-by-row. However, that would have meant at least three more conditions to test, for at least 27 overall... Ooof! Maybe another time.
instructions: Hit the green flag! Use the space bar and up arrow to experiment.

title: GU_Day6
description:
Today I storyboarded before starting. (Yesterday I just started messing around and let my playfulness guide me.) My project is different from some of my original ideas. (I wanted a superhero character to fly in and save the day.)
The project uses 5 different random commands.
Making the lists was quite easy. I kept the StrategyName list visible when I was creating sprite costumes to make sure that each costume number corresponded with the list number. (In the end, I didn't use that list in the code.)
I figured out the geometry of a superhero logo and coded the pen to create one.
I decided to drag and organize my sprites in order of their appearance.

title: Bonita's Favorite Fruit
description: I'm having trouble ending the game. I tried sending a message EndGame and then having sprites receive the message and stop all scripts or stop all scripts in this sprite. I tried just adding the end elements to the scripts, but nothing quite works. I'd like the dog animation to stop, the dog to say you win, and to change the background to a different background. I also wonder if I could put the shoes as a costume of the fruit sprite, rather than as a separate sprite. I couldn't figure out how to make the shoes separate to target them for different point values, so I made them a separate sprite, though I think it's possible, maybe I'd have to make a variable for them.
instructions: Press the green flag to start. Use the arrow keys to move the dog to the sprites, Bonita is HUNGRY. You must score 5 points. Be careful, not all items are suitable for eating!!!!
writing: I'm having trouble ending the game. I tried sending a message EndGame and then having sprites receive the message and stop all scripts or stop all scripts in this sprite. I tried just adding the end elements to the scripts, but nothing quite works. I'd like the dog animation to stop, the dog to say you win, and to change the background to a different background. I also wonder if I could put the shoes as a costume of the fruit sprite, rather than as a separate sprite. I couldn't figure out how to make the shoes separate to target them for different point values, so I made them a separate sprite, though I think it's possible, maybe I'd have to make a variable for them.Press the green flag to start. title: Challenge6HotPotato
description: Fixed. The remix is here: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236238818/
instructions: This is supposed to be a hot potato game. The "random" block is in the color of the ball. When the ball turns pink, the sprite that has the ball at that point, disappears. What I can't figure out is how to continue so that the ball does not get thrown to the person who is out. You'll find a whole lot of extraneous variables as I tried various things, but none of it worked. I suspect I'm being too complicated, as usual. There is probably something very simple I have not seen. If anyone can figure out my issue, please let me know.
writing: Fixed. The remix is here: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236238818/ This is supposed to be a hot potato game. The "random" block is in the color of the ball. You'll find a whole lot of extraneous variables as I tried various things, but none of it worked. I suspect I'm being too complicated, as usual. There is probably something very simple I have not seen. If anyone can figure out my issue, please let me know.

title: Unstuck Day 6 Rushing
description:
This lesson is one that I use in 4th grade. Our focus was on learning more about variables (Random number block) and using conditionals with operators (If / answer </> random number).  This activity correlates with our code.org lessons.  It's also a great way to talk about computational thinking strategies to solve the problem in as few guesses as possible.  

Students are then challenged to increase the range in the random block to make the challenge harder.

Adapted from a Max Wainewright activity.  Check out his books!!  They are great!!
instructions: Click the Green Flag to start.  Can you guess the secret number?
writing:

title: Underwater word game
description:
This project responds to the prompt for Getting Unstuck:  Day 6:  "Create a project that uses the random block."  This project does include a random block--one within a list block.

Today's strategy was "Compromise."  I was originally inspired by the old "Electric Company" TV show and the compound word game as two people said words that combined on the screen to create a new word.  However, since this was my first go at lists in Scratch, I had to keep it simple.  I would love to know how to include the randomly-chosen list items in another block so that I can join the words and have it check against the master list of compound words (if that makes any sense!).  Any ideas?
instructions: Click on the green flag, then click on Starfish for your first round of this compound word game!
writing:

title: Random Story Inspirator
description:
The inspiration for this project comes from a wonderful book that I've been recently re-reading called "The Grammar of Fantasy - An Introduction to the Art of Inventing Stories" by Italian writer and pedagogist Gianni Rodari. In his book, Rodari talks about the "fantastic binomial": the more two objects are unrelated or conceptually distant, the more potential is there to invent a story.

So I decided to make a random "fantastic binomial generator", to help people invent stories with Scratch. I was surprised to see how many stories came to my mind by trying this simple project! I hope it can help other people come up with fantastic stories!

I've been also tinkering with different "prompts". At the end I landed on "Wait, what?" that I've found both universal and generative. That also comes from a book, it's called "Wait, what?" by James Ryan.

Enjoy the unexpected!
instructions:
Click the green flag and invent a story!
If you are not inspired.. click the green flag again!
writing:
The inspiration for this project comes from a wonderful book that I've been recently re-reading called "The Grammar of Fantasy - An Introduction to the Art of Inventing Stories" by Italian writer and pedagogist Gianni Rodari. In his book, Rodari talks about the "fantastic binomial": the more two objects are unrelated or conceptually distant, the more potential is there to invent a story.

So I decided to make a random "fantastic binomial generator", to help people invent stories with Scratch. I was surprised to see how many stories came to my mind by trying this simple project! I hope it can help other people come up with fantastic stories!

I've been also tinkering with different "prompts". At the end I landed on "Wait, what?" that I've found both universal and generative. That also comes from a book, it's called "Wait, what?" by James Ryan.

Enjoy the unexpected!Click the green flag and invent a story!
If you are not inspired.. click the green flag again!

title: Hit the Apple! day-6
description:
Getting Unstuck day-6
by Massimo Marletta

Same game as day-5 with a new feature: every 5 seconds each sprite moves to random position.
instructions:
Hit the Apple and avoid the Shark!
Move fast the Red-Arrow to hit the Apple but stay away from the vicious Shark!
Use the Left Arrow key to increase speed, the Right Arrow key to decrease speed, the Up/Down Arrows to change direction.
Every time you hit the Apple you will earn as many points as your speed; if you touch the Shark you will lose points.

title: Unstuck 6 - Whack-a-Scratch
description: Random made me think of a jack in the box, and that made me think of Whack-a-Mole, and that lead me here. I'm not sure if I intended to end up with a full game, but here it is. I always forget about the timer function, it came in handy here.
instructions: Click the green flag, use your mouse to move the hammer and space to whack the cat. You have 60 seconds to get as many points as you can. Don't worry, no actual Scratch Cats were hurt in this game!

title: Unstuck - Day 6
description: This project was a bit challenging to work out the timing of when to have the Scratch Cat say the name of the backdrop he was walking through.  Originally, I had him say something for 4 seconds each time the backdrop switched, but after the program ran for 30 seconds or so, the backdrops and speech bubble no longer matched up.  To remedy this, I had the background broadcast a message that prompts the Scratch Cat to announce his setting.  Sometimes, timing is everything...
instructions: Click on the green flag to take a tour of some of Scratch Cat's favorite places.
writing: This project was a bit challenging to work out the timing of when to have the Scratch Cat say the name of the backdrop he was walking through.  Originally, I had him say something for 4 seconds each time the backdrop switched, but after the program ran for 30 seconds or so, the backdrops and speech bubble no longer matched up.  To remedy this, I had the background broadcast a message that prompts the Scratch Cat to announce his setting.  Sometimes, timing is everything...Click on the green flag to take a tour of some of Scratch Cat's favorite places.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 6
description:
After looking over the sample scratch projects, I was inspired to create a random gambling game and the unpredictability of slot machines came to mind. If I had more time, I would make it more difficult to get 3 in a row (which is the reality of many slot machines) by making the program have some Artificial Intelligence. I also didn't create a "LOSE" page yet, but I can do so easily in the future.

I used a cartoon image from the Li Casino Transportation Website. All sprites coded in this project were all created and hand drawn by me.
instructions: Press the green flag to begin the project! Next, press spin to start the slot machine. If all three images are the same, then your Earnings will go up by 3. However, every time you spin, you will lose 1 from earnings. What score do you want? How many spins are you willing to take to get there?
writing:
After looking over the sample scratch projects, I was inspired to create a random gambling game and the unpredictability of slot machines came to mind. If I had more time, I would make it more difficult to get 3 in a row (which is the reality of many slot machines) by making the program have some Artificial Intelligence. I also didn't create a "LOSE" page yet, but I can do so easily in the future.

I used a cartoon image from the Li Casino Transportation Website. All sprites coded in this project were all created and hand drawn by me.Press the green flag to begin the project! Next, press spin to start the slot machine. If all three images are the same, then your Earnings will go up by 3. However, every time you spin, you will lose 1 from earnings. What score do you want? How many spins are you willing to take to get there?

title: Almondrian - Getting Unstuck day 6
description:
I usually use the random block at least once in every project, at least the biggest ones, so the exercise would be of little use for me. I had to find something new to learn or experiment with. Since I think the Scratch turtle miss a fill block, I took the chance to create a procedure that emulate it. 

The perpendicular lines are drawn at random positions. Also the cells to fill with color are chosen in the same way.

What I would have do with more time
===========================
I would have traced better the lines, with some thicker and layered an algorithm for drawing with a more realistic simulation.
Actually the drawing are similar (read I utterly copied it) to https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/mondrian-composition-with-yellow-blue-and-red-t00648

The most difficult thing
=================
The real hurdle of this project was laying the lines. A really random choose does not do the trick as the lines appear too near each other, or the canvas is not used in his entirety. What I've done is to split the stage into columns (and rows) and tuning them with random adjustment to imitate the  feeling of a Mondrian composition.
The result is quite satisfactory to me.

@tarmelop for challenging me on creating a simple fill procedure for the scratch pen (I cheated, as I can fill just square and rectangles, but there is space for improvement)
instructions:
Click on the green flag to generate a piece of auto generated art inspired to the Mondrian works.
When you hear the jingle the picture is done and the program is ready for another run.

The results are really far from the formal beauty of the Mondrian composition but, at least, I do an heavy use of the random block!

What I've done is to split the stage into columns (and rows) and tuning them with random adjustment to imitate the  feeling of a Mondrian composition.

@tarmelop for challenging me on creating a simple fill procedure for the scratch pen (I cheated, as I can fill just square and rectangles, but there is space for improvement)Click on the green flag to generate a piece of auto generated art inspired to the Mondrian works.
When you hear the jingle the picture is done and the program is ready for another run.

The results are really far from the formal beauty of the Mondrian composition but, at least, I do an heavy use of the random block!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 6
description:
* Made for Getting Unstuck Day 6. This is based on an earlier project I did for Hull City of Culture in 2017. It now has added randomness. I'd like to add more varied fountain shapes.
* Thanks to @sandboneill for a good explanation of colour effects in this project https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/2653282
* This project was inspired by the new water fountains in Queen Victoria Square, Hull. At night they are lit from beneath with different colours.
* See them here: https://youtu.be/bhtWcZxUr0M
* The building to the right is the Hull City Hall and the one behind and to the left is Ferens Art Gallery.
* The square is named for the statue of Queen Victoria to the far left.
instructions:
Press the Green Flag to go and watch the fountains.
Press the space bar to change the colour a randomly picked fountain.
Challenges:
Can you get Scratch to dance or play in the water?
Can you get the fountains to go up and down in different ways? If you've seen the fountains, you'll know what I mean. Take a look at the video in the notes.
writing:

* Thanks to @sandboneill for a good explanation of colour effects in this project https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/2653282
* This project was inspired by the new water fountains in Queen Victoria Square, Hull. At night they are lit from beneath with different colours.
* See them here: https://youtu.be/bhtWcZxUr0M
* The building to the right is the Hull City Hall and the one behind and to the left is Ferens Art Gallery.
* The square is named for the statue of Queen Victoria to the far left.Press the Green Flag to go and watch the fountains.
Press the space bar to change the colour a randomly picked fountain.
Challenges:
Can you get Scratch to dance or play in the water?
Can you get the fountains to go up and down in different ways? If you've seen the fountains, you'll know what I mean. Take a look at the video in the notes.

This is my project for Day 6 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. The random block is rather simple to use and can be useful in many more or less complex projects.

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions:
Create a project that uses the random block.

The computer chooses a random number from 1 to 10. The aim of the game is to guess the number chosen in the fewest possible attempts.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 6
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 6 Reflection:
Something that surprised me about this project is how long it took me...I thought I had a pretty straightforward idea of what I wanted to do, but it didn't work at all the way I wanted it to.  Writing scripts for interacting sprites was harder than I thought it would be.  I surprised my family (but mostly myself!) because my preschool-aged son was fascinated by this project and wanted to help me.  I was surprised at how much it held his attention.
instructions: Click the green button to start.  Use the arrow keys to move the frog to catch the bug, but watch out for the dragon.  How many bugs can you catch before the dragon gets you?
writing:

title: Magic 8 ball
description:
This is obviously inspired by the magic 8 ball toy. I've never seen one in Italy. The first time I saw one was in "Sam & Max Hit the Road" point-n-click adventure.

Aaaargh Scratch developers, why did you put such a poor support for text? Maybe I overlooked at a simpler solution, but it was very annoying to write every single label. Everything in Scratch works very well and it's an exceptional piece of software and art, except text management :\ :D

At last I did all the projects I left behind!
instructions: Click on the ball, read the message!
writing:

title: Simple Addition (Getting Unstuck #6)
description:
Gettind Unstuck: Day 6
Create a project that uses the random block. 

I had previously made a multiplication project (with the help of https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GkewBLjexd0 ), so this time I decided to make an addition project using two random number variables. At first I used the same random number variable for both numbers in the addition problem (kept getting 2+2, 5+5, 10+10, etc.). Took me a second to realize I needed two different random number variables..oops!
instructions: Click on the sprite to practice simple addition.
writing:

description:
Today's challenge was to use the random block.  The two numbers on the board are picked at random when the green flag is clicked.

I will be teaching an Algebra class with coding in the fall, so this is the extent of my Scratch use prior to starting the coding challenge.  I have to give a huge shoutout to @DrShoe32 for teaching me how to code the math portions!
instructions:

Then click on the cat to find out what the answer is.

Click on the green flag again for a new problem.

title: Roll the Dice
description:
Although not the most creative idea (as many of my fellow Scratchers did the same), I really enjoyed challenging myself to come up with a way to do this.  If I had more time, I would really like to add sound effects, make 3D dice (that actually turn) and maybe even have the program say the total of the dice after the roll.

Update - I am stuck.  I decided to add a dice rolling sound effect to my project, but for some reason the sound does not stop when it receives message1.  Any advice?
instructions: Press the Space Bar to "roll" the dice.

title: Random Walk
description:
Having heard of 'random walk,' this Day 6 Getting Unstuck project seemed like just the place to try it out -- with thanks to Daniel Schiffman for his Processing description as well as the 'assignment' he gives at the end of the video. In this posted version the step size and pen shading change together.

Already I have changed how this works many times -- currently it is less interactive than it had been, but it made it quicker to explore possibilities!
instructions:
Day 6 Getting Unstuck - playing with Random Walk
Click the green flag for 1000 steps of random walk.
Press the green flag again to add to drawing.
Press the space bar to clear and start over.

Run in turbo mode to add to the picture more quickly.

At the moment, the color is in shades of green -- feel free to experiment with pen color, ETC!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 6 - The Random Artist
description:
This particular project came to in the middle of the night. I originally started drawing a Helix and come up with the idea to create an original piece of art using Scratch. 

I was surprised that my creativity was able to run wild and come up with the program. It took me a long time to figure it out but in the end, I was very proud of my work. 

I am always surprised by my city's Microclimates. It can be foggy in one part of the city and gorgeous downtown. Today I surprised my daughters.
instructions: Click on the green flag to see an original piece of an abstrct art from the Scratch cat.

title: Snakes and Ladders 2018
description:
I've been working on this 'on and off' for quite a long time, but 'Get Unstuck' got me motivated enough to get it finished!! As several contributors did, I started with some dice - inspired by an OLD Commodore 64 game (Monopole), but I took it a step further and integrated the dice into a full game. I think there's a lot of learning in translating the rules of a board game into a working computer programme.

NB - it's not guaranteed to be bug-free ! :-)

The game 'board' is from https://www.everypixel.com/image-4479851198415772260; I'm sure I've borrowed some code or inspiration from other sources along the way but can't currently remember where. I know https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/744/#editor was a useful place to start but my project has mutated quite a bit since I first started, so I don't think it qualifies as a re-mix.

I'm sure there are more efficient ways to do some of this and I'd love to see if anyone can optimise it. I'd love to adapt as much of this project as possible to other classic board games and I'm open to collaboration!
instructions: Instructions are included but click the green flag to run, then press space to start the game. Click the green button to 'roll the dice'.

title: Ee-volution
description:
@unseatingBread helped me debug some of the logic and the timing of the music. I got a little stuck on the text validation to make sure that the user couldn't accidentally put in a number outside the range of the list (but could've just randomized costumes). Scratch forums to the rescue! I also heavily relied on the Scratch wiki for my understanding of how the List blocks worked. 

***Credits***
+ All the other Pokemon projects in the Scratch community for different ideas about what evolution might look like + music.
+ KHInsider for Pokemon soundtrack music (OG - Victory + Evolution, Best of - Pokemon Theme song)
+ Images are all from Bulbapedia
instructions: Press the green flag to start, then follow along with the prompts! In this project you can choose how you'd like to evolve your Eevee. Make sure your sound is on!
writing:
@unseatingBread helped me debug some of the logic and the timing of the music. ***Credits***

title: Magic!
description:
Major credit to @mizzpeters, @ceebee, @asparklekat, and @paulinah for encouraging me to read the Harry Potter series this year.

I feel like I learned a TON about reimplementation in this project. (The details: I had initially implemented all of the sensing logic in the monster, but that seemed to be too resource-intensive for Scratch, so I then redistributed the code across the other objects and the project was less laggy.)
instructions:
Press the green flag to start.
The A key summons your wand.
The L key lights up your wand.
The E key summons your trusty patronus: the starfish.

title: Petopticon
description:
This project was created for day 4 of Getting Unstuck. I made this project because I wanted to see what happens when you create the maximum number of clones that Scratch 2 supports (300). The feed transition effect is achieved by having each each of the 300 clones (a 20 x 15 grid of cells) cycle through a set of costumes. (Apologies for any glitches...it's a lot of clones.)

Would there have been easier ways to achieve this effect? Definitely.

Was is fun trying to get it to work anyway? Definitely. 

If I had more time, I would work on additional feeds with different transition effects.
instructions: You find yourself at an unfamiliar computer terminal. What is this system, and who built it? When the menu is loaded, you realize that this is some kind of surveillance system, with numeric options. What happens when you make a selection with the keyboard?
writing:

title: Space Happenings (In Process)
description:
I was excited to draw some inspiration from a recent reminder of the glorious Zenon: Girl of the 21st Century with @mizzpeters and @asparklekat! The movie inspired the setting and my outfit. The cats are inspired by my actual cats, Truffle and Turnip.

As I was working on my project, I encountered a number of bugs to work through. First, I couldn't figure out why my sprite seemed to have 'disappeared' and wouldn't come back when I pressed the green flag. As a Getting Unstuck strategy, I decided to try pressing all of the keys I used for sensing to see if I could find out what was happening or working. Turns out my sprite had just gotten so small I couldn't see it anymore!

I was glad to continue playing with broadcast, which I learned with Day 3's musical project. This time around, I realized that sometimes I needed to tell a script to stop until it received another message -- by using the "stop this script" block.
instructions:
Things are getting really weird up in space -- it seems there's been a spell cast on all in the atmosphere! I can't find my friends, can you help? After pressing the green flag, press the sprite to begin exploring in space!

(I'm definitely still working on this. I started with the prompted commands, though I'd like to create my own, too!)
