title: Getting Unstuck Day 4: Magical Sprites!
description:
Thank you SO much to @culturedgirlygirl for the *gorgeous* Hogwarts illustrations! I used the backpack tool to capture Hermione, Luna, and a Hogwarts fan.

Today's reflection: I immediately thought of Harry Potter when I saw today's challenge! Getting the character to grow and shrink wasn't too hard, but I got stuck for a little while on how to get her back to normal from the transfiguration without some funky things happening. I found the _ = _ block and got excited to use "costume=4" to change the broadcast. I also got stuck on thinking about what would happen if people didn't type transfigure, and originally tried to do something more complicated, but I decided to keep it simple and just broadcast the message even if someone types the wrong thing.
instructions: Press the green flag to start.
writing:
Thank you SO much to @culturedgirlygirl for the *gorgeous* Hogwarts illustrations! I used the backpack tool to capture Hermione, Luna, and a Hogwarts fan.

Today's reflection: I immediately thought of Harry Potter when I saw today's challenge! Getting the character to grow and shrink wasn't too hard, but I got stuck for a little while on how to get her back to normal from the transfiguration without some funky things happening. I found the _ = _ block and got excited to use "costume=4" to change the broadcast. I also got stuck on thinking about what would happen if people didn't type transfigure, and originally tried to do something more complicated, but I decided to keep it simple and just broadcast the message even if someone types the wrong thing.Press the green flag to start.

title: Getting Unstuck #4
description: This was tricky. What I really wanted to have happen was for the user to be asked for a word, and then the beetle to take each letter of the word and apply a corresponding effect slowly, while the beetle "said" the word back to the user in a speech bubble. I couldn't figure out how to do it. With more time I'd try to get that to happen. I'd also make sure that every letter had a unique effect attached to it, so that every word created a unique look to the beetle.
instructions: Just type a word. The beetle will transform to represent your word. Press the space bar to clear the effects and start again.
writing: This was tricky. What I really wanted to have happen was for the user to be asked for a word, and then the beetle to take each letter of the word and apply a corresponding effect slowly, while the beetle "said" the word back to the user in a speech bubble. I couldn't figure out how to do it. With more time I'd try to get that to happen. I'd also make sure that every letter had a unique effect attached to it, so that every word created a unique look to the beetle.Just type a word. The beetle will transform to represent your word. Press the space bar to clear the effects and start again.

title: GU_Day4
description:
Previously I had not considered using negative numbers for appearance variables such as whirl and mosaic. I discovered that it is like "undo". Ah-ha; a new observation. It depends which key of a pair you use first. Either key of the pair will cause the effect. Then, the other key of the pair will reverse it. 
I can press multiple keys simultaneously to make effects change simultaneously.
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin. Then control appearance changes. 
b - bigger
s - smaller
m - do & undo mosaic
n - do & undo mosaic
w - do & undo whirl
v - do & undo whirl
c - color; add
d - color; subtract

title: Play With My Face (v2)
description:
I created this project in response to Challenge #4 of the "Getting Unstuck" initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

This project is a variation of one of my first Scratch projects, created back in March 2007 (before the public launch of Scratch!):
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/142/
instructions:
Press keys to play with my face
C to change color
P to pixelate
F for fisheye effect
W for whirl effect 
Space to restore original photo

To reverse the effects: Press the key immediately to the left on the keyboard. For example, press X (immediately to the left of C) to reverse the color shift, press O to reverse pixelate, press D to reverse fisheye, and press Q to reverse whirl.

title: Unstuck Day 4: Sprite Appearance
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #4 of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
In this project I struggled with modifying a lot of sprites after having created them (26!). I knew I should get the fireflies the way I wanted them before duplicating them 25 times but of course testing them as I went along I saw changes I wanted to make to improve the firefly effect. One thing I did to make that easier was to create a global variable for the brighness value so I wouldn't have to change it in every sprite. If I spent more time I would do the same for the minimum and maximum size for each as well.
instructions: Press any letter key to make a random firefly light up. Mash a bunch of letters to make them light up as a group!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 4 — Effect Explorer
description:
Reflection

I created a basic effect explorer that allows users to increase and decrease each of the 7 effects using keyboard input.

There are two phases to the code. First, when the project starts the initial settings are reverted to a normal state. Second is the forever loop in which the project responds to key presses and applies the appropriate effect.

I like this project because it's simple: it does one thing and does it well.
instructions:
space — clear effect
1 & q — color
2 & w — fisheye
3 & e — whirl
4 & r — pixelate
5 & t — mosaic
6 & y — brightness
7 & U — ghost

title: Getting Unstuck Day 4—RAINBOW!
description:
For this project I was thinking about using costumes to 'change the sprite entirely' but then I thought- does it mean literally change it to a different sprite? So I tried that! Ultimately, I'm glad I did because I wasn't sure how I could also make the text RAINBOW be multicolored without changing the color of the rainbow icon sprite... I wonder how one might also do that? So fun!! <3rainbows. 

Ok- I came back to it and tried to add sparkles for when it got bigger or smaller... :D
instructions: "Create a project that casts spells on a sprite. Whenever you press the B key, the sprite gets a little bigger. Whenever you press the S key, the sprite gets a little smaller. Whenever you press the M key, the sprite becomes a different sprite entirely." Press N to switch back to the Rainbow symbol!

My next version would give the user more control to toggle through each of the clothing items and dani options, maybe even toggle through different hair colors, like the backdrop.

title: Unstuck Day 4: Playing Tag
description:
Wanted to have one sprite chase another.
When Scratch Cat moved one space, wanted the dog to follow behind.  When Scratch Cat moved forward, wanted dog to move closer, as well.
When Scratch Cat moved away, wanted dog to do the same.
Getting Scratch Cat to use keyboard controls to move was straight forward.  Getting Dog to do the same motion, but delayed by a certain number of steps or seconds was very challenging.  Never quite got it right and would love to hear suggestions from more experienced coders. Changed many times.  Right now, Scratch moves, but Dog doesn't :(  Time to share anyway . . .  
Note: Copied code from one sprite to another to save time.  Thanks again, @susanattenheim, @alirb, @Mittenbrother for your advice!
instructions:
Create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard. 
Playing Tag: F=forward, C=closer, A=away
writing:
Wanted to have one sprite chase another.
When Scratch Cat moved one space, wanted the dog to follow behind.  When Scratch Cat moved forward, wanted dog to move closer, as well.
When Scratch Cat moved away, wanted dog to do the same.
Getting Scratch Cat to use keyboard controls to move was straight forward.  Getting Dog to do the same motion, but delayed by a certain number of steps or seconds was very challenging.  Never quite got it right and would love to hear suggestions from more experienced coders. Changed many times.  Right now, Scratch moves, but Dog doesn't :(  Time to share anyway . . .

So I worked on 1 sprite first, then copied to the 2nd and 3rd sprites, just changing the "actions" for each key that is pressed. I would have liked to figure out how to make subroutines / functions, but didn't have time.

title: Randomized Graphic Effects remix
description:
A remix of daveywonder's remix using broadcast instead of forever-if. UPDATE: I removed the broadcast block and just inserted the broadcast code into the main script.

I put a reset in each of the possible effect changes also and added a mosiac effect. I also tweaked some of the effects to make them more animated.

I also reworked the "set switch to random" so it always picks a different effect.
instructions:
Click the up arrow for a random response (1 of 3 possible responses). Space bar to reset.

Must wait 1 second before re-randomizing. Can someone figure out how to eliminate this delay without changing the programmatic result?

title: Froggo in Wonderland: Getting Unstuck Day 4 Size
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 4 Costumes

Creativity:
Changing a Sprite's appearance reminded me of an Alice in Wonderland scenario, where she grows bigger or smaller based on what she eats. My froggo friend is Alice, but I also wanted to play with another character changing costumes, as well as changing the background in response to events in the script.

Production:
Used a lot of "broadcast message" blocks to coordinate the activity between all the different sprites. I also realized that if I wanted to run two parallel sequences (like talking and moving) that I could create two scripts that each start with the same event (green flag, or message) and that they would run at the same time. No more fiddling around with wait blocks.

Getting Unstuck:
I was stuck in one area, where I wanted a script to repeat until a specific message is broadcast. You can start a script with a message but you can't end a loop with a message. So I had to Google for some help and found a workaround where you set a variable to 1 with the message and then set the loop to run until the variable = 1.
I'm still unclear about how some events are timed in Scratch, such as what happens when you have a "wait" block versus the "say" block or the "play sound" block, each of which has a certain duration, but what happens to the rest of the script during this time?
instructions: Just press the green flag!

title: Getting Untuck Day #4: Something's wrong!
description:
Inspired by Karen's Harry Potter project, I remember this project of a little Magic story.
I remixed it to make it interactive.
I found difficult to delete the clones and continue without clicking on the green flag and restart it all again. 
Thanks to @mstone326 to helping me get unstuck!
instructions:
Click the green flag to start
Use Arrows and space keys to make magic and prompts to make magic.
writing:

title: You Do You
description:
I was inspired by the book Elmer by David McKee for this project.  I'm thinking of expanding my use of Scratch to my second grade classes next year. I already do another (non-coding) project based on this book, so it came to mind. 

This project took me a bit longer to create than I originally planned, but I'm happy with how it turned out.  I used keystrokes, changing backdrops, wait blocks and broadcast.  Moving further and given more time, perhaps I'd like to make it rain at the end to make the grey wash off.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to begin.

Click the A and B keys when Ellie the elephant prompts you to do so.

I was inspired by the book Elmer by David McKee for this project.  I'm thinking of expanding my use of Scratch to my second grade classes next year. I already do another (non-coding) project based on this book, so it came to mind. 

This project took me a bit longer to create than I originally planned, but I'm happy with how it turned out.  I used keystrokes, changing backdrops, wait blocks and broadcast.  Moving further and given more time, perhaps I'd like to make it rain at the end to make the grey wash off.Click the Green Flag to begin.

title: Remix: Froggo in Wonderland: Getting Unstuck Day 4
description:
I remixed this and took out the forever-if loop. 
Each gift is activated by either the <b> or <s> key. 
This remix is not an improvement; I love the original! Thanks for making it!

A few years ago I noticed that after giving my students a number of introductory projects, some thought every script required a forever block. Since then I have tried the exercise of finding alternatives to using "forever."

Related to this is how students will use an "if" block thinking it will loop indefinitely, when instead they should use the  <wait until ___> for their condition.
instructions: Just press the green flag!
writing:

title: Getting Unstuck #4: Control the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard
description:
Scratch project was created as activity #4 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.
Day #4 Challenge: Create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard. As just one example, you could create a project where a sprite gets a little bigger when you press the B key, gets a little smaller when you press the S key, and changes its costume when you press the M key.
instructions:
Press the green flag, then:
- when you press the B key, the tree gets a little bigger  
- when you press the S key, the tree gets a little smaller 
- when you press the M key. the tree changes its costume.
writing:
Scratch project was created as activity #4 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.
Day #4 Challenge: Create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard. As just one example, you could create a project where a sprite gets a little bigger when you press the B key, gets a little smaller when you press the S key, and changes its costume when you press the M key.Press the green flag, then:
- when you press the B key, the tree gets a little bigger  
- when you press the S key, the tree gets a little smaller 
- when you press the M key. the tree changes its costume.

title: Space Cruiser
description:
I wanted to make a little, input-dependent animation for Day 4. I used the Scratch Wiki to figure out how to make a 'previous costume' script for when the engines turn off.

I struggled with the script to make the asteroids show up on the right edge of the screen, and while I'm okay with how it came out, I bet there's a more efficient way to do it!
instructions:
Press SPACE to fire the engine

Press LEFT/RIGHT ARROW to turn

title: GettingUnstuck#4 - Impossible Triangle
description:
Getting Unstuck challenge/activity#4 - "Create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard"

Already knew how to make basic sprite changes via keyboard and the code is very simple here. But the addition of the text which meant I need to find out how to move in front and then back behind another sprite. Also had to try and centre the sprite so spinning looked ok!
instructions:
Press the following keys to affect the sprite:
Right arrow - spin right
Left arrow - spin left
Up arrow - make bigger
Down arrow - make smaller
C - change colour
F - bring to front
B - send to back

title: Homerow Fun
description:
Notes: Did you know there are only a-z and 0-9, and spacebar key controls?  Poor Semicolon. 

Reflection:  This was all about setting initial conditions for me.  I talk about setting initial conditions a lot with my students and here I was having to go back and fix a bunch of conditions I forgot to set.
instructions:
Day #4: Create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard.

Use your keyboarding skills to practice homerow keys.
"Where's the fun in that?" You ask....

title: Chase Unstuck #4
description:
This was trickier than I thought it would be. The idea is that if you press D the dog chases the cat and if you press C the cat chases the dog. It's a little glitchy sometimes and I'm not sure why. Sometimes the dog doesn't bark or the cat doesn't meow. It seems like the sprites don't always know they are touching. 

If anyone has ideas for how I might do this better and/or more efficiently I'd love your suggestions.
instructions: Press the green flag to begin or to reset. Press D to make the dog chase the cat and see what happens. Press C to make the cat chase the dog. Press the green flag before you press D or C.
writing:
This was trickier than I thought it would be. The idea is that if you press D the dog chases the cat and if you press C the cat chases the dog. It's a little glitchy sometimes and I'm not sure why. Sometimes the dog doesn't bark or the cat doesn't meow. It seems like the sprites don't always know they are touching. 

If anyone has ideas for how I might do this better and/or more efficiently I'd love your suggestions.Press the green flag to begin or to reset. Press D to make the dog chase the cat and see what happens. Press C to make the cat chase the dog. Press the green flag before you press D or C.

title: Unstuck Day 4 - Keyboard Sprite
description:
For the coding, I placed all keys in a big forever loop using if statements. This structure allows you to hold a key down to move / change the sprite more fluidly than if you use the "When Key Pressed" event.

After having fun messing with the sprite, I assigned the stamp function to the space bar and set the r key to clear the screen. Why waste the cool effects - make art from them!
instructions:
Arrow Keys: Move Sprite
q / w Keys: Rotate Sprite
a / z Keys: Change Colors
s / x Keys: Whirl / Unwhirl
r Key: Reset
Space Bar: Stamp Sprite
writing:
For the coding, I placed all keys in a big forever loop using if statements. This structure allows you to hold a key down to move / change the sprite more fluidly than if you use the "When Key Pressed" event.

After having fun messing with the sprite, I assigned the stamp function to the space bar and set the r key to clear the screen. Why waste the cool effects - make art from them!Arrow Keys: Move Sprite
q / w Keys: Rotate Sprite
a / z Keys: Change Colors
s / x Keys: Whirl / Unwhirl
r Key: Reset
Space Bar: Stamp Sprite

title: Ducky magical powers
description:
I was inspired by the project "Getting Unstuck | Day 4 | Magic!" by @karenb to do something related to magic.
I've created a project where the backgrounds change at a specific moment, and where I could control the appearance of a sprite with the keyboard in a more interactive way.
I added some music and sound effects too.
I like the story and I'd like to combine more effects and images.

                                      ----Credits----
+ Sprites and bakcgrounds: All of them (except the butterfly) have been created with the Scratch paint editor.
+ Song: "Intro (Callin Karma)" by The Kyoto Connection is licensed under a Attribution-Noncommercial-NoDerivatives 2.5 Argentina License. 
http://freemusicarchive.org/music/The_Kyoto_Connection/No_Headphones_Required/01_-_Intro_Callin_Karma
instructions:
Press the green flag to start.
Use the Left and Right arrow keys to move the character.
Try to cross the red river. If you can cross it, try to pay attention to the signs by following the story.
Enjoy it!

title: Challenge4Size remix
description:
I'm not sure I saw the glitch you mentioned, so maybe you fixed it before I remixed. I streamlined the code by deleting the broadcast element names. I created a list of element names and had the princess say a # item from the list. This would allow you to add elements to the list to extend the game with much less code.

Each answer is one if/else block when the key is pressed. If you add elements, you need to add an "___ or ___" block to the "if true" condition for the right answer. See the -2 block for an example.
instructions:

There are 2 reasons why it shouldn't - I stopped broadcasting question 1 and I said the variable "question" = 2. It's driving me crazy. Please help.

title: Day4 Unstuck: You in Minecraft!
description:
I decided to go back to an old project I had done, in that project the the idea was that you remix and use the editor to customize your character.  So I did a little more creating and came up with this. 
I first got stuck when it was time to dance, the pieces of the character were not in sync(I was using Move block).  I took a break and when I came back to it, I decided to use the GLIDE block instead and that worked.
Currently having a problem now with other keys not always working. If you press the green flag twice it works.  

What I like about this project is making the Scratch Cat into a Minecraft character.   If I had more time, I would make more costumes for more looks.  

Background from http://pixelpapercraft.com/papercraft/4f9f9283c42edb5666000054/grass-background
music from
 https://soundcloud.com/shadowmaster01/revenge-minecraft-creeper-song

Press S key to choose skin and then up arrow to select
Press E key to choose eyes and then down arrow to select
Press M key to choose mouth and then right arrow to select
Press H key to choose hair and then left arrow to select
Press P key to choose pants and then X key to select
Press T key to choose top and then Z key to select
Once you are done press D key to Dance!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 4
description:
I tried to be more creative today since I took a little short cut yesterday and used part of a project I had made in the past. For some reason I thought a little bit about a nursery rhyme - that is where the spider idea came from when I was thinking about growing and shrinking.

It probably took longer to modify the characters today then it did to create the coding pieces. I still kept it a short project, but feel my ideas came across. 

I sometimes think in simplistic terms because I teach Scratch to 3rd and 4th graders so most of the projects are on the shorter side while they are learning to create.

This was fun today!
instructions:

To see Spider grow press the B key, to shrink the S key

After girl says goodbye. press space bar to see her run away.

title: Scratch Through the Looking Glass
description: My first inclination was to make a sprite do something fun with keyboard commands, but I was away from the computer for the whole day, so I had lots of time to think about it. I saw a picture of Alice in Wonderland, and wondered if I could do a shrinking and growing Scratch. I could figure out exactly how to trigger him on either side of the mirror though. One side to make him grow, and one side to make him shrink. My extremely "elegant" solution was to edit my mirror by putting VERY tiny gray lines on either side of the image that Scratch could bump into and sense and trigger an effect. It worked! And you can't really see the lines!
instructions: Use the left and right arrows to move scratch through the looking glass.
writing: My first inclination was to make a sprite do something fun with keyboard commands, but I was away from the computer for the whole day, so I had lots of time to think about it. I saw a picture of Alice in Wonderland, and wondered if I could do a shrinking and growing Scratch. I could figure out exactly how to trigger him on either side of the mirror though. One side to make him grow, and one side to make him shrink. My extremely "elegant" solution was to edit my mirror by putting VERY tiny gray lines on either side of the image that Scratch could bump into and sense and trigger an effect. It worked! And you can't really see the lines!Use the left and right arrows to move scratch through the looking glass.

title: Gattus Sfortunatibus
description:
I got the idea by looking at @mres project, I liked how simple and compelling it was, and it reminded of this project that I made years ago with children during a summer camp in Italy. One of them @GiochiBlu gave me the idea for the clones trick. Only after I realized how many people chose a magic theme, including @mizzpeters @karenb @heloisazal and many others!

In the original project I only had the voice for the banana spell, I added all of the others. If I had more time I would invent more magic tricks!
instructions:
Press keys 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 to try all the magic spells on the poor Scratch Cat!

Press the space bar to cancel the effects.

title: Planet Fall - 2 Player (Unstuck 4)
description:
The goal for this challenge was to "create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard." My entry for project 3 did that, so I wanted to try experiment with some other ideas:

* the background changes as the rocket sprite moves; I was going for the illusion of movement

* having the planets resize via the "b" key but also "snap" back to normal automatically while also "falling" and changing location with each pass.
instructions:
This is a two player game meant for connecting to Makey Makey. 

The  idea is that Player 1 (the rocket) can only move side-to-side (like in Galaga) while Player 2 controls the size of the planets as they scroll down the screen. 

The object of the game is for Player 1 to dodge the planets by pressing the left arrow/right arrow keys,  while Player 2 can scale the  planet 1 with the up arrow and planet 2 with the down arrow. 

Players could make custom, 2 button space themed controllers that would trigger the keyboard keys.

Things to add: more objects for the rocket to avoid and a system to keep score and one to change players.
writing:
The goal for this challenge was to "create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard." My entry for project 3 did that, so I wanted to try experiment with some other ideas:

* the background changes as the rocket sprite moves; I was going for the illusion of movement

* having the planets resize via the "b" key but also "snap" back to normal automatically while also "falling" and changing location with each pass. 


This is a two player game meant for connecting to Makey Makey. 

The  idea is that Player 1 (the rocket) can only move side-to-side (like in Galaga) while Player 2 controls the size of the planets as they scroll down the screen. 

The object of the game is for Player 1 to dodge the planets by pressing the left arrow/right arrow keys,  while Player 2 can scale the  planet 1 with the up arrow and planet 2 with the down arrow. 

Players could make custom, 2 button space themed controllers that would trigger the keyboard keys.

Things to add: more objects for the rocket to avoid and a system to keep score and one to change players.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 4
description:
This is a remix from a project I made with my students and Makey-Makey. Ss had to draw all characters after making some research and by creating a physical controller, guests could navigate through Mexico by going North, South, East or West to uncover Mexico's traditions and providing different types of information. The controller had to match the character that is taking you through Mexico: in this case, ss made a colour pallette and a paint brush to navigate.
Thank you Miranda and Ulises for your inspiration.

I am still working in timing as it might get stuck sometimes.. specially if you touch three entities in the southern part of Mexico.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 4  - Music and dance in Mexico.

Click on the green flag.
Navigate through Mexico
Up arrow - North
Down arrow - South
Right arrow - East
Left arrow - West

Try not to touch two states at a time (I'm still fixing timing and program, any suggestions?)
writing:
This is a remix from a project I made with my students and Makey-Makey. Ss had to draw all characters after making some research and by creating a physical controller, guests could navigate through Mexico by going North, South, East or West to uncover Mexico's traditions and providing different types of information. The controller had to match the character that is taking you through Mexico: in this case, ss made a colour pallette and a paint brush to navigate.
Thank you Miranda and Ulises for your inspiration.

I am still working in timing as it might get stuck sometimes.. specially if you touch three entities in the southern part of Mexico.

Getting Unstuck Day 4  - Music and dance in Mexico.

Click on the green flag.
Navigate through Mexico
Up arrow - North
Down arrow - South
Right arrow - East
Left arrow - West

Try not to touch two states at a time (I'm still fixing timing and program, any suggestions?)

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 4
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 4
Challenge: Create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard. As just one example, you could create a project where a sprite gets a little bigger when you press the B key, gets a little smaller when you press the S key, and changes its costume when you press the M key.

Nice way to zoom in and to scale down a sprite. I know that in this project wuold be better if the changes are commanded by code... But I took the opportunity of this task to do this project for one of my friend who celebrating his birthday today.
instructions: Cake gets a little bigger when you press the B key, gets a little smaller when you press the S key, and changes its costume when you press the M key. The background music lasts 20 seconds.
writing:
Getting Unstuck: Day 4
Challenge: Create a project that controls the appearance of a sprite via the keyboard. As just one example, you could create a project where a sprite gets a little bigger when you press the B key, gets a little smaller when you press the S key, and changes its costume when you press the M key.

Nice way to zoom in and to scale down a sprite. I know that in this project wuold be better if the changes are commanded by code... But I took the opportunity of this task to do this project for one of my friend who celebrating his birthday today.  Cake gets a little bigger when you press the B key, gets a little smaller when you press the S key, and changes its costume when you press the M key. The background music lasts 20 seconds.

title: Day 4 - Getting Unstuck
description:
My robots => LEGO® BOOST https://shop.lego.com/

REMIX by Mitchel Resnick (@mres), LEGO Papert Professor of Learning Research at the MIT Media Lab 
(https://scratch.mit.edu/users/mres/)
created a project in response to Challenge #4 of the "Getting Unstuck" initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

This project is a variation of a first Scratch projects, created back in March 2007 (before the public launch of Scratch!):
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/142/
instructions:
Click the Green Flag. Move the mouse over the photos to play with different image effects. Click the Green Flag again to restart. 

Press keys to play:
(C) to change color - (P) to pixelate
(F) for fisheye effect - (W) for whirl effect 
(M) to hear Frankie the cat meowing

To reverse the effects: Press the key immediately to the left on the keyboard. For example, press X (immediately to the left of C) to reverse the color shift, press O to reverse pixelate, press D to reverse fisheye, and press Q to reverse whirl.
writing:
My robots => LEGO® BOOST https://shop.lego.com/

REMIX by Mitchel Resnick (@mres), LEGO Papert Professor of Learning Research at the MIT Media Lab 
(https://scratch.mit.edu/users/mres/)
created a project in response to Challenge #4 of the "Getting Unstuck" initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

This project is a variation of a first Scratch projects, created back in March 2007 (before the public launch of Scratch!):
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/142/Click the Green Flag. Move the mouse over the photos to play with different image effects. Click the Green Flag again to restart. 

Press keys to play:
(C) to change color - (P) to pixelate
(F) for fisheye effect - (W) for whirl effect 
(M) to hear Frankie the cat meowing

To reverse the effects: Press the key immediately to the left on the keyboard. For example, press X (immediately to the left of C) to reverse the color shift, press O to reverse pixelate, press D to reverse fisheye, and press Q to reverse whirl.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 4
description:
Thanks to #GettingUnstuck Day 4 for the inspiration.
I chose a different sprite here because I often just stick with Scratch.
The biggest decision I had with this project was with how to respond to key presses.
Years ago, I started off (with 1.4) using the hat blocks for a game
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/2757068/#player
 but someone suggested that I use a loop. I tried it and it was smoother.
However for this project I found the hat blocks worked better. Compare with https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235910619/
instructions:
Click the green flag to start or to reset the graphical effects.
These keys change something on the sprite
e - changes the ear colour
c - changes the costume (choose from 1, 2, 3, or 4
t - changes the transparency until Nano becomes invisible!
w - changes the whirl effect ( I've loved this since Scratch 1.4!)

Press Space to stop the stage colour effect. it might get on your nerves
writing:
Thanks to #GettingUnstuck Day 4 for the inspiration.
I chose a different sprite here because I often just stick with Scratch.
The biggest decision I had with this project was with how to respond to key presses.
Years ago, I started off (with 1.4) using the hat blocks for a game
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/2757068/#player
 but someone suggested that I use a loop. I tried it and it was smoother.
However for this project I found the hat blocks worked better. Compare with https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235910619/Click the green flag to start or to reset the graphical effects.
These keys change something on the sprite
e - changes the ear colour
c - changes the costume (choose from 1, 2, 3, or 4
t - changes the transparency until Nano becomes invisible!
w - changes the whirl effect ( I've loved this since Scratch 1.4!)

Press Space to stop the stage colour effect. it might get on your nerves

title: Ee-volution remix
description:
My background knowledge on Pokeman = 0. So, I made the list visible to check my coding results. (You could certainly hide the list.) My goal was to keep the project similar to the original while tweaking it to let the user have multiple tries at evolving. I faced many challenges...and persevered! Getting unstuck --> try and fail, and try again! 
First, I needed to understand the sequence of broadcast blocks. I numbered them with comments. I eliminated one broadcast block, & renumbered the rest. 
In order to make the theme music stop playing, I made a variable and triggered it to change. The theme music plays in a "repeat until" loop. 
To make the victory music stop, I finally found a simple solution: a wait block followed by a stop all command.
I eliminated the evolve music from the original project b/c it didn't work well with the user choice to repeatedly select different evolutions.
instructions: Press the green flag to start, then follow along with the prompts! In this project you can choose how you'd like to evolve your Eevee. Make sure your sound is on!
writing:
My background knowledge on Pokeman = 0. So, I made the list visible to check my coding results. (You could certainly hide the list.) My goal was to keep the project similar to the original while tweaking it to let the user have multiple tries at evolving. I faced many challenges...and persevered! Getting unstuck --> try and fail, and try again! 
First, I needed to understand the sequence of broadcast blocks. I numbered them with comments. I eliminated one broadcast block, & renumbered the rest. 
In order to make the theme music stop playing, I made a variable and triggered it to change. The theme music plays in a "repeat until" loop. 
To make the victory music stop, I finally found a simple solution: a wait block followed by a stop all command.
I eliminated the evolve music from the original project b/c it didn't work well with the user choice to repeatedly select different evolutions.
Press the green flag to start, then follow along with the prompts! In this project you can choose how you'd like to evolve your Eevee. Make sure your sound is on!

I did however stumble upon a great way to crash Flash by creating way too many sprites :)
instructions: Pound on the keyboard

I was really in trouble this time because I was lacking interesting ideas, so I had a quick tour of other projects and decided to employ something I really find interesting: the periodicity in the definition of the hue.
The game itself is quite boring and probably a bit frustrating: the funny part was to get the ball correctly finding if it was on the correct color (just the first time it touches it). I also had to remove apples border

When the ball rolls on her color you increase points, otherwise they are subtracted.
Ball itself changes color randomly.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 4
description:
I love how open ended this project was.  It was challenging to be creative.  I think this is something kids (and adults) need.  We all need more chances to get creative. When I watch my kids play, I'm always amazed at how they imagine such unique things.  I need to be more like them! 

If I had more time, I would figure out how to make the sprite say "GOAL" if it hit the net or "Bummer, missed!" if not.
instructions: Click the green flag to play some soccer!
writing:
I love how open ended this project was.  It was challenging to be creative.  I think this is something kids (and adults) need.  We all need more chances to get creative. When I watch my kids play, I'm always amazed at how they imagine such unique things.  I need to be more like them! 

If I had more time, I would figure out how to make the sprite say "GOAL" if it hit the net or "Bummer, missed!" if not. Click the green flag to play some soccer!

title: Getting_Unstuck_Day4
description:
Reflection:
I've just realised that I focused on the "using keyboard" aspect of the project brief instead of the "change appearance".  Sigh.  Programming 101: read the brief, understand the brief, deliver the brief!  If I have time, I will make changes to the game to reflect the brief.  In the meantime...

This game was a lot of fun to create, with my seven-year-old son as the primary tester!  Having a smaller child test your creations is really useful as they are so honest and expressive that you can tell exactly what they are thinking!

The challenge was to use broadcasting to pass off to different sprites when things were happening so I could capture the event properly. I also needed to use lots of variables to keep track of different parts.  One challenge early on was working out how to handle what happens when a laser bolt hits a meteor.  I worked it out using a variable but before then, often EITHER the meteor OR the laser bolt would be destroyed but not both.
instructions:
Meteor Dash!

Avoid or shoot to meteors before they hit you.

Use arrow keys to move the spaceship.

Press spacebar to shoot.

Press s to unleash a supernova fury but be careful! You've only got three.

There is a secret cheat mode if you know

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 4
description:
I had fun creating a teen-friendly pop culture quiz. Although I expected it to be simple, this project was more difficult to implement than I thought because the computer would register the key press faster than it could print an output. I used a repeat until keys 't' or 'f' were pressed and then followed that with two if statement blocks and a wait coding block. I also then broadcasted to another question so that the questions would not be clustered under one main coding block.

I also made the code cleaner by using several functions on the different questions. Originally I was going to make a 10 question trivia but realized that might be too much work.
instructions: Press the green flag and wait for instructions from Rad Chad. You will only need to press two buttons to make this Scratch app work.
writing:

I also then broadcasted to another question so that the questions would not be clustered under one main coding block.

I also made the code cleaner by using several functions on the different questions. Originally I was going to make a 10 question trivia but realized that might be too much work.Press the green flag and wait for instructions from Rad Chad. title: Key-change
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 4
After mulling it over (approaching 'stuck'), the starting ideas emerged as simply clones and a square, with thoughts of 'how can this change by tapping a key?'
Shading and adding designs within the square led to the 'what if' play factor which became ... a bit addictive. So, knowing there's plenty more that could be tweaked and tried, I stop here and share ... or i'll never get "unstuck"!
instructions:
Green flag to start / Stop sign to stop
Click question mark (or background) to toggle help for keys
writing:
Getting Unstuck: Day 4
After mulling it over (approaching 'stuck'), the starting ideas emerged as simply clones and a square, with thoughts of 'how can this change by tapping a key?'
Shading and adding designs within the square led to the 'what if' play factor which became ... a bit addictive. So, knowing there's plenty more that could be tweaked and tried, I stop here and share ... or i'll never get "unstuck"!Green flag to start / Stop sign to stop
Click question mark (or background) to toggle help for keys

Press the Green Flag to clear effects and switch backgrounds.
Press the C key to change colour.
Press the F key to increase fish-eye effect.
Press the G key to grow Scratch.
Press the S key to shrink Scratch.
Press the W key to increase whirl effect.
Press the H key to increase ghost effect.
Press space to make Scratch breathe fire!
Press the arrow keys to move Scratch around the stage.
Make your Scratch Monster and enjoy!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 4
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 4 Reflection:
I liked that I used keyboard commands to create choice in Anna's moves.  It will turn out differently each time you play.  If I had more time, I'd want to add more substance to it.  It would be cool to program using letters for a certain word or phrase.  I don't know sign language, but what if you created a program where you typed a letter and it showed you that letter in sign language?  Or you could use it for basic literacy skills.
instructions: Make Anna dance!  Use the number keys to choose her dance moves.
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 4 Reflection:
I liked that I used keyboard commands to create choice in Anna's moves.  It will turn out differently each time you play.  If I had more time, I'd want to add more substance to it.  It would be cool to program using letters for a certain word or phrase.  I don't know sign language, but what if you created a program where you typed a letter and it showed you that letter in sign language?  Or you could use it for basic literacy skills.Make Anna dance!  Use the number keys to choose her dance moves.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 4 - appearance
description:
I spent waaaaayyyyyy too much time on this trying to build a little game where the net moved back and forth and randomly changed sizes. I got the appearance of the soccer ball via the keyboard part right, but got hung up on other aspects that I just couldn't get right.

The biggest problem was getting the net to move back and forth across the screen. It kept changing the heading by 10 degrees or so. I couldn't get it to stay on a flat plane and just move back and forth.
instructions:
Press the green flag to start. Match the size of the ball to the net and then kick it in!

B=makes the ball bigger
S=makes the ball smaller
Space=kick the ball

description: I enjoyed this project because I was able to code it exactly the way the saw it on in my mind. If I could change something about this project, I would like to have the sprite move across the screen as it grows, shrinks, or modifies its costume.
instructions: Click on the green flag to start the program. Pressing the 'b' key will make the sprite bigger. Pressing the 's' key will make the sprite smaller. Pressing the 'm' key will modify the sprite's costume.

Pressing the 'b' key will make the sprite bigger. Pressing the 's' key will make the sprite smaller. Pressing the 'm' key will modify the sprite's costume.

title: Blue Cat Group! (Getting Unstuck, Day 5)
description:
I recently experienced food poisoning and missed seeing the "Blue Man Group". My friends had a hard time explaining what it was, so I've created this project of what I thought it was based on their various reports.

Rather than engage in a high-fidelity representation of jumping, I opted for a pretty simple approximation, which I achieved by stringing together several "glide" blocks.

Project strength? I think I have a pretty strong narrative concept! (Donuts + cats are beyond reproach.) Future work? I think I could have done better on my flaming hoop. I'm going to use Scratch's search feature to see if I can find slightly higher-fidelity flames.
instructions: Press the green flag!
writing:
I recently experienced food poisoning and missed seeing the "Blue Man Group". My friends had a hard time explaining what it was, so I've created this project of what I thought it was based on their various reports.

Rather than engage in a high-fidelity representation of jumping, I opted for a pretty simple approximation, which I achieved by stringing together several "glide" blocks.

Project strength? I think I have a pretty strong narrative concept! (Donuts + cats are beyond reproach.) Future work? I think I could have done better on my flaming hoop. I'm going to use Scratch's search feature to see if I can find slightly higher-fidelity flames.Press the green flag!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 5: Help Mr. Octopus!
description:
This is the first scrolling game i've made!

I spent *too* much time trying to learn about scrolling games... but I'm very proud of my project! I ended up getting very frustrated so I took a break to cook a meal. When I came back to my project, I had a lot more clarity and was able to accomplish what I'd hoped for!

The only issue I'm still having is how to ensure the user doesn't go too far left and off the screen. I would love some help thinking of how to stop this from happening!
instructions: Press the green flag and wait for the octopus to give you instructions!

title: Jump!
description:
This project was created for Day 5 of Getting Unstuck. I borrowed the jumping math from a project that I worked on with a friend at a ScratchEd meetup. I haven't used Scratch's Backpack feature much before, but this was a great way to move a snippet of code from one project to another.

Music: Starbox, "Digital Dream (Azureflux Remix)"
instructions:
Press the space bar to jump and use the left/right arrow keys to move around. 

Press the big button in the upper left hand corner to toggle modes.

title: Falling + Feeling
description:
Sound remixed from: 
Steven Universe Episode S04E04 "Mindful Education"
"Here Comes A Thought" (from the episode): 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dHg50mdODFM

My first foray into aligning sound and (admittedly bare) animation was an exciting challenge. I needed to use a BUNCH of Getting Unstuck strategies to get to this point (and I could continue tweaking this for much longer...) Some that I used throughout the day were:

- Fail A LOT
(glitches and other weird, unexpected responses can be very fun to discover, and sometimes bring something even more exciting!)

- Take A Break

- A Stack at a Time 
(you'll see that I abandoned many dancing stacks in this process -- part because it was getting hypnotizing, part isolating bugs)

- Break It Down 
(this was especially helpful when I wrote out the cues for who was singing and dancing when, which would ultimately lead to the broadcasts)

- Answer Someone's Question 
(very helpful as a fairly new scratcher to have reminders that there are plenty of things I do know, and that I can ask questions to figure out that which I don't)

- Be Inspired By Others  
(all of the Getting Unstuck projects are inspiring me so much!!)

- Help a Friend

- Talk it Through

- and JUST KEEP GOING

I'll be cleaning up inside soon (and will try to keep at least some of the event-less mind mess with notes to the side)
instructions:
Press the green flag to start (:

This project continues from my Day 1 Getting Unstuck project,  'Can I Come In?'

Coming to a new place can be scary, especially alongside other challenges. Our friends have thoughts and feelings flying in a bit of a frenzy. After entering the U.S. seeking help, they're feeling a bit overwhelmed. Thankfully, they have each other for support! After some time talking about their experiences, they reach out to a caring adult and they all engage in mindful practices.

At the end, use your mouse to keep butterfly thoughts flying -- the friends will be grateful for something to watch!

title: Wandering Link
description:
If I had two more days, I would change so many things! @unseatingBread tells me it's glitchy in a special way, which is to say that there are so many things to fix, I'm not sure where to start! I had gotten basic movement working, and then thought I'd get fancy by adding gravity, and then obstacles, and then, and then...I'm reminded of my students who, in their first week, see one of the Super Mario remakes and insist that they're going to make something like that. The strategies that I should definitely have employed MORE of would be "compromising" and "being a minimalist." But hey - just because it's a public project doesn't mean it's finished! I will probably continue to tinker with it for a long time...

References:
+ https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/67727504/ by @griffpatch_tutor
+ https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Advanced_Platformer_Physics 

Link sprite sheet: https://www.deviantart.com/tiozacdasgalaxias/art/Link-Sprite-Sheet-662562870

What I wanted to implement but didn't have time for: http://error454.com/2013/10/23/platformer-physics-101-and-the-3-fundamental-equations-of-platformers/

Sounds:
+ Zelda: KHInsider
+ Mario: OrangeSounds
instructions:
Definitely a work in progress, since I ran out of time to work on this yesterday. 

Arrow keys left and right to move, and up to jump. Down to face the player. Don't hit the obstacles!

Also for some reason it works better in the offline editor than online, hmmMm...

title: How Does a Crab Jump?
description:
This jumping script could be polished into a platform game. I left some variables visible and adjustable so users can tweak the behavior to something they like, and maybe learn something about the script in the process.

Using variables (in place of constant values) makes it much easier to tweak the behavior of your game, too. By adjusting them, you might use the same script for different size characters, underwater, outer space, etc.
instructions:
I don't know the answer to this question, but maybe we can figure something out that looks appropriate...

Press the LEFT/RIGHT ARROW to scuttle around
Press SPACE to jump

Adjust the 'Jump Strength' slider to make the crab try to jump higher
Adjust the 'Gravity Strength' slider to change the force of gravity

title: Unstuck Day 05 Scratchy Bounce
description:
This is based on the Hasee Bounce game from the neopets web site: http://www.neopets.com/games/game.phtml?game_id=368

UPDATE: Timer is the orange bar at the top. Black line counts down time remaining. I have added apples to float from left and right. They increase speed throughout the game. Different colored apples are worth different points. Every additional apple caught beyond the first during one jump down and up multiplies points scored.

Previous notes: I plan to add objects floating horizontally across the screen for the cats to catch for points. I have only programmed the bouncing so far.
instructions:
Press the space bar to bounce one cat down and the other cat up. Time the jumping to catch and eat the apples!
You can move each cat to the right and left with the right and left arrow keys.
Time is up when the orange line is gone.
The apples speed up throughout the game!

title: Day 5 of Getting Unstuck
description:
This is a project I usually do with my students so I created a new one for this and changed my sprite to a bird that flaps his wings instead of my usual helicopter. 

I immediately thought of this project when I saw today's challenge. My students always have fun when we create this game and they always think of ways to change it up. I wanted to do something a little different just to add some creativity to it. This was fun to think about. I am not a good player of this game however.

If I had more time I might add in a piece that would make the bird go faster or the bars speed up once a person reaches a certain score. I might try to come back and do that later on. I am teaching a Scratch camp this week so my time is limited right now.
instructions:
Day 5 Challenge of Getting Unstuck

Press green flag to start, but use the Space bar to make the bird move up and fly ahead through the bars.

title: Getting Unstuck #5
description: I never thought that this would be easy, and I was right. I'm quite happy with the way that the ground moves up and down. I can't get the clouds to move correctly. I can't even quite figure out what's wrong with them, but they don't move the way I expect them to. One of the clouds appears on the ground once you get too low, but I'm happy to call that mist. If I had more time on this I'd fix the mist and try to figure out why the clouds don't move up and down as I change the angle of the plane. I'd also add some hills to make the illusion of movement stronger.
instructions: This is my project for Getting Unstuck Day 5. Just use the Up and Down arrows to have a fly, but don't get too low.
writing: I never thought that this would be easy, and I was right. I'm quite happy with the way that the ground moves up and down. I can't get the clouds to move correctly. I can't even quite figure out what's wrong with them, but they don't move the way I expect them to. One of the clouds appears on the ground once you get too low, but I'm happy to call that mist. If I had more time on this I'd fix the mist and try to figure out why the clouds don't move up and down as I change the angle of the plane. I'd also add some hills to make the illusion of movement stronger.This is my project for Getting Unstuck Day 5. Just use the Up and Down arrows to have a fly, but don't get too low.

title: Day 5 - Flying

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 5 — Jumping Scratchy
description:
Reflection

I set out to create a jumping effect that used velocity, acceleration, gravity, and friction to make the animated sprite look and feel more fluid. To accomplish this, many variables were needed to track the changes in movement.

There is a bug in the project in which Scratchy will start moving beyond the edges and gets semi-stuck. This is what I would fix given more time.
instructions:
Move with LEFT and RIGHT arrows.
Jump with SPACEBAR.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 5
description:
I made the Cat perform a relatively realistic jump with "proper" gravity. The balls then felt natural as a challenge. It's a sort of minimalist flappy bird but without the hassle of flight! You can easily adjust the jump by changing the value of gravity or the initial jumpSpeed value given when the space bar is pressed. Might be fun to make them into sliders. Also needs some decoration and sound effects!

Confession - I did have some bits of this game lying around already, but I'd never managed to make a pleasing game with them before. If I had more time I'd maybe mix up the objects a bit so you had some variety, or make jump power depend on how long you hold the space bar down.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 5

Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying.

Click the green flag and then use the space bar to jump over the rolling basketballs.

- Please avoid from the BLACK oil dropped from the invaders or the Triangle will get poisoned (⊙_⊙)

title: Flying Cat Finished
description:
****Updated
Ok, I figured it out. Removed the unneeded 4 way movement with arrows, added in a point system, and included a way to win. It makes much more sense now. 

****Orginial
I  really wanted to make my cat move, but I had a lot of trouble figuring out how. I tried to  implement a similar block of code that I used when testing out the Moonhack activity for Scratch, the one that governs the lunar landar, but I couldn't get it work the way I wanted. I then realized that what I wanted Scratch to do was more akin to Flappy Bird, so I looked for an example of that in Scratch. The first result was almost a pixel for pixel reproduction and I couldn't understand the code, so I searched for something simpler and found a block of easier to understand code from a @gotrhythm and that seems to be working for me now. I expect to have the flying ball as something Scratch avoids, or maybe catches. Haven't figured that out yet. It still needs to be fixed so I don't get a ball explosion when Scratch causes the cloning to start.
instructions:
Use the space bar to "fly"

Avoid landing in the grass, and try to collect points by touching the yellow ball. 1000 points will let you win!

title: Space Nyan: Getting Unstuck Day 5 Jumpin n Flyin
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 5 project, jumping and flying

Creativity: 
I wanted to use a gif, as I learned how from another scratcher recently to import a gif to make an animated sprite. I also wanted to make more of a game-type project, with a score and a clear end-point. Often, the sprites I use depend on what I can find through Google Image Search :-/ So, NyanCat flies through space!

Production:
Lots of sprites, each with animation. It was fun and easy to make a sprite blink quickly between two or three costumes to give them more interest. Getting the objects flying through space at an appropriate speed and spaced out enough was also difficult. I feel I could still improve that aspect of the game.
In addition, I did manage to make NyanCat react every time it got hit, but I wasn't quite sure how to use the "Touching sprite" sensor in such a way as to only react once, rather than continuously as the two sprites passed over each other. I ended up putting "Wait" blocks in my "If touching" blocks, but as always, I wonder if there isn't a more elegant way of doing this.

Getting Unstuck:
So I've realized that I always think there is a more elegant way of doing things... but I rarely go look for it or ask for help. I do like to try to figure things out on my own. I have been using the "help" commands more often. Part of it is that I'm not sure how to find the specific information that I'm looking for. 
Another scratcher recently remixed one of my projects and indicated another way of doing something (waiting for keyboard input), so I've made sure to reuse that new strategy in this project.
instructions: Click the green arrow, then follow the onscreen instructions.

title: Platform jumps
description: Man, I forgot how tough simple physicsy stuff is in Scratch. Lots of competing challenges here for a student, from just understanding and implementing the physics model to grappling with challenges with sprite-sprite interactions and figuring out the right order of instructions to make everything work. I went with a really simple sprite shape to help simplify the collision issues, but still spent a good deal of time debugging my logic.

title: Unstuck Day 5: Jumping
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #4 of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
For this project I wanted to remind myself how to give a jumping sprite some feeling of gravity. I thought I would remember how from having done it before but ended up having to look up a strategy by searching other scratch projects. This seems very simple. There is a gravity variable that starts with a positive value and is added to the y position, and in a repeat loop a small amount is subtracted each loop. So it goes up slower and slower, then heads back down and gets to the original value at the ground.
instructions: Just click the green flag, the horse will jump forever!

title: GU_Day5
description:
When I began, I didn't know what I would create. I just started tinkering. 
At one point I inadvertently created an infinite loop with the result that my cursor turned into a spinning pinwheel. 
One challenge was figuring out how to let the user play again without restarting the project. 
I had a tough time finding sound effects that I like...still not satisfied with my  choices. B/c I was trying so many effects, I added variables so I could tweak volume and timing more efficiently.
instructions: Use the arrow keys to move Nano around the city. Discover which objects gain or lose points.
writing:
When I began, I didn't know what I would create. I just started tinkering. 
At one point I inadvertently created an infinite loop with the result that my cursor turned into a spinning pinwheel. 
One challenge was figuring out how to let the user play again without restarting the project. 
I had a tough time finding sound effects that I like...still not satisfied with my  choices. B/c I was trying so many effects, I added variables so I could tweak volume and timing more efficiently. Use the arrow keys to move Nano around the city. Discover which objects gain or lose points.

title: Unstuck 05 Walking, jumping, flying
description:
I wanted to learn how to make sprites have "classic" arrow key control, including jumping over a distance. Didn't get too far, but time is limited today and I hope to come back to it. I learned how to define a block (make a procedure) so I'm super happy with that. Will come back to work on this more later but am sharing as is. Note credits, where I remixed to get the mario character with costumes. The beach is calling me NOW.
Thanks to @PrescottRoadrunner for teaching me how to jump in "Nano Jump on Scratch"

title: Unstuck Day 5 - Flying
description:
This is a remix from an earlier project I did with my students. I have added more sprites into the mix and developed this into a game, rather than just a sample of movement and emitting projectiles.

Game portion is a work in progress. Could add lives, change enemy sprites, make it faster as it progresses further into the game, and more.
instructions:
Challenge:
Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying. For example, you could animate a bird flying through the clouds or a video-game character jumping across lava.

GOAL of the game: Score 10. Space bar to shoot. Don't get hit.

This sample was created to show how you can control a sprite with UP, DOWN, RIGHT and LEFT to move around the screen, and use SPACE bar to shoot a projectile. 

I used the clone blocks to create a new projectile at whatever point the ship sprite is located at the moment SPACE is pressed.

Look inside for more information. How can you make this better?
writing:

Game portion is a work in progress. Could add lives, change enemy sprites, make it faster as it progresses further into the game, and more.Challenge:
Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying. For example, you could animate a bird flying through the clouds or a video-game character jumping across lava.

I used the clone blocks to create a new projectile at whatever point the ship sprite is located at the moment SPACE is pressed.

Look inside for more information. How can you make this better?

title: Ninja Duck v1.0
description:
I've created a mini game based on one of the mode games of the "Ninji Spinki Challenges!!" game. 
I decided to use simple gravity when the character reaches the ground and a variable to control when it jumps.
The enemies glide in different positions to make it more difficult.

                                              --Questions--
+What did you like most about your project? 
I think I've created cute characters.

+ What would you do with it next, if you had more time?
I would like to add more levels, enemies and music.

                                        --Credits--
- Art design: I've created characters and backgrounds with the Scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Press the green flag and then the colorful button to start.
Press Left and Right arrow keys to move the Duck.
Use the spacebar to jump.
Try to avoid the enemies in 15 seconds to win the challenge.
Enjoy it!

**HERE AN UPDATE:**
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237298318/

title: Frog and Butterfly
description:
Credit for the frog croak goes to SoundBible.com 

Reflection: The Flappy Parrot project from Code Club World is one of my club's favorite projects.  This is a 2-player take on that project.  This needs a bunch of testing to gauge the fun/difficulty or imbalance between the players.

I thought about using a clone for the levels, but duplicating the frog Sprite was a quick way to get a few levels.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #5: Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying.

This is a two player game.   Frog: use spacebar to make the frog jump and try to eat the butterflies.

Butterfly: use up-arrow to fly up and right-arrow to go forward.  Try to get past the frog.

There are three levels.

title: Unstuck Day 5 - Baskeball Playing Wizard
description:
Challenge: sprites jumping or flying

If I had more time, I'd like to make the shots from random places.  In order to keep score, I had to add the Scratch logo to the backboard. I tried some other strategies, but this seemed to work best. 

Update: The basketball is now being shot from random spots. Plus I have it disappear for a very short time to give the appearance it's going through the hoop. Also, I created another costume for the wizard, so that his wand arm disappeared.
instructions: Press the flag first. Then press the spacebar as many times as you wish. The wizard will cast his magic spell and make a basket each time. You can see the score.
writing:
Challenge: sprites jumping or flying

If I had more time, I'd like to make the shots from random places.  In order to keep score, I had to add the Scratch logo to the backboard. I tried some other strategies, but this seemed to work best. 

Update: The basketball is now being shot from random spots. Plus I have it disappear for a very short time to give the appearance it's going through the hoop. Also, I created another costume for the wizard, so that his wand arm disappeared.
Press the flag first. Then press the spacebar as many times as you wish. The wizard will cast his magic spell and make a basket each time. You can see the score.

title: Day 5-Flying bonus power in a platform
description: I was stuck on this and then got some help from @HESteachers  THANK YOU!  So this project was just about figuring out how to give sprite bonus power of flying within a platform game. I have made simple platform games before but never with a bonus power.  All my effort went into the code and not the sprite or background, so that is all very minimal.  I am happy with the solution but still wondering if there is a better way to do this.

title: Nano Jump
description: Created for Getting Unstuck Day 5: "Flying Leap: Create a project that involves sprites jumping or flying." I was so engrossed in this project that I forgot to feed my kids lunch at a decent hour! I wanted Nano to jump boulders that enter the screen at random speeds and sizes, and I wanted the game to get progressively more difficult. I was stuck on how to score points by jumping the boulders, but I figured out I could create an invisible sprite that the boulders touch. I created the music loop using Apple loops in Logic Pro.
instructions: Click the green flag to start and the up arrow to jump the space boulders. Bonus points if you touch the rocket ships!
writing: Created for Getting Unstuck Day 5: "Flying Leap: Create a project that involves sprites jumping or flying." I was so engrossed in this project that I forgot to feed my kids lunch at a decent hour! I wanted Nano to jump boulders that enter the screen at random speeds and sizes, and I wanted the game to get progressively more difficult. I was stuck on how to score points by jumping the boulders, but I figured out I could create an invisible sprite that the boulders touch. I created the music loop using Apple loops in Logic Pro.Click the green flag to start and the up arrow to jump the space boulders. Bonus points if you touch the rocket ships!

title: day 5 Getting Unstuck - puppy play
description:
I like the way I was really careful taking the pictures and while they are jumpy, they work a little together. 
If I had more time, I'd like to give the dog more context and have a smoother transition between the rug and the background. Today was frustrating because I didn't have much time for this and I want to see all of the projects and learn everything! How do you balance just doing something to keep up and learning something new each day? Although.. today was the first day I actually asked for help so I definitely did learn something today!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 5
description:
So many wonderful flying themed activities today.
I have created a simple flying game using lots of different blocks.
My kids love creating this style of game. Once they get their heads around that movement is created by the buildings moving and not the background, they are happy!
Would like to spend more time creating more appropriate background for this game.
Like the flying costumes of certain sprites and need to develop more skills in creating own costumes to extend this.
instructions:
Help the witch gather apples while avoiding the bats.
Move up and down, left and right using arrow keys.

description:
If I had more time I'd keep tweaking it. The snowman seems to hit the red (or be hit by the red) more frequently than the blue. 

Thanks to @speakvisually for the idea to make the snowman jump and rotate
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin. Use the arrow keys to move up, down, left, and right. You can also use S to shrink the snowman to avoid the red bell and G to grow.

Score 2 points by hitting the blue bell. Try to avoid the red bell or you'll lose a point.

title: Summer Fly Unstuck Day 5 by Dawn
description: many many iterations.!!!
instructions: Press the Flag to determine when the cat will catch and eat the fly.   Press the flag a couple of times. My computer is going crazy...must be my browser.  I am starting the question of randomness and fairness. Naturally, we often have flies that will fly slow and low to the ground making it easier for them to catch.  I am questioning if I should remove the low flying possibility to ensure the fly will never start in the cats mouth or be caught in less than two jumps.

I am questioning if I should remove the low flying possibility to ensure the fly will never start in the cats mouth or be caught in less than two jumps.

title: Number Hop and Spell
description:
This project responds to the prompt for Getting Unstuck:  Day 5:  "Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying. For example, you could animate a bird flying through the clouds or a video-game character jumping across lava." 

Today's strategy was "Find a tutorial."  I used the Pong Game cards from the Scratch Coding Cards set!

I could also add points for right answers.  One question that I have is how to make the hopping seem a little more realistic.
instructions: Click the green flag, then get ready to practice spelling numbers 0 - 10!

title: Going on Vacation
description:
I had an idea for an awesome project where the Scratch Cat would jump higher and higher, and fly into space, and then land to the moon, and jump from there back to the earth... but today it was a crazy day and I couldn't find the time do make it, yet! 

So for now I decided to post this old project that I made for April's Fool 2016, when the Scratch Cat went on vacation and Scratchers were wondering where the cat was and how they were getting around! https://scratch.mit.edu/discuss/topic/191220/

I imagined the Scratch Cat happily flying on a magic carpet, wearing sunglasses and casually slaloming through the trees. I guess I'm dreaming of a getaway too! :)

Music is royalty free, from incompetech.com

Thanks @ceebee for the original project and the getting unstuck community for being so encouraging!
instructions:
Click the green flag and enjoy the ride.
Press the space bar for extra fun!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 5  MoonHack Remix
description: I recently completed the Moonhack 2017 project and it included a jump script.  I added Gobi as my second character for that.
instructions:
Instructions for completing this project are found at https://codeclubprojects.org/en-GB/scratch/moonhack-scratch/

For Scratch the Cat:
Space Bar = jump
Right Arrow = walk right
Left Arrow = walk left

For Gobi:
Up Arrow = jump
L = walk left
R = walk right

title: Getting Unstuck Day 5
description:
Thanks to Getting Unstuck for the idea for this project.
I was inspired to use sound sensing by the project @mres demonstrated during his TED talk where a bat is controlled by the sound made by the audience.
I'd like to make this project into a game where obstacles appear and move towards Scratch and the user has to try and control Scratch to avoid them or collect them.
Feel free to remix and have a go yourself.
instructions:
Click the green flag to go.
Use the microphone on your computer to detect noise. The more noise you make, the higher Scratch will fly!

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 5
description:
The most difficult part of this project was the skipping of the rock and changing the size as it got farther away.  When I did that with the cat AND the rock at the same time it became difficult to keep the rock in the cat's hand.  So, it hides during the cats run and then shows at the time of the toss.  I added the geese and the canoers just for interest.  

If I had time, I'd add add code for IF the rock hits the canoers as they go by.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 5: Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying.

I was inspired by my lake house and a news report I saw about a rock skipping contest.  

Click on the green flag to start everything. Then Click on the Scratch Cat to skip a rock a random number of times between 1 and 10.  Click on the Scratch Cat to replay.

The most difficult part of this project was the skipping of the rock and changing the size as it got farther away.  When I did that with the cat AND the rock at the same time it became difficult to keep the rock in the cat's hand.  So, it hides during the cats run and then shows at the time of the toss.  I added the geese and the canoers just for interest.  

If I had time, I'd add add code for IF the rock hits the canoers as they go by.Getting Unstuck Day 5: Create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying.

title: Unstuck Day 5 Rushing
description:
This lesson uses a moving background.  The bat's position is only moving up and down.  The illusion of forward movement is gained by the background moving to the left.

To make this more engaging to students -- we would add a way to score points.  Maybe insects would randomly appear and if the bat caught them points would be earned.  Or -- perhaps the game would be over if the bat hit the tree.  Lots of options.
instructions: Click the Green Flag to start.  Then use the space key to help the Bat fly through they sky.
writing:
This lesson uses a moving background.  The bat's position is only moving up and down.  The illusion of forward movement is gained by the background moving to the left.

To make this more engaging to students -- we would add a way to score points.  Maybe insects would randomly appear and if the bat caught them points would be earned.  Or -- perhaps the game would be over if the bat hit the tree.  Lots of options.  Click the Green Flag to start.  Then use the space key to help the Bat fly through they sky.

title: Hit the Apple!
description:
Getting Unstuck day-5
by Massimo Marletta
instructions:
Hit the Apple and avoid the Shark!
Move fast the Red-Arrow to hit the Apple but stay away from the vicious Shark!
Use the Left Arrow key to increase speed, the Right Arrow key to decrease speed, the Up/Down Arrows to change direction.
Every time you hit the Apple you will earn as many points as your speed; if you touch the Shark you will lose points.

title: Unstuck - Day 5
description:
This one was fun to make!  My daughter and I were incremental and iterative as we went move by move to make the animation.  I showed her how to make a sprite scroll up to give the impression that another stationary sprite was falling.  She made the suggestion that the Scratch Cat look like he is shrinking when he flies to catch the ballerina.  Every time we ran the program, Mik would read the speech bubbles and act out the voices of the character.  I should have just recorded her voice and played the sound for each of the exclamations. :-)
We are going to look at other people's projects and leave a comment or two.
Hope you enjoyed watching this as much as we enjoyed making it!
instructions: Click the green flag to start the show!
writing:
This one was fun to make!  My daughter and I were incremental and iterative as we went move by move to make the animation.  I showed her how to make a sprite scroll up to give the impression that another stationary sprite was falling.  She made the suggestion that the Scratch Cat look like he is shrinking when he flies to catch the ballerina.  Every time we ran the program, Mik would read the speech bubbles and act out the voices of the character.  I should have just recorded her voice and played the sound for each of the exclamations. :-)
We are going to look at other people's projects and leave a comment or two.
Hope you enjoyed watching this as much as we enjoyed making it!Click the green flag to start the show!
