title: Jumping Music
description:
I shared a slightly different version on my test account! I was thinking about it and thought it would be interesting if the jumping things were music notes that hit the notes at their peak. 

I find this really mesmerizing to play with with big number of notes. 

Update: Just added chord changes after being inspired by @jsh's project Drops.

===Notes from the original===
I wanted to make something for the Getting Unstuck prompt about jumping (but ultimately also incorporated music and randomness). I didn't know exactly what I wanted it to be like, but I thought it would be fun to have lots of interactive things jumping. So I started with some clones and went from there. 

While making this, I experimented with different ways to make a smooth jumping effect. At first, I was doing it the "math" way, with a parabolic equation. But I found that confusing in terms of getting the effect that I wanted, and I knew that the code would be big and hard to look at! So I switched to the "physics" way, by having a y velocity that I constantly changed with gravity, and repeatedly changing the y position.

Of course, either would work (and they're very related) but the "physics" version felt more like I was using the affordances of Scratch and was easier for me to think about, so I stuck with that.

I also added "play note" sounds. I experimented with different scales, using lists, and ultimately landed on Bb blues.
instructions:
Wave your mouse to make them jump.

Change the number of jumping notes with the slider.

See what happens when you press 'r'.

Feel free to remix! What else could be jumping?

I'd also make it more of a challenge, like give the hippo obstacles to avoid.

title: Volare oh oh getting unstuck 5
description:
A lot of project in scratch use a side view of a flying character.
It was time to a switch of perspective. To render the fligth I tried to leverage on the shadow of the glider. 

When you are higher the shadow is bigger and lighter, as you approach the soil it get darker and shrink.

I'd liked to refine the shadow behaviour but the core concept is here. Time to accept a compromise and pass on the next project of the Getting Unstuck Challenge.

Credits

Clouds are courtesy of Freevector.com https://www.freevector.com/cartoon-clouds-in-sky-vector-18516#

The chessna is courtesy of gfkDSGN from pixabay.com https://pixabay.com/en/aircraft-cessna-icon-pilot-typ-172-1828996/
instructions:
Give flying another perspective.
Use arrow keys to fly the glider and relax (pretend to, please)  ;-)

title: Flying Fritos
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 5
Somehow, as I mulled over things that might fly, what came to mind was "flying fritos" (go figure!). I wanted to try physics-y motion (based on my very basic understanding!) and add some randomness to each Frito's flight path.  This is as far as I've gotten. Suggestions are welcome!
What surprised me along the way was seeing how the number of clones quickly maxes out if clones are not deleted along the way, or if they are requested in rapid succession.  It wasn't obvious at first what was happening because multiple Fritos would end up moving stacked together. Adding a variable to see how many were being generated helped give some insight into what was happening.
instructions:
Press Green Flag to start / restart setup
Click the cat to request a "flying Frito"...
  OR press "f" key for a "flying Frito"

Sometimes a Frito will reach the cat...sometimes it will not!  Try again. :)

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 5
description: Today's challenge is to create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying.  I chose two animals that fly, knowing that I could change their costumes to create a flying animation.  I also knew that I wanted them to bounce, instead of flying off the screen.  It took me a few attempts to get them to flap their wings slower and I had to adjust so that they wouldn't flip upside down after bouncing.  Then I added the ghost and made him "jump" up and then return down.  This is my second challenge that I could figure out on my own.  It just took a little experimenting with the motion blocks.
instructions:
Click on the green flag to see the bats fly across the screen.

Click on the ghost to see him jump!
writing:
Today's challenge is to create a project that involves one or more sprites jumping or flying.  I chose two animals that fly, knowing that I could change their costumes to create a flying animation.  I also knew that I wanted them to bounce, instead of flying off the screen.  It took me a few attempts to get them to flap their wings slower and I had to adjust so that they wouldn't flip upside down after bouncing.  Then I added the ghost and made him "jump" up and then return down.  This is my second challenge that I could figure out on my own.  It just took a little experimenting with the motion blocks.Click on the green flag to see the bats fly across the screen.

Click on the ghost to see him jump!

title: Polite cats
description:
***What did I learn from creating this project?***
It was so fun to explore the Scratch community and look at other projects to see what kinds of sprites Scratchers have made! I'm not a particularly good artist, so I often find the Backpack to be really helpful for remixing. With credit, of course! Also, walk cycle studios are a great place to find sprites for remixing.

***If I had more time...***
I would want to make the animation more natural looking, especially when Cat2 turns around. I wonder about making them smaller, so that the stage looks bigger? Or should one cat move off-screen? 

***Questions I have...***
I struggled to change the color of Cat2 using the color effect, probably because the original sprite is so light colored (the Scratch wiki says that it's harder to do color effects with black, so I imagine that shades of gray would be similar). Help! How do I do that?

***Credits***
Music: Siesta by Jahzzar (FreeMusicArchive.org)
Sprites/Project: IcoQuest's Walk Cycle project
instructions:
I started with a remix, but added a few changes: 
+ Added a second cat and pointed the cat to walk towards the first cat.
+ When they bump into each other the second cat walks around.
+ Changed the music.
+ Added more broadcasting instead of responses to a key press (so that commands are linked to each other and will be easier to update in the future if I don't want the sprites to respond to a space key press).

title: galactic interaction
description:
This is my first Scratch project!

The initial concept involved thinking about blood cells eating a bacteria. That is way too complicated for me at this point, so I tried to boil it down to the most minimal but similar interaction, which ended up being two objects passing each other in a hallway. (I thought maybe the blue and yellow would somehow intersect and turn into green, one absorbing the other.)

This pushed me toward exploring perception and depth of the objects and how they interact in the frame. I wanted to make it seem like one was getting closer to the other and vice versa.

Turning them into planet-like objects came after I started playing with changing the background to give more of a sense of motion.

I found the interface complicated. I assumed the sprites and pieces of data would reset to a default state when you reset the program. However, they don't... so I got super confused when I tried to make my planet spin. When I decided to revert to my original code, the timing and position were completely off and different from what I had originally. 

Was inspired by @jsh using layers to give the sense that the fish were moving between bubbles.
instructions: Click the green flag

title: A Bear and A Cat
description:
I wanted my project to be a short animation. Given that, I could have easily programmed the same effect without using any sensing and relying entirely on timing, but I think that this sensing-based version makes it more adaptable (e.g., if I move the cat or bear). I'm wondering how else I could have programmed the back-and-forth dialogue (instead of using broadcasting and not using timing). If I was going to spend more time on my project, I'd add a more interesting background and some music, like I saw in @paulinah's project: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235480210/

My images are from Wikimedia:
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Cat_illustration.jpg
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sloth_bear_(PSF).png
instructions:

title: Unstuck Day01
description:
I duplicated and modified a Gobo costume so it could walk.
Gobo broadcasts "bump" to Pico the when the condition "touching Pico" is true in Gobo's walking script before Gobo says "Excuse me.".
Then Pico waits a second, says "Certainly," and broadcasts "start walking" so they can begin again.

Elaboration ideas:
• count the number of times they bounce off walls before they collide
• change backdrop color each time a sprite bounces off a wall
• have them speak from a list of different languages (audio files?)
instructions:
Press the green flag. Gobo starts on the left side and Pico starts on the right side. They walk back and forth until they bump into each other, say a few words, then start the process over again.

I keep getting a glitch where one of Pico's costumes points the wrong way. I've tried clearing the art from the costume and replacing the entire costume, yet the glitch reoccurs.

title: day 1 getting unstuck - the summer storm
description:
This project made me think about the storyline development process. The coding felt so natural, like writing sentences, that I became more involved with the story than finding which block to use. This is a feeling I would like to develop in my students this fall. Too often when we give directions or clear instructions, we block the creativity of the story in completing the directions "properly".

Question: Right now the story stops showing the rain, which gives away the story. How can I make the preview be the sunny day?
instructions: For now, you just watch but this should become interactive too!

title: Ice and Fire - Unstuck Day 1
description:
Phase one

At first I decided to keep the project as simple as possible, but it was too simple: two LHC particles are shot through the screen until they collide, apologize and annihilate the universe (sort of).

It was a very simple project and it was really boring to code, nothing to learn and nothing to think about. At least if I would not want to write on how to cheat with homeworks and get bored to death.

Usually, when I get stuck this way, I start looking for inspiration.

This time I was loosely inspired by an old example of Context Free Art http://www.contextfreeart.org/gallery/view.php?id=185

I keeped the squareness of the patterns but, after a couple of failed attempt I tracked the trail of the sprite to understand the patterns I was coding. It looked good and I got the first version of the project.

The following version got evertime more complex, I had to choose two different colors for differentiate the trail of the sprites, choose to rotate a little the patterns to have a more pleasant look.

Phase two

At this point the project was done: time to have a little fun and optimize it. 
An aspect I dislike of Scratch is the interface.The screen become cluttered as you start to stack more than a few blocks and then I have to simplify and encapsulate as much functions I can or I get confused. No, zooming out does not do the trick, maybe a collapse would but we do not have such a function.

The trickest part was the sync of the sprites on collision. I knew I should have used the messages but went for the syncronization by waiting blocks. Bad idea. The sprites keep to start at the same time, or, a sprite started to talk but the other did not respond.

What I would do with more time:

I'm quite satisfied of the result so far. An amelioration would be to change the patterns to have hexagonal or triangular shape. I was thinking that just needed a change of a couple of parameters, but I was wrong. I have to take some time to get a grasp on it.

Phase three 

The funniest one, as I really love to peruse the other projects to see the different approaches people have on common problems. Or the creative choice they made to give life to their projects.

One for all for the last category is 

https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235573012/ by @Mittensbrother

For the technical solutions used in an inspiring setting @CiberParra with https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235616394/ (though there is a lot of room for impriving the title)
There are a lot more lovely projects but I need a little rest before the day two ;-)
instructions: Two simple sprites are wandering on the screen drawing on their own. They are so focused to forget of the world around them. But, they are still of good manners and they remember how to be polite.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 1: Polite Bee
description:
What did you learn from creating this project? 
I wanted my bee to fly like the cartoon bees I've seen on TV, but had a lot of trouble! Since that wasn't really the focus of today's challenge, and I didn't have the ability to spend all day learning about flight paths on Scratch, I made it a lot simpler than I originally had envisioned.

I did get some help and support from my friends Alexa and Jhenna, and learned about having sprites follow a path (which I'll definitely use in a future project)!
instructions: Click the green flag.

title: On the Prairie of Prax
description:
This challenge seemed very narrative to me, so I made a short animation of two characters colliding. 'The Zax' by Dr. Seuss is one of my favorites, and deals with the same theme, so I pasted them in the background to give angry Nano some perspective on her situation.

As a parent and teacher, I am constantly asking young people to be patient and understanding with each other. I've learned that in addition to modelling how to forgive someone, teachers should also acknowledge that everyone gets angry and it feels rotten every time. In this project, I gave Nano some time/animation to fume while she came around to forgiveness.

Check out "The Zax" in "The Sneeches and Other Stories" by Dr. Seuss, 1961
instructions:
A short animation about forgiveness. Press the Green Flag, and try not to be a Zax.

Made for Day 1 of ScratchEd's Getting Unstuck. Challenge: Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly."

title: Unstuck 1
description: This project encouraged me to use the broadcast function that I do not normally use. Other people were very creative and choose to make their projects with more elements and some choose to just complete the task. I am motivated to try more complex code in future "Unstuck" projects.

title: Day1 - getting unstuck
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 1

"One's destination is never a place, but a new way of seeing things."—Henry Miller

Prompt: Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly."
instructions:
I approached this challenge by 
first: making two different sprites bounce around the stage
two: having one respond when they touch
three: timing the other one to respond upon touching
and then tweaking everything until adequate.

I'm wondering if broadcasting might have been a better way to do this for timing purposes. I'm also curious to see how others handle what happens after the collision of the two sprites. Do they keep moving in the same directions? Different directions? Are you ok with another "excuse me?" "certainly" popping up immediately after?
writing:
Getting Unstuck: Day 1

"One's destination is never a place, but a new way of seeing things."—Henry Miller

Prompt: Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly." 
I approached this challenge by 
first: making two different sprites bounce around the stage
two: having one respond when they touch
three: timing the other one to respond upon touching
and then tweaking everything until adequate.

I'm wondering if broadcasting might have been a better way to do this for timing purposes. I'm also curious to see how others handle what happens after the collision of the two sprites. Do they keep moving in the same directions? Different directions? Are you ok with another "excuse me?" "certainly" popping up immediately after?

title: Unstuck #1
description: So my approach was to have each character move randomly, but differently. So the guy with the wheel glides of course. and the other guy just jumps around and changes costume. I wanted them to stay within the frame, so I added if on edge bounce. and I did not want them to spin about, so I told them not to rotate.

title: Bee journey
description:
I wanted to make a mini story with different backgrounds, characters, costumes and effects.
Before doing that I've make a list of the different things that I wanted to do on this project. It helped me to organize better my ideas.
I approach this by:
- making one sprite moves around the stage while it says or does something at specific moments.
- switching backdrops when a sprite touches the edge by using messages.
- showing other sprites with different effects at a specific backdrop.
I've learned that there are simply ways or more difficult ways to do the same thing.

Some images like the hive and the tree are from pixabay.
https://pixabay.com/en/
instructions:
This is my first project of "Getting Unstuck". 

Day 1 challenge:
--Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly."--
Press the green flag and enjoy the journey of this little bee.

Challenge 1 of Getting Unstuck - Make 2 sprite touch and say excuse me and certainly.  Click the Green Flag to begin

I programmed this as a sequence of broadcast events. Makes it very easy to debug when you can follow the order and isolate glitches. You can follow the events under the Green Flag in the backdrop. 

The only broadcast not in the sequence order is the broadcast to delete clones that I kept local to the water sprite, it isn't necessary in this project but I like to delete clones not in use, just a good habit

title: Unstuck Day 1: Sprite Interaction
description:
I made this as part of Scratch Ed's Getting Unstuck. The challenge was: Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly."

In honor of FIFA World Cup 2018 I decided to give it a soccer theme. I think I focused too much on all the movement rather than the interaction part. I was disappointed by the "touch" block behavior and need to explore that more. Or perhaps its my code.

While researching some code I came across a teacher's comment: "I teach my students at school to focus on their “Scope” of the project.  We all want to make a huge Zelda or Fifa type game but realistically the “Scope” is far too great for our programming knowledge and what Scratch can do." 

I thought this was awesome advice and had to use it to bring my skills back to reality, otherwise I'd spend all day getting that soccer ball to move between the players!
instructions: Click the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck Day1
description: I had to tinker a bit to find the best way to get the sprites to go back and forth without getting stuck on each other and throwing the dialogue out of order. In most of my projects I have moved away from using "move_steps", opting for "change x by _". In this case however, "move_steps" turned out to be the most efficient way to do things. So I guess I learned not to make things more complicated than they need to be.
instructions: Click the green flag. Cheers!

title: Day 1
description: I got stuck on making them turn around properly! I didn't pay attention to where their starting x coordinate was and then used the = operator instead of < / > in the repeat until equation. They weren't ever going to get to x=150! I can't taking credit for getting unstuck solo though - as I was berating the dinosaurs for not doing what I wanted, a colleague mentioned having the same problem and the solution. Pair programming for the win!

Particular like this challenge because there are so many ways to solve the challenge.  How are you going to make the sprite move?  How are you going to signal the collision for the sprites to respond?

title: GettingUnstuck#1 - Bat Meets Dinosaur!
description:
Learnt a little about variables on this. Used a variable to hold the direction of travel (-20 or +20) . Also think I have finally learnt that the 0,0 co-ordinates is in the middle, not the bottom left!

I suspect there is a better way to bounce off walls and change direction without needing to know how many steps it takes!
instructions:
Getting Unstuck: Day 1 challenge - Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly." 

Bat randomly moves up and down while moving side to side and eventually hits dinosaur (who is also going left and right). If the bat goes too high he suddenly forgets how to fly and drops down nearer the dinosaur. A collision brings out the short spoken exchange.

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge 1
description: My approach is fairly conventional, with Cat sensing when it's touching Beetle, then broadcasting. But this way, it's always Cat who apologizes, even if Beetle is the one who runs into Cat. Thinking about ways to determine who's "at fault" and should apologize. Also, I might have everybody slow down for a bit after a collision.
instructions:
Cat and Beetle are playing in the garden, but not watching where they're going! Click the green flag and watch. 
Then remember to be polite if you run into somebody IRL!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 1
description: For this challenge I had only the prince move. I originally had them both sensing if the other was touching and was concerned that they both might not sense each other, so I changed it to the prince sensing and then sending a broadcast and wait. He turns the other way after the princess answers him. Broadcast and wait worked better than broadcast in this case because I didn't want the prince to leave until after the princess said "certainly".
instructions: The prince runs into the princess.

The prince runs into the princess.

title: Getting Unstuck 1
description:
I tried to make it random which one will say "Excuse me" and which one will say "Certainly". It's a little buggy at the moment - sometimes it works right, sometimes they both say "Excuse me", and sometimes they are terribly rude. Right now I have both sprites broadcasting different triggers when they collide depending on the results of a random variable, but maybe having only one sprite do it will be more reliable.
Edit: That made it a little better.

I loved all the different versions of this project in the studio. One thing I didn't do that a lot of other people did was play with sounds and backgrounds. In the future I will work on those fun details!
instructions: Press GO! to make Pico and Giga move, and STOP! to make them stop. Click the green flag to reset them to their original positions.

Edit: That made it a little better.

I loved all the different versions of this project in the studio. One thing I didn't do that a lot of other people did was play with sounds and backgrounds. title: Small pool, big floats
description:
This project responds to the prompt for Getting Unstuck:  Day 1:  "Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, 'Excuse me!' and the other sprite says, 'Certainly.'"
The bouncing and colliding wasn't as easy as I thought!  I used two strategies:  1) Problem?  Opportunity! and 2) Try something else.  This led me to give each sprite a territory, and to send the dog back  a layer.  It still isn't perfect, but I'm pleased enough to call it a day!

title: Unstuck - Day 1
description:
Thank you, Karen and Paulina for these Unstuck Challenges!  I cannot wait to do all of them.  After looking at the instructions, I have decided that I would like to do these with my daughter.  Watching her learn and talk through her thought process will help me understand how a student might think their way through the project.  So here's some of our dialogue from today's challenge: 
Me: Let's read the directions and figure out how we're going to do this.
Mik: Ok
Me: Now that you've read the directions, what do you want the project to look like?
Mik: Can I pick any sprite?
Me: Sure, but let's not spend too much time deciding.
Mik: Ok, lets use the Scratch Cat.
Me (while we are looking for sprites): Do you want both of the sprites to move or just one?
Mik: Both.  Let's pick one that's pointing away from the cat so he turns around when the cat runs into him.
Me: Ok - how about the Dog2?
--------------------
Me: Because our sprites will be changing directions and moving, I like to initialize the program by setting their starting positions and directions. (***later we realized that we would be changing size as well, so we set the starting size too)
--------------------
One of our first troubleshooting issues we ran into was when we tested the program and the dog did not move.
Me: Hmm, the dog quickly turned around and the Scratch Cat didn't move, but quickly said, "Excuse me."  Why?
Mik: I don't know.
Me: Well, let's look at the code.  When is the cat supposed to say "Excuse me?"
Mik: When it touches the dog?
Me: Are the two touching each other when we press the green flag?
Mik (tries it): yes
Me: Maybe we need a wait command.
Mik: ok, where should we put it?
Me: Well, let's look at the code - the first few things happen quickly, but we need them to move to their locations before they move.
Mik: Let's put it right before they move.
We tested it and it worked.
---------------------------
At one point, Mik wanted to use the send a message command (she remembered this from a previous project we worked on where sprites were having a conversation).  So we discussed where in her code this would work well and I explained how she could call the message whatever she wanted. 
-----------------------------
Throughout the creation project, my daughter wanted to add more and more.  Even though we accomplished the challenge, I wanted to see where her creativity would lead her.  
Mik: I want the dog to get smaller so he looks like he's moved to the side so the cat can pass.
Me: Ok, lets shrink him - where do you think this would be?
Mik: Under looks (she looks through the blocks) what about set size to?
Me: Let's try it.  When do you want this to happen?
Mik: After he say's, "Certainly."
Me: Ok, now if we are going to be changing the size, what do we need to do at the beginning? 
Mik: Set his size to big.
Me: Let's do it.
----------------------------
Me: How are you going to get the cat to keep moving after the dog gets smaller?
Mik: Use a broadcast?
Me: Exactly - do it.
---------------------------------
After running the code, Mik wanted the animation to look even more realistic.
Mik: Can we make it so the dog gradually gets smaller, not suddenly skipping?
Me: Sure, lets try changing his size little by little - try a change size by block.  But you want it to keep getting smaller, so what does it need?
Mik: We could make it repeat.
At this point, I showed her how to gradually change size by 1 twenty five times to go from 75 to 50. 
Me: if we use a 1 it will get bigger, what should we do to make it get smaller?
Mik: Negative 1?
Me: Try it -- perfect.
------------------------------
We could have kept going, but I explained that we already kinda went above and beyond.  I really enjoyed watching my daughter express herself through this activity.  She was really excited and enjoyed the challenge.  If only we had time to sit with all of our students one on one to see their thought process in action.  This is where pair programming and reflections could accomplish similar goals. Getting the kiddos to think about their thinking is important.
instructions: Click Green Flag to Start
writing:
Thank you, Karen and Paulina for these Unstuck Challenges!  I cannot wait to do all of them.  After looking at the instructions, I have decided that I would like to do these with my daughter.  Watching her learn and talk through her thought process will help me understand how a student might think their way through the project.  So here's some of our dialogue from today's challenge: 
Me: Let's read the directions and figure out how we're going to do this.
Mik: Ok
Me: Now that you've read the directions, what do you want the project to look like?
Mik: Can I pick any sprite?
Me: Sure, but let's not spend too much time deciding.
Mik: Ok, lets use the Scratch Cat.
Me (while we are looking for sprites): Do you want both of the sprites to move or just one?
Mik: Both.  Let's pick one that's pointing away from the cat so he turns around when the cat runs into him.
Me: Ok - how about the Dog2?
--------------------
Me: Because our sprites will be changing directions and moving, I like to initialize the program by setting their starting positions and directions. (***later we realized that we would be changing size as well, so we set the starting size too)
--------------------
One of our first troubleshooting issues we ran into was when we tested the program and the dog did not move.
Me: Hmm, the dog quickly turned around and the Scratch Cat didn't move, but quickly said, "Excuse me."  Why?
Mik: I don't know.
Me: Well, let's look at the code.  When is the cat supposed to say "Excuse me?"
Mik: When it touches the dog?
Me: Are the two touching each other when we press the green flag?
Mik (tries it): yes
Me: Maybe we need a wait command.
Mik: ok, where should we put it?
Me: Well, let's look at the code - the first few things happen quickly, but we need them to move to their locations before they move.
Mik: Let's put it right before they move.
We tested it and it worked.
---------------------------
At one point, Mik wanted to use the send a message command (she remembered this from a previous project we worked on where sprites were having a conversation).  So we discussed where in her code this would work well and I explained how she could call the message whatever she wanted. 
-----------------------------
Throughout the creation project, my daughter wanted to add more and more.  Even though we accomplished the challenge, I wanted to see where her creativity would lead her.  
Mik: I want the dog to get smaller so he looks like he's moved to the side so the cat can pass.
Me: Ok, lets shrink him - where do you think this would be?
Mik: Under looks (she looks through the blocks) what about set size to?
Me: Let's try it.  When do you want this to happen?
Mik: After he say's, "Certainly."
Me: Ok, now if we are going to be changing the size, what do we need to do at the beginning? 
Mik: Set his size to big.
Me: Let's do it.
----------------------------
Me: How are you going to get the cat to keep moving after the dog gets smaller?
Mik: Use a broadcast?
Me: Exactly - do it.
---------------------------------
After running the code, Mik wanted the animation to look even more realistic.
Mik: Can we make it so the dog gradually gets smaller, not suddenly skipping?
Me: Sure, lets try changing his size little by little - try a change size by block.  But you want it to keep getting smaller, so what does it need?
Mik: We could make it repeat.
At this point, I showed her how to gradually change size by 1 twenty five times to go from 75 to 50. 
Me: if we use a 1 it will get bigger, what should we do to make it get smaller?
Mik: Negative 1?
Me: Try it -- perfect.
------------------------------
We could have kept going, but I explained that we already kinda went above and beyond.  I really enjoyed watching my daughter express herself through this activity.  She was really excited and enjoyed the challenge.  If only we had time to sit with all of our students one on one to see their thought process in action.  This is where pair programming and reflections could accomplish similar goals. Getting the kiddos to think about their thinking is important. 
 
Click Green Flag to Start

title: Excuse Me!
description:
Today's prompt: 
Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly."

I've found the prompt very funny and generative. A few days ago I made a Scratch project with my avatar floating into space, so I started from there. I experimented with different ways to move the sprites while keeping the code simple. Just before adding my project to the studio, I checked out other projects. It was awesome to see the variety of projects generated by that simple prompt, and to recognize so many friends who are participating to this online adventure. I loved to see my friend @lilyland reference to getting "unstuck" on her sailboat, so I decided to work more on my project, playing with the idea of getting stuck and unstuck. It was really fun!

The music is "The Blue Danube Waltz" by Johann Strauss
https://www.imagevienna.com/en/services/downloadarea/downloads.html
instructions:
Green flag to start floating.
Space bar to get unstuck!

This is for Day 1 of Getting Unstuck!
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/

title: 5-July: Unstuck: Manners-2
description: Through trial and error, I knew that I needed to write a script for each sprite and have them interact.- I looked at the different script categories and found 'color A is touching B.' I added those to both sprites, but found that they didn't react to each other. I searched 'touching' and came across TheLogFather's "Why touching tests 'fail.'" That introduced me to the Broadcast block. I then searched on 'Broadcast' and used DockStreetCodes' 'Broadcast and Receive.' After additional experimentation, I got a working project.
instructions: Day 1 of gettingunstuck@gse.harvard.edu. Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, "Excuse me!" and the other sprite says, "Certainly." Repeats 10 times.

title: Can I Come In?
description: After creating the sprites, I was initially unsure how to have the U.S. respond. I thought initially that I would have the U.S. sprite respond when any character sprite moved (to a set coordinate location within the U.S.), though this wasn't *really* meeting the challenge, just a simulation of what that kind of response might look like. A quick trip to the sensing blocks and I found the 'touching (dropdown)' block, which seemed it would come in handy. A trip back to the control blocks and I found the 'wait until' block. By combining these blocks,  If I signaled to start by pressing the green button, the response became no longer simulated -- if someone moves the character sprites arbitrarily, the U.S. sprite will respond to touching a character sprite. Perhaps I should have the character sprites speak if they're touching the U.S. sprite. I think I'd also like to add some more scenarios and potential conversations.
instructions: Press the green flag to start, then click on character sprites (:

title: GettingUnstuck#1-Excuseme
description:
Thanks to the Scratch Team for organizing the "Getting Unstuck" series. This reminds me of projects done early on with Pong, when sometimes sprites do not bounce off properly, and seem to get stuck.

The issue is with sprites which are irregularly shaped as well as not being centered properly. When the "if touching" condition is true, the sprite turns around. But after turning around, it is still touching the other sprite, and hence it turns around again, which results in some weird glitchy behaviours.

We found the best way was just to force the sprites to move away from each other once the condition is true, by adding an extra move block inside. Works the best :)
instructions:
Just click the green flag :)

writing:
Thanks to the Scratch Team for organizing the "Getting Unstuck" series. This reminds me of projects done early on with Pong, when sometimes sprites do not bounce off properly, and seem to get stuck.

The issue is with sprites which are irregularly shaped as well as not being centered properly. When the "if touching" condition is true, the sprite turns around. But after turning around, it is still touching the other sprite, and hence it turns around again, which results in some weird glitchy behaviours.

We found the best way was just to force the sprites to move away from each other once the condition is true, by adding an extra move block inside. Works the best :)Just click the green flag :)

title: Sprites ... In ... Spaaace! (#Unstuck Day 1)
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 1

The Challenge: "Create a project that whenever two sprites collide, one of them says, 'Excuse me!' and the other sprite says, 'Certainly.'"

I started with the idea of having the sensing blocks "detect" the other sprite, which went fairly smoothly, but I struggled with the movement of the sprites to mimic zero g interactions.

As an educator, one of the most power ideas for students to experience is the "wide walls" or multiple ways to approach and solve the same problem.

title: Getting Unstuck Day #1: Collision
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 1

Sprite-sprite collisions are always tricky for students - for example, which sprite should "own" the collision detection? How do you avoid race conditions when both sprites collide? For this challenge I opted to avoid using broadcasts and instead went with a simpler approach that has each sprite detect collision separately and respond independently using timers.

To up the challenge level I decided to create a "wander" function to replicate a behavior students frequently ask for but have difficulty replicating. A couple of surprising difficulties arose out of this.

First, I couldn't easily couple timed costume changing animations with a smooth movement function. For the cat I resolved this by setting a separate forever loop to animate the costume, but for the dog I attempted a more sophisticated approach that still required a separate forever loop, but uses the mod of a constantly incrementing variable to determine when to animate, which has the benefit of easily stopping animation when the two collide at the cost of being more difficult for a student to understand (would be simpler if Scratch exposed a "frames elapsed" var like it does for seconds or minutes).

The second issue is one the frequently trips students (and me!) up when combining collisions at animations - the sprites' collision footprint changes every time the costume changes, which makes it more finicky than feels necessary to respond to collisions only once. I had to push sprites off by several pixels any time a collision was detected to avoid recolliding when the costume changes.

I liked the range of graphics that other people used to create their animations.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 1
description:
Reflection

When I started, I had a few goals in mind. I wanted to create a situation in which two sprites are always colliding with one another. This was accomplished by simply having the two sprite walk back and forth.

A second goal of mine was to ensure that the conditions of the project always start the same way. Location, direction, color, etc, are initialized at the beginning for both sprites.

I wanted to organize the the program. This was accomplished using the a define block for checking collision, and creating a broadcast/receive pair.

Last, I wanted to add a delay to prevent the dialog from being re-triggered should the sprites collide for multiple frames in a row. I learned to use the timer so that there is a minimum 2 second delay before a collision will trigger the dialog again.

description:
At first reading this feels like a simple project. However, there are many questions that need to be answered: 
How will the sprites move?
What will end the program?
Will both sprites need to check for a collision?
As a teacher, I would need to provide much more direction for an assignment such as this. However, this challenge can be introduced at different times throughout a unit as students learn more.

title: Competition for Resources: GettingUnstuck1 Collision
description:
Part of the Getting Unstuck project.
Creativity:
I started thinking about a story where one character might say "Excuse me!" to another, which got me thinking about how Canadians are stereotyped as excessively polite. There's the beaver. American Independence Day was only two days ago, so there's the eagle. Those sprites I had to find online, as these animals did not exist in Scratch's library. A bit of fiddling to get them the right size, with transparent backgrounds. Where would a beaver and an eagle interact? At a lake. The lake background comes from Scratch's library, and the heron that's already there provided the "conflict" necessary for any good story.
Production:
A bit fiddly, as I mentioned, to get outside images into Scratch. As for the code, I am not convinced that there isn't a more elegant way to take care of the timing between the "thought bubbles" of each character, rather than just hard-coding all the glide, wait, and thought blocks. Likewise with the collision at the end. I used an "if" block, but I have a feeling that there are more elegant ways of accomplishing that little bit of interaction.
Getting Unstuck:
There was a lot of testing and iterating to get the timing right for the thought bubbles. Initially, I had "forever" blocks around the "if" blocks to sense when the two characters were touching, but I realized I didn't need them as the two characters would only touch once, and in a defined sequence. It's not like in a game where two sprites might touch at any time, so you would need the "forever" block to account for that.
instructions: Nothing to do, just press the green flag!

title: HTGU - Day 1
description:
Notes: I got stuck and my own pride prevented me from doing much other than unsystematically trying lots of different blocks (and refusing to use resources available to me).

It's not all bad.  I learned about many things in Scratch:
 - Direction
 - Costume centers
 - Cloning
 - Sensing
instructions:
My original idea was to have 2 sets of eyeballs in a black room randomly moving around.  However, I wanted to have only 1 sprite move at a time, and the collision would cause the roles to swap.

Turns out that implementing the movement swapping was not as easy to do or is error prone with the approach I took.

The balls often get stuck (no pun intended).

title: Drop-in Spider
description:
I started with the idea of a spider dropping, but wasn't sure who would be the landing pad...until I started browsing the sprite library. Sitting outside to work on this inspired taking a shot for the background. Although this shouldn't be a surprise, I was surprised at how little tweaks, actions & interactions can take more than a little time!  With more time, I'd like to see if I could streamline things a bit and name the sprites & costumes fittingly,  but for now....here it is.
I love seeing all the clever scenarios people have come up with in their projects!

title: Unstuck Challenge 1
description:
Reflection

1) What I learned is that separation of functions is very important. Often I try to put everything into one giant block line, but it does not always work. 

2)  I did look at a few programs in the class studio to see how others completed the challenge.  I then took parts of what others did and used it in my own code. 

3) As I was going through this challenge, I realized how important it is for students to have examples and references.  I will probably create a reference packet of quick coding tips to start students off the semester.  I can have students also create references and example coding tips for students too.
instructions: Press the green flag to begin.  Press space bar to reset the sprites at the end of the animation.

title: Getting Unstuck 1
description:
This project was made for the Getting Unstuck Creative Computing Day 1.
I decided to use football after watching England play in the World Cup.
I thought it would be nice to introduce some manners to the game - not always in evidence in the real game!
I thought it would be interesting to play around with some randomness to see how it would work out. I also used move and glide to see the difference between the two. I think it would have been harder to move Gobo using the move block.
For the next steps, I might use cloning to make more flags in random positions and different sizes. Maybe animated.
Getting Scratch to kick the ball at some point would be cool too.

title: KP_Unstuck1
description:
As a teacher of Scratch and coach of Scratch, I needed to revisit my own practice of creating and exploring through this great 21 initiative.

I don't know if I remembered that when my sprite bounces off an edge that my sprite rotated upside down until I set her rotation style. I also noticed that I didn't have to adjust the move direction. Perhaps I just took this for granted :)

title: Excuse me! Certainly.
description: A big shout out to 5Bics1 for showing how to get through a glitch I couldn't work out. Thank you 5Bics1! I found this project challenging trying to get the sprites to register each time they actually touched. It took me a while to realise that it was dependent on the right part of each sprite touching before it would activate the reaction.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 1
description: I struggled with the sprites getting stuck on each other.  I searched for some help from other Scratchers on how to have sprites bounce off of each other.  There were several different options, some complicated and some easy.  I went for the easier version, having the sprites turn 180 from their current direction after they collide.  They do still get stuck to each other once in awhile.  But, that's not unlike how people might do that when they run into each other and then move to the same side and continue to do the same.
instructions:
Assignment 1: When two sprites touch have them exchange pleasantries.  

I wanted a random movement.  The two balls bounce around the screen and bounce off the edges and off of each other.  When they run into each other is unpredictable.

title: Getting_Unstuck_Day1
description:
Reflection:
I enjoyed putting a few enhancements into my project to personalise it a little.
I used "broadcast message" to handle the conversation between the sprites.
I found it difficult to balance smooth movement (I used "glide" movement) with being able to capture the "collide with sprite" event.  I wasn't terribly successful!

I was able to use other works to try and figure out my way around it. Most interesting to me was probably all the different ways people used to have the sprites move and run into each other.

title: Getting Unstuck day 1 remix
description:
So, I decided to make this a collaborative project with my son, NanoWhisp. I let him approach the challenge first, then critiqued and debugged it with him, and I'm doing the reflections.

This one didn't need any serious debugging, although I did refactor it a bit to remove an unnecessary event! Nano used events to communicate between balloon and ball to co-ordinate the conversation. The balloon politely stops moving while the beach ball slowly moves past after saying excuse me - a wonderful characterization! (hi I'm an excessively proud dad right now) And the event routines were very well organized and also I'm excessively proud of that too

Okay, reflection: how would I have approached it differently?
I would have been tempted to make this universal - could we have a LOT of instances of the same sprite, who somehow can negotiate this between any pair, without specifying in advance which one says "excuse me"?

ie. I overthink things

That aside though, I love the event approach here. You *could* do the whole thing without any inter-sprite communication, just having them each execute a timed script on contact. But the event approach is easier to modify, and in a sense it's more "natural". When one sprite talks to the other, it also behind-the-scene talks to the other through the event system.
instructions: Press the spacebar to start movement!

title: 1 : Scratch & the Starfish
description:
The photos is from Sorø, the town where my adventure with Scratch started back in 2012. The photos is from an old project from 2012 so the quality is not the best.

In this project I have played with different ways how to make Scratch look smaller when he walks from far away, how to make him go in a specific direction with help from a ghost sprite and how the starfish react when Scratch bumps into him.
instructions:
Just press the green flag and see what happens.

This project is made for day 1 at GetttingUnstuck.

The photos is from Sorø, the town where my adventure with Scratch started back in 2012. The photos is from an old project from 2012 so the quality is not the best.

In this project I have played with different ways how to make Scratch look smaller when he walks from far away, how to make him go in a specific direction with help from a ghost sprite and how the starfish react when Scratch bumps into him.

title: unstuck day 1
description: From the Getting Unstuck project, day 1. https://us18.campaign-archive.com/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=58f14fb2df
instructions:
Two clouds wander randomly, talking when they touch.

They only talk when they first meet, not repeating the conversation if they stay in contact for a long time. I control that with a variable which is set when they're touching and cleared when they're not. The talking only starts if the variable is clear.
writing:
From the Getting Unstuck project, day 1. https://us18.campaign-archive.com/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=58f14fb2dfTwo clouds wander randomly, talking when they touch.

They only talk when they first meet, not repeating the conversation if they stay in contact for a long time. I control that with a variable which is set when they're touching and cleared when they're not. The talking only starts if the variable is clear.

title: Unstuck Day 1
description: What did you learn from creating this project? I learned that as part of being a good programmer, you need to plan first.  I had to decide which characters, stage and blocks to use.  I had to decide which approach I wanted to use to make th interaction of the Sprites.  I chose to use a sensing and send receive blocks.  What did you notice about how other people approach the challenge?  Everyone has a different strategy so it shows their are multiple ways to solve this challenge and none of them are incorrect!
instructions: This was fun!
writing: What did you learn from creating this project? I learned that as part of being a good programmer, you need to plan first.  I had to decide which characters, stage and blocks to use. title: Apples & Butterfiles

title: Getting Unstuck Day 1
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 1 Reflection:
I've played around with Scratch a bit, so I had an idea of how I wanted to approach this.  What I learned is how exciting it is to give an open-ended challenge like this.  There were so many creative projects that met the same basic parameters!
instructions: Click on the green flag to see how long the fish can swim without bumping into each other.

The Getting Unstuck Day 1 challenge reminded me how to use costumes along with motion. Also, I decided to randomize the direction of the two costumes to make the animation more engaging.

title: Moon Crater formation (polite)
description:
Asteroids making craters on the moon, but politely! My attempt at a solution to 'Get Unstuck! Day 1'. Sprite1 is a (mostly) invisible box covering the 'moon'. When the rocks (asteroids) hit it, they say 'Excuse Me!' and bounce off back into space. 

I wrote another version where the rocks were cloned but Flash and Chrome had a major falling out and I lost it...
instructions: Just click the flag

title: Capocciate marine - Getting Unstuck Day 1
description:
Ho creato un nuovo progetto per partecipare al programma di allenamento Getting Unstuck ^^

Mi farebbe piacere che mi aiutassi con i miei esercizi di coding :) se trovi bug o scorrettezze non esitare ad inviarmi feedback o/remixare e far diventare molto più bello questo breve progetto. Grazie mille <3

Accenni sulla tematica: 
Rispetta le regole del bravo esploratore subaqueo e tutela l'equilibrio dell'ecosistema dei fondali marini:
Il privilegio di immergersi con le bombole nel meraviglioso mondo sottomarino con le nostre branchie sintetiche, comporta grande opportunità come anche una serie di responsabilità, tra le quali quelle di rispettare e preservare gli organismi acquatici e l'ambiente in cui essi vivono.
instructions: Clicca sulla bandierina verde e dai un occhiata alla breve disavventura di un sub inesperto.

Working through the prompts from the July 2018 Getting Unstuck project by ScratchEd. Great ideas and exercises!
I learned that it always takes longer than you think... especially when you insist on creating your own sprites....

title: Day 2: Flower stamps!
description:
Originally I drew my own flower (purple circle w/ green petals) and made that move around the screen as a clone, but then I wondered how hard it would be to draw using the pen tool (I am always astounded by @scmb1's use of the pen!). The answer? Very hard! I wanted to recreate my purple circle and green oval petals, but couldn't figure out how to fill them in. Also couldn't figure out how to draw beautiful parabolas.

Anyway, eventually I sought some inspiration from others' pen drawings, poking around the Scratch "Help with Scripts" forum as well as just searching the community to find other pen flowers. There were many different ways to accomplish this, but since I had already succeeded in drawing pen circles, I decided to draw connecting circles with random colors in order to make flowers. 

Highly inspired by @P0lliw0g's Pen flower drawing: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/76609616/
instructions: Press the green flag to start the project, then click anywhere on the screen. In order to make imperfect flowers, click close to the edges (is this a feature or a bug? TBD). Turn sound on for random notes when each flower appears.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2: Flower Stamp
description:
**Thank you so much to @mstone326 for your help in getting unstuck! I'm so happy I was able to get this project to be what I envisioned!**

Field image from public domain pictures. 
Flower drawing loosely based off of this tutorial: https://www.drawingnow.com/tutorials/119946/how-to-draw-a-flower-step-by-step/

I had a lot of fun with this challenge! I wanted to challenge myself to learn something new, so I looked at the flower drawing tutorial and used the paint editor to make my flowers. My students always struggled with the paint editor, so I wanted to spend more time using it to see what might be frustrating for them. It was definitely more time-consuming than I thought!

What you currently see (the random colored flowers) is only one part of what I had hoped to make. I also want to make a little "flower palette" where you can choose what color flower to stamp. I couldn't get this to work last night because of the way I programmed the flowers to stamp (any time the background is clicked). You can see what I was trying to do if you look at my "purple" broadcast blocks. Would love any advice for how to make this extra part of my project work!
instructions:
Press the green flag to start. Then, click where you'd like to make a flower garden!

If you'd like to add different color flowers, press the space bar and click on the color you want!

title: Unstuck Day 2 - Flower Surprise!
description:
This was a fun project to make! I enjoyed playing around with the paint editor to create my flower—it makes me even more excited for 3.0's redesigned editor! 

The one thing I found trickey about this project was that I couldn't figure out why a flower kept popping up whenever I'd press the green button. That's why I did the "wait x seconds" block— I imagine it was taking the press of the green button as a 'mouse down'...Does anyone have any thoughts about a different way to approach this?
instructions:
Unstuck Challenge Day 2:
Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. There are at least three different ways of programming this in Scratch—what will your approach be?

I wanted to play with the idea of tesselation— when you click you don't know if you will get a flower or a bird!

title: 21 Days of Flowers
description:
I'm quite fond of the visual effects I played with in this project. If I had more time, I would figure out how to implement this with cloning instead of with stamping. I wanted to use cloning because I wanted the petals to fall away at some point—but I couldn't figure it out (yet!).

Credits
I found the petal via a Google Image search for "petal". I found the poem at poets.org: https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/petals
instructions: Every time you click on the background, a flower appears. After 21 clicks (in honor of the 21 days of Getting Unstuck), a poem about petals appears, and the project resets. Everything is iterative!

I'm quite fond of the visual effects I played with in this project. If I had more time, I would figure out how to implement this with cloning instead of with stamping. I wanted to use cloning because I wanted the petals to fall away at some point—but I couldn't figure it out (yet!).

After 21 clicks (in honor of the 21 days of Getting Unstuck), a poem about petals appears, and the project resets. Everything is iterative!

title: 4 Flower Garden
description:
This was fun. I wanted to draw my own sprites, something I never do, and obviously I am still terrible at (I am comfortable with my terrible art abilities!) But I really wanted my flowers to appear randomly around the page, so it was fun messing around with random, and then I realized that random could fit inside broadcast! So I could make the broadcast be one of 4 randomized flowers. 
Setting up the x/y I always find it easier to use the x/y stage. However, when I switched over to something nice for flowers it looked like I had made my flowers TOO random. They were growing in the concrete. So I limited my Y coords randomness to stay inside the mulch where the flowers belonged.
instructions: Click anywhere on the stage to create one of four flowers.
writing:

They were growing in the concrete. So I limited my Y coords randomness to stay inside the mulch where the flowers belonged. Click anywhere on the stage to create one of four flowers.

title: Getting Unstuck Day2
description:
What did you like most about your project? I like the random size/colour. I also like brightening up that brick wall, it's crying out for some flowers in this garden. 

What would you do with it next, if you had more time? I love the idea of geometric art flowers. I'd change my sprite to use the pen function and do some flower patterns instead.

title: day 2 flower surprise
description: I wanted the flowers to be random but in the grass but sometimes they bunch too much. How can I change that?
instructions: Click anywhere on the grass to make flowers grow. My mother always said gardens should be planted in threes. My sister likes to coordinate colors so I compromised in slight color changes to keep color families together. Of course, a garden always needs a supervisor and of course the sun had to get in on the fun too.

title: Flower! - Getting Unstuck! - Day 2
description:
The one thing that I had to get unstuck was that I was 'stamping' my flower so when I was using the pen for the stem it was in front of it.. but that wasn't the desired way.  So I changed the stem to a costume and stamped it first and then the petals and then the centre. 
This was more the desired outcome!
instructions:
I used a function and some random numbers to create my flowers for this challenge today. 

Click the mouse on the background and the flower of a random number of petals (4-8) and colour will appear. 

Enjoy!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2
description:
I decided to do this in as unusual way as I could think of:
- the backdrop detects clicks
- it creates a clone of a costumeless drawing sprite for each click
- it uses the pen with a large pen size value to draw circles without having to move the pen

I liked this approach because the clones mean you could be drawing more than one flower at a time. I think it's fun not to have any costumes for the sprite - so no worrying about hiding the original sprite when using clones. I could add some more variety to the flowers drawn by having a whole set of parameters beyond size and colour. Maybe the pen could be used to draw spirograph flowers. Stalks would be fun. Maybe add an animated bee to enjoy the flowers.
instructions:

title: Watch the Garden grow
description: Spend way too much time erasing background. Can not figure out how the erase background feature in the bitmap works. So ... Then had some trouble with the appearing and disappearing. title: Day 2-Click to create flower - Growing a Garden
description:
Day 2 Getting Unstuck - Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. 

I used multiple costumes with different kinds of flowers and an operator to choose a random costume. I used this same approach to play different tones for each stamp and give the user time to move the cursor. I think it would be neat to create a variable so a voice sang the name of each kind of flower in the project.
instructions: Click on the background to create your garden.

title: Droppin' Daisies
description:
I'd never used pen blocks in a project before, and used this project to try it out. For help, I used the tips window quite a bit, and also searched online to read about pen blocks on the Scratch Wiki and Discussion Forum pages.

I used variables on sliders so new Scratchers can play with the behavior of the project before they even hit the 'See Inside' button. This also gives them some familiarity with what each variable block affects, so they will have some background knowledge once they start looking at the scripts.

This variables idea is more developed in the Bug Maker project I made back in January: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/200011652/#player
instructions:
Click the stage to have the butterfly drop a seed. Pick your daisy color and brightness with the variable sliders, or turn up 'Variety!' and be surprised!

What variable settings did you use to make your garden?

Made for Day 2 of 'Getting Unstuck' (display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background)

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 2
description:
Reflection

I wanted to generate a variety of different flowers from a simple set of rules and I wanted them to be animated as they were being drawn onto the screen. To accomplish this, I started with a simple flower shape and set it to hidden at the start. When the stage is clicked, the sprite is cloned and a process begins that creates a randomly generated flower. Two loops are used, one for creating the size and colors, while the other is used to animate the flower as it grows. Once an animation completes, the image is stamped. Once then entire process completes, the clone is deleted to prevent the project from slowing down. If I spent more time on this I would have created custom flower graphics.
instructions: Click screen to generate a flower.
writing:
Reflection

I wanted to generate a variety of different flowers from a simple set of rules and I wanted them to be animated as they were being drawn onto the screen. To accomplish this, I started with a simple flower shape and set it to hidden at the start. When the stage is clicked, the sprite is cloned and a process begins that creates a randomly generated flower. Two loops are used, one for creating the size and colors, while the other is used to animate the flower as it grows. Once an animation completes, the image is stamped. Once then entire process completes, the clone is deleted to prevent the project from slowing down. If I spent more time on this I would have created custom flower graphics.Click screen to generate a flower.

instructions: Click on the background to plant a flower.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2 - flowers
description:
This one I started out by checking out all the other project. I got tons of ideas of how to randomize the flower size and color.  I can now see the value of students remixing other projects. I learned a lot just by checking out how others had done it!

Two things I'd like to learn how to do:
1) I want the flowers to fade/disappear after a few seconds so the user has to keep adding flowers. Perhaps using clones?
2) I used conditionals to restrict where the user could click to plant a flower (so they can't click off the screen). But I found that flowers still ended up hanging off the screen. I need to figure out how to make it so the flowers can't hand half off the screen.
instructions:
Click the green flag to start. Click anywhere in the dirt to plant a flower. Make your flower garden grow!

Created for Getting Unstuck Day 2: Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2 - flowers remix
description:
The original project poster asked about making the flowers not go off screen. I also added one possible fading clone script.

The off-the-edge code checks to see if the sprite is touching the edge before stamping. If it does, it points towards the center and moves ten steps, then repeats until it is not touching the edge.

To point towards the center, I hid a ball sprite at x:0 y:0 and had the flower sprite point towards that sprite.
instructions:
Click the green flag to start. Click anywhere in the dirt to plant a flower. Make your flower garden grow!

Created for Getting Unstuck Day 2: Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background.

title: Unstuck Day 2 Rushing
description:
I used a lesson I teach my 4th and 5th graders each year as the inspiration for this challenge.  Learning about functions is part of our computer science curriculum and this is a fun way to help them practice creating functions with parameters.

I created two functions -- one for the flower and one for the stem.  Using the "pick random number" block made it very easy to have different color flower petals and centers -- as well as flowers with different numbers of petals.  

This project was adapted from a lesson I found in a DK publishing book called "Coding Projects in Scratch".
instructions: Draw flowers using Functions!  Click the Space Bar to clear any "gardens" and Click the Green Flag to start the program.  Every time you click your mouse on the stage, you will grow a flower.
writing:
I used a lesson I teach my 4th and 5th graders each year as the inspiration for this challenge.  Learning about functions is part of our computer science curriculum and this is a fun way to help them practice creating functions with parameters.

title: GettingUnstuck#2 - Multicoloured Flower Power
description:
Getting Unstuck challenge/exercise#2 - "Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background"

Started off thinking I would need lots of flower sprites. Then it got messy and some searching suggested clones. Check out the use of the "clone" variable's use to stop clone's being cloned on later clicks.

Based on other people's work it looks like the "stamp" block may have made things easier (so lesson learned for today!)
instructions: Click the grassy background to make a new flower appear (a different colour with each click!)
writing:

Started off thinking I would need lots of flower sprites. Then it got messy and some searching suggested clones. Check out the use of the "clone" variable's use to stop clone's being cloned on later clicks.

Based on other people's work it looks like the "stamp" block may have made things easier (so lesson learned for today!)Click the grassy background to make a new flower appear (a different colour with each click!)

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge 2 - Plant
description:
My wife has several of these in our yard. Thought I'd use it as my idea. And yes, that is me...........

I have to work out the layering system for multiple clones and their location within the planter, stored in a list. Each flower has an id, size and y position stored in a list. Will add that later on. 

I also plan to turn this project into a Counting Game for my Kindergarten/1st Grade students. Ex: Please plant 2 red, 1 pink, 1 orange flower. Once they do they will watch them grow, then the next plant instructions will come.

I also may add a save system to reload your planter if you wanted
instructions:
Click the Green Flag

Click the planting area of the flower bed. 

Added delete function. Hold space and click a flower you planted to delete it from the box

title: Unstuck Day 2 Rushing remix
description:
This is a great original project. I modified the script so the ball follows the mouse around, then checks to see if it is touching the green grass color before creating a clone. It lags a little bit so won't always make a flower if I click too fast.

I also made the stalk length and width vary slightly. What can I say? I actively seek ways of adding random blocks to my code.
instructions: Draw flowers using Functions!  Click the Space Bar to clear any "gardens" and Click the Green Flag to start the program.  Every time you click your mouse on the stage, you will grow a flower.

title: Getting Unstuck | Day 2 | 21 Days of Flowers remix
description:
I changed it to one day, just to mess around with the clone code you left in the script area. 

I tried a few basic shapes (line, ellipse, circle) then made each petal a clone, growing then shrinking, changing colors along the way. Is this closer to "falling petals?"
instructions: Every time you click on the background, a flower appears. After 21 clicks (in honor of the 21 days of Getting Unstuck), a poem about petals appears, and the project resets. Everything is iterative!

title: Getting Unstuck 2
description: I used clones to create a flower whenever the mouse was down. I had to add some waits in to prevent it from being a little too sensitive and creating a ton of flowers at once.
instructions: Click the green flag to get started, then click the background to add a flower to the flowerbed. You can also hold the mouse down to add multiple flowers. Click the squirrel to remove the flowers.

title: Day 2 Unstuck Flower Creation
description:
I like the simplicity of the stamp tool here.  But what I really wanted to do was use the pen down tool and draw out my flower with commands.  

Unfortunately I kept running into issues with letting it run after the mouse down was detected.
instructions: Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. There are at least three different ways of programming this in Scratch—what will your approach be?

I like the simplicity of the stamp tool here.  But what I really wanted to do was use the pen down tool and draw out my flower with commands.  

Unfortunately I kept running into issues with letting it run after the mouse down was detected.Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. There are at least three different ways of programming this in Scratch—what will your approach be?

title: Getting Unstuck | Day 2 | 21 Days of Flowers remix
description:
I attempted the clone approach to make the petals fade after a few seconds. It was only semi-successful. Making all the petals clones very quickly made the program glitch like crazy. I combined the clone/stamp approaches to at least the get the last petal to fall and fade away. It still gets a little glitchy if you click too fast though. If you wait a few seconds for old clones to be deleted before adding new ones it's okay.

I thought this project was so pretty, and I liked the idea of leaving in unused code blocks with comments to show process. I will definitely use that with my students next year. Thanks Karen!
instructions: Every time you click on the background, a flower appears. After 21 clicks (in honor of the 21 days of Getting Unstuck), a poem about petals appears, and the project resets. Everything is iterative!
writing:
I attempted the clone approach to make the petals fade after a few seconds. It was only semi-successful. Making all the petals clones very quickly made the program glitch like crazy. I combined the clone/stamp approaches to at least the get the last petal to fall and fade away. It still gets a little glitchy if you click too fast though. If you wait a few seconds for old clones to be deleted before adding new ones it's okay.

I thought this project was so pretty, and I liked the idea of leaving in unused code blocks with comments to show process. I will definitely use that with my students next year. title: Flower chain reation! (Getting Unstuck Day 2)
description:
Thinking about something appearing when the stage was clicked reminded me something. And then I realized it was one of my first scratch projects.
So I adapted it in a floral version.
Modifying a code I had written a lot of years ago is hard (I regret I didn't comment it out) and I notice now I know a bit better Scratch so I could make it simpler.
Anyway, I'm very proud of this game because I played it on prehistorical smartphones :) and I like how it is similar to the original game.
If I had more time I would have use images with higher quality and simplified the code.
instructions:
One click per level.
Trigger a flower chain reaction!

P.s. There is at least one magic easter egg :)

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2 Flower Clones on Mouse
Unstuck - Day 2
description:
This was a tough challenge!  But we enjoyed making it!  Again, I worked with my daughter to complete this project.  Here are some things we tried.
First we found a background that would be suitable for planting flowers.
Then we created a flower sprite with three costumes. We wanted a different flower to appear where your mouse was pointing each time you clicked your mouse.
We experimented with the stamp block under pen, but could not make the flower appear when we clicked, so we added the if...then conditional with a mouse down sensing block in it.  It still wasn't working.  I explained to my daughter that when you clicked the green flag, it only checked one time to see if the mouse was down, so we would need a forever block wrapped around it, so the program would constantly check to see when the mouse was down.  The stamp feature still would not work, so we experimented with the create a clone of myself block.  It was working, but only one flower would be stamped, so we added a next costume block.  Now it printed three different flowers all at once.  Adding a wait block solved that issue.  Next, we wanted to hide the initial flower, so we added the hide block before the forever and put in a show block after the if...then conditional.  Finally, we had to decide whether or not to keep the Scratch Cat.  Of course, we kept him - he's the hero.  He gives the user a purpose and directions for planting a garden.

After looking at other people's projects, I liked how jrushing72 used functions to define drawing random sized/colored flowers.  I may use that example for my define a block lesson later this year.  I also found a project that had a similar problem as mine and I made a suggestion to add a wait block.
instructions: Click the green flag to start!
writing:
This was a tough challenge!  But we enjoyed making it!  Again, I worked with my daughter to complete this project.  Here are some things we tried.
First we found a background that would be suitable for planting flowers.
Then we created a flower sprite with three costumes. We wanted a different flower to appear where your mouse was pointing each time you clicked your mouse.
We experimented with the stamp block under pen, but could not make the flower appear when we clicked, so we added the if...then conditional with a mouse down sensing block in it.  It still wasn't working.  I explained to my daughter that when you clicked the green flag, it only checked one time to see if the mouse was down, so we would need a forever block wrapped around it, so the program would constantly check to see when the mouse was down.  The stamp feature still would not work, so we experimented with the create a clone of myself block.  It was working, but only one flower would be stamped, so we added a next costume block.  Now it printed three different flowers all at once.  Adding a wait block solved that issue.  Next, we wanted to hide the initial flower, so we added the hide block before the forever and put in a show block after the if...then conditional.  Finally, we had to decide whether or not to keep the Scratch Cat.  Of course, we kept him - he's the hero.  He gives the user a purpose and directions for planting a garden.

After looking at other people's projects, I liked how jrushing72 used functions to define drawing random sized/colored flowers.  I may use that example for my define a block lesson later this year.  I also found a project that had a similar problem as mine and I made a suggestion to add a wait block.     
Click the green flag to start!

title: Bloom to Fade: Getting Unstuck Day 2 Flowers
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 2 Flowers

Creativity: 
I realized right away that if you kept clicking and adding more flowers, the screen would get really full so that there would have to be some way for the flowers to disappear or be removed. I decided that their petals would fall to the ground before they faded away.

Production:
Fairly straightforward with a bit of testing and iteration. Drawing the flowers with Scratch's drawing tools was not that difficult. I did run into a bug where the flowers wouldn't change colour each time I clicked, because I put the code for that inside the "When a clone is created" block, rather than before the creation of the clone. That means each clone started at the first colour and only changed colour once, so they all ended up at the same colour. Additionally, I had some trouble working out the code to make the size of the flower depend on the y-position of the mouse when clicked. I did have to use my math skills on that one to figure out how to make the size a function of the y-position.

Getting Unstuck:
I went back to good old paper and pencil to graph the size of the flower as a function of the y-position of the mouse. I used y=mx+b and initially messed up on calculating my b value. The great thing about Scratch is that when I tested it, I saw immediately that the program wasn't doing what I expected it to do, so that I knew I had made an error. Not sure I would have caught that without the immediate feedback. Not so much getting unstuck with my coding as my coding helping me get unstuck with my math!
Still not sure how to make the flowers appear when the mouse button comes up, as you can simply hold the mouse down as you move it around on the screen.
instructions: Move the mouse around and click anywhere on the green grass!
