title: Rose Clicker
description: Getting Unstuck Challenge Day 2: "Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background." After playing around with unlimited rose clicks, I decided to keep score and limit it to a dozen, followed by a final message from the sun. Not too complicated, but fun!
instructions: Click the green flag to start, then click anywhere on the screen to grow a long-stemmed rose. Once you've grown a dozen, you'll receive a special message!
writing: Getting Unstuck Challenge Day 2: "Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background." After playing around with unlimited rose clicks, I decided to keep score and limit it to a dozen, followed by a final message from the sun. Not too complicated, but fun!Click the green flag to start, then click anywhere on the screen to grow a long-stemmed rose. Once you've grown a dozen, you'll receive a special message!

title: Moon Garden
description:
I've always liked creating "interactive gardens", so I was happy to have a chance to tinker with a new type of interactive garden as part of the Getting Unstuck initiative (challenge #2), organized by the ScratchEd Team: https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

The project using cloning to create multiple flowers. At first, I tried to broadcast a message directly from the stage to the flower sprite, telling it to clone. But that led to a bug, since the clones were also receiving the broadcast message. So I added a "seed" sprite as an intermediate sprite (between the stage and flower).
instructions: Click anywhere on the moon to plant a seed, then watch your flower grow!
writing:
I've always liked creating "interactive gardens", so I was happy to have a chance to tinker with a new type of interactive garden as part of the Getting Unstuck initiative (challenge #2), organized by the ScratchEd Team: https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

The project using cloning to create multiple flowers. At first, I tried to broadcast a message directly from the stage to the flower sprite, telling it to clone. But that led to a bug, since the clones were also receiving the broadcast message. So I added a "seed" sprite as an intermediate sprite (between the stage and flower).Click anywhere on the moon to plant a seed, then watch your flower grow!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2
description:
To continue my ocean theme, I decided to have coral reef appear instead of regular flowers for the challenge of displaying a flower every time the background is clicked. By having the coral change color with each click, I added a bit of the vibrancy that coral reef naturally brings to the oceans. 

This was definitely more of a challenge, but it certainly helped to be able to see how others approached the task.
instructions: Click the green flag. Then click anywhere to make the coral reef appear.
writing:
To continue my ocean theme, I decided to have coral reef appear instead of regular flowers for the challenge of displaying a flower every time the background is clicked. By having the coral change color with each click, I added a bit of the vibrancy that coral reef naturally brings to the oceans. 

This was definitely more of a challenge, but it certainly helped to be able to see how others approached the task. Click the green flag. Then click anywhere to make the coral reef appear.

title: Getting Unstuck Day #2: Flowers Dance
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 2 - Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background.
I remixed an old project to adapt it to the Day#2 challenge, making it interactive. It was not easy because there were so many sprites to control. 
The original project was made inspired by a wonderful e-card I received from a friend.
I tried to explore, wondering how could we make an e-card using Scratch. To give originality, I used a picture from an oil work made by myself.
From the picture, each small group of flowers was cut off to became a separated sprite. 
Each one goes into the valse "dancing".
Music:  Tchaikovsky's "Flowers Valse".
instructions:
click on the green flag to start.
Then click on the ground to add flowers to the vase.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2
description: I looked inside the beautiful project by rbotero for ideas on how to create this program. I tweaked the structure slightly so the flowers were not continuously generated when the mouse is clicked but rather allows time for the user to move around the screen to different locations before clicking again. When creating this project I learned more about the pen scripts. Previously I had never thought to use the stamp tool. I like that my project stamps the flower in three different colors.
instructions: First click the green flag to start/reset the program. Then click somewhere on the screen to plant a flower. You may repeat this process as many times as you desire. Have fun!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 2
description:
Unstuck thanks to @rbotero 's work

Icons made by Freepik from https://www.flaticon.com/ is licensed by Creative Commons BY 3.0

title: Cherry blossom
description:
- What did you like most about your project? 

I like the zoom effect on flowers.

- What would you do with it next, if you had more time?
If I have more time I'd like to draw my own flowers and make an animation of a cherry tree where flowers could blossom little by little.

--Credits--
I found the images on pixabay website:
https://pixabay.com/en/
instructions:
Click the mouse anywhere on the background and a flower will appear.

Getting Unstuck Day 2: Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background.

--Approach--
I decided to make a simple project by using the cloning.
At first, when I tested the program the flower appeared constantly and I didn't like it, so I used the ghost effect to disappear it thanks to a comment by @scratchteacheralpha032.
After that, I added a wait block each time I pressed the mouse, because I realized that when the flower started as a clone, it appeared like 3 flowers.
Then, I added like a zoom effect on the flower using "repeat blocks" and "change size blocks".
writing:
- What did you like most about your project? 

I like the zoom effect on flowers.

- What would you do with it next, if you had more time?
If I have more time I'd like to draw my own flowers and make an animation of a cherry tree where flowers could blossom little by little.

--Credits--
I found the images on pixabay website:
https://pixabay.com/en/Click the mouse anywhere on the background and a flower will appear.

Getting Unstuck Day 2: Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background.

--Approach--
I decided to make a simple project by using the cloning.
At first, when I tested the program the flower appeared constantly and I didn't like it, so I used the ghost effect to disappear it thanks to a comment by @scratchteacheralpha032.
After that, I added a wait block each time I pressed the mouse, because I realized that when the flower started as a clone, it appeared like 3 flowers.
Then, I added like a zoom effect on the flower using "repeat blocks" and "change size blocks".

title: Bug School
description:
This project responds to the prompt for Getting Unstuck:  Day 2:  "Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. There are at least three different ways of programming this in Scratch—what will your approach be?'"
I originally thought that the "Prof" sprite would draw the flowers, but realized that the coding would take a lot of time!  So I decided to go with the Stamp block and have a few different flower drawings in the form of costumes.

 I did get stuck at one point, and used the strategy "Ask a friend."  My teenage son was a great resource person :)
instructions: Click on the green flag to start, then click anywhere on the blackboard!

title: Sunflower Garden (pen)
description:
I wanted to create sunflowers by drawing with the pen blocks. One challenge I had was creating the color gradient on the petals to make them look like they were changing from orange to yellow-- I tried a few different ways but ultimately settled on changing color and shade in a loop and experimenting until I got the colors I wanted.

I had fun learning about the math of sunflowers! The seeds are in spirals called Fermat's spirals: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat%27s_spiral

Song: "Song for a Pea" for Podington Bear
instructions:
Click to place a sunflower!

One thing that I've loved about Scratch since I first started using it is that it allows you to apply math to create art. On the surface, this doesn't look like it uses math, but actually, it uses a lot of trig. Take a look inside!

title: Unstuck Day 2 - Increasing Flowers
description:
Challenge: Display a flower each time user clicks on background.

I realized that if I used broadcast on the background script, it would only allow me to create 9 clones. By changing the background script to create a clone of the flower when clicked, I can now create infinite clones. I had never done cloning before and found this tricky. But it makes sense now.

Update: I added a second background, changed the flower sprites to have multiple colors flowers and snazzed up the butterfly.
instructions: Click on flag to start. Then click on background to make flowers appear. When the sun sets, the flowers will disappear, although you can click and add more.

description:
I struggled to  manage the clones...at the beginning I've used the situation "when stage clicked" ---->"send message" but for every click The number of clones in each spot increases...so strange!!
I changed the code cheating a little bit....each time you click the mouse (no matter if it the stage or not) you'll create a clone!!
The bee is usefull to keep the a low number of clones at the same time..preventing lagging!! :)

title: Unstuck Challenge 2
description:
Reflection: 

1) I liked creating the flower in using the costume editing feature.  It was fun and I was able to create something simple.  This may be a tool I focus on more during my lessons.  It was a quick solution for me when I couldn't find the sprite I wanted. However, it may take a student longer to come to the same solution. 

2) I also liked adding in the background and the sun.  Having an open challenge like this allows for student creativity.  I can see using this as an extension activity for some of my scratch lessons for my students. 

3) If I had more time, I would probably add a way to delete the clones.  Another thing I could add is to have the flowers change color as they are created.
instructions: Click anywhere on the ground and help plant 10 flowers in the garden!
writing:
Reflection: 

1) I liked creating the flower in using the costume editing feature.  It was fun and I was able to create something simple.  This may be a tool I focus on more during my lessons.  It was a quick solution for me when I couldn't find the sprite I wanted. However, it may take a student longer to come to the same solution. 

2) I also liked adding in the background and the sun.  Having an open challenge like this allows for student creativity.  I can see using this as an extension activity for some of my scratch lessons for my students. 

3) If I had more time, I would probably add a way to delete the clones.  Another thing I could add is to have the flowers change color as they are created.  Click anywhere on the ground and help plant 10 flowers in the garden!

title: dandelion... sort of - Getting Unstuck day 2
description:
At start I planned  create a dandelion for every click but got stucked into drawing a realistic stem, the corolla was unsatisfying too.

Time to restart and think again on the problem. Note for me: Learn to draw stems, it shouldn't be so difficult! (Any suggestion, Anyone?)

I have got a new Idea, plant a seed and let the flower grow for a while and then wither,
The first part of the project was set, but the withering part let me a little depressed. Better let flowers fly away (and I already had the dandelion seeds).

The result is the project you see on the left.

What I would have done if I had more time.
===============================
Lets say that already used a little more time to create the project, I would have added an minimalistic ambient music, and maybe revert to the original project. 

The look is sketched as I feel it was the best option for this kind of project (apart that I'm not really strong at drawing).

The least pleasant part 
=================
As usual the sprite editor is not the best of the ones I've tried in this years but, it does his work quite well. Just it does not works as I expect and usually I resort to Inkscape to create my graphics. This time I stuck with the standard tools and had to work a little more to obtain something viable.

What Noticed looking around
=====================
instructions:
Click on the stage, i prefer the lower left triangle, to plant some dandelions and look at them spreading into the world.

If I was you I would click a lot and then pause for a while.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2
description:
Made for Getting Unstuck Day 2.

Inspired by Seymour Papert and Turtle Logo I thought I would use the pen tools and draw things that are a bit like crystal flowers. When doing any Logo I'm always reminded of a photo in the MIT museum of Seymour with one of the big early turtles.

I started with drawing the flowers in a random place but this felt a little strange so I changed it to draw at the mouse pointer to give the user more control. The random block is still there though, if you want to give it a try.
The next thing I'd like to do is let the user choose a colour from a palette. Maybe choose the line thickness as well.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag.
Click anywhere on the background to draw a flower.

title: Peony Season
description:
Peonies are one of my favorite flowers, but they only bloom between April and June. During these months, I fill my home with any many peonies as I can find.

I looked inside a few projects in the Day 2 studio before getting started on my project. It was interested to see the different strategies people used to accomplish their projects. 

I drew the peony in the Paint Editor. I knew I wanted the finished project to be a stage filled with peonies of all colors and sizes, so I played around with the color and size effects.
instructions: Click the stage to fill the screen with as many different-colored peonies as you'd like!
writing:
Peonies are one of my favorite flowers, but they only bloom between April and June. During these months, I fill my home with any many peonies as I can find.

I looked inside a few projects in the Day 2 studio before getting started on my project. It was interested to see the different strategies people used to accomplish their projects. 

I drew the peony in the Paint Editor. I knew I wanted the finished project to be a stage filled with peonies of all colors and sizes, so I played around with the color and size effects. 
Click the stage to fill the screen with as many different-colored peonies as you'd like!

title: Disegna tanti fiori
description:
Ho utilizzato le equazioni parametriche:
x = n sin mt  *  cos t              y = n sin mt  *  sin t
dove x e y sono le coordinate del punto in cui si trova la penna; dal parametro n dipende la dimensione del fiore; da m il numero di petali; al variare di t avviene lo spostamento che consente di tracciare le coppie di petali e completare un fiore; x1 e y1 sono le coordinate di un punto a partire dal quale viene disegnato un fiore e a,b le coordinate della penna in base a un sistema di riferimento che abbia l'origine in (x1,y1). OK, spero sia una spiegazione abbastanza chiara!       
    :)))
#gettingunstuck2
instructions: Clicca sulla bandierina verde, muovi il mouse e clicca per disegnare i fiori.

title: Getting_Unstuck_Day2
description:
This was fun but boy did I start overthinking it towards the end!

It highlighted an important part of the creative process - to have a broad goal in mind but also know that as you unpack the idea, you are likely to be think of new, creative aspects that you hadn't thought of at the start.

For this project, that meant adding a "reset" button and a "grow" button...

I was particularly proud of the (simple) scene changes to simulate the sun going down and a new day with a new field.

Another challenge was working out how to detect the colour green using the mouse so the flowers would only be planted in the field and not the sky.
instructions:
Click on the field to plant a random flower!

(Doesn't seem to work as well in full-screen mode?)

I was particularly proud of the (simple) scene changes to simulate the sun going down and a new day with a new field.

title: Fantastical Flowers
instructions:
Click the space bar to make a variety of flowers appear in random places on the screen. If you want more of a particular flower, you can make that happen, too. For orange flowers, click the up arrow key. For purple flowers, click the down arrow key. For additional yellow flowers, click on the left arrow key. Pink flowers will appear if you click on the right arrow key.

To start over with a new flower bed arrangement, just click the green flag.

This project is for Getting Unstuck, Day 2!

I don't usually use the stamp block, so I thought this would be a nice chance to experiment with it. I'd like to add lilypads in the next version (but I don't want them to overlap flowers - need to figure out how to get them to lie underneath if added).

Flower modified from Wikimedia Commons: https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?search=lilypond-logo&title=Special:Search&go=Go&searchToken=6re5otlvflgp1f6ku3466xld8#/media/File:LilyPond-logo.png

title: Flower Display- Day 2
description:
Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. 

**My getting unstuck strategy was, "Be Inspired by Others."  Thank you to the projects I looked at (I kept clicking on different ones so I can't remember which one exactly helped me!) who helped me figure out why my code wouldn't work.  I was forgetting to code, "When Stage Clicked," on my background!
instructions: Click the green flag to begin and use your mouse to make flowers appear!
writing:

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2
description:
Day 2's Getting Unstuck challenge.

The flowers are created by making clones. The flower is hidden when the user clicks the Green Flag. Each time the stage is clicked, a message is sent out. On receiving the message, the sprite clones itself. When a clone is created, it moves to where the mouse pointer is, and shows itself.
instructions: Press the Green Flag, then click on the stage - a flower will appear anywhere you click!
writing:
Day 2's Getting Unstuck challenge.

The flowers are created by making clones. The flower is hidden when the user clicks the Green Flag. Each time the stage is clicked, a message is sent out. On receiving the message, the sprite clones itself. When a clone is created, it moves to where the mouse pointer is, and shows itself.Press the Green Flag, then click on the stage - a flower will appear anywhere you click!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 2 Reflection:
The part of my project I like the best is that I figured out how to make the flowers different colors.  If I had more time, I'd like to figure out how to make them grow, and I'd like to make them different sizes.  It would be cool if there were different types of flowers too, instead of just different colors.
instructions: Click the green flag, then click on the stage to make the flowers appear.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 2
description:
This is my project for Day 2 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge.

I created the flower sprite with the Sprite paint editor and I used the stamp block for adding flowers to the stage. It can be done using the clone block too, but it's tricky, in my opinion.

Challenge archive:
https://us18.campaign-archive.com/home/?u=5dd4d8b32f719a30cbde507c6&id=cc0b423621
instructions: Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. There are at least three different ways of programming this in Scratch.

This might the beginning of a game or of an interactive story.

https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/index.html
instructions:
Click the green flag to start the gardening game.
The robot will tell you what you need to know.

Getting Unstuck Challenge 2: Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background. (In my project you click on the sun!)

Challenge: get the audience involved in telling your story. 
Behaviors to understand: clicking a sprite to make something else happen; cloning sprites; random numbers to position sprites.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 2
description: Day 2 and the challenge is already beyond what I previously knew!  I was able to design the flower sprite and choose the backdrop.  Then I had to look through several projects to figure out how to get the sprite to display when the background was clicked.  That led me to figuring out how to get the flowers in different sizes as well.
instructions: Click on the green flag and then a flower will display each time that the user clicks on the background.

That led me to figuring out how to get the flowers in different sizes as well.Click on the green flag and then a flower will display each time that the user clicks on the background.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 2: Growing Flowers
description: I borrowed code from a previous project I had done and modified it a bit to draw the flowers. If I had more time, I would add stems to the flowers & make sure they weren't going to be drawn in the sky.

title: Flower Power (Getting Unstuck #2)
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 2
Display a flower each time that the user clicks on the background.

Decided to use the stamp block to duplicate flowers when the background is clicked, still working on figuring out the clone option. Played around with the size and color to have a variety of flowers. Made it so the flowers appeared where the mouse - pointer was located. Decided to create the background, sun and flower sprites with the paint option.
instructions:
Click anywhere on the background to create a beautiful flower garden. 
Click on the sun for a fun message!
Click on the green flag to start over.

Used this project to create my own sprites.
Learned how to set each sprite to be hidden within the information box. I needed to refer to other projects to understand how to use clone and stamp blocks.  Hide and Show blocks were useful. Still a few bugs to work out.

title: Character Flowers
description:
Getting Stuck Day 2

I started by creating spiral flowers. I was going to move into creating fractal flowers. But got a little bogged down with this so went with the strategy "try something else". Tera Tulip and Giga Gladiolus were born!
instructions: Click the green flag to create Tera Tulip and Giga Gladiolus. Click the background to add more flowers. Enjoy your character garden.
writing:

title: AWV - Getting Unstuck, Day 2
description:
Getting Unstuck, day 2.
I think I should have used clone instead of stamp so that the user could change the appearance of multiple flowers instead of just the latest one. 

I played around with adding a wait before starting the stamp to avoid getting a flower in the upper right by the green flag, but couldn't figure out the right amount of time without causing too much of a delay for the other stamps.
instructions:
Click the mouse anywhere to make a flower appear. 
Press the space bar to change the appearance of the latest flower. 
Click the green flag to clear the scene and start over.

I like the flower garden that grows every time I play this project (and I've done it a good few times now! It's so much fun!)

If I had more time, I'd make more costumes for the flowers and add some sounds and music. Ah yes, music.

title: Piano Lessons
description:
As I began individually calling on each note, I knew there must be a way to set them to play one after another, though I wasn't sure how. I decided to ask a friend, @asparklekat, who showed me the variable blocks! I also used broadcast for the first time with this project -- both exciting discoveries!

If I were going to continue working on this project, I'd like to invite the audience to play their own song with the piano after hearing the sprite's song! Also maybe I should name the characters I created for day 1 of Getting Unstuck, especially if I'm going to continue to use them (:
instructions: After pressing the green flag, start by pressing the space key!
writing:
As I began individually calling on each note, I knew there must be a way to set them to play one after another, though I wasn't sure how. I decided to ask a friend, @asparklekat, who showed me the variable blocks! I also used broadcast for the first time with this project -- both exciting discoveries!

If I were going to continue working on this project, I'd like to invite the audience to play their own song with the piano after hearing the sprite's song! Also maybe I should name the characters I created for day 1 of Getting Unstuck, especially if I'm going to continue to use them (: After pressing the green flag, start by pressing the space key!

title: Dance with the chords
description: If I had more time I'd actually implement a I-IV-V7-I or perhaps a I-V-vi-IV - maybe later!
instructions:
I wanted to think more about chords, so I made this to help me think!

+ Press space to start the notes.
+ Press up arrow key to start the drum.
+ Press the right key to freeze the action!
writing:
If I had more time I'd actually implement a I-IV-V7-I or perhaps a I-V-vi-IV - maybe later!I wanted to think more about chords, so I made this to help me think!

+ Press the right key to freeze the action!

title: Bottles! remix
description:
When I first saw @threeships' original Bottles! project created for a class we were taking together, I was blown away -- literally! I was mesmerized by her process and wanted to create a musical project, too! I'm so glad to be remixing the project now!

If I had some more time, I would draw some more instruments and record some weird sounds to put in there, too!
instructions:
After clicking the green flag...
The wind is blowing magical powers into the bottles, allowing them to play many instruments! Click the bottles to play! (and click the green flag to reset if you'd like)
writing:
When I first saw @threeships' original Bottles! project created for a class we were taking together, I was blown away -- literally! I was mesmerized by her process and wanted to create a musical project, too! I'm so glad to be remixing the project now!

If I had some more time, I would draw some more instruments and record some weird sounds to put in there, too!After clicking the green flag...
The wind is blowing magical powers into the bottles, allowing them to play many instruments! Click the bottles to play! (and click the green flag to reset if you'd like)

title: Twinkle
description:
I started with the suggested prompt from today's challenge (i.e., "you could play piano notes 1 to 120 at 240 bpm, with 0.5 beats per note") and used that as the soundtrack to nightfall. I then transitioned to using the "play note" blocks to play "Twinkle, Twinkle". This was a chance for me to use cloning (which I had aspired to use with my Day 2 project, but didn't make work).

I really like the twinkling effect in my project and the choice of pizzicato for the music. (Thanks to @jsh for introducing me to that instrument choice.) There are currently a couple of star/melody line synchronization issues that I'd like to smooth out!
instructions: Press the green flag.
writing:
I started with the suggested prompt from today's challenge (i.e., "you could play piano notes 1 to 120 at 240 bpm, with 0.5 beats per note") and used that as the soundtrack to nightfall. I then transitioned to using the "play note" blocks to play "Twinkle, Twinkle". This was a chance for me to use cloning (which I had aspired to use with my Day 2 project, but didn't make work).

I really like the twinkling effect in my project and the choice of pizzicato for the music. (Thanks to @jsh for introducing me to that instrument choice.) There are currently a couple of star/melody line synchronization issues that I'd like to smooth out!Press the green flag.

title: day 3 the dance
description:
Big question!
I noticed that the notes went up in 2s. I created a variable note and set it at 60 and tried to play note +2 the way you would animate movement by incrementing the x or y value but I couldn't put that operator in the sound block! Than I used the next note with an operator and that worked better.

I wonder about the difference between change the tempo and rest...

If I had more time, I would make the dancer dance more in between the music... not sure how.. 

Doing these exercises each day is creating greater empathy in me for when my students want to spend more time on projects!
instructions: Just click the green flag for the performance.

title: Unstuck Day 03 World Cup 2018 Game Seven Nation Army
description:
This game was originally made during a summer camp held while World Cup 2014 was being played. I remixed it while watching the 2018 Sweden vs. England quarterfinal match.

To meet the Day 03 Getting Unstuck challenge, I added the stadium chant Seven Nation Army melody to play whenever a goal is scored. The original played the "triumph" sound effect.
instructions:
Score as many points as you can in ten shots! Longer shots and higher goalie difficulty (both randomly selected) = higher points.
The mouse, when pressed, aims the ball.
Up and down arrow keys adjust speed up and down, but be careful - too much speed just might send the ball over the goal.
Left and right arrow keys curve the ball slightly to the left (negative curve) or right (positive curve). It takes a while to get the hang of how much curve you want. I am considering making the curve something you can adjust while the ball is moving towards the goal.
Space bar shoots the ball. 
If you use sliders to adjust speed and curve, aim after making the adjustments.

The original played the "triumph" sound effect.Score as many points as you can in ten shots! Longer shots and higher goalie difficulty (both randomly selected) = higher points.
The mouse, when pressed, aims the ball.
Up and down arrow keys adjust speed up and down, but be careful - too much speed just might send the ball over the goal.
Left and right arrow keys curve the ball slightly to the left (negative curve) or right (positive curve). It takes a while to get the hang of how much curve you want. I am considering making the curve something you can adjust while the ball is moving towards the goal.
Space bar shoots the ball. 
If you use sliders to adjust speed and curve, aim after making the adjustments.

title: Scratch-808 Drum Machine
description:
Reflection

I decided to build a drum machine. I built one in Scratch many years ago, but there was some issues with the timing of sample playback. So I decided to use today's topic as a reason to rebuild it from scratch. While the tempo is still a little janky, it's a major improvement over the original. I'm also hopeful this will run better in Scratch 3, as my experience with it indicates that it is far more strongly timed than Scratch 2.

To make this project work, I make extensive use of variables and cloning.

If I were to spend more time on this, I would use samples from a real Roland-808. The presentation could be improved on. I could also organize this better by placing duplicated code into custom blocks.

Update: Refactored the code which increases the performance of the drum machine. Instead of having 5 step button sprites for each row, only 1 step button is used to spawn all 80.

Originally, each of the 80 step buttons we're responsible for responding to triggers. Hence, 80 if blocks were being run per trigger. Now the trigger logic has been moved into a single sprite, so now only 5 triggers / conditional blocks are used.

The result is a more strongly-timed drum machine. That is, it's less janky.

Update 2: Found a way to improve timing. Inside the clock sprite I created the "update step" block and enable "Run without screen refresh". Then I moved over the code from the "When I receive  trigger".
instructions:
1) Press the Play button to start.
2) Control the tempo with the slider.
3) Press the buttons to activate and de-active which sounds are played.

So I decided to use today's topic as a reason to rebuild it from scratch. While the tempo is still a little janky, it's a major improvement over the original. I'm also hopeful this will run better in Scratch 3, as my experience with it indicates that it is far more strongly timed than Scratch 2.

To make this project work, I make extensive use of variables and cloning.

If I were to spend more time on this, I would use samples from a real Roland-808. The presentation could be improved on. I could also organize this better by placing duplicated code into custom blocks.

Update: Refactored the code which increases the performance of the drum machine. Instead of having 5 step button sprites for each row, only 1 step button is used to spawn all 80.

Originally, each of the 80 step buttons we're responsible for responding to triggers. Hence, 80 if blocks were being run per trigger. Now the trigger logic has been moved into a single sprite, so now only 5 triggers / conditional blocks are used.

The result is a more strongly-timed drum machine. That is, it's less janky.

Update 2: Found a way to improve timing. Inside the clock sprite I created the "update step" block and enable "Run without screen refresh". Then I moved over the code from the "When I receive  trigger".1) Press the Play button to start.
2) Control the tempo with the slider.
3) Press the buttons to activate and de-active which sounds are played.

title: Memory
description:
This project was created for Day 3 of Getting Unstuck. Here, we pick up the story of the cat and bear. After an initial chance encounter (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235478923), the bear tries to hold on to his fleeting memory of the cat. Could it ever work?

It was a lot of fun exploring some of the limits of music generation with Scratch. If I had more time, I would transcribe more of the epic soundtrack. But I think my simple music player might quickly be overwhelmed by more simultaneous notes or more complex rhythms. 

The implementation of rotational motion used in this project was borrowed from another project that I made several years ago. 

Music: Ludwig van Beethoven, "Moonlight Sonata"
instructions: Help the bear focus his memory by moving your mouse cursor (like, a lot).

title: Unstuck Day 3: Making Music
description:
Things I got stuck on:
-first started with a single button to toggle pick & play and a finger sprite to click it. discovered that a sprite can't detect it is clicked if another sprite is following your mouse.
-toggle system got complicated so I changed to separate buttons for pick and play
-adding note values to the list based on the y position was pretty simple except last item was always played as a low boom, realized first item is 1 not 0 so had to start playing on item 1 not 0 as in lists and arrays.
-had to get a mapping function from here an adapt it https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/3266303/
-kept adding another note when I click the PLAY button so had to add condition that X position is > 0
instructions: Click the bar on the right to choose some notes, then click PLAY to play your melody. Pick more notes when you want a different melody by clicking the PICK button.
writing:
Things I got stuck on:
-first started with a single button to toggle pick & play and a finger sprite to click it. discovered that a sprite can't detect it is clicked if another sprite is following your mouse.
-toggle system got complicated so I changed to separate buttons for pick and play
-adding note values to the list based on the y position was pretty simple except last item was always played as a low boom, realized first item is 1 not 0 so had to start playing on item 1 not 0 as in lists and arrays.
-had to get a mapping function from here an adapt it https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/3266303/
-kept adding another note when I click the PLAY button so had to add condition that X position is > 0Click the bar on the right to choose some notes, then click PLAY to play your melody. Pick more notes when you want a different melody by clicking the PICK button.

title: Day 3
description:
I reused part of an old project here - I had already worked out this exceptionally rough rendition of "Girl From Ipanema", I added movement, tried a variety of other instruments and tried working out "I Go to Rio" - I also added text so no one would have to try to figure out what that noise was!
I started working on letting the kids have fun exploring sound the last nine weeks - to be honest, I rarely allow them to use it in class because I cannot take 6 straight classes of non-stop meowing! I find that headsets cut collaboration drastically, so I almost never have kids use those either.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 3: Bouncy Ball Piano
description:
I spent *way* too much time working on yesterday's project, so I wanted to keep today's simple. I went with the suggestion of playing notes in succession, and went back to look at a project by @karenb to remind myself how to use variables and increase them each time. I thought about doing a more complicated animation, but liked the idea of a little ball moving around space while music plays.

I didn't get nearly as stuck today as I did yesterday, but I did utilize the strategy of looking at another project to see how they tackled this idea!
instructions: Click the green flag to hear the piano play piano notes 1 to 120.

writing:
Music intimidates me, so I was already off my game when I saw the directions. I had never explored the music blocks before so this pushed me to explore a new area.

I borrowed ogranatedu's (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235760857/#player) idea to play Mary Had a Little Lamb and added the option of choosing which instrument to play it in.Click the green flag to start.

Click an instrument to play. 

Then click either the letters on the screen or they keyboard letters to play Mary Had a Little Lamb.

title: GettingUnstuck-03
instructions:
I "play" cello and I'm really curious about video-sensing, so I mixed them in this project.
Green flag to start, move in front of the camera: the direction of your movement affects the tone you play.
Still a draft since I want to better calibrate sensing and add (maybe) dependence between tempo and movement.

Still a draft since I want to better calibrate sensing and add (maybe) dependence between tempo and movement.

title: GU_Day3
description:
Day 3 of Getting Unstuck: I had already started experimenting with this project. 
Music and math :) Piano key string lengths are: 1, 8/9, 4/5, 3/4, 2/3, 3/5, 8/15 and 1/2 (no sharps or flats are included).
The least common denominator is 180.
The numbers used for each string length represent the numerators with 180 as the common denominator.
instructions: Click on the green flag to begin. After the piano strings and black circles appear, you may start playing!

title: Fleurs musicales: Getting Unstuck Day 3 Notes
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 3 Notes

Quickie remix of my own project, adding a piano note every time a flower is produced. The tone of the note is determined by the same variable as the size of the flower (between about 100 and 25). Had to round the variable, as tones in between whole numbers were not super pretty.
instructions: Move the mouse around and click anywhere on the green grass!
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 3 Notes

Quickie remix of my own project, adding a piano note every time a flower is produced. The tone of the note is determined by the same variable as the size of the flower (between about 100 and 25). Had to round the variable, as tones in between whole numbers were not super pretty.Move the mouse around and click anywhere on the green grass!

title: Getting Unstuck #3: Playing a musical instrument
description:
I wish I knew how to play piano! I had though so much fun running similar scratch projects and seeing so many unique projects!

Scratch project was created as activity #3 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.
Day #3 Challenge: Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?
instructions: Press the green flag.
writing:
I wish I knew how to play piano! I had though so much fun running similar scratch projects and seeing so many unique projects!

Scratch project was created as activity #3 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

title: Silly Sliding Scale Singer
description:
I harvested the costume assets from a previous ScratchX + Micro:Bit project to make this 'instrument.'

Scratch cleverly provides a dropdown keyboard in the 'play note' block to show which notes you are choosing, and I used this tool to build lists of notes in the scales I wanted to play.
instructions:
Slide the 'Note Picker' variable to sing up and down the scale.

Press the buttons to pick a different scale to sing.

Made for Day 3 of Getting Unstuck: Using the 'play note' block

title: Drumtastic
description:
I used the book 'Coding Projects in Scratch - A step-by-step visual guide to coding your own animations, games, simulations, and more!' by Jon Woodcock @RoboSquid to help me create this project. I bought this book for use with my students with the intention of checking it out this summer. 

I used the 'play a drum' block instead of 'play a note' block. I'd like to tinker around further and try to use the 'play a note' block in the project instead.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to begin and type letters, words (or whatever you'd like) to turn the letters into repeating drum sounds.

Use the up or down arrows to change the tempo. Use the space bar to reset the tempo.
writing:
I used the book 'Coding Projects in Scratch - A step-by-step visual guide to coding your own animations, games, simulations, and more!' by Jon Woodcock @RoboSquid to help me create this project. I bought this book for use with my students with the intention of checking it out this summer. 

I used the 'play a drum' block instead of 'play a note' block. I'd like to tinker around further and try to use the 'play a note' block in the project instead. Click the Green Flag to begin and type letters, words (or whatever you'd like) to turn the letters into repeating drum sounds.

Use the up or down arrows to change the tempo. Use the space bar to reset the tempo.

title: Getting Unstuck 3
description:
Original video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b9viv_A60Mk
Source for music notes: https://pianoletternotes.blogspot.com/2017/10/swan-lake-op-20-dance-of-little-swans.html

I used giphy.com to turn 10 seconds of the video into a gif. Then I used and animated that gif for the backdrops.

My year of piano lessons at the age of 10 stood me in good stead when translating the notes from pianoletternotes.com into the tones in Scratch. The timing is still a little off, but that's okay.

This project was a lot of fun, if frustrating at times. I enjoyed playing with blocks I haven't used much before.

title: Music from Words
description:
Is something like a musical alphabet. Here I have used an easy algorithm: the A letter plays the note 48 (that is C), B plays 49( C#)  and so on in sequence. More complex algorithms can be experimented.

updated for Getting Unstuck challenge
instructions:
Insert the word to be transformed into music
you can change the Instrument to play, the number of times it repeats the music and the BPM, moving the slider on the corrispective items

Play Again button to listen again the musc
New Word button to insert a new word

title: GettingUnstuck#3 - Basic Piano
description:
Written as part of challenge#3 of "Getting Unstuck" - "Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category"

Didn't have much time today so went with a basic keyboard with specific buttons to play the notes. Would have loved to have made the whole key play the note when clicked (and include the black keys). 

Maybe other people's projects will give clues for maybe making a section of background act like a sprite and respond to clicks? Or fire a click event just on the background as a whole but the code know what section it was in based on co-ordinates (tricky with odd shapes).
instructions: Click the play buttons to play the white keyboard notes.
writing:

Maybe other people's projects will give clues for maybe making a section of background act like a sprite and respond to clicks? Or fire a click event just on the background as a whole but the code know what section it was in based on co-ordinates (tricky with odd shapes).Click the play buttons to play the white keyboard notes.

title: Musical treasure chest
description:
I've created a mini game where a sound effect (making with some musical notes) sounds where the character touches a treasure chest while earns a treasure. 
I was wondering how to play an easy song or an effect from my favourite video game soundtracks. I realized that it was very difficult, so I decided to make a sound effect from the "Legend Of Zelda: A Link to the past" when you get a treasure.

--Questions--:
-What did you like most about your project? 
I love the idea to use the webcam to create a more interactive game and the choice of making an easy sound effect with a different instrument.

-What would you do with it next, if you had more time?
I'd like to make more musical effects.

--Credits--
Some images like treasures and treasure chest are from pixabay:
https://pixabay.com/en/
The main character is created with the Scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Use your hand to move the duck towards a treasure chest.
Try to get as many treasures as possible in 30 seconds.
Good luck!

*You can play with others and try to earn more points than them.

--Getting Unstuck Day 3--:
Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category.

title: Day 3 - Brazil
description:
I quickly deviated from my initial plan and became interested in trying to simulate a tune using sheet music equivalents. I took the sheet music for Brazil and entered the notes into a spreadsheet to calculate the numeric equivalents and assigned formatting to note values such as whole notes were bold, quarter notes italic, etc. When I plotted the notation into Scratch, however, it didn't really hold up. Not sure if it's my shortcomings in music or in Scratch. :) Fun, all the same.

Day 3 - Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. For example, you could play piano notes 1 to 120 at 240 bpm, with 0.5 beats per note. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?
instructions: Click flag to start

I quickly deviated from my initial plan and became interested in trying to simulate a tune using sheet music equivalents. I took the sheet music for Brazil and entered the notes into a spreadsheet to calculate the numeric equivalents and assigned formatting to note values such as whole notes were bold, quarter notes italic, etc. When I plotted the notation into Scratch, however, it didn't really hold up. Not sure if it's my shortcomings in music or in Scratch. :) Fun, all the same.

Day 3 - Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. For example, you could play piano notes 1 to 120 at 240 bpm, with 0.5 beats per note. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing? Click flag to start

title: Day 3 Unstuck: Random Bubbles
description:
I love bubbles so I decided that I wanted to use bubbles in this project. Random block used to change size, look, note and the instrument that will play.  Again I used the clone blocks to make lots of bubbles!
What did you like most about your project? I like the bubble graphic which I found with a quick search on Scratch.  Thanks to @naimora for a beautifully drawn bubble!  What would you do with it next, if you had more time? I would like to have added another costume or 2 to animated the bubble popping.
instructions:
Move the cursor over the bubbles to hear the notes.  
If you click the bubbles they will pop!   
Press the Space Bar to change the instrument-you never know what instrument you will get as it set to random!

Getting Unstuck Day 3: Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category.

title: Getting Unstuck day 3: Piano Happy birthday
More Cowbell!
description: This project is for Getting Unstuck: Day 3 and focuses on the "play note" block. For some reason, this old Saturday Night Live skit came to mind, so I thought it would be fun to interactively click Will Farrell's cowbell during the intro to Blue Oyster Cult's "Don't Fear the Reaper." One problem I'm having is that the guitar and bass go out of sync after a while, even though the total number of beats and rests are identical. Hopefully I can fix that. I might also add more lines from Christopher Walken.
instructions: Click the green flag to start. Once you hear the "Don't Fear the Reaper" opening riff, wait for the right moment to click the cowbell. You will, of course, be reminded to provide MORE COWBELL.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 3 - Ukulele
description:
I am so proud of this project! 
The first time I taught using Scratch was during our sound unit. During this sound unit we typically show students a youtube video of vibrating strings on a guitar while a song is being played. This program is inspired by these youtube videos and programs designed by StephanieLing and angiulina84 for Getting Unstuck Day 3.
instructions: Start the program by clicking on the green flag. Then move the red pick to each ukulele string and click to play the note.
writing:
I am so proud of this project! 
The first time I taught using Scratch was during our sound unit. During this sound unit we typically show students a youtube video of vibrating strings on a guitar while a song is being played. This program is inspired by these youtube videos and programs designed by StephanieLing and angiulina84 for Getting Unstuck Day 3.Start the program by clicking on the green flag. Then move the red pick to each ukulele string and click to play the note.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 3: Xantolo
description:
This projects is based in a Mexican tradition in the city of Tempoal, Veracruz, México. It is celebrated on the Day of the Dead, November 2nd. People wear masks and dance all night as they say wearing masks will fool the Death so it doesn't take their soul. This is part of a research project with my students. 

Definitely this is my weak side. I'm a terrible musician so I just experimented with changing notes randomly. What I would change in my project is to at least simulate in simple notes the real music you can hear at the end :D

Music:
instructions: Play the Green flag and enjoy the show.

title: Faucet tune
description:
This project responds to the prompt for Getting Unstuck:  Day 3:  "Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. For example, you could play piano notes 1 to 120 at 240 bpm, with 0.5 beats per note. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?'"  I decided to take it in a slightly different direction, using faucets rather than instrument sprites.

Today's strategy was "Take a Break."  I started with a concept, but didn't know in which way to take it.  I let my ideas "percolate" until the end of the day, and then they flowed easily (pun intended!).

Faucet image:  www.pixabay.com

title: Musical Spinner
description:
Today I was stuck. I've spent a lot of time deciding what to do, and went back and forth among multiple projects ideas. Maybe it was also because it was late at night and I was exhausted and jetlagged. But I really didn't want to break the chain! So I had a look to the strategies on the website and choose to "make a small goal today".

I already had the pinwheel spinning project, so I decided to add the sound playing with the tempo and the pitch of the notes, according to the spinning speed. If I had more time I would tinker more with tempo, notes and instrument to make it sound better.

Enjoy!
instructions: Click multiple times on the pinwheel to make it spin and make music!
writing:
Today I was stuck. I've spent a lot of time deciding what to do, and went back and forth among multiple projects ideas. Maybe it was also because it was late at night and I was exhausted and jetlagged. But I really didn't want to break the chain! So I had a look to the strategies on the website and choose to "make a small goal today".

I already had the pinwheel spinning project, so I decided to add the sound playing with the tempo and the pitch of the notes, according to the spinning speed. If I had more time I would tinker more with tempo, notes and instrument to make it sound better.

Enjoy!Click multiple times on the pinwheel to make it spin and make music!

title: Banana Piano
description:
I'm a teacher who's trying to learn as much Scratch as some of my 6th graders know.  I'm also introducing them to the use of littleBits (http://littlebits.cc). Watch my sons use bananas to try and play this game: https://youtu.be/8D4JgkU6JWU
You can easily remix this game to change the sounds, colors, effects, and if you have a MakeyMakey, keys. The littleBits MakeyMakey only offers three keys as far as I know.

I used this as part of my #GettingUnstuck Day 3 challenge because I'm a day behind and thought I'd catch up by using an existing Scratch program of mine.
instructions:
If you want to play this game, you can just click the green flag to start and use the left and right arrows and the space bar to make crazy colors, effects, and random sounds.
This was intended however to explore some of the ways to use the MakeyMakeyBit from littleBits. This bit allows you to touch any conductive surface instead of the keys. Check the videos in the credits to see my sons playing this game with bananas.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 3
description:
Everything set at random, so different result every time you press the green flag!

I started just doodling with sound blocks and random numbers. Then I though about something I'd seen in a Sonic Pi tutorial where you restart the random number generator to create a repeating sequence to give a repeating rhythm. I like Scratch Cat so for visuals I just keyed Size to the pitch. I ran out of time, but would like to find ways to make the note sequence more musical.
instructions:

So making any scratch projects that include music isn't something I generally think about. I know plenty of my students are interested in it though, so I really need to keep it in mind.

Click the green flag, give scratch a second to collect his thoughts, then start music! Whenever Scratch is touching a drum, it will play, and he can add to the background music!

title: Play the Stage
description:
I created this project in response to Challenge #3 in the "Getting Unstuck" initiative from the ScratchEd Team https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

The core of the program includes calculations for "scaling" the x and y positions of the mouse to the appropriate inputs for the pitch and instrument of the note. Also, I created a list of midi-notes so that the notes would be constrained to the white keys on the piano keyboard (a major scale). See the comments in the code for an explanation of how I did the calculations for the scaling.
instructions:
Click on the stage to hear a musical note. As you move left and right (x position), the pitch changes. As you move up and down (y position), the instrument changes.

To explore the space of possible notes and instruments, hold down the mouse button as you move the mouse around the stage.

Also, I created a list of midi-notes so that the notes would be constrained to the white keys on the piano keyboard (a major scale). See the comments in the code for an explanation of how I did the calculations for the scaling.Click on the stage to hear a musical note. As you move left and right (x position), the pitch changes. title: Unstuck Day 3 - Play Note Block
description:
I thought about adding the x coordinate as well. Actually tested this out, but with both going on it was difficult to distinguish sounds. Also thought about adding a keystroke to switch between Y and X values.

This project helped me to realize that Scratch can be such a terrific simulator for science and math applications if you plan it well.

Much to add here potentially. Allow for adjustment of volume, speed of ball (by adjusting beat value), gravity effect, more.
instructions:

Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. 

Click the flag to begin. A random instrument will play and its tone will change based on the height of the ball. 

Click on the "i" key to change to another random instrument.

description:
Made for Getting Unstuck Day 3.
Music has never been a strong point and it often intimidated me when I was younger, so this project was a challenge.
I decided to use maths to alter the note played, allowing the user to create a different note by interacting with the project.

I wonder if it's possible to add more instruments?

Use the up or down arrow keys to move Scratch up and down.
What do you notice about the note produced?

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 3
description: The code I used for the chords is code we used with students when they designed an instrument and then coded the instrument to play with a Makey Makey board.  I tried adding 3 instruments and wanted to be able to have each instrument play its own sound.  I am still working on that part of the code.
instructions:
To play the various chords press and hold the following letters for each chord and then the numbers 1-6 for the notes.

Chord A press the letter a while tapping the 2-6 number keys
Chord C press the letter c while tapping the 2-6 number keys
Chord D press the letter d while tapping the 3-6 number keys
Chord E press the letter e while tapping the 1-6 number keys
Chord G press the letter g while tapping the 1-6 number keys

Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. For example, you could play piano notes 1 to 120 at 240 bpm, with 0.5 beats per note. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?
writing:
The code I used for the chords is code we used with students when they designed an instrument and then coded the instrument to play with a Makey Makey board.  I tried adding 3 instruments and wanted to be able to have each instrument play its own sound.  I am still working on that part of the code.To play the various chords press and hold the following letters for each chord and then the numbers 1-6 for the notes.

Chord A press the letter a while tapping the 2-6 number keys
Chord C press the letter c while tapping the 2-6 number keys
Chord D press the letter d while tapping the 3-6 number keys
Chord E press the letter e while tapping the 1-6 number keys
Chord G press the letter g while tapping the 1-6 number keys

Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. For example, you could play piano notes 1 to 120 at 240 bpm, with 0.5 beats per note. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?

title: Unstuck - Day 3
description:
When I first read this challenge, I was immediately excited!  I have been wanting to sit and compose an electronic piece of music using Scratch, but never really sat down to do it.  I took the ending line from a song that has sentimental value to me and my family and arranged it using Scratch.  I assigned the Scratch Cat the soprano line and gave Giga the descant.  My daughter helped out (and practiced her music reading skills) by reading off the notes to me while I coded them.  When we finished, we experimented with the instruments and adjusted the tempo.  Not bad for our first attempt with creating harmony.  In the future we'll play around with changing the tempo at the end and adjusting the volume level of each voice.

"My Home Among the Hills" was written by E.W. James.

My Home Among the Hills Picture: https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=images&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwiv1omt75DcAhUSU98KHarxDVoQjRx6BAgBEAU&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DZDZeioiCHWY&psig=AOvVaw0Y2lYM0o-vchFI9Y84YTmE&ust=1531186230932837
instructions: Click the green flag for music!

I may still go back and and animate the instruments while they are playing.

title: Happy Birthday to You!
description: This is the first project I have ever created and finished with my own original idea!  I am so excited to share.  I found it really challenging and rewarding to be in the position of a "learner" and "creator".  I did get some inspiration from the "Unstuck" page. One time I deleted my whole script and had to start over!  I walked away and came back several hours later and recreated it, much faster and much easier the second time around!
instructions: Use the letters on the key board to play the tune!

title: Getting_Unstuck_Day3
description:
Reflection:
This isn't exactly what was asked for but I did play around with sound.

I wanted to have a series of frogs and when you clicked on each frog it played a different note.  But I couldn't find different frog noises and I wasn't able to change the pitch from within Scratch.

The main difficulty I had was trying to get the frogs to sound off together.  It seems that you can't have the one sound starting multiple times.  So used a random start time to at least have the sound happen a couple of times.

If I had time, I would upload a few different sounds so we can have a true chorus!
instructions:
Frog Chorus!

Click on a frog to have his friends join him on the wall.

But watch out! If there are too many frogs on the wall, the flies might get cranky!!

title: Insomnia - Getting Unstuck day 3
description:
I didn't get to far trying to explore the world of sound, so resorted to try generative music and stumble on a pair of video using music to explore the digits of PI and the Fibonacci sequence.

I HAD to try to do something in that direction and here there is the awful result. Though after several listenings it still does feel a little weird, I start to appreciate it.

What I would do it I had more time
=========================
Lear to play an isntrument, but it is really too time consuming, at present.
instructions: Just press the gree flag and try to enjoy the music (at the end I start to find it a little hypnotic, expecially the Fibonacci section.

title: 3 : Starwars
description:
Noder found at https://www.noteflight.com/

This is a copy of a project I made last year 

Starwars - played on saxofon and a piano. It took some time to find out that the easiest way to get the two instruments to play together was adding a third sprite (the conductor) who decides when to go on to the next part.
instructions:
Hør Starwars - spillet på saxofon og klaver. Det tog et par dage at finde den smarteste måde at lave dette projekt på, og jeg lærte rigtigt meget om musik-brikkerne. Efter 1 dags arbejde fandt jeg ud af, at hvis man vil lave musik med melodi og akkorder er det lettest at bryde musiksstykket op i de enkelte takter og så sætte en dirigent ind til at styre værket. 

Experiment with Starwars, music blocs and my own blocks.. Enjoy. 2 days work. If you want to hear the music played on other instruments - use the code to change them.

title: Pastel Pentatonics
description:
"Oh! Susanna" music from
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentatonic_scale

The hope was to have an animated character sing each note of a particular type of scale; as the characters emerged in pastel colors, the scale alliteratively became the pastel pentatonic scale.... A 'creative constraint' was to try to get to bed at a reasonable time. ;)
instructions:
Click the green flag to reset starting positions, if needed.
Click each soloist of the Pastel Pentatonics choir to have it sing a note in the Pentatonic scale.
Click the background to see the first two phrases of the music 'Oh, Susanna' -- which is written using a pentatonic scale.

"Oh! Susanna" music from
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentatonic_scale

The hope was to have an animated character sing each note of a particular type of scale; as the characters emerged in pastel colors, the scale alliteratively became the pastel pentatonic scale.... A 'creative constraint' was to try to get to bed at a reasonable time. ;)

title: Getting Unstuck Day 3
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 3 Reflection:
I liked that I could showcase different types of instruments and their sounds, but the types of instrument sounds didn't match up too well with the Scratch sprite library.  If I had more time, I would have looked elsewhere for clip art.  I also would have written out scripts for the whole song instead of just the first line, and added some sort of a hint for when to start the next instrument.
instructions: Click each instrument to start the song.  See if you can figure out when to start the next instrument to play Row Row Row Your Boat in a round.

I remixed this awhile ago and tweaked it a bit today. The timing is still off a bit on the round but the general idea is there.

Playing with the timing using a broadcast block to start the song on both sprites. It seems a bit better, I think.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 3
description: This one was much easier for me than the first two! I just needed to find a tune and I was able to use the keyboard on the "play note" block.  I opened up a few projects with longer tunes because I didn't want to write the entire song, and that was how I figured out how to break it up into "messages".  I was super happy that my daughter started singing the right song while I was piecing it out!

title: musical toy - musical radar
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 3
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?

Some ideas are by Marceau.

I got stuck on this, and decided to abandon this circular version and pivot towards a more traditional (but also more usable) horizontal version instead. cf https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236954426/
instructions:
It's a sequencer, in circular form.

Click anywhere on the stage to add a new note to be played by the "musical radar".

Press space to start with a clean sheet.

(See https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236954426/ for a newer version)

Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?

I got stuck on this, and decided to abandon this circular version and pivot towards a more traditional (but also more usable) horizontal version instead. cf https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236954426/It's a sequencer, in circular form.

title: musical toy - sequencer
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 3
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?

Some ideas are by Marceau and Sara.

I got stuck for a while because the collision detection (notes&line) was not triggering anymore. I debugged this by taking the whole code apart, but in the end it turned out to be the line's costume! When the line is too thin (as lines tend to be!) then for some reason the "touching line" block reports false :(
instructions:
It's a note sequencer.

Click anywhere on the stage to add a new note.
Notes are played once the moving line gets to it. 

Click a note to delete it.

Press space to show some settings, or T for some test notes.

https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
Explore playing a musical instrument with Scratch through the "play note" block in the Sound category. What triggers the playing? What happens while the notes are playing?

I got stuck for a while because the collision detection (notes&line) was not triggering anymore. I debugged this by taking the whole code apart, but in the end it turned out to be the line's costume! When the line is too thin (as lines tend to be!) then for some reason the "touching line" block reports false :(It's a note sequencer.

Click anywhere on the stage to add a new note.
Notes are played once the moving line gets to it. 

Click a note to delete it.

Press space to show some settings, or T for some test notes.

title: The Time Laboratory
description:
Ugh! I definitely took on more than I anticipated with this project. I thought it would be really cool to know how long I've been alive. But calculating the number of days is SO complicated! So I did a very crude estimate. I marked this as draft because it's kind of a mess. It's hard to share work that I feel so uncertain about—but I think it's good for me. :) #learning

Images from https://commons.wikimedia.org/
Laboratory: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Laboratory#/media/File:Photographing_Sound_in_1884._A_rare_photograph_taken_at_Volta_Laboratory_by_J._Harris_Rogers,_a_friend_of_Bell_and_Tainter_(Smithsonian_photo_44312-E)_i009.jpg

Scientist:
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f7/MARK_TWAIN%281883%29_p213_-_A_SCIENTIST.jpg
instructions:
The Time Laboratory is run by a nefarious cat named Sparkles, who wants all of your personal data! Sparkles has her assistant, Jeff, working late in the lab to collect data from you.

Press the green flag to meet Jeff and learn how long you've been alive.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10: Digital Clock
description:
Thanks to @jsh for lots of support on the original project, and for moral support from @asparklekat and @karenb!

I tried to keep this pretty simple! I started by trying to make a digital clock. Then, I decided I wanted to make an analog clock—that's where things got tricky! I used the dots from my last project to make a little circle, and then incorporated the arrow keys. I figured out the angle for each by dividing 360 (degrees in the circle) by the number of seconds/minutes/hours. I had some difficulty with the initial direction the lines were facing, but eventually got it figured out!
instructions:
Press the green flag to see the current time.
Press a for analog mode.
Press d to go back to digital mode.
writing:
Thanks to @jsh for lots of support on the original project, and for moral support from @asparklekat and @karenb!

I tried to keep this pretty simple! I started by trying to make a digital clock. Then, I decided I wanted to make an analog clock—that's where things got tricky! I used the dots from my last project to make a little circle, and then incorporated the arrow keys. I figured out the angle for each by dividing 360 (degrees in the circle) by the number of seconds/minutes/hours. I had some difficulty with the initial direction the lines were facing, but eventually got it figured out!Press the green flag to see the current time.
Press a for analog mode.
Press d to go back to digital mode.

title: Drops remix
description:
I LOVED @jsh's project so much that I both wanted to understand how it was working and also see how the sounds might shift over time. Remixing was a wonderful way to explore both of those! 

Shoutout to @paulinah and @karenb for helping me Get Unstuck! I had most difficulty getting the new bars and the ball objects to interact (change visually, create sound). My first strategy was to look for these features in the code, which brought me to a list which organized the sound structure. I'd never used lists before, so it was fun to explore to see what I could discover. What I discovered was that it wasn't the list I needed to be tinkering with at all. The buggy color sensing with ghost effects proved to be the culprit. Once that bug was isolated, and I was having difficulty remedying, I
SEARCHED ONLINE, 
TALKED IT OUT, 
and ASKED FRIENDS.
With their help, I was able to create the features I'd imagined for this remix! 

I added a few more bars, of decreasing size, that appear over time. I'm still fooling around with details, but am excited with where this is going (:
instructions: Press the green flag and enjoy!
writing:
I LOVED @jsh's project so much that I both wanted to understand how it was working and also see how the sounds might shift over time. Remixing was a wonderful way to explore both of those! 

Shoutout to @paulinah and @karenb for helping me Get Unstuck! I had most difficulty getting the new bars and the ball objects to interact (change visually, create sound). My first strategy was to look for these features in the code, which brought me to a list which organized the sound structure. I'd never used lists before, so it was fun to explore to see what I could discover. What I discovered was that it wasn't the list I needed to be tinkering with at all. The buggy color sensing with ghost effects proved to be the culprit. Once that bug was isolated, and I was having difficulty remedying, I
SEARCHED ONLINE, 
TALKED IT OUT, 
and ASKED FRIENDS.
With their help, I was able to create the features I'd imagined for this remix! 

I added a few more bars, of decreasing size, that appear over time. I'm still fooling around with details, but am excited with where this is going (:Press the green flag and enjoy!

title: Time Lab redux
description:
When @karenb shared her project on our ScratchEd group chat, I loved the idea and the sounds. It's a fairly straightforward project, and I've done things like this before, but when I looked inside, I was surprised to see that her code looked completely different from what I had been expecting. It's a reminder that there are many different ways to get things done. so I decided that my project for today would be a remix of Karen's, but I would add a few things to make it more organized. Once I reorganized the code, though, I was playing with the project and wondering if I was "done," a concept which I have been thinking about a lot. Was it enough? Did I put enough of "me" into this project?

But then an idea struck, and I was excited about how suddenly goofy the project was <-- that's definitely part of my style. ^_^
instructions: Press the green flag and follow along with the prompts. If you wait long enough, other Time Lab friends might appear...
writing:
When @karenb shared her project on our ScratchEd group chat, I loved the idea and the sounds. It's a fairly straightforward project, and I've done things like this before, but when I looked inside, I was surprised to see that her code looked completely different from what I had been expecting. It's a reminder that there are many different ways to get things done. so I decided that my project for today would be a remix of Karen's, but I would add a few things to make it more organized. Once I reorganized the code, though, I was playing with the project and wondering if I was "done," a concept which I have been thinking about a lot. Was it enough? Did I put enough of "me" into this project?

But then an idea struck, and I was excited about how suddenly goofy the project was <-- that's definitely part of my style. ^_^Press the green flag and follow along with the prompts. If you wait long enough, other Time Lab friends might appear...

title: My better alarm clock
description:
This is one of my favorite projects b/c I actually use the alarm clock feature from time to time in real life! (I created it last summer.)
I changed the orientation of the hand sprites so they can be coded while pointing in direction 0. I made adjustments for setting the alarm  by changing military time to standard time. I added code for the hour hand to change its position every minute. I cut the sound file so that it would end closer to exactly 60 seconds.
instructions:
Click the green arrow to turn on the clock.
Use the sliders to set the alarm clock.

title: Unstuck Day 10 Scratchy Bounce w/Timer
description:
The time-related blocks have always been one of my biggest stuck places, so thank you for this opportunity to Get Unstuck. I created this game for day 5 (jumping), but with a timer bar that I designed specifically to avoid using the timer. Today I went back to the project and replaced the bar with a variable that counts down from 100 by subtracting the timer. There is another script that waits until the timer is greater than 100 to end the game. Piece of cake!

 This is based on the Hasee Bounce game from the neopets web site: http://www.neopets.com/games/game.phtml?game_id=368
instructions:
Press the space bar to bounce one cat down and the other cat up. Time the jumping to catch the apples!
You can move each cat to the right and left with the right and left arrow keys.
Time is up when the timer reaches zero.
The apples speed up throughout the game!

title: Getting Unstuck #10
description:
I think I've invented the world's most annoying and inaccurate clock.

I was trying to think of alternative ways to represent time. This is hardly an exhaustive pair of approaches. If I had more time I'd think of a way to represent seconds. I'd also like the whole thing to be more musical. I'd try to get the breaths blowing up the balloon, and the frog's bounces to be in time with the ticking of the pendulum. 

PS- It's just turned midnight here, and at 00:00 it's a pretty uninteresting clock.

title: Catch 5 Flies
description:
When a player 'wins' your game, do they want to play again?

'Replay value' is a big deal in game design. Even simple games take significant time and effort to code, and the we hopes the hours we put in will create, at least, minutes of fun for the players. This is a challenge, especially when we're new to making games.

I thought of this for Day 10 because the 'timer' block might be the lowest-hanging fruit for adding 'replay value' to a game. Playing a game with a timer changes the challenge from "can you do XYZ?" to "how well can you do XYZ?" Can you improve on your last performance? Will your time be faster than hers? The clock creates a relationship between each time you've clicked the Green Flag, and an incentive to do it again!

(I adapted this project from a game I wrote with @L2TT2L2018 last year)
instructions:
Jump with the UP ARROW
Catch flies with SPACE

How fast can you catch 5 flies?

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 10 — Binary Counter
description:
Reflection

I wanted to recreate an old Arduino project I once assembled that acted as a binary counter. It included 8 LEDs that represented the state of an byte, or 8-bit value, in memory.

The challenge for this project is that there are no bitwise operators (that I'm aware of) in Scratch. In order to simulate changing of the bits, I used a list so that each element of the list represents a bit. Building this 8-bit memory, along with the supporting functions, took most of the time.

Update: I went ahead a fixed the things I would have done if I had more time. Mostly refactoring and reorganizing. This involved rearranging and deleting unnecessary blocks, and separating and organizing the logic within the 4 sprites.
instructions: Move the slider to change the delay time of the binary counter.
