title: Unstuck Day 10: Using Time blocks
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #10-time blocks- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
This looks simple but was hard to figure out! I wanted to use timer to control a day/night cycle with the sine function. At first I thought there wasn't a sin block but then I found it. Then I had to figure out how to keep the tint of the sky, made by drawing with a big pen, in a positive value, as well as the brightness of the desert sprite. So I realized the absolute value block came in handy there. 
Math is hard so this was a good challenge!
instructions:
Day/night cycle using sin & cos of timer.
The lighting is good but as you can see I'm having a tough time with the rotation of the sun and moon. It's getting there...currently I have to figure out why they go clockwise sometimes in their cycle.
Eventually I figured out why but I can't fix it...

title: Getting Unstuck 10 - Travel
description:
Spent way more time on this than I planned. Headed to Red Sox game so out of time. I have a few things to add, days of trip, cat saying final time, etc. 

Had fun using those blocks and working out ways to convert the time. One note, had the arrival time clock go hour by hour to show the travel but taking a duck to California took a long time to spin. So I went without screen refresh. If you want to see the clock animate, edit that block on the arrival clock and watch that hour hand spin

title: 10 Second Maths Challenge (Unstuck#10)
description:
Getting Unstuck challenge/activity #10 - "Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000)"

Timer is used to set a 10 second limit on answering questions. Would be interesting to know if a "ask and wait" could be interrupted based on a timer or other event (at present as long as the question is within 10 seconds the user can take any length of time to answer due to the wait).
instructions: Click the flag to begin. Then click the button to start the challenge. How many questions can you get correct in 10 seconds?
writing:
Getting Unstuck challenge/activity #10 - "Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000)"

Timer is used to set a 10 second limit on answering questions. Would be interesting to know if a "ask and wait" could be interrupted based on a timer or other event (at present as long as the question is within 10 seconds the user can take any length of time to answer due to the wait).Click the flag to begin. Then click the button to start the challenge. How many questions can you get correct in 10 seconds?

title: Charlene's Timed Closet
description:
A remix of my Charlene's Closet https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/99536620/ based on a Math Forum Problem of the Week scenario.

Reflection: I thought it would be great to have your outfit chosen for you based on the day of the week and the weather.  I've tried to simulate that here a bit with one day lasting 60 seconds. Some choices are random, other more considered, like wear a hat when the sun is out or black socks at night (?). 

Getting Unstuck: I used a variable to help me set up the formula to choose which shirt to wear.  More time could be spent making the project more accurate, but I'm happy with the way it turned out.

It was nice to remix an project where all the costumes were set already.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #10: Use the timer/ time sensing block.  

Time will tell Charlene what to wear when you click the Choose for me button.

Use the other buttons to make your own choice for Charlene.
Hats must be worn when the sun is out!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10
description:
The Digi-Clock 2000 is an LED clock from the 1970's. It is hard to read and is decidedly clunky but now looks insanely cool.

I started just trying to make some sort of unusual linear/barchart clock, but it evolved over about 30 minutes' coding into this retro-silliness. Spent most of the time trying to get the right bar lit with silly 0/1 59/60 errors.

title: Is it Friday? -- Unstuck Challenge 10
description:
This is just a silly little application that delights in its utter impractability. 

My original idea was to have the cat come out and report how many days left until the start of school, then after school started, the days left until the end of the year.  I decided that project was more than I could take on -- yet.  

Instead, I scaled down the idea to experiment with some of the blocks and concepts that might be necessary to make my original idea happen.  I think I have a better idea of how to go about it after playing with this project, but I may need to see what others have done first before I attempt my own project.
instructions: Just follow the on-screen instructions

title: Unstuck Day 10: Circles are on the Radar!
description:
Seem to be exploring geometry concepts in my projects . . . 
Working with circles is much more challenging than I expected!  Yesterday taught me to keep track of lines of code that I have tried, so today I created a new spite for each trial. 
Started by looking at "Digital Clock" by @mizzpeters and "My better alarm clock" by @Curious_AEF.  Curious to see how they created their circles.
When I got the project to work, I wasn't actually using the time-related blocks to accomplish the main task. Wanted solid radar colour to change when line pointing up, but haven't quite got that yet. Unfortunately, "time" is up for today!  May revisit.
Any suggestions and tips from experienced coders would be greatly appreciated!
instructions: Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category.  My idea was to create a radar-style circle effect and have the colour change once the circle is complete.
writing:
Seem to be exploring geometry concepts in my projects . . . 
Working with circles is much more challenging than I expected!  Yesterday taught me to keep track of lines of code that I have tried, so today I created a new spite for each trial. 
Started by looking at "Digital Clock" by @mizzpeters and "My better alarm clock" by @Curious_AEF.  Curious to see how they created their circles.
When I got the project to work, I wasn't actually using the time-related blocks to accomplish the main task. Wanted solid radar colour to change when line pointing up, but haven't quite got that yet. Unfortunately, "time" is up for today!  May revisit.
Any suggestions and tips from experienced coders would be greatly appreciated!Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category.  My idea was to create a radar-style circle effect and have the colour change once the circle is complete.

title: GU_Day10_PoisonIvy
description:
Lots of trial and error to figure out how to serrate the leaves! 
In this project I combined:  drawing with pen, color sensing, timing, and importing a photo (taken in my yard).
The user decides for how long to run around touching and/or avoiding poison ivy. Arrow keys are controlled by the user. I decided not to hide the person sprite at the end b/c I like how she is pointing up at the morals. In order to not have her speech bubble hide the morals, I needed to ditch the stop other scripts in this sprite block.
instructions:
Click the green flag.
When prompted, enter for how long to play. Use the arrow keys to move.

title: Clock (Getting Unstuck Day 10)
description:
I've used the timer blocks quite often, but I hardly ever use the current time blocks.

At first I wanted to make a water clock like the one I had seen in a Science Museum, but that turned out to be too complicated. Then I decided to go for this easier alternative and somehow it was a kind of magical moment that while I was still making this project another pink ball turned into a dark one because it was 8 o'clock overhere.

This only took me half an hour to make, but I enjoyed taking the challenge again. This is my third Unstuck project. One of my unstuck projects can be found on my main account @PinkyPepper.
instructions:
Just click the green flag and try to find out what time it is.

Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10.1
description:
The Digi-Clock 2000 was an imaginary LED clock from the 1970's (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236398675/). It was hard to read. In response to complaints, the Digi-Clock Corporation made the Digi-Clock 2001 released in 1980 just in time for a new decade.

Just couldn't stop fiddling. This time I think you could actually use this clock.

title: GettingUnstuck 10
description:
I like the concept for my project, having had many staring contests with my own cats.

I am a little stuck at the moment with the sensitivity on the video motion. If I set it to 99 or less, I can't get past a single second of the contest no matter how still I am, unless I actually hold my thumb over the webcam. But if I set it to 100, it doesn't pick up any motion at all. I tried varying whether it was measuring the motion on the stage or the sprite, and the result was the same. Maybe I'm just jittery?

Cat image by Thomas Wolfson via Pixabay.
Music is Home by Komiko via the Free Music Archive.
instructions: Click the green flag to have a staring contest with this cat.

My project is a chat bot that uses the current month and day to calculate how many months until someone's birthday when they answer questions during the "chat". It also uses a timer to have the chat end after 1 minute. I ran out of time to work on this so the first 3 questions are more interactive than the remaining questions.

description:
My mini game was inspired on some elements of the "DK" arcade game.

                                     ---Questions---

I took me more time how to move the yarn ball along the stage and stop it at a certain time. I have also problems with the random position of each clone kitten.

+What would you do next with your project, if you had more time?
I'd like to move the yarn ball differently together with more levels.

                                       ---Credits---

Press the start button.
Use RIGHT and LEFT arrow keys to move your cat.
Use SPACE key to jump.
Use UP arrow key to climb.
Try to get your kittens as quickly as possible.
When you get all kittens, don't forget to touch the other cat once and he will say you your time.
Enjoy it!!

title: Unstuck 10 Timers
description: I wanted to create a project I could see student making in conjunction with Makey Makey. I used a timer to count down the number of seconds allowed for the answer button to be pressed. I also wanted to use a "list" variable to hold all the questions and answers. I still have the timing a bit off for the "say" commands, and I would have liked more time to include some animations to make it more interesting. Happy that I learned a bit about list variables and how to set them and check them.

title: Getting Unstuck Day10
description:
What took you the most time? Originally I was going to edit Nano's costumes to go from baby to child, teen etc but it was taking ages. I've not used timing blocks before so I was too excited to get coding so I changed my plan.

What would you do next with your project, if you had more time? I think the idea is good but the execution is a bit poor. If I had more time I'd make this as a historical project 'Britain through the ages' or something with costume and background changes and a greater spread out timeline.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 10 (time)
description:
Oh man. This was the hardest project yet. I've been trying to imagine my own ideas first before checking out other people's work for Getting Unstuck...but I've never used time-related blocks before! (gasp) So I broke my own rule and poked around a bit — and I saw a lot of numbers, which typically scare me off. But I wanted to push myself, so I looked for a basic structure to remix.

I knew one of my all-time favorite projects from 
@crazynimbus (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19013498/#editor) used a countdown, so I examined the scripts inside. Then I asked myself -- what date am I excited about? And realized I'm just happy that it's Saturday. And voila! I made a simplified time project that doesn't really use a countdown, but is a good start to thinking about computing with time.

Since I ask myself "Is it the weekend?" pretty much every day, I used my own sprite :)
instructions: How many days until the weekend? Click the green flag to find out!

title: Pizza success
description: I  realized when I had submitted the project that it was supposed to be time related. Oh well- it took a long time! I found out that you can download and edit images in the costumes part of the sprites using a combination of eraser and remove background. It works best if the background is fairly uniform. Next time I will take my own images though if possible as it will be quicker!  I suspect I can simplify the script for setting the variable counters if I look more closely at the operators and use some ratios.
instructions: I am always forgetting how many cups of flour I have added when making pizza so I made this counter to keep track! click on green flag and select the number of pizzas you wish to make. click on the flour and water cups to add the correct ratio of flour to water.

title: Unstuck Day 10 - Bug on a Donut
description: I had a tough time figuring out the sensing timer. I realized that it constantly runs, and that I'd be best off keeping it hidden. It does restart every time the flag is clicked. By having the donut say the time, the player knows how long it took the bug to land on the donut. The timer resets after each time the bug lands on the donut. I'd like to include a list of the last 5 times, but I'm not sure how to do that.
instructions: Press the flag. A timer is running. See how long it takes the bug to land on the donut. The timer will reset each time he leaves the donut.
writing: I had a tough time figuring out the sensing timer. I realized that it constantly runs, and that I'd be best off keeping it hidden. It does restart every time the flag is clicked. By having the donut say the time, the player knows how long it took the bug to land on the donut. The timer resets after each time the bug lands on the donut. I'd like to include a list of the last 5 times, but I'm not sure how to do that.Press the flag. A timer is running. See how long it takes the bug to land on the donut. The timer will reset each time he leaves the donut.

title: 7 segment clock
description: I had a lot of fun with this one. I started out with an analog clock, but decided it might be more fun to try and replicate a classic LED 7 segement display based clock. The toughest part of getting this right is trying to create a 2d array for the truth table that dictates which combination of LEDs to use for each number. While I couldn't create a true 2d array, I got around the limitation by storing an array of strings and then using each character of the strings to represent an LED in the display.

title: The Tube Challenge_ Unstuck Day 10
description:
Many iterations. I was inspired while watching my boys swim in the hot summer sun. I began by making a swimming pool and inner tubes, then remixing a sprite to make Maya in a tube.  I had fun trying to figure out a method of keeping the floating tubes inside of the pool.  Even though Maya can go outside of the pool, the tubes can not. At first, I had the tubes with a set angle and move, but then I made them random. When I tried to play, I would never win, so I adjusted the random range to make the game possible. I still am wondering how to record all three tubes have entered the green space as a success.  (i just figured out how to do this).  I also want to add bonus coconuts that will fall from the trees.  If Maya gets these, in the next level, she will have super powers. 

Music from Incompetech by Kevin McLeod  Undaunted.mp3
instructions: Use your keyboard arrows to move Maya's tube around to get all the floating tubes to the green space in the swimming pool.  You have 60 seconds to do so!  Good luck.

title: Messing About with Time
description:
Today I finally had more time to spend on my project, and yet this is the most unfinished, messy, experimental, uncomfortable thing I've shared so far.

In my countless experiments I came up with clocks that made much more sense and looked better than this one. I've saved some of them, and took apart many others. But I choose to share this one because is the one I learned the most from.

If you look inside at the code you'll see an explosion of blocks all over the place.. I think they are sound evidence of a deep tinkering process and a rich creative learning experience, something that should be valued rather than stigmatized when we assess students' work.

I also learned a lot about clones and performance, continuously pushing the boundaries to see what was possible to achieve, instead of changing strategies, even when I could see a better alternative solution.

I prioritized inquiry, exploration and investigation over efficiency and getting "right answers" or making the "right project", in the spirit described in the wonderful article shared today: http://www.papert.org/articles/ComputerAsMaterial.htm

Anyway, I have many other reflections about time.. but I'll share them another time. Now it's time for me to go to bed! I hadn't noticed because my clock here only counts seconds.. at this time! :)

Until next time!
instructions: Click the green flag and... see the result of more than 4 hours of messing about with time.

title: Fruitworm Christmas Edition v3 remix-2
description:
Credits to ninja35 who helped me a lot with this remix of his project.
I have always loved this project and I thought of setting a time limit to see how many fruits the worm can gobble in a minute.
However, this set of blocks are kind of beyond me, so I asked for help.
THANK YOU ninja35!
My wish is to be able to announce the total but with the stop all block, I cannot do that. 
I will have to revisit this again when time permits.
instructions:
Click green flag to start.
Instructions as follows.
1. The worm will follow your mouse. Try to gobble up as many fruits as possible. 
2.Gobbling the bomb slows the speed but eating the blue sprite speeds the worm up.
3. Gobbling the special fruit increases the worm's size.
4. Post your best scores in a message.
My best is 54.

title: mechanical clock
description:
Getting Unstuck day 10
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).
A pendulum is used as oscillator, performing a regular motion depending on its length (physics tells us how the period is related to the length and it is unrelated to the mass). At each 1/4 of period the pendulum raise an impulse (actually a broadcast message to the needles). Each needle when receive the impulse rotates of a fixed amount, depending on the period of the pendulum and the "role" of the needle (hours, minutes, seconds). In reality it depends on the gears that connect needles to the mechanism.
The user can change the length of the pendulum and see the results.
The pendulum block uses the Timer to establish at which time raise the broadcast message.
instructions:
In this project I simulated how a mechanical clock works.
The project is not intended to be a precise clock (there are obviously better ways to do it).

Select the length of the oscillating pendulum that giver the impulse to the needles to rotate.

A pendulum is used as oscillator, performing a regular motion depending on its length (physics tells us how the period is related to the length and it is unrelated to the mass). At each 1/4 of period the pendulum raise an impulse (actually a broadcast message to the needles). Each needle when receive the impulse rotates of a fixed amount, depending on the period of the pendulum and the "role" of the needle (hours, minutes, seconds). In reality it depends on the gears that connect needles to the mechanism.

*** Update ***
- Now the clock synchronizes with the real time clock when the green flag is pressed (seconds excluded so that orange needle always starts at 00).
- Seconds counter added (it counts pendulum ticks and scales to seconds)
- Press Space Bar the follow the clock of 100 pendulum ticks

title: Day 10 TIMER
description: I'm pretty proud of this little timer. It took thinking!
instructions:
This may not look like work, but it took me a long time.

First I set up a variable to run down from 60 seconds. Then I got numbers, and added costumes for each digit place and had them switch costumes every second.
writing:
I'm pretty proud of this little timer. It took thinking!This may not look like work, but it took me a long time.

First I set up a variable to run down from 60 seconds. Then I got numbers, and added costumes for each digit place and had them switch costumes every second.

Does anyone know how to stop the timer without resetting it?
instructions: Use the green flag to start/ reset the game. Then use the arrow keys to move around the screen and catch the mice. *Note: There is a slight delay making it harder to "catch" the mice so stay with them until they disappear. Your time will display once all mice are caught.

title: Unstuck - Day 10
description: For this project, my daughter and I still have some questions. We kept this simple - we only asked "What year were you born?" and gave an estimated age as the answer.  To determine the actual age, we would need the day, month and year. We will be checking out other people's projects to see if anyone else figured out how to tell the exact age.  I predict that you would need to use if-then blocks, and possibly some variables.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 10 Reflection:
These challenges are definitely getting harder!  I'm not thrilled with how this turned out, but after a lot of trial and error I figured out how to get the timer to show up.  I don't see how to stop it at the end of the race though.  It just keeps tracking time until you start the game over again (or hide the timer, but I wanted to freeze it on the time.  If that had worked, I would have had the player "drive" the car and play against my self-driving car.  :)
instructions: Click the green flag to start the timer, then click on the car to start the race.  (Don't worry, it's a self-driving car, so just sit back and enjoy the ride!).
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 10 Reflection:
These challenges are definitely getting harder!  I'm not thrilled with how this turned out, but after a lot of trial and error I figured out how to get the timer to show up.  I don't see how to stop it at the end of the race though.  It just keeps tracking time until you start the game over again (or hide the timer, but I wanted to freeze it on the time.  If that had worked, I would have had the player "drive" the car and play against my self-driving car.  :)  Click the green flag to start the timer, then click on the car to start the race.  (Don't worry, it's a self-driving car, so just sit back and enjoy the ride!).

title: 10 : Julekalenderen - Christmas calendar
description:
I have wanted to make a Christmas calendar for some years now - it is so great with these tasks - now I know how after getting the idea from CompTeacherK5s project with the count down to Happy New Year! 

I found this beautiful background here: https://pixabay.com/da/julen-juletr%C3%A6-baggrund-struktur-3029496/ 
The stop sprite here: https://pixabay.com/da/knapper-multimedie-pause-afspilning-150350/
Christmas music was found here: http://www.freexmasmp3.com/
And Santa Claus from here https://opengameart.org/content/christmas-charactes-zombie-santa-weapons
instructions:
Det er en julekalender, som er lavet i meget god tid. Du kan kun åbne lågerne, når vi når til december 2018 - medmindre du klikker 2 gange på lågen. Der sker noget særligt ved lågerne 1, 2, 9 og 24. Husk lyd.

You can only open the boxes in December 2018. But if you can't wait - click on the box twice. So far it only works with the boxes 1,2,9 and 24. Remember sound. Work-in-progress - new fully version will be made before December in Scratch 3.0.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 10 Car Game
description:
Made for day 10 of getting unstuck creative computing.
I quite like the controls for this game, using the left and right to steer with acceleration.
I'd like to look into making this into a game with a cloud variable and a high score list. I've never used them before but I think they have always been a feature of Scratch 2.0.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to start and reset the timer.
Use the arrow keys to control the car.
Left and right rotate the car.
Up and down accelerate and decelerate.
Space acts as a break.
See how quickly you can get to the finish line.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 10
description:
Today's challenge is to "Create a project that uses one or more of the time-related blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., timer, reset timer, current [year/month/date/etc.], days since 2000)".

I knew I wanted to be able to move my sprite around and have it catch a regenerating object.  I had to search a lot to figure out the timer.  All the YouTube videos I watched used a variable for the timer, which was NOT the challenge.  I finally began searching the scratch wikis and that helped me figure out that the timer will not stop, it will only reset.  So then I just had to program the score variable to stop after 15 seconds and make sure when the game started that everything reset to 0.  Then it was a little bit of a struggle to get the start/during/end backgrounds to do what I wanted.

Credit my daughter for the idea of creating Scratch's cape!

If I could change it... I would write a script to either stop the timer or make it hide after 15 seconds.
instructions:
Click the Green Arrow to show the starting screen.

Then click the space bar to start the game.
Use the arrows to move and change the directions of the cat.

How many tacos can you catch in 15 seconds?

title: Getting Unstuck Day 11: Gusbear remix
description:
For today's challenge, I've remixed my *first ever* Scratch project from 2015. It took me over a week to make this project work how I wanted, at the time!

I specifically chose to remix this project because one of the biggest things I was stuck on when I originally made it was "how to get everything to disappear at once." @karenb happened to come by as I was working, and showed me how to use the broadcast block!

I also want to challenge myself to spend more time thinking about how to integrate Scratch into content-area classrooms for the second and third weeks of Getting Unstuck. When I first encountered Scratch, my main goal was to figure out how to incorporate creative computing into my 6th grade math classroom.
instructions: Click on the green flag and let Gusbear help you practice fractions.

title: Drops (lullabye remix)
description:
Remix of a beautiful Getting Unstuck project by @jsh

I made this to better understand the very clever key changing script used in the original. It uses a list ('chords') to define sets of four-note chords, and plays a few random notes from each as it cycles through the sequence of sets. The effect is a structured harmonic progression that uses new notes on each loop.

I couldn't make sense of the original code, but @jsh answered the question I put in the comments and got me unstuck!
instructions: Green Flag and enjoy.

title: Free Draw! Unstuck Day 11: Broadcast Remix
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #11-remix a broadcast project- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
For this I remixed one of my 6th grade students' projects. She used broadcast to set the pen color and an erase mode. I added a paintbrush and different pen sizes. I encountered what seems like a Scratch bug where the pen size won't change if triggered by "if this sprite clicked" so instead had to use a variable to set the pen to different sizes. I made the eraser work better by just setting the pen color to white.
instructions: Use the drawing tools to free draw!
writing:

I encountered what seems like a Scratch bug where the pen size won't change if triggered by "if this sprite clicked" so instead had to use a variable to set the pen to different sizes. I made the eraser work better by just setting the pen color to white.Use the drawing tools to free draw!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 11
description:
This is my project for Day 11 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. I found this project and I decided to remix it since it is very simple but cool al the same time. The remix is a very useful feature because it allows you to take the work done by others and modify it according to your needs. It can also be interesting for the author to see which interpretations others have of their own idea.

Challenge archive:

title: Getting Unstuck Day11
description:
How did remixing help you? I remixed this project from CodeClubRik. I added some more broadcasting to introduce pickles bringing the cup out when the player reaches 5 goals. Remixing meant I had the project foundation to build on, it let me expand what I had time to do beyond the usual basics. 

 What questions do you still have about remixing? None. I love remixing, it's a great way to find answers, get new ideas and understanding/building on someone else's code is a great skill to develop.
instructions:
Player 1:
Use 'space' to kick the ball towards the goal. You have 30 seconds to score as many goals as possible.

Player 2:
Use the left and right arrows to try and stop goals being scored.

title: dice simulator remix
description:
This is a remix of a project I did years ago on my original (non-teacher) Scratch account. I added a way to do 30 quick rolls so the user does not need to click "roll" 30 times. I also added a button to see the current sum of the list.

I love the ability to remix projects! It is a great way to learn how the code for a project works by tinkering with it.

Does anyone teach lessons on remixing? I have not, but I am wondering now if perhaps it would be a good idea to show students how to go about looking inside a remix to learn how it works.
instructions:
Click the green flag to start
The colored boxes allow you to roll the dice or examine the accumulated data.
"clear list" lets you start over

title: Scratch Parade 1 (final)
description:
I would love to share an old project for this Getting Unstuck Challenge, because it really shows the power of cooperation and remixing. To me, this was a very special project. 

Scratch Parade 2 and 3 can be found here:

https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/93959612/

https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/95715008/

Thanks to @schittering06, owner of the Scratch Parade studio, for the great idea to make a Carnival parade. And thanks to these Scratchers for joining: @Dan0510 (3rd wagon), @robnoo (4th), @naccho (5th), @BSGrkdprincess (6th), @bubble103 (7th), @LiFaytheGoblin (8), @vargcity123 (9), @hugmyster (10), @puffleEBP (11), @haras5 (12), @more_bagels (13), @-robox- (14), @schittering06 (15), @moekaroe (16), @Superbatman007 (17), @goodluckchloe (18). @ffred (19), @KeVeg (20), @Silvertail_Studios (21), @RileyPsych (22), @BB8 (23), @yorissen (24), @DerpyLord7 (25), @genny7 (26), @PeanutGuy03 (27), @pixiedus30 (28), @memowpie (29), @Caitlingt3 (30), @chokoji (31), @leszpio (32), @Digitaldesigngirl (33), @scream101 (34) and @suyann (35).

Thanks to the Scratch Team for putting our studio on the frontpage.

Thanks to @ffred, @the_grits and @vargcity123 for the people and to Sergio van Pul en Jessica Chiang for the idea for the robot (I found it in the book Scratch 2.0 Game Development).
instructions:
Scratch is celebrating Carnival with a Scratch Parade, featuring wagons/floats from Scratchers from all over the world! 
A big thanks to everybody who's has made a project for the Scratch Parade. There are contributions from every continent (except Antarctica)! Scratchers from 23 countries have joined!

This is a parade with about 30 wagons. If you want to increase the speed of the parade, please use the slider at the bottom on the right. At the regular speed the whole parade takes about 7 minutes (on my computer - the speed of the Parade depends on the speed of your computer). I hope you enjoy watching it! Making it, together with so many Scratchers, was lots of fun.

Untill January the 29th, the closing date, everybody who wanted could make his or her own wagon and I've added all those floats to my three Scratch Parade. Besides this @schittering06 will share his own Carnival Parade on February the 7th, the first day of Carnival in 2016.

title: Fire Breathing Dragon remix
description:
We were big HP and dragon fans in the day so this early project by daaiyahw6 really caught my eye. I did think that the dragon would be a bit upset at being in the crossfire of the wands so added another broadcast and a click counter to change its response to being pig in the middle. Thanks for the inspriration daaiyahw6!
Remixing is a great way to validate the work of the originator and generating an environment of collaboration.
instructions: Use the magic wands to grow or shrink your dragon! Just press on each wand and see the magic

The games that I like today (Shenzhen I/O, Manufactoria, Silicon Zeroes, Konstruktor, Jahooma's Logic Box, etc. ) are in fact programming puzzles.

I prefer to talk about vg because I feel a bit awkward about speaking about myself, hope you will forgive my shyness :)

title: Unstuck 11 Broadcasting (starting with a remix)-2
description:
Remix of https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/77208674/ by @ECS_Scratcher 
Changes:
Created a sprite to control HeroStartPosition for each level (isolate start position to not repeat x,y coordinates).
Defined blocks for repeated code: MoveByArrows, BlinkAndStartAgain.
I love the structure used by @ECS_Scratcher, with lives, levels, obstacle sprites, etc. One day I will spend more time to add more abstractions, so it could be easily changed with different backdrops for each level and different "obstacle paths" of deadly sprites.
Thanks @ECS_Scratcher for sharing!

title: Seasons_of_Scratch
description:
First, I thought about the timing of a year in minutes (yesterday's challenge); then, the song from "Rent". Finding downloadable music proved to be a challenge. I purchased the MP3 on Amazon. While viewing the lyrics, I created costumes for some of them. (To get the timing right, I inserted a reset timer block and noted the seconds at different places.) I invested a lot of minutes in working on the timing. 
Credits:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/mwichary/2398136060
https://www.publicdomainpictures.net/en/view-image.php?image=28953&picture=sunset-15
https://pxhere.com/en/photo/1271329
https://pxhere.com/en/photo/851236
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin.
Remixing ideas: 
1) There is a 13 sec photo of a toddler. You could use more photos of people within this time duration. 
2) Add what you would like to do with your remaining minutes.

title: Unicorn Maze remix
description:
Credits: This is a remix of the showcase project https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/219998074/ by one of my 4th grade Code Club members.

Reflection:  Perfect timing.  I am gathering examples of my students' work to use in my Scratch@MIT 2018 Conference workshop: Project Management from Design to Showcase. This was a project that struggled to stay on track and be completed in time for the Showcase. I'm reworking it and taking it to a more finished state in order to see how I could have supported the student better.

I tried to stay true to the student's ideas and added some flair of my own.

Reflection:  Perfect timing.  I am gathering examples of my students' work to use in my Scratch@MIT 2018 Conference workshop: Project Management from Design to Showcase. This was a project that struggled to stay on track and be completed in time for the Showcase. I'm reworking it and taking it to a more finished state in order to see how I could have supported the student better.

I tried to stay true to the student's ideas and added some flair of my own.Getting Unstuck #11: Remix a project that uses broadcast.

Click the green flag.  Help the Unicorn get his wings.

title: fill the bucket (shoot the rocket) remix
description:
I remixed an independent project created by one of my students who is passionate about creating in Scratch.

I have been streamlining the code to a basic aim and fire game and will start adding features back later today, when I have more time. I understand someone else's code more when I deconstruct it and focus on one component at a time. 

The other project I considered doing this for war the Sunflower Garden (pen) project by Scratcher scmb1: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235674874/
instructions:
Use arrow keys to target
S to increase strength
D to decrease strength
Space bar to shoot
Find the secret!
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

title: Snake remix
description: I found this snake game on the home page that used a pretty neat cloning method to draw the snake, but had some bugs that I wanted to address - most importantly it didn't fail when the snake ran into itself. It's always a fun challeng to try and dig into someone else's code and suss out their logical assumptions. Over the course of adding the functionality I initally wanted I also did a bunch of refactoring to simplify the scoring and speeding-up mechanism.

title: Unstuck Day 11 - Crazy Pineapple (remix)
description:
This is a remix. I found this awesome pineapple art/animation with really cool music. I changed some of the graphic effects. I also added the four stars in the corners. Finally I changed the beginning so the pineapple changed size 10 times then added a countdown.

I'm not sure that I completely understand all the variables that were used. I played around with them and saw how the animation changed if I changed numbers in the blocks. That made sense, but I'm not sure that I could have created this code in the first place. I've never created new blocks like Offbeat did, so it was a good learning experience.

Thank you for creating such a cool project, Offbeat.
instructions: Press the flag then press the spacebar.
writing:

title: GU#11 - GU Day 10 — Binary Counter (remix)
description:
GettingUnstuck#11 said - "Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it".

I looked for cool looking projects in GettingUnstuck#10 studio and looked to see what used broadcast. I like the idea of a controller in the original project this is based on. It made me realised that remixing is a good way to look closer at other projects.

My edits are sprite costume based only. This is mainly to add 0 or 1 above the dot so that the binary number is displayed in digit form. More minor - the "on" costume for a bit has a different color.
instructions: Move the slider to change the delay time of the binary counter.
writing:

title: The "3 Favorite Things" Pass-It-On Project! remix remix remix remix remix remix remix remix
description:
Reflection

Thanks to all the other remixers of the project that did this before me. It was fun and challenging working inside the same space as others while trying not to break existing work. The most difficult part in doing this remix is that I wanted all my added material to exist within a single sprite so that I wouldn't convolute the project with lots of additional sprites.

One thing I did which was extremely helpful was that I developed most of my contribution in a separate project. Then I moved everything over using the backpack. I had to make a few extra modifications to make it work once it was in this project, but it sped up development quite a bit.
instructions:
Click the green flag to learn about my three favorite things!
Then remix the project to add you and your three favorite things!

title: Spider Web (Unstuck 11)
description:
For this I wanted a light-hearted yet"spooky" type of computational art for this project, and went looking on the Day 11 Studio for inspirations to remix. "Appearing Plants" was such a delight to play and it seemed like the perfect place to start. 

The idea of the "remix" is so liberating, especially with my students, as it totally changes the dynamic of creating and sharing. Rather than being concerned with "getting it right" and being cautious with sharing (or even getting defensive when someone incorporates their solution), they take delight in seeing their creativity and ingeniuity reflected in the projects of their classmates.
instructions: Press the green flag to start.
writing:
For this I wanted a light-hearted yet"spooky" type of computational art for this project, and went looking on the Day 11 Studio for inspirations to remix. "Appearing Plants" was such a delight to play and it seemed like the perfect place to start. 

The idea of the "remix" is so liberating, especially with my students, as it totally changes the dynamic of creating and sharing. title: Remix -- Unstuck Challenge 11
description:
This project originally had the cat controlled by the keyboard. This remix alters the controls so that the cat follows the mouse.(I also made minor cosmetic changes to the princesses, giving them each different hair and dress colors.)

Originally, I tried adding a mouse control script from a previous project I created.  I thought it would be a simple drag and drop fix, but it didn't work with the number of sensing scripts in the project.  Instead, I had t develop a new method to have the sprite follow the mouse on click and stop following on clicking the background all while still making use of the color and sprite sensing scripts.  Ultimately, I followed the example of the original project and used the custom block control, which made it much easier to add the necessary code to several scripts.

Remixing was rather fun, as the original creators -  @ECS_Scratcher and rbotero - already had great animations and sensing scripts.
instructions:
Click on Scratch cat and use your mouse to save princess!


From Remix challenge: Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it. For example, you could remix this pass-it-on project that we started.

title: Getting Unstuck  #11 - Day 8 Activity remix
description:
This was really difficult. I found it hard finding just the project to remix. Eventually I found this one by @Topsie that I really liked, and thought that I'd just change what it does. 
What I learned from this is that a great way of learning how a project works is to remix it and change one thing at a time. It's certainly a strategy I'll be using with my students.
instructions: Press the green flag to start. Use A, D and Space keys to play the drums, but don't play too fast.

title: balls and bricks remix
description: In my remix, I tried to make a sound play when the block disappeared.  I need to work on the timing, because the sound plays when I press the letter key, not when the ball hits the block.  I'll keep at it!  Thanks CyberParra for the original project!
instructions:
14 balls fall from the sky and must reach the ground (when this happens the ball become yellow). But there are bricks that block them. You have to click the right letter to make the brick disappear and allow the ball to reach the ground.
At the end all the bricks should be replaced by yellow balls

title: Memory remix Time Dilation: Getting Unstuck Day 11
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 11 Remix

I liked the idea of "energy" as a variable in a project. Yesterday, I tried to implement this idea from scratch in my project but I didn't get very far and abandoned it.
This new project starts as a remix of jsh's Memory project, where I first got the idea for "energy." Rather than trying to remake his wheel, I used his energy variable and applied it to the passage of time and the movement of the Sun across the sky.
Still loving the music, too!
instructions: When you move your mouse around a lot, time advances quickly. When you are still, time advances slowly.
writing:

title: Find the Duck! - remix
description:
Remixed from @karenb.
I've made a few changes:
+The background, the character, more costumes and the music are different.
+Coding:  I've added 3 variables: time+ right +wrong choices to make it more challenging; I've added a pixelate effect to make it harder too. 
When you finished it, you can start again if you press the space key.

++This project helped me to understand better how to combine the cloning with variables and randomness. Thanks a lot @karenb for your useful comments.++
instructions:
Press the green flag to start.
Find the random duck.
You have limited time.
Correct duck= + between 5 and 10 secs.
Wrong duck= - 5 secs.


Press the Green Flag to start playing!

Then remix the project to add you and your three favorite things!
writing:
I really enjoyed seeing what other people had done and using that as inspiration for my own section.  I think this would be a great intro for a beginning of year project to introduce each other.  Although I think I'd break it up into groups because it would get a little tedious to sit through 30!  I wasn't sure how to add my sprite to the backdrop.  I fudged it a bit, I'm sure there's an easier way.  Thank to the people who went before me for your inspiration.Getting Unstuck Day 11
Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it. 

Click the green flag to learn about my three favorite things!
Then remix the project to add you and your three favorite things!

title: Where I do put it?
description:
Grazie Carmelo per lo spunto educativo sulla raccolta diffrenziata: mi è piaciuta l'idea di classficare e differenziare i rifiuti domestici con un gioco.
Ho aggiunto un bidone RAEE e qualche altro esempio di rifiuto. Svilupperò in seguito con qualche altra interazione, ad esempio con domande.
instructions:
Usa i tasti 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 e 6 per muovere i bidoni e riciclare i rifiuti, in questo modo il materiale di cui sono fatti non andrà sprecato.

E ricorda che a volte puoi aggiustare o riutilizzare gli oggetti invece di buttarli.

title: Day 11 - Broadcast and Receive remix
description:
Thanks to those below for your project. 

I was way behind today, so made this simple.  I tried other projects but they were too complicated.  I felt that this would be simple for my students to use and reference if they needed help when using Scratch.
instructions:
This project demonstrated the broadcast and receive event blocks. 

I use them as cues for the sprites and stage. Notice how I use comments to keep track of what's going on. 

Pay attention also to how I reset everything back to the start with the green flag.
writing:
Thanks to those below for your project. 

I was way behind today, so made this simple.  I tried other projects but they were too complicated.  I felt that this would be simple for my students to use and reference if they needed help when using Scratch.This project demonstrated the broadcast and receive event blocks. 

I use them as cues for the sprites and stage. Notice how I use comments to keep track of what's going on. 

Pay attention also to how I reset everything back to the start with the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck 11: Pass it On Bees remix
description: I remixed a project that I did on a different account. I changed it so that instead of telling the jokes in the same order every time, the jokes go in a random order. There were a lot of broadcast blocks in the original project, so it took some thinking to get everything to make sense and make sure that the same joke doesn't repeat. I also love that the first bee leaves and is hidden after the second bad joke gets told, so you can't see its reply and the joke-telling bee is just left shouting the punchline.
instructions: Click the green flag to start. Hope you like bad puns!
writing: I remixed a project that I did on a different account. I changed it so that instead of telling the jokes in the same order every time, the jokes go in a random order. There were a lot of broadcast blocks in the original project, so it took some thinking to get everything to make sense and make sure that the same joke doesn't repeat. I also love that the first bee leaves and is hidden after the second bad joke gets told, so you can't see its reply and the joke-telling bee is just left shouting the punchline. Click the green flag to start. Hope you like bad puns!

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge Day 11
description:
Music
Angelique Kidjo "Once in a Lifetime"
Fantastic Negrito none yet
Residente "El Futuro Es Nuestro"
instructions: I tried the pass it along challenge but it was a pain to have to listen to everyone's projects before me to test and debug mine, so I gave up. I made this project, my 3 favorite concerts of this year. There's some more work to do, and find a Fantastic Negrito song I can use. I'm probably done though, this took too long. Interestingly enough, I didn't use pseudo code for this one, and I was going back and forth without a plan too much. Note to self *always use pseudo code*

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 11
description:
This project ended up very different than the one I started remixing.  When I was looking for clipart to use for a sprite I was inspired by "Paint Splat Tree Clipart".

I learned to think and plan ahead.  I made many timely mistakes while stumbling upon the result.

The part that I found the hardest was using the background editor.  I'm not sure when to use Bitmap vs Vector.  I was originally putting the tree and the grass on the background and was pulling in transparent clipart, but the editors were doing funky things.  Later I figured out that I needed the tree to be a sprite so that I could keep it in front of the paint splats.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 11 - Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it.

Instructions are included in the project.
writing:
This project ended up very different than the one I started remixing.  When I was looking for clipart to use for a sprite I was inspired by "Paint Splat Tree Clipart".

I learned to think and plan ahead.  I made many timely mistakes while stumbling upon the result.

The part that I found the hardest was using the background editor.  I'm not sure when to use Bitmap vs Vector.  I was originally putting the tree and the grass on the background and was pulling in transparent clipart, but the editors were doing funky things.  Later I figured out that I needed the tree to be a sprite so that I could keep it in front of the paint splats.Getting Unstuck Day 11 - Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it.

Instructions are included in the project.

title: S stands for Spelling
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 11
by Massimo Marletta

I remixed the very nice project by @Ladyra with the following improvements:

- Translated the messages in English.
- Added not Italian letters (J, K, W, X, Y)
- Simplified the word-search routine (it checked manually for all the letters instead of using a cycle).
- Added a second sprite (the Dinosaurs), so now the Cat say the first part of the sentence and the dino say the second part.
- The control is alternated by the two sprites by means of broadcast messages.
- There is a little chance that the Dino say the wrong word. In this case the Cat asks him to repeat the answer and counts the errors.
instructions:
Write you name and the characters will play spelling your name with words. 
Don't expect the Dino is perfect.. maybe if he have known the alphabet, he would not be extinguished now :(

title: Getting Unstuck Day 11
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 11 Reflection:
I started this project for a Scratch class a month or so ago, but I didn't get a chance to finish it.  Is it cheating to remix your own project?!  Remixing helped me save different versions of my project, so I felt a little more comfortable trying different things with it.  I didn't get quite as tangled up in my scripts as I have in other projects.  I don't know how I feel about remixing other projects - I looked for a water cycle one to remix instead of using my own, but I didn't see one I wanted to tinker with.  How do people find projects to remix?  I can see the value in remixing, both for myself and my students, but I didn't find a good search strategy for finding something to remix.
Background image from https://pmm.nasa.gov/education/sites/default/files/article_images/Water-Cycle-Art2A.png.
instructions: Click on the green flag to start, then click on each stage of the water cycle to see what it is..

title: Unstuck #11 Water Cycle
description:
Information:

https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-difference-between-seepage-percolation-and-infiltration
Background:

instructions:
This is a remix of a project that I could assign to my elementary school students to demonstrate their learning AND to enable teachers to get comfortable with Scratch. I learned a lot about layers!! 

This project uses broadcast and sounds, and screenshots to make the background interactive. There is a variable that ensures that only one area can be active at a time.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 11 remix remix
description:
The challenge for day 11 was to find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it.  So I searched on twitter for #GettingUnstuck 11 and saw @billmarsland 's video of his program with pugs.  So I decided to switch out all of his pugs for cats.  Then I had to figure out how to change the song at the end. You can't just link it, so that dilemma led me to figure how to convert a youtube url into an mp3!

Kitten images from: https://www.pngarts.com/explore/23435
(Thank you @MrMarslandSF fo posting the links on yours!)

Song from:
https://youtu.be/9RShudgllmY

title: The "3 Favorite Things" Pass-It-On Project! [gmenegoz remix] remix
description:
This is an heavy remix of the original project. I refactored the way the script interacts each other (Hope there will no visible differences when running the script)

I added my two cents of favorite things and reworked all the previous sprites: Unified the two sprites in one (There is a limit of ssprite in a project?) and removed the polling cicles of broadcast variable in favor of a message based interaction in order to let the animation a little faster.

It was a long and sometime tedious work but it was satifying at the end ;-)

Feel free to peruse the differences and let's tallk about them in the comments below.

title: Steven + Amethyst
description: Inspired by Steven Universe! I was poking around the sprites library (because of commuting I end up working in the offline editor a lot) and found a purple helicopter, which reminded me of Amethyst as a helicopter. I coded the project while riding the subway, with the purple helicopter and Gobo as sprite stand-ins, and then swapped sprites and added music when I got somewhere with wifi. I had also tried to reuse my newly learned gravity from previous Getting Unstuck days, but those really only worked with button presses, as opposed to "forever gravity" blocks. And since Steven only needs to float once...it was fine.
instructions: Press the green flag to watch. Move the mouse onto the helicopter to annoy Amethyst, and leave her alone for some praise.
writing: Inspired by Steven Universe! I was poking around the sprites library (because of commuting I end up working in the offline editor a lot) and found a purple helicopter, which reminded me of Amethyst as a helicopter. I coded the project while riding the subway, with the purple helicopter and Gobo as sprite stand-ins, and then swapped sprites and added music when I got somewhere with wifi. I had also tried to reuse my newly learned gravity from previous Getting Unstuck days, but those really only worked with button presses, as opposed to "forever gravity" blocks. And since Steven only needs to float once...it was fine. Press the green flag to watch. Move the mouse onto the helicopter to annoy Amethyst, and leave her alone for some praise.

title: Fussy Cat Simulator
description:
I was super inspired by @Mittensbrother's "Easily Spooked" project from Day 8 (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236238057/) and wanted to do something similar with an easily-annoyed-cat theme. :)

I like the discovery aspect of the project. Two things I'm still thinking about:
(1) Do I have bugs? The logic of my program seemed straightforward in theory:
   cat is initially fussy
   if you leave it alone for long enough, it is not fussy
   if it is not fussy, you can pet it
   if you pet it for too long, it gets fussy again
But the implementation seem convoluted. I need a code review. :)
(2) Is it too much discovery? (Will the temptation to peek into the code be really high? :))
instructions: Sparkles the Cat, who runs the notorious Time Laboratory, has demanded that her beleaguered assistant, Jeff, pet her. But Sparkles is a bit fussy. Jeff has reached out to you for help. Can you help Jeff figure out how to pet Sparkles the Cat without getting clawed?

(1) Do I have bugs? The logic of my program seemed straightforward in theory:

   if you leave it alone for long enough, it is not fussy

But Sparkles is a bit fussy. Jeff has reached out to you for help. Can you help Jeff figure out how to pet Sparkles the Cat without getting clawed?

title: Affection
description:
This was such a fun project to make! I'm really enjoying continuing to work with the vector editor! 

At first I had the curled-up cat and close-up cat within the same sprite (as many costumes). In order to make use of the "next costume" block, I decided to separate them out to separate sprites. 
Working on fixing a bug that causes the two to overlap during some of the transitions.
instructions: After pressing the green flag, press the space bar and use the mouse to interact with the cat.

title: Secret
description: This project was created for Day 13 of Getting Unstuck. I really enjoyed today's challenge to think about what happens when the mouse is moved further or closer from a location. But I definitely had to play with a few different project concepts before I found something that I liked.

title: Unstuck Day 13
description: I tried to leverage some of the requisites of creativity for this assignment, mainly limitation: I used a simple sprite and little code, and I allowed myself about 10 minutes to make the project while getting ready to go to work. I also lost track of the precise instructions (regarding a mouse getting close to a sprite), and didn't let this concern me too much in what I was making. I just worked with mouse and sprite. To be creative also means I'll return to this with some ideas that occur later in the day or overnight, so I'm marking it as a draft. Everything is a draft.
instructions: Green flag, click the mouse on stage and move it around

title: Unstuck Day 13: React to Mouse
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #13-respond to mouse- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
I couldn't make the sprite and its clones respond after a few seconds of not touching them because that blocks the interactivity, but i did manage to get them to behave differently depending on whether the wand (lightning) was touching them or they were away from the mouse. I learned that while clones cannot keep their own instance of a variable they do have their own position and can be aware of how far they are from the mouse pointer.
instructions:
Cook the magic stew! Use your magic wand to make the stew boil but work quickly, if you stop using your wand the ingredients will shrink.

Update: Thanks @jsh for clueing me to the fact that clones can keep their own variables if a varialbe is create "only for this sprite." Now each clone is maintaining its own effect amount and waiting its own amount if it is neglected by the mouse before it starts shrinking.
writing:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #13-respond to mouse- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
I couldn't make the sprite and its clones respond after a few seconds of not touching them because that blocks the interactivity, but i did manage to get them to behave differently depending on whether the wand (lightning) was touching them or they were away from the mouse. I learned that while clones cannot keep their own instance of a variable they do have their own position and can be aware of how far they are from the mouse pointer.Cook the magic stew! Use your magic wand to make the stew boil but work quickly, if you stop using your wand the ingredients will shrink.

Update: Thanks @jsh for clueing me to the fact that clones can keep their own variables if a varialbe is create "only for this sprite." Now each clone is maintaining its own effect amount and waiting its own amount if it is neglected by the mouse before it starts shrinking.

title: Bored Electron
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 13
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I used the block "distance from mouse pointer" to calculate the Coulomb repulsion force between two electrons (which is proportional to the inverse of the distance between them).
The timer is user to sequence the events (i.e. electron waiting, electron bored, etc.)
I had a lot of fun drawing costumes for the electron sprite with my children.
instructions:
In this project we have a bored electron: yes, a poor negative charge all alone in the void space.
The mouse pointer is another electron and you can apply Coulomb force to the bored electron simply getting close to him. 
Put a bit of fun in his boring life!
But be attentive to him: if you stay too long without pushing the electron he will complain because your are not paying enough attention to him!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 13
description:
I have always loved the Dog 2 sprite in Scratch 2.0. He's so blue and appears curious/confused by the world.

If I had more time I would equip him with a wide range of resting behaviours - I remember liking Crash Bandicoot's resting actions on the PS game so much that sometimes I would leave him standing there just to watch them.

I thought about giving him sounds as he walks or thinks, but they weren't necessary and I removed them. Dog2 is quiet sophistication personified.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 13

Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

Run the project - the dog will follow a close-by mouse pointer.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 13 — Reactive Color
description:
Reflection

I wanted something that would react to mouse gestures and ended up with lots of dots that cycle through the hue when a mouse gets within a certain distance. The dots continue to cycle for a time even after the mouse is out of range. Eventually, the hue for each dot will cycle back to red.

There's definitely room for improvement here. For example, I would like to spend time working on a process for creating a better random distribution than the default "go to random" block.
instructions: Move the mouse pointer.

title: Getting Unstuck #13
description:
I'm quite pleased with this. If I had a bit more energy I'd try to make sure the lion wasn't moving quite so much. Also, the munching sound goes on for too long when the lion stops eating. The only way to fix this, I think, is to make the sound loop shorter, which I didn't want to do because then it gets far too repetitive. I might try to fix it by adding a few different short recordings and playing them in sequence. Maybe that will mean that they can be interrupted more easily.

Thanks to @welfringer for fixing my audio problem. 

Another thing that I've noticed from doing this and my Howard Arkley project on Day 9 is that my appreciation for the artworks increases with my exposure to them. Although I don't feel great about stealing the artworks, I'm sure that it has been good for me.

I'm losing all sense of positive digital citizenship and just stealing images. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sleeping_Gypsy
https://thegaudyblog.wordpress.com/2013/05/02/on-rewatching-monty-python-and-mocking-the-french/
instructions: Press the green flag. Move your mouse near the lion to stop the gypsy from being eaten. If your mouse stops moving for too long an old friend pops in to visit.

title: Unstuck 13 Sensing position
description:
Well I got a bit off track, I realize as I'm finishing this. I didn't have time to have the sprite change as the mouse pointer gets closer. It took a long time to figure out how to check position, for closeness and getting closer/farther. I'm happy with what I learned.
To improve the program, I would like to have an "indicator sprite" in the corner showing the "level of closeness," maybe a gauge that gets fuller with closeness? I think my code is well structured to add that in.
instructions: Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

title: Perchance to Dream_GU_Day13
description:
My inspiration came from the "Snoozetern" news story (brilliant advertising). First I thought about The Princess and the Pea. While looking for mattress pics I found the Rwandan truck which fascinates me. Associative thinking led me to search for dream quotes. There was a gender imbalance in my choices; which I fixed. The attributions are in a list which is matched by number with each quote. (The attribution list is not used in the code.)
Got unstuck from this glitch: the Z sprite was not centered in the costume drawing canvas so the "distance to mouse-pointer" command was not calibrated correctly.
Credits:
https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/tag/dream?page=9
https://pxhere.com/en/photo/612534
http://freemusicarchive.org/music/TRG_Banks/Dreamland/Great_Aunt_Henrietta
instructions:
Click the green flag.
To view the lists, click on the orange Data section under Scripts. Find the "Make a List" heading. Click on the check box next to the list(s) you want to view.

title: Taco Dog
description:
I stumbled a bit on the clone replication with this one, as I wanted to delete tacos that were eaten and then pop up a new one after a delay. Because "delete this clone" must be at the end of a sequence, I tried several apporaches to initializing a new clone one second after the previous was removed, each with surprisingly different results:

- Send and recieve broadcast: This was my first attempt, and it served the purpose of not creating a clone until after the delay. It also, however, created a new clone for each of the existing clones on the screen (as each was receiving the broadcast separately, I assume). This made for a kind of fun version where you need to eat tacos quickly to avoid a taco explosion, but not quite what I was looking for.
- Function: My second attempt was to create and call a function that waited and then cloned. The "wait" inside my function blocked execution in the loop from which it was called (execution blocking commands are tricky!), so it didn't behave any differently than if I had just called the wait and clone inline.
- Hide: This is the one I ended up going for - just hide the clone I plan on deleting right away so it doesn't really matter that it doesn't get deleted until after the clone is created.

Other approaches could include using a timer or a non blocking alternative to wait (like the mod of a counter var), but I'm gonna leave well enough alone :)
instructions: Use the mouse to get the dog to eat those tacos!

- Hide: This is the one I ended up going for - just hide the clone I plan on deleting right away so it doesn't really matter that it doesn't get deleted until after the clone is created.

title: Poor crab! Getting Unstuck: Day 13
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 13 - Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.
I love animals and stories. Maybe that's why I often create stories on my projects. Scratch always stimulates my creativity! Love it! :)

In this project, I draw different costumes, tinkered with time, sound, and rhythms to create the crab's movements and expressions.
Thanks to @Augusto, after seeing his project, I wanted to use his idea and includied another sprite following the crab, the crab's shadow.

title: Day 13 - React to Mouse - Dan and Beanstalk
description:
Day 13 - Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should respond.

Looked at a few projects this morning and was thinking of trying to make a plant grow. Landed on Jack and the Beanstalk idea. Looked at a couple projects that created a variable from the distance from mouse pointer which made it easier to tell how far away the mouse actually was a visible variable. Started with the clone, but too difficult to control the clearing. Added Dan for some fun climbing up the beanstalk.
instructions: Click green flag. Bring mouse pointer to plant to see it grow!
writing:
Day 13 - Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should respond.

Looked at a few projects this morning and was thinking of trying to make a plant grow. Landed on Jack and the Beanstalk idea. Looked at a couple projects that created a variable from the distance from mouse pointer which made it easier to tell how far away the mouse actually was a visible variable. Started with the clone, but too difficult to control the clearing. Added Dan for some fun climbing up the beanstalk.Click green flag. Bring mouse pointer to plant to see it grow!

title: Unstuck 13 Sensing position (with gauge)
description:
Update: Added a gauge to show proximity to target. 

Well I got a bit off track, I realize as I'm finishing this. I didn't have time to have the sprite change as the mouse pointer gets closer. It took a long time to figure out how to check position, for closeness and getting closer/farther. I'm happy with what I learned.
To improve the program, I would like to have an "indicator sprite" in the corner showing the "level of closeness," maybe a gauge that gets fuller with closeness? I think my code is well structured to add that in.
instructions: Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

title: Annoying parrot - GettingUnstuck-13
description:
This parrot acts like the sheep I have in the company I work for: when you get closer she declares its independence but when you leave she calls you back...
With more time I would like to modulate the reaction to the distance from the pointer or create a better reaction. It could even say something
instructions:
Green flag to start.
Getting too close to the parrot with the pointer will disturb it and it reacts accordingly, but if you leave it alone for a few seconds it comes to seek attention

title: Challenge 13 - ants don't like that!
description:
Had to think of something quickly, under 30 minutes, and threw together a group of ants that like their space. Make them angry and run with the mouse. 

The program uses a list to track all the distances to each ant. However, each ant clone will always know its distance from the mouse pointer so the list isn't necessary however it makes debugging a lot easier when you can see their data. Quick fun project
instructions:
Had to keep it very simple today for lack of time due to work, BOOO! My 4.5 hours on number 12 yesterday put me behind. So quick one today. But still fun nevertheless

But the ants do not like to be near the mouse and will get angry and scurry away until they are far enough to be comfortable.

The program uses a list to track all the distances to each ant. title: Creepy Chaser -- Unstuck Challenge 13
description:
I'd still like to make my cloned bugs crawl around randomly on the screen until approached by the mouse.  I couldn't quite come up with a scheme I was happy with yet.  For now it's OK.  I still don't quite have the hang of the clone command.  I'd like them to all flash and move out of sync, but I will need to look into how to make that happen later.  Maybe they each need to be their own sprite.

In one iteration, the code had both the original sprite and the clones making clones.  That was quite fun as the screen quickly filled up!

title: Tag: Getting Unstuck Day 13
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 13

The idea of interacting with the mouse led me to the idea of tag. I don't know if my project really fulfills the brief, but I enjoyed making it.
If I were to continue working on it, I would introduce a few other elements, such as making the reaction of "running away" sprites dependent on their distance to "it." 
In addition, I would have the characters call out "You're it!" or "I'm it!" when they were tagged.
instructions: Press the green flag. Play tag as Scratch Cat.
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 13

The idea of interacting with the mouse led me to the idea of tag. I don't know if my project really fulfills the brief, but I enjoyed making it.
If I were to continue working on it, I would introduce a few other elements, such as making the reaction of "running away" sprites dependent on their distance to "it." 
In addition, I would have the characters call out "You're it!" or "I'm it!" when they were tagged.Press the green flag. Play tag as Scratch Cat.

title: Ant them - Getting Unstuck day 13
description:
uThe difficult part was to do not think too big. I wandered a lot of time on internet looking for spritesheet to use in the project as I do not have time and skill to create a sprite by myself.

I Started with a dragon guarding a threasure, the passed on a cat playing with the mouse pointer (did anyone remember neko on X?)

I do not achieve to get an usable spritesheet, diminished again the size of the project and decided to animate an ant nest. 

Unlike the real ones, the ant populations will cap at 30 individuals.
instructions:
Ants are usually shy but odds are that you can foster a community of curious individuals, did you manage to attain such a result?

As the ants approach your mouse they react in different ways depending on their character. Most of them are shy and will return to the nest. Some are just curious and if you leave they resume wandering. Some others will chase your mouse and you will have to find a way to get rid of them. Yes, you can peruse into the code.
writing:
uThe difficult part was to do not think too big. I wandered a lot of time on internet looking for spritesheet to use in the project as I do not have time and skill to create a sprite by myself.

I Started with a dragon guarding a threasure, the passed on a cat playing with the mouse pointer (did anyone remember neko on X?)

I do not achieve to get an usable spritesheet, diminished again the size of the project and decided to animate an ant nest. 

Unlike the real ones, the ant populations will cap at 30 individuals.
Ants are usually shy but odds are that you can foster a community of curious individuals, did you manage to attain such a result?

As the ants approach your mouse they react in different ways depending on their character. Most of them are shy and will return to the nest. Some are just curious and if you leave they resume wandering. Some others will chase your mouse and you will have to find a way to get rid of them. Yes, you can peruse into the code.

title: Will the cat catch the parrot?
instructions:
When you move the mouse pointer left and right the parrot will follow it. If you stay more than 3 seconds without moving the mouse pointer then the cat will ask to move the mouse pointer (the parrot).
Whren the parrot is closer to the cat it will jump. If the cat gets in contact with the parrot the game is finished.
writing:
nanWhen you move the mouse pointer left and right the parrot will follow it. If you stay more than 3 seconds without moving the mouse pointer then the cat will ask to move the mouse pointer (the parrot).
Whren the parrot is closer to the cat it will jump. If the cat gets in contact with the parrot the game is finished.

title: No Te Gusta Moz? (Unstuck 13)
description:
I just saw Antman and the Wasp and a scene from it inspired today's response to the prompt. This was the first time I've tinkered with this approach and it's definitely given me some ideas on how to apply it in other ways, especially with student projects. 

(Also, I'm out of town for the next few days, so these next projects might be a little rough until I can polish them up.)

The whole Getting Unstuck process has been a quite a gift - there's still so much to learn, but now I have a new sense of creative confidence going into each day. Thank you!
instructions: Press the flag to start. Keeping the mouse away makes Morrissey sad. But then again, so does keeping it close.

title: generative art - shy interactive barcodes
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 13
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

This project evolved organically, with many intermediary versions discarded while pursuing interesting glitches. The result could definitely be rewritten cleaner and more efficiently with the pen blocks, but I like the analog feel of the current iteration using stamps :)

ToFix: When using the full screen height 180x2, the line sometimes gets stuck on the bottom of the screen - why it is not moving further?

ToDo: Play with interactive colors, line thickness, speed... anf get back to a more "barcodes" look!
instructions:
Move the mouse closer/further away from the middle axis to help shape this computer-generated drawing.

Press space to pause and admire your work of art :)

title: Spaceship survivor
description:
Inspired by classical spaceship arcade game I've created a simple shooting game.
The ship moves faster or slowly depending on the distance from the enemy. I decided to added this kind of movement to make the game more challenging.

                                         ---My next goal---
I'd like to add more enemies, safe zones when you can hide and maybe some power-ups.

                                            ----Credits----
+ Sprites and backgrounds: All of them have been created with the Scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Press the play button to start.
Use the mouse to move your ship.
When you see "target" on the screen you could shoot your enemy by pressing the space bar.
Try to get as many points as possible. 
**Tips**: don't forget to get "HP" before it dissappears.

                                  ---Getting Unstuck day 13---
