title: Unstuck Day 13: Hide and Seek
description: This is my second attempt at Challenge 13. Tried coding using strategies of @mauretta @clarimer @alirb.  Had trouble getting mine to work.  Computer has been glitchy last few days. (Too many lines of code? Too many sprites?)  When sprites were reduced in size, they seemed to move better.  Also layers seem to be important. If more than one sprite, does the mouse interact with only the top layer?  Not sure if the mouse is controlling motion here . . . Giga seems to move even when mouse not nearby, and seems to get stuck near the rock, which is two layers below. Tips and advice would be appreciated if you have suggestions :)
instructions: Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

"Ode to Joy" (German: "An die Freude" [an diː ˈfʁɔʏdə]), is an ode written in the summer of 1785 by German poet, playwright, and historian Friedrich Schiller and published the following year in Thalia. A slightly revised version appeared in 1808, changing two lines of the first and omitting the last stanza.

"Ode to Joy" is best known for its use by Ludwig van Beethoven in the final (fourth) movement of his Ninth Symphony, completed in 1824. Beethoven's text is not based entirely on Schiller's poem and introduces a few new sections. His tune[1] (but not Schiller's words) was adopted as the Anthem of Europe by the Council of Europe in 1972 and subsequently by the European Union.
Reference - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ode_to_Joy\

I was inspired by cooljewels piano keys project view:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/115556287/#player
There you will find the notes to simple tunes.

title: Steven The Bug
description:
Ok, I've been spending waaay too much time on this, but I'm super proud of my project today.

I've always been wanting to make a sprite that follows the mouse with their eyes, so this project seemed to be a good opportunity to do it. Then I realized how cool it would be to feature Steven, inspired by project made today by @Mittensproject, @augusto and @aitan

After playing a bit with the imported image, it was clear to me that Steven deserved a vector version. I started playing with the graphic editor and I got stuck there! My strategy today was "keep going" and that made me to spend hours to create Steven, my first vector sprite ever! I was so excited and proud that I couldn't stop, so I also made vector graphics for the scratch blocks, inspired by the awesome illustrations made by the Getting Unstuck team.

Feel free to use Steven and the script blocks in your projects, you can also add new costumes or improve them!

Happy debugging!
instructions:
Steven The Bug doesn't like to be caught.
Move the mouse slowly and see what happens when you get closer.
Press space bar to generate a new background.

title: Fussy Cat Simulator remix
description:
I, the cat, make the rules (or, do I?) 
The hand may pet me at any time
I will react differently to the hand depending upon certain conditions
I am fussy when the hand first meets me
When I get fussy, I hiss
To avoid being hissed at, the hand must be a certain distance away from me for a count from 0 to 20
When I am happy, I purr
I purr softly to let the hand know that it may approach me
I purr loudly when the hand is petting me after a break, but only for a short while  
I get fussy again each time after a countdown from 20 to 0
I am actually controlled by the hand
I am an A.I. cat!!!!

I do not naturally excel at writing or following logic. I persevered to analyze and understand @karenb 's code. Scratch is hard to read when there are multi-layered nests of code. After using post-it notes on my kitchen counter, I decided to use some "my blocks" and comments in my remix.
instructions: Sparkles the Cat, who runs the notorious Time Laboratory, has demanded that her beleaguered assistant, Jeff, pet her. But Sparkles is a bit fussy. Jeff has reached out to you for help. Can you help Jeff figure out how to pet Sparkles the Cat without getting clawed?

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 13
description: My inspiration was a walk that I took with my dog at the beginning of this summer.  We can across a porcupine in the middle of the path.  It just froze and looked at us.  It wouldn't start moving until we backed up a distance. It took FOREVER for it to finally wander into the woods so that we could pass.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 13 - Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

Move the sprite to see how the porcupine reacts.  Click the green flag to reset. More your sprite to the left side of the path to start.

My code is not as complex as theirs but it works ... I think.
instructions: Click the green flag to begin. Move the mouse close to, but not over, the blue balloon. Pop balloons by moving the mouse over them. Move the mouse over the original blue balloon to pop all the balloons.

title: plant a flower
description:
This is for 'Getting Unstuck' day two, I'm catching up. I like generative patterns and this one is related to something a student of mine stumbled upon by accident once. Controlling the amount of curve by relating it to position in some way can create some fantastic patterns!

If I had more time, I'd, I dunno, probably add something weird generating in the background independent of clicks ... :)
instructions: Click the green flag, wait just a moment, then click the backdrop. Once it's done drawing you can click again to draw more!

This was a fun project to create.  I liked figuring out how to control the clones and create different interactions between the bat sprite and the bug.  I spent a lot more time than I meant to trying to create a sunrise backdrop.  If I had more time I would tweak that more, or find a better set of backdrops.  Press the green flag, then click on the bat to catch the bugs.

title: 13 : The mystery painting in San Diego
description:
Great idea - I never thought of this before. I will use this in my next workshops for sure.

Does anyone know how to import a photo as a backdrop and make it look sharp in the full screen mode? 

Here I used the online editor Vector Magic to transform the photo - but I would rather have used the original photo.
instructions:
Move your mouse slowly around the painting to see what art comes to life! Sound on.

Flyt musen langsomt rundt i billedet og se det komme til live. Tænd for lyden.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 13 - reaction
description:
When I saw the instructions for this challenge I immediately pictured a ball moving around almost like a magnet being repelled. I had no idea how to do that until I saw @mcshicks project and was able to remix it. I'm still not sure exactly how the script works, but I was able to modify it enough to realize my vision.

I still wish I could figure out how to make it move smoother (so the lines were not staggered - maybe similar to the Bored Electron project)
instructions: Press the green flag to start moving the ball around. If you move away from the ball for a few seconds it will switch colors.

I still wish I could figure out how to make it move smoother (so the lines were not staggered - maybe similar to the Bored Electron project)Press the green flag to start moving the ball around. If you move away from the ball for a few seconds it will switch colors.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 13
description:
When I first started this project, I thought that I would have to calculate the distance between the beetle and the pointer so I set about doing this using a bit of trigonometry.
I got quite involved in this until I spotted the Distance to Pointer block!
I left my working to show what I had done.
As a next step it would be nice to get the beetle to move away from the pointer.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to get the program going.
Move the mouse pointer towards the beetle and see what happens.
What happens if you keep the mouse pointer away from the beetle?

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 13
description:
The challenge for day 13 is, "Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently." 

Scratch the cat will ask someone to chase him if the dog is not moving toward him.  Once the dog starts to move towards Scratch, he will begin to move away.

I used the Scratch Wiki to figure out how to make the dog follow the mouse pointer.  This project also made me think about layering.  I started by just trying to program everything at once... Then I figured out that I should start with just the cat and making it move, then program the dog to follow, then program the speaking.

I would definitely like to clean it up a little bit and make it flow more smoother.
instructions:
Click the green arrow to get started.

Use the mouse/touchpad to control the dog.
writing:

I used the Scratch Wiki to figure out how to make the dog follow the mouse pointer.  This project also made me think about layering.  I started by just trying to program everything at once... Then I figured out that I should start with just the cat and making it move, then program the dog to follow, then program the speaking.

I would definitely like to clean it up a little bit and make it flow more smoother.Click the green arrow to get started.

title: Getting Unstuck- Day 13
description: Using a if-else block and the distance variable, I made the vampire move away from the mouse. If I had more time, I would make the monster glide away from the mouse while simaltaneously crying for help. Such is the dichotomy with vampires--very brutal but even the most innocent garlic can conjure thoughts of horror!

title: Make your way through the poke mansion
description:
Sprites from spriters-resource; music from khinsider. 

This was pretty tricky! Originally I tried to set it up so that if you were at certain xy coordinates that would trigger the floor transition but for some reason wasn't able to get the detection set up right, so I settled for making different stair sprites. 


Next up - real walls!
instructions: Walk around using the arrow keys to find the right staircase to navigate between floors.

title: Escape The Room
description:
At the moment, I am feeling more proud of this project than anything else I've created. :) I'm obsessed with escape rooms and I've long wanted to make one in Scratch. Today's Getting Unstuck prompt (Day 12, "Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through.") seemed like the perfect reason to try!

I'm definitely enjoying a self-congratulatory "WOW!" moment. I hope you enjoy it! If I had more time, I would definitely add more challenges.

I took the soundscape from @jsh's "Space Chomp" https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/1735345/
instructions:
Press the green flag.
Help the Scratch Cat.
writing:
At the moment, I am feeling more proud of this project than anything else I've created. :) I'm obsessed with escape rooms and I've long wanted to make one in Scratch. Today's Getting Unstuck prompt (Day 12, "Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through.") seemed like the perfect reason to try!

I'm definitely enjoying a self-congratulatory "WOW!" moment. I hope you enjoy it! If I had more time, I would definitely add more challenges.

I took the soundscape from @jsh's "Space Chomp" https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/1735345/Press the green flag.
Help the Scratch Cat.

title: quahoggin'
description:
I was inspired by @mizzpeters to return to my first ever scratch project, or, the inspiration behind my first scratch projects - Surf Cat Summer and Surf Cat Clams, created after finding a secret beach with friends.

For this project I decided I'd explore the vector editor and a walk cycle with the changing scenes. After a bit of playing, I enjoyed using the vector editor and I'm excited to continue to work with it. I'm feeling OK about the walk cycle for a first go -- would like to create more steps so that it appears smoother. Continuing with the project I'd also like for the background to appear as moving, too! I started to look into scrolling sprites, though that will be a challenge for another day (: I'd also like to have interactive features with each scene.

-- [ Started from the bottom, now I'm here! ] --
Surf Cat Summer + Surf Cat Clams here:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/175038091
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/175039887
--[As seen in these projects, I can create SO MUCH MORE now!!!]--

sound sources:
https://freesound.org/people/straget/sounds/411206/
https://freesound.org/people/DasDeer/sounds/161815/
https://freesound.org/people/InspectorJ/sounds/400632/
https://freesound.org/people/13FPanska_Marval_Lukas/sounds/379334/
instructions:
Press the green flag, then press the space bar.

Once in the ocean, move around with the up, down, left, and right arrow keys to find a quahog!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 12 — Moving Rooms
description:
Reflection

This is a remix of my Day 5 project which allows the user to control Scratchy by making him move and jump. This upgrade adds the ability to move rooms.

How does it work? When Scratchy touches the left or right edge, the room number changes, and the background updates accordingly.

While this is a small update, the size of the world has gotten so much bigger.
instructions:
Move with LEFT and RIGHT arrows.
Jump with SPACEBAR.

Reflection

While this is a small update, the size of the world has gotten so much bigger.Move with LEFT and RIGHT arrows.
Jump with SPACEBAR.

title: Where is Mrs. Pollard?
description:
Turtle from PlusPNG.com
Computer Lab Teacher artwork by a former 2nd-grade student
Photos by me.

Reflections:  I notice that I tend to get stuck when I jump right in without a plan for the project.  I like to be creative but planning out all the scenes, Sprites and animations ahead of time will help with deciding which algorithm to use for the flow of the project.

Stuck: I had a tricky time getting the bubbles to show and hide on cue. Better planning would have saved time debugging/recoding.

Ironically, I would insist my students have a well-defined plan before I would let them start a project such as this.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #12 Use Scenes

Press the spacebar. Wait. Repeat. Enjoy.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 12
description: I added to my hide and seek game that I created on day 8.  I decided to have the cat search in other rooms too.  I had a look at someone else's code to see how to change the backdrops and had great fun.  I even managed to get my cat facing the right way!  feeling more confident as I go through this project.
instructions:
Playing hide and seek.

title: Getting Unstuck 12
description:
I had no time and no ideas today, so I remixed a wonderful little project by @TheGreatMe11 to include fading in of three totally inappropriate background (actually stored in sprites to make the fading work. Did you know you can drag a backdrop into a sprite and it will become a costume? Took a minute or five to fix a weird glitch that turned out to be due to having one of the chosen backgrounds as the actual background which would show through sometimes. I fixed that by leaving it for a while - when I came back it was obvious. Looking for that bug, I found a more subtle bug that also got fixed - so often the case when debugging.)

If I had more time I would go to the shops as there's not much in the fridge.

title: Day 12 Getting Unstuck
description:
Challenge: Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through. 

This was pretty straightforward to create, but it gave me a chance to use custom blocks to simplify the code. I also had to use two sprites unexpectedly in order to add a pose in the end that wasn't part of the first sprites walking costumes. Finally, I discovered that you can change the stage backdrop from a sprite without having to broadcast to the stage.
instructions: Click the green flag to start.

title: A Lovely Day
description:
For today's Getting Unstuck challenge, I modified a scrolling script to create multiple scenes along a walk.

Scene one is in the lab. 

Scene two is walking past a sunflower patch, remixing a beautiful pen solution from Scratcher scmb1:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235674874/

The third scene is a butterfly passing by.

I interpreted the second and third scenes as interactions vs. specific backdrops. My next plan is to add an evening fireworks display using the script from the Fireworks projets by Scratcher 77Tigers: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/195160155/
instructions:
Press the green flag to go for a walk with Avery.

Use the left and right arrow keys (mostly right) to walk around.

title: Falling apple...
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 12
by Massimo Marletta

A simulation on gravity acting on a falling apple.
I used 3 scenes, representing 3 different gravitational system: Earth, Moon and Jupiter.
In each of them you can simulated an apple falling subjected to the gravity force. The timer is used to keep time and increment the apple's velocity of a constant quantity (which is the acceleration of gravity, g) depending on the particular gravitational system.
The time of the simulation is slowed down to let you observe the motion. As you can see the total falling time is different in different planets due to the different value of g.
instructions:
A simulation on gravity acting on a falling apple (by Isaac Newton, not Steve Jobs).

Click on the scene to select a planet (Earth, Moon, Jupiter) or click on the apple to make it fall down.

The time of the simulation is slowed down to let you observe the motion. As you can see the total falling time is different in different planets due to the different value of the acceleration of gravity.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 12 Moving thru 3 Scenes
To the moon!
description:
Obviously this is a remake of the classic game "Lander". The spaceship comes from another game of mine (check "planet seeder" and "orbiter"). The vector of the spaceship is modified by the sine and cosine function of the angle.
Fun fact: I never fully understood what a sine and cosine were until a made a game which used them. It was a driving game made in (then Macromedia) Flash. Maybe one way for understanding something is trying to do a videogame about it!
Explosion by Naveenan on Pixabay https://pixabay.com/en/comic-blast-blast-effect-2340467/
instructions:
UP = thrust, LEFT, RIGHT = rotation, SPACE = ignition
Try to get to the moon of the alien planet. 
You start on Earth, just press up to win gravity until you reach outer space.
In space you have to manouver to the moon revolving around the alien planet. There is no friction and gravity here.
On the moon you have to land. Beware! There is little gravity here and the spaceship can land only if it's pointing up and with very little speed (both horizontal and vertical)
writing:
Obviously this is a remake of the classic game "Lander". The spaceship comes from another game of mine (check "planet seeder" and "orbiter"). The vector of the spaceship is modified by the sine and cosine function of the angle.
Fun fact: I never fully understood what a sine and cosine were until a made a game which used them. It was a driving game made in (then Macromedia) Flash. Maybe one way for understanding something is trying to do a videogame about it!
Explosion by Naveenan on Pixabay https://pixabay.com/en/comic-blast-blast-effect-2340467/



UP = thrust, LEFT, RIGHT = rotation, SPACE = ignition
Try to get to the moon of the alien planet. 
You start on Earth, just press up to win gravity until you reach outer space.
In space you have to manouver to the moon revolving around the alien planet. There is no friction and gravity here.
On the moon you have to land. Beware! There is little gravity here and the spaceship can land only if it's pointing up and with very little speed (both horizontal and vertical)

title: Getting Unstuck day 12
description:
It took me a while to come up with an idea today. Once I did and got started, I realized that I would need more than 3 scenes. When it comes to telling a story, brevity is not my strong suit. I did my best to keep it concise. I am pleased with this project because it is a personal story. I think that's the most authentic possible use of Scratch, or any kind of creating really, when it is deeply personal. It may not be "wow" to everyone, but it IS "wow" for me.

images from wikimedia commons
final image by MrQuentin
music - J.S. Bach- Partita No.2

title: Unstuck Day 12- Different Scenes
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #12-use at least 3 scenes- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
This took a long time because of the many assets I needed to make, but most of it came together pretty easily because I planned out how it would work. 
One thing was hard, which was I wanted to make the keys by just making one and having it clone itself when you find more. but that didn't work, it kept adding a lot each time. So I just made 6 keys.
instructions: Get the 6 keys to escape the room! Face different walls of the room by clicking the sides. There's a surprise when you get out. Good luck!!

On July 16, 2018, the project was enhanced based on activity #12 of  "Getting Unstuck" of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #12 Challenge: Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through.

title: Tadpole adventure!!
description:
I've created a very short demo game.
I've wanted to create a platform game which combines other game elements. I decided to draw everything from scratch, and I'm proud of it. I used only a few scenes (6).

                                      ---My next goal---
I'd like to add more worlds, enemies, food, sound effects and to make a longer story.

                                          ----Credits----
+ Sprites and bakgrounds: All of them have been created with the Scratch paint editor.
+ Song: "NES level1" by Labbed is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.
instructions:
---Welcome to Tadpole adventure---

Help your little tadpole to get home. Eat plankton to make you stronger. Every 12 pieces of plankton your tadpole will grow. The other fishes can grow too. 
When you are bigger than the fishes, they will be smaller and vice versa. 
Be careful with lava.
Get at least 23 pieces of plankton to win the game.
Enjoy it!

**Tips**: variable: food1 is for tadpole.
variable food2 is for fishes.
Tadpole only eat plankton with her little mouth.

                                        ---Controls---
Press the green flag and then click the button bellow to start.
Arrow keys to move your character.

                         ---Getting Unstuck Day 12---
"Make a project that includes three separate scenes that a sprite moves through."

I've created a very short demo game.

title: Unstuck Day 12: Three Sequential Scenes
description:
Still draft version. Revised my earlier project to change scenes.
I was having fun making my underwater scene complex, with various sprites moving in different directions and using different types of motion. 
Used "broadcast" to backdrops scenes. Have a much better understanding of command after working on today's project. Still not perfect.  Have to get rid of unwanted sprites in certain scenes. Yesterday, I was following the pattern given during my remix, and today I was building my own code.  
Very funny to see sharks in space and fish flying. Know what to do, and fixed many errors, but project was glitchy and did always run properly.  (Too many lines of code?)
instructions:

Press the green flag and then the space bar to begin

title: G.U.  Day 12 - QUATTRO PASSI ...
description: #NAME?
instructions:
Una della tante versioni  di " Quattro passi per Crevalcore" , un Progetto di Storia locale iniziato in Classe Prima , qui rappresentato come una passeggiata nel Centro Storico del paese. 
Uno degli obiettivi principali del Progetto era quello di riallacciare i fili della memoria e i legami con un territorio colpito dal sisma del 2012. E' stato un Progetto poliennale, che ha coinvolto bambini, insegnanti, genitori e nonni di due classi. 
Parte del Progetto  fa riferimento agli studi e alle attività di formazione del Prof. Vaccarelli, dell'Università dell'Aquila, relativi alla pedagogia dell'emergenza.
Il Centro Storico di Crevalcore, poi, è adattissimo per una Caccia al tesoro con Coding … (reale)

Questa versione è una copia modificata. 
Sequenze molto lunghe, con istruzioni che si ripetono. 
So già che avrei potuto usare delle combinazioni più complesse, ma più funzionali.
 Aspetto consigli e suggerimenti.

title: Unstuck - Day 12
description:
This was a pretty simple challenge.  In the past, I have created projects where two characters are talking to one another in two different locations.  The characters would show and hide as the background switched.  
My goal in participating in this Unstuck 21 Day Challenge is to gather ideas for my classroom.  I would like to use these Unstuck projects as bell ringers to introduce students to new programming challenges.  Today's challenge will probably be used relatively early in my course, but I would bring it back later to ask students to either elaborate on a previous idea or challenge themselves to try something new.
instructions: Click the green flag to start.

I would like to use these Unstuck projects as bell ringers to introduce students to new programming challenges. title: Day 12:  Do the Honey Bee!
description:
This project is an example project I did for a Scratch Conference workshop that Cynthia Solomon and I are doing on "Atoms to Bits" with animation.  The Bee was lasercut in wood and painted, then I took a photo.  I uploaded the photo into scratch, made it into a sprite and then animated the sprite.

I learned that cutting out a photo with the magic wand turns it grey, so you have to use the erase tool.  I used my chain reaction broadcast scheme like a boss, again!

The song is from the Point View School Kids Hip Hop Honeybee dance.  Google the video. . . it's very cute!
instructions:
Just press the green flag and enjoy.

The bee is an actual necklace that I made in the South End Technology Center @ Tent City's Fab Lab in Boston.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 12
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 12 Reflection:
I hope it's okay to use this project for day 12, since it's one I just made for a Scratch class I'm taking.  I wowed myself by creating different scenes from the doorways, and I was surprised how hard it was to make my scripts match up to the idea I had in my head.  It's still not exactly what I wanted, but I'm learning more with each day of Getting Unstuck and with each project I make.
Clip art images from openclipart.org.

title: Wandering - Getting Unstuck 12
description:
The main credits is to the long novels "Intraworld" by Neil Gaiman and Michael Reaves, which you need to know to fully appreciate this work. Or at least go in a library or a bookstore and peruse a couple of pages, please ;-) 
I used the english translation of the italian title to have an excuse for creating a 007 like intro.
The hardest things to obtain was to enlarge the text beyond the maximum size allowed by Scratch and obtain the spiral effect zooming out the text. It uses a trick I had to google hard to find.
AND YOU CAN HAVE TO ALMOST FREE: just open the project and read the code (ask for help in the comment if needed)!

https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/Overriding_the_Costume_Size_Limit
instructions:
Just click, on the green flag, click when required and enjoy.

I had no idea on what to do for this project and then created one describing that impasse, and gives an hint on the way I solved it, or, better got unstucked!

title: Visiting the house of Scratch
description:
My original idea was to share some of the places I'm going to visit during my upcoming holidays, visiting my friends and family in Italy.
I wanted to start the journey by going out of the Media Lab, but I realized that it would have been cool to let other people in the lab, to visit this incredibly playful and inspiring place.

I'm pretty satisfied with the project, especially because I was able to make it in a short time. Yesterday I've been spending hours working on a different project idea but I realized that I need more time for that.

So my design response to this project is "yes!", I hope it might be "wow!" for someone else! :)

Enjoy!
instructions: Click the green flag and enjoy a quick tour of the MIT Media Lab, home of Scratch!

title: Deep Thought
description:
This week has been a little short on time, so I haven't been able to spend as much time on the project as I want to, but it does force me to  think about time as a design constraint, particularly for implementing these activities in classrooms. I got the MVP (minimum viable project) working, and then I thought...what else do I have time for? In <30 minutes, there's definitely not enough time for looking for/making sprites, so I stuck with what was in the sprite library. And, it's a reminder that the sprite library is so rich! And I still have a fully functioning project!

If I had more time, I would make the answers more respondent to the questions, instead of just at random. Any thoughts on how to do that much appreciated!

Music: Zora's Domain (night) - Zelda breath of the wild.

title: 5-Question Scratch Cat Jeopardy
description:
(For Day 16 of Getting Unstuck)
Today's invitation to make was: "Create a program that answers the user's questions." My first thought was to create a Magic 8 ball, but then I tried to think of other situations where the user (or the player) is stating a question. I was reminded of someone from our apartment building who watches Jeopardy in one of the building's common areas every evening and used that as my inspiration. I took the questions from Jeopardy's online practice test sets (Teen edition).
Were I to invest more time in this project, I would...
* make it a big more flexible for answers that are "close enough"
* make it more Jeopardy-like, with identified categories and varying prize amounts
instructions: Press the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 16: Foodie dice!
description:
I was stuck on this challenge. The only thing I could think of that directly answered the prompt was some sort of magic 8 ball... which is cool, but not what I wanted to make! Eventually, with the help of @paulinah, I remembered a great gift I received for Christmas—foodie dice! They're meant to help you decide what to eat. So, I decided to turn this into my project :)

It's not exactly answering a question the user *poses*, but I think it's definitely a question lots of people have!

I'd like to come back to this later and add in more options, store the options in a list, and then only show the options available for those conditions.

Wood image from Wikimedia Commons.
Foodie dice found here! https://www.foodiedice.com/
instructions: This project answers age-old question... what should I make for dinner tonight?

title: Tell Me More
description:
I got most stuck conceptualizing this project. I had a difficult time thinking about how to frame questions and answers in this context. Initially I wanted to try to really have the answers "make sense", that is, for the project to listen well and respond accordingly. Listening is HARD, and teaching a computer how to listen well seemed too large a hurdle any of the attempts I made at it. 

So, I wondered how I might highlight that dilemma in the answers. I thought some more about listening, to each other and ourselves, and wondered how I might make a list of responses to think with. I ended up searching to see if I could find an interview by teacher + teacher educator Eleanor Duckworth. I thought I'd take the "answers" from there. (I didn't have a particular interview in mind, just that I'd like to to find one.)

I found 'On Thinking about Teaching: A Conversation with Eleanor Duckworth', and pulled out some of her responses and this project unfolded (:
http://www.ascd.org/ascd/pdf/journals/ed_lead/el_199103_meek.pdf

loop that I used:
https://freesound.org/people/arseniiv/sounds/159422/

loops that I thought I might use:
https://freesound.org/people/zagi2/sounds/351433/
https://freesound.org/people/suonho/sounds/57870/
instructions: Press the green flag to start to interact with Truffle (:

title: Getting Unstuck Day 16 - The ChatDuck5000
description:
This project uses the stringToWords block by @jsh from his Visual Editor of a few days ago: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236732850/ Thanks! 
HINT - you don't have to remix to reuse - the backpack will carry items between projects if you're working online (look at the bottom of the editor). Remember to credit those who help you. 

The duck splits the words of the question and uses the first word - probably the question word. It looks in a list Q for this word and if it's there it uses a corresponding reply. With more time I would extend the code to check the whole sentence to allow it to scan for trigger words like Orange or Quack and create a response. 

You can see the lists used Q and A - dive in and remix to add some more replies. The trigger word (if first word in the question) will result in the reply. The last entry in A is the response if no match is found and should always be the last item.

title: As simple as possible...
description:
This started as a joke, but looking back, some of these responses sound pretty familiar :)
As a teacher, I am all for encouraging inquiry and critical thought, but hope I remember to be more engaged and less aloof than this knock-off of Professor Einstein.

Photo from www.thoughtco.com
instructions:

writing:
This started as a joke, but looking back, some of these responses sound pretty familiar :)
As a teacher, I am all for encouraging inquiry and critical thought, but hope I remember to be more engaged and less aloof than this knock-off of Professor Einstein.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 16 — Magic Advice
description:
Reflection

This is a straight up recreation of a Magic 8-ball. The user asks a question and then a random answer is selected from a dataset of answers stored in a list. The part that took the longest was manually inserting the answers into the list. This probably took me about 15 minutes to complete.

Here's a Wikipedia article on the Magic 8-Ball:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic_8-Ball
instructions: Ask Scratchy a yes or no question.

title: European day of languages
description:
I thought about the European Day of Languages and tried to combine different sounds with objects.
This idea was born at school last year and I've worked on a project carried out with children: they thought of asking family and friends to record words from school objects. I've tried to write with them a simple sequence of scenes. It was interesting, this project is their idea.
I would like to make it easier and simpler in writing codes.
How could I make it easier or more simple?

Thanks to the friendly voices
instructions:
An activity dedicated to European Day of Languages.
Click on the green flag. Home to restart 

Clicca sulla bandiera verde per iniziare (in inglese).

title: Getting Unstuck day 16
description:
I took today as an opportunity to revisit and improve an old project. A number of people have mentioned doing so the last couple of weeks and I have been meaning to follow their lead. This is a fairly straightforward magic 8 ball type project. I removed the extraneous code that recreated the list of answers every time the program is run. I also made it possible to ask another question without enduring the set up spiel each time. Finally, I added a spooky soundtrack of radio noise recorded by NASA's Cassini spacecraft (RIP brave robot). 

soundtrack - https://soundcloud.com/nasa/cassini-saturn-radio-emissions-2?in=nasa/sets/spookyspacesounds
instructions: Click the green flag for answers to your most pressing questions.

title: Getting Unstuck #16: Internet Safety Quiz
description:
In fact, the user answers the program's questions and the program evaluates their responses and calculates the user's score.

Originally, I created this Scratch project as part of a lesson plan for the WWW2 handbook (http://webwewant.eu/handbookdownload/handbook/). The Quiz aims to raise pupils' awareness on Internet safety issues.

Special thanks to Scratch wiki editors for providing useful quiz implementation tips here http://wiki.scratch.mit.edu/wiki/Creating_a_Quiz

Instrumental music by Longzijun

Day #16 Challenge of "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education: Create a program that answers the user's questions.
instructions: Press the Green Flag and then, the Space key to take the quiz.

title: Day 16:  Ask the Squirrel
description:
Like many, I struggled with how I can make the conversation seem authentic.  So I decided that I could at least code it so in the beginning when the squirrel ask the user a question that it recognizes if the input is correct or not and responds accordingly.  After that, I had to go for more generic answers.  Actually, they are the 10 ten ways to avoid answering a question.    
I just thought of an additional idea that I would like to include in this project.  That is to use the the list block: CONTAIN THING?  I hope to get back to this project later today to add that option as well.  With this, I think I can answer the where, what, who, why and when questions that may give the user the feeling that the squirrel really is understanding their questions. 
 
Nature sounds from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wKnS8VPxpHI
instructions:
Day 16 Challenge: Create a program that answers the user's questions.

Press the green flag to talk to the squirrel.  He will answer any question you may have!  Sometimes he gets a little grumpy if you don't answer his questions correctly!  Many find him a bit evasive!
writing:
Like many, I struggled with how I can make the conversation seem authentic.  So I decided that I could at least code it so in the beginning when the squirrel ask the user a question that it recognizes if the input is correct or not and responds accordingly.  After that, I had to go for more generic answers.  Actually, they are the 10 ten ways to avoid answering a question.    
I just thought of an additional idea that I would like to include in this project.  That is to use the the list block: CONTAIN THING?  I hope to get back to this project later today to add that option as well.  With this, I think I can answer the where, what, who, why and when questions that may give the user the feeling that the squirrel really is understanding their questions. 
 
Nature sounds from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wKnS8VPxpHIDay 16 Challenge: Create a program that answers the user's questions.

Press the green flag to talk to the squirrel.  He will answer any question you may have!  Sometimes he gets a little grumpy if you don't answer his questions correctly!  Many find him a bit evasive!

title: Snake chatbot (Getting Unstuck Day 16)
description:
I made this project for Getting Unstuck Day 16. It's my fourth Unstuck project (one is my other account: @PinkyPepper). Wow, I am amazed by how many people already made 16 projects. Good job!

I've wanted to make a chatbox for a long time, but never took the time to actually do it. Now I did :) I've used this tutorial made by @crazynimbus: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/23615814/ The hardest part is making interesting questions. I'll try to add some more later on.

The drawings of the snake are inspired by a childrens book of Catharina Valckx, called "Poten omhoog!" ("Hands up"). I've made them three years ago for this project: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/61060236/

Thanks to @DeKrache for the stars used in this project.
instructions:
PLEASE CLICK ON THE SNAKE TO CHAT.

You may just say "Hello" and/or ask one of the following questions:
- What is your name?
- What time is it?
- Do you like Scratch?
- What is your favorite food?
- What's your favorite colour?
- How old are you?

Or you could just ask a random question...

title: Unstuck 16 Ask me a math question
description:
Wow, this became very difficult for me very quickly.
My code tried to determine if a valid math problem has been entered, and then solves it. It has to find a number followed by an operator (+ - * /) followed by a number, then calculate the answer.
I didn't have enough time and would still like to put in more error checking:
-more than one operator entered
-divide by zero
-invalid number format either before or after the operator
I also wondered about a way to display the calculated answer in a larger more celebratory format, like as a sprite that could be animated. I will look into that. As I'm learning more about scratch, I wish it had some features of other languages, like a function that returns a value.

-non-numeric characters entered

title: geo quiz
description:
Today I'm in a super-rush... no eye candies!

Just two thoughts:
1) If you need a non-dynamic two-dimensional array, just use two lists with the same index.
2) Did you know that you can import list from a text file? Every line is a record. Just right-click on the list and select "import" (you can export, too).

The map is from Wikipedia by Strebe
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_map#/media/File:Winkel_triple_projection_SW.jpg
instructions:
Enter a capital or a country, the cat will find the corresponding country or capital!

The names have to be correct and no acronyms are allowed... so the cat won't find "USA", you should search for "United States of America".
The accented words are made with an apostrophe!

description:

typewriter - https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin-_Royal_mechanic_manual_portable_typewriter_-_3128.jpg

script for typing effect from - https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/115324471 by @footsocktoe

I have been wanting to try the typing effect since @jsh used it a few days ago. I thought today was the day and then I looked at the script! I promise myself I will set aside time to pull it apart and figure it out, but today was, in fact, NOT the day! I found a much simpler substitute from @footsocktoe and used that instead. 
I have lots of practice with the Magic 8 ball (coins, dice, spinners, paper fortune tellers, etc!) as I do a unit with 3rd grade every year on creating Scratch randomizers. I was looking for a slightly different take, just for a change.

description:
The quiz is in the list "data":
1 line - topic of the quiz
2 line - question 1
3 line - 1 answer
4 line - 2 answer
5 line - 3 answer
6 line - 4 answer
7 line - 5 answer
8 line - question 1
9 line - 1 answer
10 line - 2 answer
11 line - 3 answer
12 line - 4 answer
13 line - 5 answer
The last line contains only one character "#"
Each line of answers begins with a "-" symbol if the answer is incorrect, and the "+" symbol if the answer is correct

title: Reader Response_GU_Day16
description:
I noticed that some projects produce nonsensical responses b/c the questions are not tightly enough constrained. I had many ideas today. Here's the rationale for the one I picked: The way “novels are taught” in many classrooms makes me crazy because the joy of reading is sucked away by countless low-level comprehension questions. EQ: How can teachers provide readers with more inspiring questioning?
I am working on a bug. Yesterday I played with @jamesdotca 's Connect the Dots. For some reason, my drawing code is not working yet, even though it looks the same as his. My sprite is having laggy, or no, response. Now I'm trying a work-around. Next, trying to get unstuck about letting the user change the pen color mid-drawing. I have a solution! Play and find out! (Bonus Q: If you cross over a line that you have already drawn, what happens?)
Credits:
http://pngimg.com/download/2115
https://www.flickr.com/photos/dominicspics/8554677475
http://freemusicarchive.org/music/Borrtex/Emotion/2Gratitude
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin.
Follow the prompts.
When you have finished drawing, click the stop sign icon. 
Then show someone what you have created!
Follow-up activity: Pretend that you are the character. Write a thank-you note that explains why you are grateful for the gift.
writing:
I noticed that some projects produce nonsensical responses b/c the questions are not tightly enough constrained. I had many ideas today. Here's the rationale for the one I picked: The way “novels are taught” in many classrooms makes me crazy because the joy of reading is sucked away by countless low-level comprehension questions. EQ: How can teachers provide readers with more inspiring questioning?
I am working on a bug. Yesterday I played with @jamesdotca 's Connect the Dots. For some reason, my drawing code is not working yet, even though it looks the same as his. My sprite is having laggy, or no, response. Now I'm trying a work-around. Next, trying to get unstuck about letting the user change the pen color mid-drawing. I have a solution! Play and find out! (Bonus Q: If you cross over a line that you have already drawn, what happens?)

title: Challenge 16 - Scratch Dictionary
description:
Had a bit of trouble thinking of what to do today. Then I thought about a dictionary. Have always wanted to create one. Few things I may do with this. 

May create the backdrops as a webpage search engine etc but we'll see how time goes. 

pathikrit on github created the dictionary file of words, parts of speech and defintions. 

I parsed them to create a csv file to import into the Scratch lists.
instructions:
Created a 6000 word dictionary on Scratch. Type a word to see if it is there. If you can't find a word, click on the word list, it will show you the list to scroll through.

The right margin on the text engine isn't perfect but it will do for this project. That will be a whole new rewrite down the road. 

This showed me I have to work on my vocabulary. 6000 words and he don't know none of me's.

Sorry, this is the only dictionary I could find that I could work with in Python and add to Scratch. Scratch as a 10048 list item limit. BIG WORDS!!!!!!!

title: Day 16 - Dig a PYG Translator!
description:
This was tricky but fun.  I made it so complicated as I tried to make variables as you do in python, but with a bit of playing around I soon found out that everything I needed was in scratch blocks. 
I have it set for 10 turns but you could add or take away as you wished. 
I changed the responses so that even if the input for the questions was not as expected, it would push you through the game!  (my high5 to myself moment!  I also imported clipart and altered it to make my sprite animate.  Again. Silent high 5 to me!  
I'm loving this!
instructions:
Today I had a bit of fun with responses.  Ive been trying to learn python (it's hard!) but I had been programming Pyg Latin.  I throught it would be fun to do a Scratch version.

title: Regrouping: Getting Unstuck Day 16 Questions
description:
Getting Unstuck

At the moment, I am only able to count out the tokens required to show the addition, but I can't get them to regroup by 10s properly. For some reason, my "repeat" loop cuts out before looping as many times as I am asking for. I'll have to come back to this one...

If anyone wants to have a look in the "regrouping" event for the ball sprite, I would be much obliged!

OK, I've got the regrouping by 10 happening, but I've since learned that I cannot go above 301 clones of a sprite, so I may have to think on this and come back, at least if I want to multiply large double-digit numbers.

I've also modified my scripts to include an idea coming from other Scratchers... instead of broadcasting and receiving from multiple clones (lots of broadcasting, so causing lots of unintended craziness) I should have one uncloned sprite do the broadcasting (and use "broadcast and wait" as well) and the clones do the receiving. That way, it's easier to control the timing of all clones' movements. It also helps to conceptualize breaking down the project into smaller steps, much like functions might, with each broadcast block dedicated to doing different things.
instructions:
Ask Scratch Cat to do any math operation (add, subtract, divide, and multiply) with numbers up to 99.
He'll give you the answer AND show how it's done.
(For the moment, Scratch Cat only knows whole numbers and can only add numbers up to 99, but other operations will eventually be added!)
writing:
Getting Unstuck

At the moment, I am only able to count out the tokens required to show the addition, but I can't get them to regroup by 10s properly. For some reason, my "repeat" loop cuts out before looping as many times as I am asking for. I'll have to come back to this one...

If anyone wants to have a look in the "regrouping" event for the ball sprite, I would be much obliged!

OK, I've got the regrouping by 10 happening, but I've since learned that I cannot go above 301 clones of a sprite, so I may have to think on this and come back, at least if I want to multiply large double-digit numbers.

I've also modified my scripts to include an idea coming from other Scratchers... instead of broadcasting and receiving from multiple clones (lots of broadcasting, so causing lots of unintended craziness) I should have one uncloned sprite do the broadcasting (and use "broadcast and wait" as well) and the clones do the receiving. That way, it's easier to control the timing of all clones' movements. It also helps to conceptualize breaking down the project into smaller steps, much like functions might, with each broadcast block dedicated to doing different things.Ask Scratch Cat to do any math operation (add, subtract, divide, and multiply) with numbers up to 99.
He'll give you the answer AND show how it's done.
(For the moment, Scratch Cat only knows whole numbers and can only add numbers up to 99, but other operations will eventually be added!)

title: Female video games characters (8-16 bits)
description:
Today I've got stuck many times because I didn't know how to do what I had in my mind. I took a look on some projects, but I didn't find what I wanted to do. So, I decided to do the same thing but in a simple way that works for me.
I wanted to ask some predetermine questions by using the list block, and then the character would answer each one differently. 
I finally used different variables instead of a list to answer the user's questions.
I'd like to add more characters and questions.

Any suggestions or comments are welcomed.

Welcome to the "Female video games hall of fame".

description:
This project responds to the #GettingUnstuck" prompt for Day 16:  Create a program that answers the user's questions.

One thing that I had to think through was how to get the individual background elements to Say.  Then I remembered the paint editor's Magic Wand tool, and voila!  I was able to create three sprites using the three cut-out images, and aligned them to the original images on the backdrop.

title: Unstuck Day 16/17- Text Input
description:
This was for the Getting Unstuck challenge Day 16 but turned into a big project that I didn't have time to finish in one day. Luckily the next day challenge pretty much fits the bill as well, so it covers Day 17, too!
I have made and taught a hangman game in Python so I thought this would be doable but ran into many many problems. One was not planning carefully enough in the beginning. I was taking out random letters instead of all occurrences of specific letters.
Then Scratch does not have indexed loops (for loops) so I had to make various counters to do things based on the the current loop number. 
I have not used Snap much but this would be a good project for Snap as it would have been useful to have custom blocks that can report something. In Scratch I had to create many variables to keep track of little tasks that would have been easier with reporting blocks.
instructions:
Play Guess the Word! This is for two players, one to type the secret word and the other to guess. Have fun!
If you want to see something cool click "under the hood" while you play and you can see the program processing the tasks as you give it input.
Note: The reason your word can't be a phrase is the program knows when you have guessed the word by checking if it has no more spaces in it, so the spaces would keep you from every being finished.

I have not used Snap much but this would be a good project for Snap as it would have been useful to have custom blocks that can report something. In Scratch I had to create many variables to keep track of little tasks that would have been easier with reporting blocks.
instructions:
Play Guess the Word! This is for two players, one to type the secret word and the other to guess. Have fun!
If you want to see something cool click "under the hood" while you play and you can see the program processing the tasks as you give it input.
Note: The reason your word can't be a phrase is the program knows when you have guessed the word by checking if it has no more spaces in it, so the spaces would keep you from every being finished.

title: Hanoi Towers
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 16
by Massimo Marletta

The Hanoi Towers Game

The main logic is in the Stack sprite, which handles a list of the sizes of the blocks which are stacked in it. The Block sprite have different costumes to represent different sizes.
An extensive use of broadcast message is used to pass game control from the sprites. Nano is the game controller which send appropriate messages to the sprites. Tera gives instruction to the user.
To satisfy challenge requirement, the user can make moves by answering to Nano's questions.
instructions:
Hanoi towers is a classical game.

(Click on Tera to see game instructions)

You have three stacks and a series of blocks in the first stack.
You can move the top block of one stack to another stack, with the aim to move all the blocks to the stack 3... but you cannot put a block over a smaller one!
There is a famous solution to the game, but this project is not about computer giving the solution: it is up to you to move all the blocks to their destination!

title: Getting Unstuck 16
description:
Now that I actually interpreted the prompt correctly, this does what it's supposed to do. I loved making these fortune tellers (or cootie catchers, as we called them) when I was a kid.

The "unfolding" animation doesn't look great, but overall I'm happy with it. If I have more time the main thing I'd like to add would be error checking. Right now it just trusts the user to enter the right numbers and colors to make the fortune teller work, but if someone typed in, say, violet instead of purple for the color at the end it won't work.

Cootie Catcher images from https://boingboing.net/2015/08/18/brief-history-of-the-cootie-ca.html
instructions: Click the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 16
description:
Thank you to the Facebook Group and mstone326 for giving me the easy way to load lists from CSV files.  So much easier...that's the only reason I chose this project.

I'm sure there is an easier way to choose which letter to highlight.  What I did was extremely repetitive. There's probably a way to use another list and an index.  I would appreciate any advice.

If I were to add to this I would use a Ouji Board pointer to move to each letter before I highlight it and show it.  I'd probably have to move the center for each letter so that the pointer does not obscure the letter.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 16 - Create a program that answers the user's questions.

I wanted to make a Magic 8 Ball...but then decided to combine it with a Ouji Board to use more of the string functions.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 16
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 16 Reflection:
This was fun to make, but I wish I could have figured out a better way to give a random answer than to just create different costumes. That seemed to be the simplest way, but it took me a long time to figure it out!    I don't know overall how much time I spent on it, maybe an hour, plus mulling it over before actually trying it out?

The part that took the longest for her was looking at others' projects for inspiration and tips.

This project is part of #GettingUnstuck initiative #CreativeComputing, Day 16

"Create a program that answers the user's questions"

Dino will ask you for a simple operation, with 1 digit operators (numbers from 0 to 9). It allows + - * and /.

For example:

4+6
5-7
8*2
9/1

title: Ask Quelo
description:
The inspiration from this project comes from one of my favorite Italian comedians, Corrado Guzzanti, who played the role of a guru of an invented religion, based on the cult a piece of wood called Quelo.

I've spent most of my time looking at other people's projects and realizing that most of my initial ideas had been realized already. It was hard to get the program respond to different questions, so this character and his jokes came into mind.

I've spent a bit of time thinking whether or not to share it.. as the reference might be fully appreciated by people who know the character, but I decided to share it anyway! I have 5 more project to go!

C'è grooossa crisi! :)
instructions:
Ask a deep question to Quelo.

Who are we? Where do we come from? Where do we go?

title: Random Answers (Getting Unstuck #16)
description:
Getting Unstuck activity #16 - "Create a program that answers the user's questions."

Simple script which asks for a questions and then gives a random numerical answer. It does a quick check of question length in order to provide some cheeky reply prior to the answer.

I'm catching up on the final week's worth of activities so this is quick and simple. It could be improved by attempting to parse the question to look for keywords or limit to maths questions which could be parsed and evaluated in script.
instructions: Click the flag and ask some questions.  I doubt you'll get the right answer!

title: The A-to-Z Game
description:
I don't know if I had a "biggest challenge" today. I played it pretty safe, picking a project I had a good idea how I'd build. title: Colorful sound
description: I had seen a previous project (Maybe the hexapath remix I did?) where a user typed in some binary (1s and 0s) in order to affect the project. What if a user could type in numbers and make some sounds happen? I had a grand vision of being able to generate strings, and perhaps "pluck" them somewhat...Anyway, I figured out how to store a username + sequence of sounds but didn't have time to sort out the playback. Oh well!
instructions: Press the green flag and follow along! Hover over the strings to play some notes back (this only works sometimes, and for some reason really softly).

title: Chromophobia Weaving
description:
When @karenb shared Chromophobia on Day 15, inspired by Josef Albers, I wondered how I might create a project inspired by both Josef and Anni Albers, combining chromophobia and weaving! Today seemed the perfect day, using list data to create potentially-hideous (and potentially pleasing) color combinations in weave structures, depending on your input!

The life once-considered and yet-to-be-lived in which I was a math major and the life I instead lived at art school as a textiles major are both very excited about this project. This might be the Getting Unstuck project I'm most proud of so far (:

Some stuck moments (of which there were certainly a handful) along the way included initially programming with pen drawing and struggling to get the layering to successfully simulate the weave structure I had in mind (a classic plain weave). At that point I thought maybe I'd set for transparency and realized pen drawings are only opaque. After a brief moment of AHHHH, I realized I could create a long 'thread' sprite which could be transparent, take color data, and be stamped (: 
(any tips on starting to explore layers in scratch would be much appreciated)

This was definitely part of continuing to explore my "where could I get with programming if I don't focus on drawing...?" question.
This also felt like something of a redemption from pattern-drawing-day disasters.

weaving sound:
https://freesound.org/people/xserra/sounds/320510/
instructions:
Press the green flag, enter some data, and see the weave structure you've made!

Wanna make another? Press the space bar (:

Update: I switched the color of the origin sprite -- I learned that this will determine the range of colors for the "color effect"
Is it more or less likely to be hideous now? 
(definitely looking to maximize hideous - beautiful range)

title: Memory Game
description:
This project was created for Day 17 of Getting Unstuck. Today's challenge was to make a project that asks the user for a list and does something interesting with it. There are multiple lists in this project, and I had a really big bug in one of them that took me 20 minutes to figure out (sheesh!). But I got to reuse a bunch of graphics and scripts from previous Getting Unstuck projects, and I had a lot of fun making it!

title: Getting Unstuck #17
description:
This was going to be the Swedish chef, but my digital citizenship got the better of me. 
The last bit of the list, where all the rest of the ingredients are added I couldn't figure out how to get an "and" in there to make it grammatically correct. I'm sure there's a way by carefully counting the ingredients and making sure that the last of them is added by itself, but I couldn't figure it out. If I devote some more time to it in the morning I might get there.

Kitchen Background: By Pbroks13 - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=4297278
instructions: Do some cooking. Press the green flag and tell us what you have in your cupboards. We'll do the rest.

title: Donut Poetry Generator
description: Credits: This is a Code Club project resource I used with 4th graders to make poetry in ELA class (projects can be found here https://scratch.mit.edu/studios/4586131/) The students, working in pairs, had to generate and code their list of words. Here I've changed it so the user adds their own parts of speech words to the list but it is still random if their word gets used.
instructions:

Add your words to this Mad-lib style poem.

title: Unstuck 17 Binary Bitmap Art
description:
Sample digits to enter: 7 e 8 1 a 5 a 5 8 1 b d 8 1 7 e
Another sample: 9 9 2 4 4 2 9 9 9 9 4 2 2 4 9 9

The activity that inspired this program is a Binary Bitmaps activity (http://cse4k12.org/binary/bitmaps.html) posted by Gary Kacmarcik on cse4k12.org and licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/). 

For binary/hexadecimal conversion practice, check out this project from gerogero: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19900885/
instructions:
This is a program that can check the hexadecimal numbers that are generated as part of a binary bitmap activity. 
Students create a picture on an 8x8 grid then convert the picture into binary numbers; an empty square on the grid is assigned the value 0 and a filled square is assigned the value 1. Each row has eight digits. If you split each row into two four-digit binary numbers you can then convert each row into a two-digit hexadecimal number. 
This program asks the user to enter the 16 hexadecimal digits, one at a time, and then will print the bitmap picture on an 8x8 grid on the stage.
I could modify the code so the user inputs all 16 hexadecimals at once. Does that make more sense that one digit at a time?
writing:
Sample digits to enter: 7 e 8 1 a 5 a 5 8 1 b d 8 1 7 e
Another sample: 9 9 2 4 4 2 9 9 9 9 4 2 2 4 9 9

The activity that inspired this program is a Binary Bitmaps activity (http://cse4k12.org/binary/bitmaps.html) posted by Gary Kacmarcik on cse4k12.org and licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/). 

For binary/hexadecimal conversion practice, check out this project from gerogero: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19900885/This is a program that can check the hexadecimal numbers that are generated as part of a binary bitmap activity. 
Students create a picture on an 8x8 grid then convert the picture into binary numbers; an empty square on the grid is assigned the value 0 and a filled square is assigned the value 1. Each row has eight digits. If you split each row into two four-digit binary numbers you can then convert each row into a two-digit hexadecimal number. 
This program asks the user to enter the 16 hexadecimal digits, one at a time, and then will print the bitmap picture on an 8x8 grid on the stage.
I could modify the code so the user inputs all 16 hexadecimals at once. Does that make more sense that one digit at a time?

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 17 — Word Randomizer
description:
Reflection

Playing with variables, lists, and data can be a lot of fun. I liked the challenge of creating a define block for splitting a string into individual words and placing them into a list. I also like creating the second define block that makes a new string by randomizing the order in which the words are removed from the list.
instructions: Tell Scratch Cat a sentence, and they will randomize the order of the words.
writing:
Reflection

Playing with variables, lists, and data can be a lot of fun. I liked the challenge of creating a define block for splitting a string into individual words and placing them into a list. I also like creating the second define block that makes a new string by randomizing the order in which the words are removed from the list.
Tell Scratch Cat a sentence, and they will randomize the order of the words.

title: Getting Unstuck day 17
description:
I wanted to try to work with some of the list blocks that I have not used before. I hit on the idea of using the length of the words given by the user to play particular notes. This ended up using more block than I expected. I needed a variable to itereate over the list and another to add the notes to the second list. 

With more time I would try to make the output a bit more consistently melodious. Possibly by using addition rather than multiplication to se the notes. Also, I think it might help if the note length is not random, or at least less random.
instructions:
Click the green flag
follow the cat's instructions
change the instrument with the slider.

title: Bug Party planner (Getting Unstuck Day 17)
description:
This is my fifth Unstuck project (three of them are shared on my other account @juf-Pinky). If you encounter a real bug, please let me know.

This was super fun to make. At first I had no idea what to make for this challenge. I wanted to do something with a dance, but I couldn't figure out in which way I could ask the user how the sprite should dance. Then I came up with the idea of a party planner. Using a list turned out to be really useful in this project. I only faced some minor bugs :) Testing all the options was time consuming though. Maybe I missed a bug... This project took me about three hours to make.

Thanks to @Mittensbrother and the Getting Unstuck team for the bug and the Unstuck logo, thanks to @ceebee for the dancing code, thanks to @chrisg for the dancing flower, thanks to @TheDiamonGamer  for the idea of the dancing pizza, thanks to @Bubblebomb for the idea of the dancing stickman. Thanks to @scratchcat for the cool Scratch cat sprites, and thanks to @TheLibrary for the code blocks I used for the confett.
instructions:
Plan your own Bug Party. Please answer the questions of the bug.

title: Drawing clones
description:
Did you know that EVERY rectangular slot in Scratch could be filled with a variable or a list element? Messages or go to something, for example. In this demo I have inserted a list element inside the clone function.

I wonder if these "hidden" features were left on purpose to exercise our "lateral thinking".
instructions:
Choose what to clone by answering the question. You can answer multiple times. When you're ready, just press enter and the clones will be created!
Use only lower case letters!

Once the clones are created, press space for drawing!
writing:

I wonder if these "hidden" features were left on purpose to exercise our "lateral thinking".Choose what to clone by answering the question. You can answer multiple times. When you're ready, just press enter and the clones will be created!

title: Challenge 17 - list sorting
description:
Wasn't sure what to do with this one today as I created 3 6000 line lists yesterday which I used Python to extract the data I needed from the raw data to import, a bit exhausting. 

Then I saw today's challenge...haha, LISTS! I was a day early. So I thought I'd work with some sorting. I had to use the Scratch wiki on the insertion sort as I haven't done those sorting methods in a few years. Good to freshen up on them and now I will create some more practice sorting for myself.
instructions:
The program will ask you how many numbers you want. I used a custom block without screen refresh for some parts, others I left there so the lists could be seen what they are performing.

Second you'll ask what you want to count by. If you put 3, the separated list will count by 3s, any other number will be sorted to an odd or even list. 

Then the list will shuffle randomly. Give you a heads up about sorting it and it will using insertion sort method to put it back in order. I used without screen refresh as the sorting took a while, this way it is just done.
writing:
Wasn't sure what to do with this one today as I created 3 6000 line lists yesterday which I used Python to extract the data I needed from the raw data to import, a bit exhausting. 

Then I saw today's challenge...haha, LISTS! I was a day early. So I thought I'd work with some sorting. I had to use the Scratch wiki on the insertion sort as I haven't done those sorting methods in a few years. Good to freshen up on them and now I will create some more practice sorting for myself. The program will ask you how many numbers you want. I used a custom block without screen refresh for some parts, others I left there so the lists could be seen what they are performing.

Second you'll ask what you want to count by. If you put 3, the separated list will count by 3s, any other number will be sorted to an odd or even list. 

Then the list will shuffle randomly. Give you a heads up about sorting it and it will using insertion sort method to put it back in order. I used without screen refresh as the sorting took a while, this way it is just done.

title: Duck Math! - Getting Unstuck Day 17
description:
I feel like this is one of the more complex projects I completed. I figure out how to do the lists, and I even figured out how to check if the math answers were correct! 
I think the last thing i would change about this would be randomizing the statements the duck gives when you are right or wrong, and I think now that I understand lists this wouldn't be a big problem at all.

Thanks to a student of mine, @Jackromance for the duck inspiration!
instructions:
The duck will ask you some basic math problems, and you can answer them as best you can!
Some sweet background music, so you should have your volume on.

I feel like this is one of the more complex projects I completed. I figure out how to do the lists, and I even figured out how to check if the math answers were correct! 
I think the last thing i would change about this would be randomizing the statements the duck gives when you are right or wrong, and I think now that I understand lists this wouldn't be a big problem at all.

Thanks to a student of mine, @Jackromance for the duck inspiration!The duck will ask you some basic math problems, and you can answer them as best you can!
Some sweet background music, so you should have your volume on.

title: Day 17:  Sum of Three Positive One Digit Numbers (Basic Project)
description:
This is the basic version . . . I have plans to fancy it up by the end of the day, and will add more detailed notes to that version.
My main goal was to include parameters to make sure the user actually followed the instructions.  Wanted to get the three numbers in one list, and find the sum that way, but it was tricky and I knew I would be short on planning time this morning.  Went with three lists with one item each (not sure of the point of having a list with only one item . . . ) and then making a new list to find the sum of those three lists.  Would love suggestions for alternate / more efficient coding ideas.

title: interest rate arbitrage
description:
For Day 17 of GettingUnstuck, in which we work with Lists.

Spreadsheets are an evocative object for me, so I was excited to use Scratch as a similar medium. I also wanted a visual to support a financial argument (an elective cash out mortgage can be sensible) that is anathema to common sense. 

A more refined model would ask for tax rates on dividends/income and would adjust for tax deductibility of interest payments on the mortgage. Mortgages are structured so that interest repayment is weighted toward the start of the loan and principal repayment is weighted toward the tail, which is advantageous to arbitrage but feels unfair if your goal is to get out of debt. A more refined model would also fluctuate the investment returns.

When I have more time I'd like to develop this so one could track payments in real time of an actual (theoretical) loan against a (paper) investment as well as against speculation, as well as spending opportunity costs, e.g. lattes vs. additional principal repayment.

I tried a formula for calculating mortgage payments, based on https://www.mtgprofessor.com/formulas.htm, and it indicated a monthly payment that was 100 more per month than the PMT function indicated by Excel. This eliminated the arbitrage opportunity, so for this simulation I input the Excel PMT result to Scratch. I left a draft block showing how the inflated payment was calculated. If anyone can find an error there, I would love to understand what it is!
instructions:
Green flag, and watch. This is a crude calculator that simulates mortgage payments balanced against a dividend yielding investment (or interest rate arbitrage). Exponential growth is visually understated (I divided results by 3) so that I could keep visuals on the stage.

Assumptions: 100,000 borrowed for 360 months at an interest rate of 4.7%. Invested in a vehicle that pays annualized 7.1% before taxes via monthly payments. (I used DNP's price and monthly dividends for this model.) Monthly dividends minus pmts are reinvested in the vehicle (no transaction costs assumed).

title: Getting Unstuck #17: Greek Olympiad in Informatics:
description:
Special thanks to Scratch wiki editors for providing useful tips here: http://wiki.scratch.mit.edu/wiki/List

Day #17 Challenge of "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education: Create a project that asks the user to type in multiple words or numbers, stores the items in a list, then does something interesting with the items from the list.
instructions:
Press the green flag and then, the spacebar to continue.

The program prompts you to enter numbers which represent pupils' heights and stores them in a list. Then, it finds the total number of students who can see the school cafeteria while they are standing in line. 
This Scratch project implements the same efficient algorithm which solves the programming exercise that is described here: http://www.pdp.gr/files/27A/PDP_27_A.pdf. Normally, these kind of exercises have a C++ implementation.

Special thanks to Scratch wiki editors for providing useful tips here: http://wiki.scratch.mit.edu/wiki/List

description:
I started with one of my previous entries with the goal of creating an experience that would evolve and change over time as more people participated. 

There are some "workarounds" that emulate cloud lists in a way, but I don't think that's what I'll do.
instructions:
This started as an experiment in making a community created list that would be incorporated into poems, but there's no cloud list feature. (Maybe one day...)

For now, it will have to stay a humble fridge poetry creator that accepts user input. Enjoy!

title: Day 17: (v2) Sum of Three Positive One-Digit Numbers
description:
What I was was trying to accomplish here . . . 
This second version has dialogue that considers many options; response when user doesn't press space bar to begin, when user types nonsense, when user types numbers other than whole numbers from 1-9, and when user types different variations of "yes" or "no" responses (e.g. yes/YES/Y/y)to continue. It was far more complicated than it needed to be, but I wanted to practise using many of the skills introduced in recent challenges, like broadcast, strings, lists, and answer boxes.  Some coding mistakes I have been making include incorrect use of blocks with "and wait" phrasing, and confusion over when to use answer boxes, variable boxes and how to effectively use lists.  My code made use of several lists with one number in them and a list to add the other lists.  I would much prefer to enter three numbers into one list and find the total of items in that list (but am happy to save that task for another day). Still not sure about the purple "Make a block" and "Add an Extension" blocks.  Not fancy, but I like it :)
instructions:
Create a project that asks the user to type in multiple words or numbers, stores the items in a list, then does something interesting with the items from the list.

title: Getting Unstuck Challenge 17- Cluedo!
description:
I have seen lists used to create inventories and my thoughts turned to  the game cluedo.
I used it as inspiration to create my project. Hence the strange looking costume trying to emulate a Cluedo token!
Assuming the player has gathered all the clues, they can give their answers to the "detective" Scratch.
I think there is an easier way to add the answers to the final link, perhaps through using data, but I think it works for now!
I would like to spend more time perhaps adding clipart to match responses. I would also like to add an alternative response if the guesses are wrong - perhaps matching a random created list? - Starting to get tricky here!
 I played with making the "detective" have animated talk, but again I will come back to this one day....!
instructions:
Click the green flag.
Enter your answers.

title: Unstuck 17 Lists - MadLib Story
description:
Ay-ay-ay. I fell down another deep deep hole with this project but managed to get to the beach today also :-) I had hoped to ake this dynamic enough to be able to plug in a new story easily, but didn't quite get that far. If I had to do this again I would make more custom blocks as I was getting very confused with all the list positioning counters. It took me a long time to find a bug in my SubString custom block.
Another improvement would be to somehow display the whole story all at once, like a printed paper with the missing words filled in.
instructions:
