title: Computer Lab Clean Up
description:
I struggled a bit with this. I was able to get it work if you answer all five answers, typed with the exact words (Steps include: quit, close windows, log off, shut down, push in chair). I tried making it so that you would get different feedback if you miss a step, but it's not working.  Can anyone please help?

Also - is there a way to have it respond if the answer the answer includes the word, but not typed exactly - for example 'close your windows' instead of 'close windows'? I would anticipate that students might not necessarily type the exact wording.

Image: https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AIUB_Computer_Lab_2.jpg

title: GCF and LCM: Getting Unstuck Day 17 Lists
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 17 Lists

In grade 7 math, we teach students to move away from making lists of multiples when finding the LCM, because it can get long with large numbers or 3 or more numbers, and students risk making mistakes with their multiples, leading to an error in their LCM. We teach them to use prime factorization instead. A computer can still use the list strategy because it won't make a mistake on the 1178th multiple, but even a computer takes a while to do it!

Getting Unstuck strategies that helped me with this project:
Sleeping on it
Going through the code step by step
Avoiding making clones broadcasters! (specific to Scratch)
Using descriptive names for my variables

TIL that if you want two clones to share information (clone-specific variables) then one strategy for this is to make a global variable and have one clone "temporarily" store its info there so that the other clone can act on it. Two clones cannot share information directly with one to another, as far as I can tell.

If I had more time (or if someone wanted to remix this project), I would either use the prime factorization method for both the LCM and the GCF, or for the LCM (which is the long part for large numbers), I would make the program make a list of (say) the 20 first multiples, check if there is an LCM in that list, list the next 20, check again, etc. This should greatly reduce the time necessary for MOST LCM calculations (except when all of the numbers are prime amongst themselves).
instructions:
Find the greatest common factor and the lowest common multiple of two or more numbers.
Enter all the numbers and say "No" or "no" when you are done.
If you use large numbers or 4 or more numbers, the program works but can take over 10 minutes (!), so if Scratch Cat is saying "Hmm..." for a long time but the timer is still advancing... be patient!

title: Story Idea Generator - Getting Unstuck Day 17
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 17: Create a project that asks the user to type in multiple words or numbers, stores the items in a list, then does something interesting with the items from the list.

This project was inspired by a student who explained a similar project he created at home. He uses his program at home to practice writing.
instructions: Press the green flag to begin. Then answer questions about Who, What, When, and Where? I recommend you capitalize only the first letter of your response to who the story is about and all other proper nouns. There is no need to add punctuation to the end of any responses. Once you "Generate Prompt" you can run with the story idea and add details to complete the story or click "Generate Prompt" again to get a new story idea.

title: Little you, big you
description:
This project responds to the "Getting Unstuck" prompt for Day 17:  "Create a project that asks the user to type in multiple words or numbers, stores the items in a list, then does something interesting with the items from the list."

I almost gave up on this one!  At first, I was going to create a Memories Memory Game, with the cards that must be matched.  I realized that it would quickly get very complicated, so I scaled it down to this comparison activity.  I'm pleased with the result--simplicity can be satisfying, too!

Artwork:  Married Children of Joseph Lea and Sarah Robeson Lea with Their Children, Augustin Amant Constant Fidèle Edouart, French, 1789 - 1861 http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/148122.html?mulR=1783981642|23

Music: 12 Variations on a French Nursery Theme K 265 by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, performed by Stefano Ligoratti  https://musopen.org/music/2664-12-variations-on-a-french-nursery-theme-k-265300e/
instructions: Click on the green flag, then be prepared for a little reflective game!

title: RPN Calculator
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 17
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I realized a very simple RPN calculator.
The starfish asks the user the data to put in the stack (which is a list) and the operation to perform.
Once an operation is specified it get the last two data from the stack and replace them with the result. The latter is ready to be used as an operand for the next calculation.
instructions:
When I was a child a teacher of mine had a calculator by Hewlett-Packard (HP) where if you want to calculate 2+3 you must type "2", "enter", "3", "+".

I was a bit puzzled... then I studied about it.

The Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) is a notation for math expression where you first put data in a stack and then type the operation you want to perform on the data.
For example, to calculate the sum of 2 and 3, instead of writing "2+3=" you must enter "2", then "3", then "+".
The good thing is the once you calculated a result it take the place of the operands in the stack, so it can be easily used for another operation.
It could sound confusing, but it is actually convenient!
This procedure allow avoiding parenthesis and confusion about operator's precedence.

If you want to calculate a bit more complex expression like:
   (2+3)*7 = 35
You must enter:
2, 3, +, 7, *

Easy! (or not?)

The starfish asks you to type the numbers or symbols you want to enter in the RPN calculator, type each item at once and press enter...
writing:
Getting Unstuck - day 17
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I realized a very simple RPN calculator.
The starfish asks the user the data to put in the stack (which is a list) and the operation to perform.
Once an operation is specified it get the last two data from the stack and replace them with the result. The latter is ready to be used as an operand for the next calculation.
When I was a child a teacher of mine had a calculator by Hewlett-Packard (HP) where if you want to calculate 2+3 you must type "2", "enter", "3", "+".

I was a bit puzzled... then I studied about it.

The Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) is a notation for math expression where you first put data in a stack and then type the operation you want to perform on the data.
For example, to calculate the sum of 2 and 3, instead of writing "2+3=" you must enter "2", then "3", then "+".
The good thing is the once you calculated a result it take the place of the operands in the stack, so it can be easily used for another operation.
It could sound confusing, but it is actually convenient!
This procedure allow avoiding parenthesis and confusion about operator's precedence.

If you want to calculate a bit more complex expression like:
   (2+3)*7 = 35
You must enter:
2, 3, +, 7, *

Easy! (or not?)

The starfish asks you to type the numbers or symbols you want to enter in the RPN calculator, type each item at once and press enter...

title: Day 17 - making sense of the sum of two dice
description:
This exploration of the game of two dice is inspired to Galileo Galilei "On a discovery concerning dice" where he answer the following question: "Suppose three dice are thrown and the three numbers obtained added. The total scores of 9, 10, 11, and 12 can all be obtained in six different combinations. Why then is a total score of 10 or 11 more likely than a total score of 9 or 12?

https://www.leidenuniv.nl/fsw/verduin/stathist/galileo.htm
instructions:
Click on the roll button to repeat rolling two dice. The "rolls" list contain the sum of the two dice for each roll; the list "roll-count" counts the number of occurrences of each sum.  
Examine the results, can you make an urn that (as a random generator) is equivalent to rolling two dice? Click on the "2dice urn" button to create it.
If you notice that a number (e.g. 6) appears many times, put more 8 in the urn.
Click on the dice to "extract" form the urn and check if this is equivalent the rolling the two dice.
writing:

The total scores of 9, 10, 11, and 12 can all be obtained in six different combinations. Why then is a total score of 10 or 11 more likely than a total score of 9 or 12?

https://www.leidenuniv.nl/fsw/verduin/stathist/galileo.htm
Click on the roll button to repeat rolling two dice. The "rolls" list contain the sum of the two dice for each roll; the list "roll-count" counts the number of occurrences of each sum.

Click on the dice to "extract" form the urn and check if this is equivalent the rolling the two dice.

title: Bubblesort - GettingUnstuck-17
description:
Bubblesort is one of many sorting algorithms, not the most efficient, but one of the simplest to implement so it was funny to play with it on Scratch.
This is just the first iteration: I would like to see the bubbles move when I swap them (and just those involved) instead of redrawing all of them like now. I used the parsing function from the day16.
And, thinking about thinking: bubblesort is not the way our brain sorts numbers, what kind of algorithm do we really use? Is it the same for all of us?
instructions:
Green flag to start.
You can enter some numbers comma separated and they will be bubblesorted (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bubble_sort)

title: Program Steven
description:
I wanted to create a todo list for a sprite, then I realized that it is exactly what a computer program is! So I made a very simple programming language on top of Scratch.

I was surprised by how easy it was to build the "interpreter", i.e. the "start" sprite that reads from the list and broadcast messages to Steven. If I had more time I would implement more programming blocks and I would add the possibility of repeat loops.

Enjoy!
instructions: Click on the blocks to create a program, then press the start button to let Steven execute it.
writing:
I wanted to create a todo list for a sprite, then I realized that it is exactly what a computer program is! So I made a very simple programming language on top of Scratch.

I was surprised by how easy it was to build the "interpreter", i.e. the "start" sprite that reads from the list and broadcast messages to Steven. If I had more time I would implement more programming blocks and I would add the possibility of repeat loops.

Enjoy!
Click on the blocks to create a program, then press the start button to let Steven execute it.

title: Day or night? (v2)
description:
A more minimalist project, remixed from an old project. I was a little pressed for time, but it was also a good reminder that these challenges are intended to be quick and easy, even if it's also so easy to get sucked into the work! 

It's also funny to go back to old projects and see how your style was different. For some reason, in the old one, my noise-dependency if it was loud was a forever loop triggered by the sound, whereas if it was soft, it was an if statement inside a forever loop. There are only two options though - why not wrap them both in the same forever loop? *headshake*
instructions: Just press the green flag!
writing:
A more minimalist project, remixed from an old project. I was a little pressed for time, but it was also a good reminder that these challenges are intended to be quick and easy, even if it's also so easy to get sucked into the work! 

It's also funny to go back to old projects and see how your style was different. For some reason, in the old one, my noise-dependency if it was loud was a forever loop triggered by the sound, whereas if it was soft, it was an if statement inside a forever loop. There are only two options though - why not wrap them both in the same forever loop? *headshake*Just press the green flag!

title: Chromophobia
description: For Day 15 of Getting Unstuck, I imagined what Josef Albers (the great Bauhaus artist) might make with Scratch. (I'm currently reading Albers' "Interaction of Color".) As part of my research for this project, I came across an Atlantic article (https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2014/12/the-secrets-of-color/382229/) about Albers. The article mentions a historical confusion, anxiety, and fear around color, described as "chromophobia". I thought this was a fascinating word (and cultural phenomenon); hence, the title.
instructions:
Press the green flag to start.
Make sure that your computer audio is audible.
Use the slider to adjust the instrument.
Use your computer's controls to adjust volume up and down.
Watch how the square pulses vary according to instrument and volume.
writing:
For Day 15 of Getting Unstuck, I imagined what Josef Albers (the great Bauhaus artist) might make with Scratch. (I'm currently reading Albers' "Interaction of Color".) As part of my research for this project, I came across an Atlantic article (https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2014/12/the-secrets-of-color/382229/) about Albers. The article mentions a historical confusion, anxiety, and fear around color, described as "chromophobia". I thought this was a fascinating word (and cultural phenomenon); hence, the title.Press the green flag to start.
Make sure that your computer audio is audible.
Use the slider to adjust the instrument.
Use your computer's controls to adjust volume up and down.
Watch how the square pulses vary according to instrument and volume.

title: Amplitude
description:
This project was created for Day 15 of Getting Unstuck. While I was playing with an idea for a different sound-based project, I kept wondering what the "loudness" block was really capturing. I created a variable to display the loudness, so I could see its value. But the value was changing very quickly, and it was hard to get a sense of the individual numbers. 

So I created this project to visualize what was happening. I liked it enough that I set aside the other project idea and focused on this helpful tool instead.
instructions: Click the green flag and make some noise. Use the time scale control to magnify.

title: Star Songs
description:
As I thought about what to create for sound detection, I wanted to see how I could have clones of something represent the shifts in sound visually. I decided to give myself a very short time limit to create a simple sprite in the vector editor (to continue exploring the drawing to programming time ratio in creating my projects). I ended up creating this star which led me to think of a twinkling night sky.

Initially I had intended to have more sensing ranges. As I would run my program, unexpected movements were happening, and the changes I was hoping for were not. I decided to simplify and just have two possibilities, above or below 30. At this point, I was able to get the visual effects I wanted (which included trying what I thought I wanted and deciding I *didn't* want that a few times) The program was running, though, so that was great! 

Boiling effects down to their most simplified and then building on that is a strategy I could probably benefit from using more. My mind often goes real big rather than starting small, and I think that I'd like to try building big and wide from simple, more easily trackable (and therefore tinkerable!), steps.
instructions:
Press then green flag, and then sing (or scream, whatever you need,) to the stars! I recommend full screen (:

(you'll need to be sure your microphone is on and that scratch is allowed to use it)

(sometimes I need to refresh the page before scratch will ask for mic permission -- bug? anyone else have this issue?)

title: Getting Unstuck Day 15: Library Adventure
description:
Images from Pixabay.com
Thanks to Jhenna for playing an angry child.

I originally had trouble thinking of an idea for today's challenge. Eventually, I went with a simple idea (that deviated slightly from the prompt): a library where someone yells at you if you speak too loudly. This, of course, led to some Hogwarts-themed ideas! I tried to mimic what happens in Hogwarts if you open up a book from the restricted section...

If I had more time, I think I'd add more tempting items that shriek when opened :)

Click on the green flag to be given instructions. Stay quiet long enough and you may be tempted by books in the restricted section!

description:
GettingUnstuck 15: This project combines ideas from the previous two unstuck projects, in which I've been reiterating on a way of drawing on the trackpad. In this iteration, alternate between different geometric shapes using loudness. Play the arrow keys and space bar. Shapes also rotate at different speeds depending on loudness. This week, I only have a few minutes for my own Scratch projects each morning, so I'm curating the same few ideas over several days. One thing that I wish I could explore further is using advanced algorithms to make the music (note and instrument selection, sound bending, etc) and other functions smoother.

From Unstuck 14, two exciting discoveries were (1) using mouse x and mouse y to change notes, and (2) using a pointer finger on the track pad to draw without ever clicking. I want to push further with these ideas.

There is additional graphics code that had to be disassembled because they were causing the program to freeze.
instructions:
Green flag, draw with fingertip on track pad.

Designed for makeymakey with grounded ring, connect to right left up down and space (see photos within). Change notes by changing mouse-x, change instruments (3 instruments available) by changing mouse-y.

Try left, up, right, space, down.

title: Day 15 Angry Teacher
description:
Today I needed to compelte a project in a short space of time.  Ive been spending way too long.
My challenge was to create something that I could use again in my classroom.
The noise levels for sound might not be set too accuratley, but if you start in a relatively quiet room and sing 'LAAA' progressively getting louder, the sprite should change what she says in response.  The end comment for a noisy room was just a fun element I decided to add.  I might work on this a bit later and add more sounds and more elements to it. 

Enjoy.
As always, I welcome feedback.

Oh and my wow moment today was ACTUALLY getting multiple conditionals to work for me!!!!! Yippee!!!

Day 15 Unstuck with Scratch
A classroom companion to monitor classroom sound.
Click the green flag and follow the instructions.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 15 — Sound Level
description:
Reflection

I started out doing exactly what the project of the day was. This part of it came together fairly quickly. At this point I took a moment to figure out what else I can do to create a slightly more polished product.

First, I realized I wasn't in a great environment for testing this, but I wanted it to work reliably. This led to me creating a Sensitivity slider so the project could be calibrated.

Second, I wanted the sound level to gradually decay over time.
instructions: This sketch changes backgrounds based on how loud the room is. Use the sensitivity slide to calibrate the project.
writing:
Reflection

I started out doing exactly what the project of the day was. This part of it came together fairly quickly. At this point I took a moment to figure out what else I can do to create a slightly more polished product.

First, I realized I wasn't in a great environment for testing this, but I wanted it to work reliably. This led to me creating a Sensitivity slider so the project could be calibrated.

Second, I wanted the sound level to gradually decay over time.This sketch changes backgrounds based on how loud the room is. Use the sensitivity slide to calibrate the project.

This is a continuation the inspiration I had from @alirb regarding theremins a few days ago and using some of Scratch's preset variables as inputs.

click allow for the microphone
down arrow to clear

title: Noise = Scratch Stamps! (Getting Unstuck #15)
description:
Getting Unstuck #15 - "Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

I had no idea Scratch could interact with a laptop's microphone! This is fairly basic as I had limited time but it's a fun interaction.  

Potential improvements:
- don't stamp if loudness 0.
- stamp slightly more frequently (tried to do this but it stopped stamping for some reason)
- use random polygons as stamp rather than Scratch costume.
instructions:
- Click the flag to start (restart or reload page if microphone not working)
- Be noisy and see what patterns you can make (stamps every half second). I find blowing into your microphone works great.
writing:
Getting Unstuck #15 - "Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

I had no idea Scratch could interact with a laptop's microphone! This is fairly basic as I had limited time but it's a fun interaction.  

Potential improvements:
- don't stamp if loudness 0.
- stamp slightly more frequently (tried to do this but it stopped stamping for some reason)
- use random polygons as stamp rather than Scratch costume. - Click the flag to start (restart or reload page if microphone not working)
- Be noisy and see what patterns you can make (stamps every half second). I find blowing into your microphone works great.

title: Oh Happy Day! (Get Happy remix)
description:
The Day 7 project from @Learn2Teach2018 has so many carefully made steps in it to simulate handwriting, and I've been itching for a chance to remix it so that work can shine in more projects.

I mostly got stuck with the microphone permissions on my laptop, but also with timing all these events, and used the Wiki and the 'help' option in the Scratch editor to re-learn how to use the 'broadcast () and wait' block.
instructions:
Green Flag and then make some noise!

Make sure your microphone is on and is allowed to listen

If you don't have a working mic, click the grey button

title: workshop tool - noise level
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 15
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is. 

ToDo/Remix idea: add a loudness graph

Thanks to PixLoger for the CC0 smileys!
https://pixabay.com/en/photos/?q=user%3APixLoger+smiley
instructions:
A noise meter that can be displayed during a scratch workshop, so that the kids can easily see when the room is too noisy.
(Apparently, some teachers are using an electronic version of this in class, shaped like a traffic light)

Press the green flag, allow access to the microphone access, and then make some noise :)
Use the space key to display the settings:
- sensitivity adjusts the noise thresholds, lower sensitivity means that more noise is needed to make the yellow/red smileys appear.
- persistence is how long the yellow/red smileys stay after the noise has gone down again.

Use the space key to display the settings:
- sensitivity adjusts the noise thresholds, lower sensitivity means that more noise is needed to make the yellow/red smileys appear.
- persistence is how long the yellow/red smileys stay after the noise has gone down again.

title: What's That Racket? GU_Day15
description:
Today, I began by reading articles about decibels. I am playing with testing my voice. When my loudness variable is = 0.1 and I whisper, that level of loudness is not be sensed until my distance from the screen is only a few inches. I want to know if sounds that are played in Scratch can be detected. I am testing "meow". Yes, but, the results for calibration are not consistent. I settle on a rather straight-forward project that allows the user to experiment with the controls. 
Credits:
https://www.thecut.com/2016/05/what-it-s-like-to-be-unable-to-bear-the-sound-of-someone-eating.html
instructions:
Click on the green flag. Then adjust the slider controls when they appear. You may use the sounds that the sprites make, or sounds in your environment to explore!

***Oops, I just realized that in my wonderings and explorations, I missed the part of today's challenge about signaling background changes.

I settle on a rather straight-forward project that allows the user to experiment with the controls. 
Credits:
https://www.thecut.com/2016/05/what-it-s-like-to-be-unable-to-bear-the-sound-of-someone-eating.html

Click on the green flag. Then adjust the slider controls when they appear. You may use the sounds that the sprites make, or sounds in your environment to explore!

***Oops, I just realized that in my wonderings and explorations, I missed the part of today's challenge about signaling background changes.

title: Scratch Dreaming - Getting Unstuck Day 15
description:
The bed is from stickpng
First, it was weird cutting off Scratch's head to get started!
Again, another block I haven't used before. This 21 days is chock full of new stuff. 
It is really fun realizing the ways all the blocks can fit into each other to make something interesting happen.
This wasn't super hard to make, but I did have to mess around because I wasn't sure how loud "loud" was while making something. I think it turned out ok though! I can't wait to see the studio today.
instructions: Click on the green flag to get started. If you are too loud, Scratch might start dreaming!

title: Connect the dots: Getting Unstuck Day 15 Loudness
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 15

Oops... misread the brief... my background doesn't change when the loudness hits a certain level, but my sprite reacts to loudness in a continuously variable manner, up to a certain limit, whereupon it reacts quite strongly!
instructions:
You can use the up and down keys to change the sensitivity of the microphone.

Also, it seems like everyone's microphone is different, so you can easily change the limit for the "strong reaction" on the screen or with right and left arrows.
writing:
Getting Unstuck Day 15

Oops... misread the brief... my background doesn't change when the loudness hits a certain level, but my sprite reacts to loudness in a continuously variable manner, up to a certain limit, whereupon it reacts quite strongly!
You can use the up and down keys to change the sensitivity of the microphone.

Also, it seems like everyone's microphone is different, so you can easily change the limit for the "strong reaction" on the screen or with right and left arrows.

title: Sound rainbow
description: Super short program with one really tricky bit - I had to use a join block in order to cast an number to a string for selecting the background. I had incorrectly assumed that the type would be coerced automatically.
instructions: Get loud! then get quiet!
writing: Super short program with one really tricky bit - I had to use a join block in order to cast an number to a string for selecting the background. I had incorrectly assumed that the type would be coerced automatically.Get loud! then get quiet!

title: Day 15-Loudness Test Pattern
description:
Day 15-Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is. 

This was my first time using the loudness input and I love it! Just created a simple test pattern that changes color, but kids would have so much fun thinking of silly ways to use this.

The block of color automatically gets smaller if it's quiet, but changes size according to the loudness. I multiplied the loudness to make the size change more quickly.
instructions:
Click the green flag
Make sure to enable the video/audio
Watch the pattern change and block change according to the level of noise.
writing:

The block of color automatically gets smaller if it's quiet, but changes size according to the loudness. I multiplied the loudness to make the size change more quickly.Click the green flag

title: Monkey Alphabet 1
description:
bensound for background music
scratch for sprites and sound effects
voice overs by csn4710 (aka wife)

Let me tell you, watching the kids work together, even as three year olds (not year 3, but actually 3 years old), was amazing. We actually used it in as a physical activity because we noticed along with yelling the letter, they kids were also jumping.  

I did try motion controls but it was far to inaccurate. I have a few ideas but will have to see them through first.
instructions:
I created this for my 3year old, pre school and kindergarten classes. I would have them stand up and then yell as a team, teamwork is essential for this game, to help him collect the letter they lost from their backpack. 

Also added a secondary choice to use the keyboard. 

The intro is a reminder to always zip up your backpack. 

3/31/18
Created for a classroom to be projected. Works on based on sound level. Kids can yell out the letter to make the monkey jump.

ALso can press J key for individual play. Press space to use the sound slider to make the response higher or lower depending on classroom acoustics 

4/1/18
Added Keyboard controls. Press 1 for standard, 2 for keyboard
Randomized letters

title: Unstuck Day 15: How Loud Can you Get?
description: I had never used the loudness blocks, so, once again I needed to look at other projects for some help.  Thanks to fun-timeonly for your inspiration.  I wanted 3 different backgrounds, so I had to do some research on the possible loudness values, which I found from the Scratch wiki.  Then, I figured out how to make the backgrounds change based on the loudness through trial and error.  I didn't make my project too complex.
instructions: Click the green flag and make some noise.  See if you can make it so you see all 3 backgrounds.

title: Orchestra and Chorus - Getting Unstuck Day 15
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 15: create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is. 

Music: “Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring” by J.S.BACH. 

It was difficult to adjust the background to the loudness produced by the music. I cheated using the sound editor to emphasizing the loudness variation since I wanted the backstage changed only when started the chorus. 
If I had more time I would fine-tune this project and add other backgrounds effects that came to my mind.
instructions: Click on the green flag and follow the music, orchestra and chorus!

title: Getting Unstuck #15
description:
I was in a bit of a hurry today. With more time I'd tinker with the sound levels, but just playing with it now it seems okay. I've done a similar thing before in class, making a background noise monitor with traffic lights that then gets shown on the screen during class. Unfortunately it turns out that this is a great way to make a class compete for how much noise they can make.
With more time I'd also make my images 4:3. I may still do that if I get a chance this afternoon.

Looking at it again, with more time I'd brush my daughter's hair.
instructions: Just press the green flag and sing something. Amelia will give you feedback on your singing voice.
writing:
I was in a bit of a hurry today. With more time I'd tinker with the sound levels, but just playing with it now it seems okay. I've done a similar thing before in class, making a background noise monitor with traffic lights that then gets shown on the screen during class. Unfortunately it turns out that this is a great way to make a class compete for how much noise they can make.
With more time I'd also make my images 4:3. I may still do that if I get a chance this afternoon.

Looking at it again, with more time I'd brush my daughter's hair.Just press the green flag and sing something. Amelia will give you feedback on your singing voice.

title: Happy Birthday
description:
Reflection:  I didn't have a chance all day to get to this project and by the time I did, I only remembered that I had to use the loudness sensing block. So, the background is not affected by loudness.

If I had more time, I would have the background change depending on loudness, too.  I was figuring out ways to do that by tinkering with the ballerinas' costume changes to increase with loudness.

My spouse suggested a cumulative loudness be reached instead of an instantaneous level. (So you actually have to sing the whole song).
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #15: Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is.

Well, I took creative license with the directions.  Click the green flag and Heart will take it from there.

title: The next door
description:
My first idea for today was: a game where you can control the character with the microphone. I realized that it could be a bit challenging, so I decided to chose another one.
Eventually, I had a simple idea: a game where you can change the stage with your voice at a specific time. 
I've also added some elements to make it difficult and fun.
When you find the hidden door you will always change your size automatically.

                                     ---My next goal---
If I had more tome I'd like to add more obstacles, levels and use the loudness in another way.

                                     ----Credits----
+ Sprites and backgrounds: All of them have been created with the Scratch paint editor.
instructions:
WELCOME TO "THE NEXT DOOR".
Move your character to find the hidden door and get pieces of your spaceship. The door helps you to change your size. When you are on the edge, don't forget to speak or blow into the microphone in order to go to a different room.
*Warning*: when you touch a wall or obstacle you will go to the initial position.
*Tips*: try to have the ideal size to avoid the obstacles.

                                             ---Controls---
Press the green flag and then the play button.
Use the arrow keys to move your character.
Press space bar to show your item list.

                        ---Getting Unstuck Day 15---
"Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

title: All we need is ♥ (for Scratch)
description:
I'm sooo excited about this project!

The Scratch Conference will start in a few days and I wanted to celebrate my love for Scratch and share it with the awesome community of people around Scratch.

Making this project took me hours, and during the process I got stuck, unstuck, stuck again, changed my mind plentiful of times, introduced bugs, discovered bugs, introduced more bugs, added, deleted, undeleted, edited scripts, costumes, ideas, and listened to this song hundreds of times!

It's one way to express my deepest and lifelong gratitude to:

- @mres, @natalie, and the @Scratchteam for creating Scratch
- @karenb and the @ScratchEdTeam for getting me unstuck
- the Beatles for composing this song
- @yknups for the sprites I remixed in this project
- the entire Scratch community for their love

with ♥, 
@tarmelop
instructions: Click the green flag and sing along

instructions:

Se fai troppo rumore, i palloncini si gonfiano fino a scoppiare.
Se fai silenzio, i palloncini si rimpiccioliscono e cambiano colore.

Click on the green flag.
If you make too much noise, the balloons will swell up to burst.
If you are silent, the balloons get smaller and change color.

Stimolata dal suggerimento di @alirb, ho creato la versione 2 del progetto, inserendo - oltre alla condizione "rumore" - la condizione "silenzio".

title: Stormy weather
description:
This project responds to the #GettingUnstuck Day 15 challenge:  "Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

I've been playing with the loudness settings to test sensitivity.  It would be fun to include other types of inclement weather and even nature noises (that users would need to replicate, of course!).

Rainy Street photo from chrismetcalfTV https://www.flickr.com/photos/laffy4k/155406169
Lightning audio by Mike Koenig http://soundbible.com/2016-Thunder-Strike-2.html
instructions: Click the green flag, then clap your hands--softly or loudly.

title: Getting Unstuck #15: Sirtaki dance and loudness sens
description:
Thanks to this challenge and "Chromophobia" https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236675985/ by @karenb, I familiarized myself with the loudness sensor and its use!

Scratch project was created as activity #15 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #15 Challenge: Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is.
instructions: Adjust the speaker level to high volume, press the green flag and enjoy the music and the effect of the loudness sensor!
writing:
Thanks to this challenge and "Chromophobia" https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236675985/ by @karenb, I familiarized myself with the loudness sensor and its use!

Scratch project was created as activity #15 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #15 Challenge: Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is. Adjust the speaker level to high volume, press the green flag and enjoy the music and the effect of the loudness sensor!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 15 - A day in the country
description: I spent some time thinking about how quickly I wanted the backdrops to change, and tried to smooth the effect adding ghosting. This means that if you are testing it at home with your voice you want to hold the note for the full effect!
instructions: This project reacts to the sound and the backdrop changes depending on the volume level. Enable your microphone and enjoy.
writing: I spent some time thinking about how quickly I wanted the backdrops to change, and tried to smooth the effect adding ghosting. This means that if you are testing it at home with your voice you want to hold the note for the full effect! This project reacts to the sound and the backdrop changes depending on the volume level. Enable your microphone and enjoy.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 15
description:
My inspiration....doing this project while watching The Open on TV.

Instead of changing backgrounds I chose to use the loudness to affect story flow.

I would like to add sound effects, like golf swing and ball strike.  Any free sound library suggestions would be appreciated.

My most difficult part...getting the timing.  Still believe that instead of using wait blocks it's easiest to broadcast between sprites to insure timing.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 15 - Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is. 

You only need to click the green flag.  It makes it's own noise, but feel free to cheer as well.  Tiger Woods cannot hit is shot until he has silence for 5 seconds.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 15
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 15 Reflection:
This might be my favorite project so far!  I think I need to tweak the numbers a bit, but I didn't want to get too loud when people are sleeping.  :)
I've seen teachers use a noise-meter before, usually an app or a part of Smart Notebook.  I wanted to see if I could create one.  I looked for public domain stoplight images I could modify.  The one I chose can be found here: http://moziru.com/explore/Traffic%20Light%20clipart%20black%20and%20white/#go_post_10344_street-light-clipart-street-stop-2.png
instructions: Click on the green flag to keep track of the noise level.
writing:

I've seen teachers use a noise-meter before, usually an app or a part of Smart Notebook.  I wanted to see if I could create one.  I looked for public domain stoplight images I could modify.  The one I chose can be found here: http://moziru.com/explore/Traffic%20Light%20clipart%20black%20and%20white/#go_post_10344_street-light-clipart-street-stop-2.pngClick on the green flag to keep track of the noise level.

title: Unstuck 15 - Sound Change
description: Back to the idea of a combination of randomness and input to create artwork. I wonder if I replaced the randomness with some order - like writing top to bottom, left to right - if you could see patterns in music or speech. I wish there was a way to detect pitch and other qualities of sound to have more inputs for patterns - to change shape, etc...
instructions: Press the Green Flag and make some noise to change the color patterns.
writing: Back to the idea of a combination of randomness and input to create artwork. I wonder if I replaced the randomness with some order - like writing top to bottom, left to right - if you could see patterns in music or speech. I wish there was a way to detect pitch and other qualities of sound to have more inputs for patterns - to change shape, etc...Press the Green Flag and make some noise to change the color patterns.

title: Substitution Cipher
description:
Tutorial from @VideoGamerCanInvent: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/74567664/#editor 

Music is Ancient Hateno Tech Lab (Zelda Breath of the Wild) - KHInsider

Remix suggestions: change the cipher! Make the encryption more complicated! Add other kinds of functionality!
instructions: Simple substitution cipher; if you want to change the cipher, go to backgrounds and change the letter order around in the cipher list. Not super complicated, but fairly tedious...one cool thing I learned was how to make your sprites spell out the words they say, like they're being typed live! Simple, but I hadn't thought of it. :)
writing:
Tutorial from @VideoGamerCanInvent: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/74567664/#editor 

Music is Ancient Hateno Tech Lab (Zelda Breath of the Wild) - KHInsider

Remix suggestions: change the cipher! Make the encryption more complicated! Add other kinds of functionality!Simple substitution cipher; if you want to change the cipher, go to backgrounds and change the letter order around in the cipher list. Not super complicated, but fairly tedious...one cool thing I learned was how to make your sprites spell out the words they say, like they're being typed live! Simple, but I hadn't thought of it. :)

title: Mystery Word
description:
My initial concept for Day 14 was to write a program that detected whether two words rhyme. A bug in my code (that was scrambling my letters) led me to this project instead. A big thanks to @jsh who played numerous iterations of the game to help me test. Together we went from "This is the worst game ever. I want my money back." to "You've got some bad bugs." to "That's much less annoying." to "Good game! Major upgrade!" It's so helpful to have someone who is willing to be totally honest with you! :)

Music: https://archive.org/details/ReallyOldRecordingsSetA
instructions:
This is a two-player word game!
Player 1 enters a mystery word and three one-word clues to help Player 2 guess the mystery word.
The program scrambles the word, which Player 2 then needs to guess.
writing:
My initial concept for Day 14 was to write a program that detected whether two words rhyme. A bug in my code (that was scrambling my letters) led me to this project instead. A big thanks to @jsh who played numerous iterations of the game to help me test. Together we went from "This is the worst game ever. I want my money back." to "You've got some bad bugs." to "That's much less annoying." to "Good game! Major upgrade!" It's so helpful to have someone who is willing to be totally honest with you! :)

Music: https://archive.org/details/ReallyOldRecordingsSetAThis is a two-player word game!
Player 1 enters a mystery word and three one-word clues to help Player 2 guess the mystery word.
The program scrambles the word, which Player 2 then needs to guess.

title: Palindrome Bear
description: This was really fun! I worked on it with @mizzpeters and had to do a lot of iterating and hard thinking. I want to work more on creating blocks as it still confuses me.
instructions:

title: Visual Editor
description: This project was created for Day 14 for Getting Unstuck. I wanted to explore the idea of drawing text and making a text input box, but without using Scratch's built-in "say" or prompt features. It was definitely a challenge, and I ran out of time before getting to many of the features that I would like to explore. So I plan to keep working on it in future, maybe as a remix for a future day of Getting Unstuck. Fun!
instructions: Press the green flag and enter a brief message in the text box. Only lowercase, unaccented characters and space key accepted for now.

title: Bad Poetry Generator - Day 14 of Getting Unstuck
description:
credit to Freesound.org for the computer sound
Beat-nik by J.M. Van Eaton (Cool Daddy O 60's beatnik music)
Unsplash.com for the Cafe Background

This was fun. After looking at the first couple projects submitted I was paralyzed! They were so good! 
Then I realized I could counter that with something sooo baaadddd!
I have used operator blocks more and more during the last two weeks. However, I really have not used the list blocks before. I saw them in someone else's project, realized how it could be used, and tested them out. Much easier than I anticipated. That, added to the realization earlier that I could randomized broadcasts, didn't make this too hard in the end. Except making the poetry and trying to get Scratch's beret correctly drawn. 
Didn't know it was a beret? I'm not surprised!
instructions:
Click on the green flag and answer the questions. 
Be prepared for some questionable poetry!

title: Getting Unstuck #14
description:
Getting Unstuck day 14. 
I have been looking for an opportunity to get my head around lists, and today is the day.
I'm quite happy with this result. I'd like to have made the user's name appear with only a capital initial and the rest in lower case, but I'm not sure that that's possible. Likewise, I'm not sure if I can make sure that users put in an actual number (eg 4) rather than the word (four). Apart from that I'm quite happy with this. I can't wait to see what others have been doing.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 14 — Taco Cat
description:
Reflection

This was a fun little project to do and came together fairly quickly. Once done, and after initially posting, I went back and refactored the code, which is probably where I spent the majority of my time. I happen to like refactoring quite a bit as this is usually where I learn the most about programming. Highly recommend! :)

How it works: After the users answers Scratchy, the script processes it by pulling out only the letters of the alphabet while creating variables forward and reverse. This is to prevent spaces and specials characters (ie !@#$%) won't be used in the check. The letters in variables forward and reverse are then checked against one another. If any comparison isn't identical, then it isn't a palindrome.
instructions:
Tell Scratch Cat a word or phrase and they'll say if it's a palindrome or not.

For example, try "taco cat".

If any comparison isn't identical, then it isn't a palindrome.Tell Scratch Cat a word or phrase and they'll say if it's a palindrome or not.

For example, try "taco cat".

title: wAvInG LeTtErS
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 14
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I used some blocks regarding text (for example extracting a single char from a text, or calculating le length of text) together to the function of recursive cloning of sprites.

The letters are sprites with a costume for each character, the costume of each sprite is selected by analyzing the string. 

The wave effect is given by changing the size of the sprite according to a sinusoidal function with a time shift different for each letter.

In another project of mine I use the same logic to simulate a transversal mechanical wave: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236681045/
instructions:
Input a text by clicking on the pencil and see it moving like a wave.

In another project of mine I use the same logic to simulate a transversal mechanical wave: 
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236681045/

title: 17 letter words
description:
My inspiration came from a local trivia outfit, who yesterday had a category "seventeen letter words." 

I haven't quite worked out the timing of the hint (fixed now?), but already fixed an issue with the ask block appearing when it shouldn't and modified the system of tracking words used to prevent duplicate questions.

My daughter suggested I add an "I give up" feature, too.
instructions:
Click the green flag to play this word-guessing game.

Every answer is seventeen letters long.

There are ten words total for you to guess.

I added a second clue (the firs five letters) and a third clue (the last two or three letters, I'm not sure why it varies).

title: Getting Unstuck 14
description:
I thought doing a hangman-style game would be fun, but I didn't know it would end up so complicated! 

My process was to build it step-by-step: first figure out how to choose a random word from a list and display it. Then figure out how to hide the letters and prompt the player to guess. Then figure out how to show the letter if they guess right and keep it hidden if they guess wrong, and so on. I tested it at each step to make sure it was working. I didn't always do the steps in an order that made sense - for example, I put in the rescue bird before nearly everything else because the idea popped into my head ad I thought it would be fun (and make the game have a happy ending!).

I didn't get stuck exactly, but I feel like there must be a more elegant way of doing it. There's a lot of repetitive code here.

Music is Water in the Creek by Josh Woodward via the Free Music Archive
instructions:
Click the green flag to start. Click each box to guess what letter it is. Try to spell out the word before the Scratch Cat sinks!

Hint (because the game is really hard otherwise): All the words are Scratch-themed.

title: substring utility block
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 14
Create a project that uses the string blocks in the Operators category (i.e., join, letter of, and length of) for some fun wordplay.

I got stuck in a deep rabbit hole, aiming for a fully ECMAScript compliant implementation. I used the "compromise" strategy to get unstuck: I reduced the scope to ship a working product :)
instructions:
This project contains a new scratch block that I have been missing:
a custom "substring" block that extracts the part of an input string between the given start and end indexes.

Feel free to use this in your projects without giving me any credit.
See inside for more details :)

title: Haiku vs Cut-Up 2 (Unstuck 14)
description:
This is the first time I've played with the string blocks, wihich is part of the reason why I love Getting Unstuck: it challenges me to go beyond what I usually do. 

This is a short experiment with the "cut-up" (or "decoupe") technique that I first encountered via William Burroughs' "Towers Open Fire." This projects takes a haiku by Kerouac and converts it to a randomized version.
instructions:
Version 2 Update: 

Press the flag to begin and think of 10 words to give to WIlliam.

Thanks @alirb for the suggestion of adding player input (and for nudging me just a bit further than I thought I could do!) 

I'm on a train right now and wifi is intermittent. This needs some polishing - specifically, I'm still trying to find a way to remove the randomly selected word from the list (so it doesn't repeat) unitl all the words are used. Any suggestions will be given finger snaps in appreciation.

title: Deriv14
description:
GettingUnstuck Day 14, a remix of ideas from several projects earlier in the GettingUnstuck series. Working alongside students today, I made a five note instrument out of toaster tongs and copper tape. See sprites for a photo of the instrument.

The idea of using mouse x and mouse y to change notes was an exciting discovery.

There is additional graphics code that had to be disassembled because they were causing the program to freeze.
instructions:
Green flag, draw with fingertip on track pad

Designed for makeymakey with grounded ring, connect to right left up down and space (see photos within). Change notes by changing mouse-x, change instruments by changing mouse-y.

to play theme from Close Encounters: left, up, right, space, down

I almost forgot the unstuck theme of wordplay! For wordplay, I used a koan I wrote for PZ's PoP. Each time a note is played, the number of letters in a random word from the koan are displayed.

There is additional graphics code that had to be disassembled because they were causing the program to freeze.Green flag, draw with fingertip on track pad

Designed for makeymakey with grounded ring, connect to right left up down and space (see photos within). Change notes by changing mouse-x, change instruments by changing mouse-y.

to play theme from Close Encounters: left, up, right, space, down

I almost forgot the unstuck theme of wordplay! For wordplay, I used a koan I wrote for PZ's PoP. Each time a note is played, the number of letters in a random word from the koan are displayed.

title: Unstuck Day 14
description:
I must confess that I had very little time today and was rather overawed by some of the projects.  But, I have never used string blocks before so I decided to go simple which is all my frazzled brain can cope with today!  I was really pleased with the result.
I thought the children would love to do this as a simple project to get into using string blocks, they would be so excited to see their name appear!  I might use this as an intro activity, when we're back at school!
instructions: For all teachers at the end of term!

title: day 14 - word game
description:
I was so pleased that I could make a list and then access it and show the typed words in another box.

I struggled with removing the item from the original list so that it cannot be typed a second time.  Any help with this would be great.  I hope you enjoy playing the game.
Please let me know what you think of it (any constructive or helpful comments are very welcome!)
instructions:
I made this game as my daughter loves word play apps. This could be easily changed by addition of lists.
Maybe there is a way of typing up a few lists and importing a list at the start of the game via a question.
I hope that I did this correctly to achieve the aim of the lesson.  Ive been trying to challenge myself but really not sure about the variables, making my own blocks and that matematical aspect. 
 Click the green flag - read what the lion says then try to guess the words.  If you get them correct you'll get a point and the word will appear in the results window.

title: Falling Letters!
description:
Phew! Speaking of getting unstuck, today I was stuck all the time! Scratch is lot of fun EXCEPT when you have to stick blocks into blocks into other blocks... I was also in a rush today, so my code is not very elegant. Translating letters into numbers and again in costumes was hard, and also the routine that checks if the user writes a number costed me a lot of time. Exhausting but rewarding.  

Fun thing: this is a remake of an example program of a dBase III tutorial. Nowadays almost no one even remembers dBase III, it was a powerful language mainly used to manage databases before SQL. MS Visual FoxPro was based on dBase III, but it was short lived.
instructions:
Guess the secret word! Select how may random letters you want to be thrown out from the plane, then use LEFT/RIGHT to get them.
If the letter is part of the secret word, then they will be revealed.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 14: Zodiac Finder
description:
I was inspired to make this project to teach people a little more about their zodiac signs! It was fun to figure out how to parse the letters and then set the month and date to align with the horoscopes. Originally, when I tried to do this, I got stuck because a month (for example, April) could mean one of two signs. I think I worked around this pretty well, but there's probably a more elegant execution of this.

If I had more time, I'd make sure there was a response for the user making a typo/not typing a correct birthday. Right now, it just stops :)

Zodiac descriptions based on this guide: https://www.allure.com/story/zodiac-sign-personality-traits-dates
instructions: Click on the green flag. Type your birthday with only lowercase letters when prompted (example: may 24), then learn about your zodiac sign!

title: Do the Jiggen! Getting Unstuck Day 14 Strings
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 14 Strings

So this challenge was super fun. Not that many hurdles to overcome, things pretty much worked the way that I expected them to.
I tried a new strategy: in the past, I would have likely broadcast two messages like "dance" and "nodancing" in order to coordinate all the different sprites' activities in the two situations. However, I tried using what is essentially a true/false variable and found that it worked rather well, as the sprites only do simple repetitive things in each different condition.
instructions: Click the different buttons on screen and see what happens!

title: Darwinian Word Ladder
description:
Yikes! I'm feeling very sticky (as in, "stuck")! From dreaming it, to doing it, is not a piece of cake! I've got some logic errors. Ha! ... unstuck...I put a "go to" block in my forever loop so that the sprite will move away when the activity has finished, so that it doesn't occur all over again.

title: Beatles: Love in 3 Words
description:
I got stuck several times dealing with all the lists in this project, but reviewed old projects and examples from other Scratchers to help sort it out. Using blocks with visible output like 'Say ()' is a go-to debugging strategy, as well.

Making this reminded me how complex even the simplest games are deceptively complex to create. It's an issue I think about all the time when creating game design activities for new coders!

With more time, I'd like to make the scripts for this project simpler to understand, so that it could be used as a demonstration of how to make a quiz like this one.

Music samples from Amazon
instructions: Green Flag and follow instructions

title: Getting Unstuck Day 14 Remix: Iglatinpay Amenay-4
description:
Loved the original! Here's another take on the idea . . . 
Took a while to figure out how to get the first letter moved to the end.
So happy when it worked, almost forgot to add "ay". Timing still not quite right and project seems to have gone from a few extraneous bowtie spins to not quite enough - will probably compare to previous drafts. Still thinking through the progression of steps when using the broadcast block, strings, loops and direction changes. 
Would not have considered remix before Day 11 challenge. Glad to have a model to work from, and not always having to start from "scratch".

title: Aliebn Lamguage
description:
The inspiration for this project came from one of the most wonderful and inspiring stories I've ever read, "badly spelled and beautifully written", in which a little alien lands on Earth to find out what is a human.

In the book, the alien speaks a very particular language full of misspellings and typos, that makes it super cute. So I tried to write a Scratch program to translate from human to alien language.

That turned out to be much harder than expected. I thought I could just replace letters but it turned out that it was much more complex because quite often the translation of a letter depends on the letter that is before and/or after, and there are a lot of exceptions. 

My unstuck strategy was to "keep it simple", so I made a couple of simple substitutions. Then I tried consider the previous letter and I made the simplest thing I could, which was "mispeling" double letter words. If I had more time I would dive deeper and try to implement the entire aliebn grammar.. for now I think it's cute enough! EDIT: I couldn't resist so I also made a simple filter that removes "I'm" or "I am" from the second answer.. it is not very robust, but it's good enough!

Here are more info about the book and the alien language:
https://www.pri.org/stories/2017-09-27/how-speak-aliebn-no-thats-not-typo

Hapy learming friemds!
instructions: Meet a little alien who's learning about humans.
writing:
The inspiration for this project came from one of the most wonderful and inspiring stories I've ever read, "badly spelled and beautifully written", in which a little alien lands on Earth to find out what is a human.

In the book, the alien speaks a very particular language full of misspellings and typos, that makes it super cute. So I tried to write a Scratch program to translate from human to alien language.

That turned out to be much harder than expected. I thought I could just replace letters but it turned out that it was much more complex because quite often the translation of a letter depends on the letter that is before and/or after, and there are a lot of exceptions. 

My unstuck strategy was to "keep it simple", so I made a couple of simple substitutions. Then I tried consider the previous letter and I made the simplest thing I could, which was "mispeling" double letter words. If I had more time I would dive deeper and try to implement the entire aliebn grammar.. for now I think it's cute enough! EDIT: I couldn't resist so I also made a simple filter that removes "I'm" or "I am" from the second answer.. it is not very robust, but it's good enough!

Here are more info about the book and the alien language:
https://www.pri.org/stories/2017-09-27/how-speak-aliebn-no-thats-not-typo

Hapy learming friemds!Meet a little alien who's learning about humans.

title: Getting Unstuck 14
description:
After a 10 hour work day near New Hampshire, then a trip to Boston, didnt' think I'd get it done today. But I enjoy working with strings. 

I thought to slow it down so it was easier to follow what is happening but decided that fast is fun. You can also use the text engine to type sentences and has some roughly built in margins. Will need a few adjustments but the framework is there.
instructions:
Ok, got it done. 

Type a word, the index will go letter by letter to add it to a list in order. Then we'll randomize the index to add the letters to the scramble list and delete the list item from unscrambled.

Once all the letters are scrambled we will join them all back into the scrambled variable. Then we'll run that scramble variable through my text engine which will then clone the letters centered on the screen.
writing:
After a 10 hour work day near New Hampshire, then a trip to Boston, didnt' think I'd get it done today. But I enjoy working with strings. 

I thought to slow it down so it was easier to follow what is happening but decided that fast is fun. You can also use the text engine to type sentences and has some roughly built in margins. Will need a few adjustments but the framework is there. Ok, got it done. 

Type a word, the index will go letter by letter to add it to a list in order. Then we'll randomize the index to add the letters to the scramble list and delete the list item from unscrambled.

Once all the letters are scrambled we will join them all back into the scrambled variable. Then we'll run that scramble variable through my text engine which will then clone the letters centered on the screen.

description: I need to work on the background, and add more questions.
instructions: I made a version of those quizzes you take to find out what animal you, what city you should live in, etc. The way I approached it was choosing 4 animals, making them variables, giving them a point, each time they are chosen as the answer. I only have 3 questions. It works, but I'm having trouble figuring out how to get it to work if the each animal had the same amount of points. It worked yesterday a few times for this, but then stopped. Any suggestions?

One of the many things I like about Scratch: learning by surprises =)

title: A Word With U
description:
I wanted to make a word-guessing game for Getting Unstuck day 14. The idea for the mechanics of this game came from a pun: "A word with U" could mean a word that starts with 'A' that also has a 'U'.

It was easier to find a word list than I thought it would be! I got it here: https://github.com/first20hours/google-10000-english/blob/master/google-10000-english-usa-no-swears.txt (You can upload a txt file to a list by right clicking on the list in the editor.)
instructions:
You have 60 seconds to guess as many words as you can! (This project only knows the most common 10,000 words in American English, so guess accordingly.) Proper nouns (like "California") and common acronyms (like "ISBN") are welcome!

If you can't think of a word, you can type "give up"-- but beware, you'll lose some points.
writing:

You have 60 seconds to guess as many words as you can! (This project only knows the most common 10,000 words in American English, so guess accordingly.) Proper nouns (like "California") and common acronyms (like "ISBN") are welcome!

If you can't think of a word, you can type "give up"-- but beware, you'll lose some points.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 14
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 14 Reflection:
I had no idea what string blocks were or how much fun they could be until this project.  And I had no idea what I wanted to try with them until I started looking at projects in the studio.  I was really impressed with CompTeacherK5's project and decided to try to make my own.  (Here is a link: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237066028/#player).

I got stuck when I tried to link more than two things in a join block.  It took me a long time to figure out that I could nest them.  Something I'd like to change or enhance (besides the rather lame story I came up with!) is adding other effects to it, like sound effects.
instructions: Click the green flag and answer the questions.  Your answers will be put into a back to school story, sort of like Mad Libs!

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 14
description:
The challenge for day 14 is to create a project that uses the string blocks in the Operators category (i.e., join, letter of, and length of) for some fun wordplay.  

I wrote this program that uses all three examples! :-)   And this is the very first program I have written that asks for a prompt to be answered!  I felt it was a little simple, so I added in some costume changes.
instructions: Click the green arrow and enter your name when prompted to find out some special facts about it!
writing:
The challenge for day 14 is to create a project that uses the string blocks in the Operators category (i.e., join, letter of, and length of) for some fun wordplay.  

I wrote this program that uses all three examples! :-)   And this is the very first program I have written that asks for a prompt to be answered!  I felt it was a little simple, so I added in some costume changes.
Click the green arrow and enter your name when prompted to find out some special facts about it!

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 14
description: When I was younger, I would always create stage names from online forms. I wanted to recreate the process using Scratch. I found this project relatively simple and know that I can expand the options to include inputs about immutable facts such as birthday and hair color.
instructions: Press the green button and wait to hear instructions from Roy!
